title: Mob Figure May Unearth Corruption of Lawmen
description: During the 16 years James (Whitey) Bulger spent on the lam, several of his former partners in crime testified that he had made payoffs to two dozen Boston police officers and half a dozen F.B.I. agents over his long criminal career  giving them thousands of dollars and rings, a Meerschaum pipe and Lalique glass.

title: Coalition of Factions From the Streets Fuels a New Opposition in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An opposition drawing its strength from Syrias restive streets has begun to emerge as a pivotal force in the countrys once-dormant politics, organizing across disparate regions through the Internet, reaching out to fearful religious minorities and earning the respect of more recognized, but long divided dissidents.

title: Two Rulings Find Cuts in Public Pensions Permissible
description: Judges in Colorado and Minnesota have dismissed court challenges by retired public workers whose pensions had been cut  developments that may embolden other states and cities to use pension reductions as a tool to help balance their budgets.

title: The Impossible Public Pensions Choices
description: Last summer, I wrote about a brewing court battle in Colorado. At issue was the question of whether the state could reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustments for the pensions of state workers who were already retired.

title: France: Moscovici Backs Hollande for Socialists
description: The Socialist legislator Pierre Moscovici, a close ally of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, said Thursday that he would support Franois Hollande for president. Mr. Moscovici, 53, had been hesitating about whether to support the Socialist Party leader Martine Aubry or Mr. Hollande, a former party leader, or to run himself. Mr. Hollande is the current front-runner in opinion polls for the Socialist primaries scheduled for October. Another ally of Mr. Strauss-Kahn, Jean-Christophe Cambadlis, has decided to support Ms. Aubry.

title: Kansas Gives License to One Abortion Clinic
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Ending speculation that new regulations could make it the only state without an abortion provider, Kansas announced Thursday that it had issued a license that would allow one of three abortion clinics to continue operating.

title: The Price of Liberty: Weeds
description: Norfolk, England

title: Brown Graduate Does Not Give Up on His Tennis Dream
description: WIMBLEDON, England  In 2008, James Cerretanis father, Chip, strongly suggested it was time for him to retire from tennis and put his Brown University degree to use. Three years later, Cerretanis sister Chrissy, a former college player at Clemson, is on the verge of quitting her job in Boston to travel with him on tour, he said  and with their fathers blessing.

title: N.F.L. Deal Is Said to Be Weeks Away as Talks Restart
description: N.F.L. owners and players continued to negotiate late Thursday evening, but progress slowed as time dwindled for striking a labor deal that would avoid the disruption of the preseason.

title: Western Funds Are Said to Have Managed Libyan Money Poorly
description: Prominent American and European investment funds managed hundreds of millions of dollars in Qaddafi regime assets poorly, charging tens of millions of dollars in fees and producing low returns, according to a document obtained by the advocacy group Global Witness. The banks appeared to have taken advantage of a Libyan investment fund that was poorly managed and "a mess," according to a western official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

title: China: Rules Favoring Local Companies for State Contracts Will Be Eased
description: The Ministry of Finance will repeal three rules on Friday that favor Chinese companies in competitions for government technology purchases, according to a statement posted this week on the ministrys Web site. China has long supported a policy of indigenous innovation, which grants advantages to Chinese companies over foreign rivals, especially in technology industries, and tries to enforce technology transfer from foreign companies in business deals. Foreign companies and governments have complained that such rules violate free-trade agreements. In January, when President Hu Jintao of China visited the White House, Chinese officials promised to drop some of those rules.

title: Practicing Medicine Can Be Grimm Work
description: Birmingham, Ala.

title: Wrong Name, Wrong Date, Yet Let on a Jet
description: When the F.B.I. caught up to Olajide Oluwaseun Noibi at Los Angeles International Airport on Wednesday, he was trying to talk a Delta Air Lines agent into letting him get on a flight to Atlanta. Mr. Noibi, 24, faced some resistance because the boarding pass in his hand was issued in another persons name and was for a flight that had departed a day earlier, according to court documents.

title: Citing Homeless Law, Hackers Turn Sights on Orlando
description: MIAMI  The hacker group Anonymous has declared a cyberwar against the City of Orlando, disabling Web sites for the citys leading redevelopment organization, the local Fraternal Order of Police and the mayors re-election campaign.

title: For Jeter, Trenton Is the Next Stop
description: Derek Jeter, who has been on the disabled list since June 14 with a strained right calf, will probably play the first of two rehabilitation games Saturday for the Yankees Class AA farm team in Trenton. Manager Joe Girardi gave the news after his teams 5-0 victory Thursday against the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: To the Limit
description: In about a month, if nothing is done, the federal government will hit its legal debt limit. There will be dire consequences if this limit isnt raised. At best, well suffer an economic slowdown; at worst well plunge back into the depths of the 2008-9 financial crisis.

title: N.H.L. Free Agents: Where in the World Is Jaromir Jagr?
description: Confusion mounted across the N.H.L. on the eve of Fridays free-agency frenzy. Among the complicating factors were turtles trundling across an airport runway and the legalization of gay marriage.

title: Strauss-Kahn Prosecution Said to Be Near Collapse
description: The sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn is on the verge of collapse as investigators have uncovered major holes in the credibility of the housekeeper who charged that he attacked her in his Manhattan hotel suite in May, according to two well-placed law enforcement officials.

title: Cuomo Administration Closing 7 Prisons, 2 in New York City
description: The Cuomo administration, following through on one of the most contentious cutbacks included in the state budget, said Thursday that it would close seven of New Yorks dozens of prisons, including a facility in the Bronx and one on Staten Island.

title: Scott and Haas Share AT&T Lead
description: Adam Scott made a couple of long birdie putts and hit a 5-iron within 2 feet for a birdie on the 14th hole on his way to a four-under-par 66 on Thursday to share the lead with Hunter Haas in the AT&T National in Newtown Square, Pa.

title: Smells Like School Spirit

title: Differing Takes on Accusers Credibility
description: Prosecutors have strongly supported the woman who said she was attacked by Dominique Strauss-Kahn, as has a lawyer representing the woman, but his defense team has questioned her credibility since the accusations were made on May 14.

title: For Some With Autism, Jobs to Match Their Talents
description: Steen B. Iversen tests mobile phones for the Danish telecommunications firm TDC. Before landing his job two and a half years ago, Iversen, 50, who has been diagnosed with Aspergers Syndrome, spent more than 12 years looking for work. Its always been somewhat traumatizing, he said. I have had jobs, but I always got fired. People would laugh about me behind my back and laugh at me to my face. Those problems have more or less been a problem for me from childhood.

title: Lottery Numbers
Local Laws Fighting Fat Under Siege
description: Several state legislatures are passing laws that prohibit municipalities and other local governments from adopting regulations aimed at curbing rising obesity and improving public health, such as requiring restaurants to provide nutritional information on menus or to eliminate trans fats from the foods they serve.

title: Connecticut Steps Closer to Widespread Layoffs
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut legislators early Friday morning gave Gov. Dannel P. Malloy dramatically expanded authority to make radical cuts to programs and employment after state employee unions rejected a labor deal meant to balance the states $40.1 billion two-year budget.

title: Two Women Struck by Car, One Fatally, in Manhattan
description: One woman was killed and another seriously injured in Manhattan on Thursday when they were struck by a car that was backing up as they were crossing the street, the police said.

title: Boeing Labor Dispute Is Making New Factory a Political Football
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  Boeings gigantic new $750 million airplane factory here is the pride of South Carolina, the biggest single investment ever made in a state that is far more associated with old-line textile mills than state-of-the-art manufacturing. In just a few weeks, 1,000 workers will begin assembling the first of what they hope will be hundreds of 787 Dreamliners.

title: Borders Picks Najafi Companies as Lead Bidder
description: The Borders Group said on Thursday evening that it had picked the Najafi Companies, a private equity firm that owns the Book-of-the-Month Club, as the lead bidder in a forthcoming court-supervised auction for the bankrupt bookseller.

title: Ethics, Politics and the Law
description: The ethical judgments of the Supreme Court justices became an important issue in the just completed term. The court cannot maintain its legitimacy as guardian of the rule of law when justices behave like politicians. Yet, in several instances, justices acted in ways that weakened the courts reputation for being independent and impartial.

title: How the British Nearly Supported the Confederacy
description: Was it a civil war twice over? Not only did the war between the states divide the American people, it sundered the larger English-speaking community stretching across the Atlantic. The conflict was followed with consuming interest by the British, it affected them directly, many of them fought in it  and it split them into two camps, just as it did the Americans.

title: Exploring Loves True Nature
description: Did you watch When Harry Met Sally and wish it had dispensed with Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan? Well, of course you did. What I mean is, did you wish that the interstitial interviews with longtime couples could be expanded into their own feature while retaining the films calculated sentimentality? If so, Jill Andresevics Love Etc. is the movie youve been waiting for.

title: Friday: Priest at Shiloh
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  How long, on average, does it take you to suss out that there is something fishy going on in a crossword? Lets say were talking about rebuses, which is actually quite convenient because todays grid happens to have a rebus element in it. Its not quite like other rebuses, though, and its kind of clever. If you are still wondering how to enter multiple letters in a grid, please read Martin Herbachs wonderful instructional write-up here.

title: Hold Onto Your Morals: Life Is Tough
description: Righteousness probably doesnt rank too high on any list of the qualities that people find seductive. Nobody tunes in to a televangelist in search of an aphrodisiac, Id be willing to bet.

title: The Google Inquiry Evokes Microsoft Memories
description: The ongoing antitrust investigations into Google invite comparisons to the case against Microsoft. But however easy the links are to make, many are also facile. The most significant resemblance between the two situations may be their outcomes.

title: New Jersey Governor Vetoes Spending
description: TRENTON  Gov. Chris Christie on Thursday vetoed more than $1.3 billion in spending, much of it for schools, and struck down a sharp tax increase on high-income people in a sweeping rejection of attempts by Democrats in the Legislature to assert some control over the state budget.

description: Glenn Beck spent his final day at the Fox News Channel thanking his viewers and colleagues and promoting his new Internet channel, GBTV, to the best of his contractual ability.

title: Indian Cinema With an Indie Sensibility
description: Starting with the pride of place given the digestive problem of the title, Delhi Belly thumbs its nose at propriety. Delhi belly, the travelers curse, afflicts a homegrown son (Kunaal Roy Kapur) in this caper comedy after he eats some particularly nasty street food. (The film lovingly shows just how unhygienic it is.) His stool sample, no less, is the trigger that sets the plot in motion, when it is accidentally switched with a similar-size package of contraband. Not what the gangster ordered ...

title: Lies and Truth About Upper Big Branch
description: Profits trumped all, including the safety and lives of 29 miners. That is the clear conclusion of a yearlong federal investigation into the Upper Big Branch disaster. Industry must finally learn its lesson. Congress and federal regulators must ensure that it does.

title: Another Area Girds for Revolt as Sudan Approaches a Split
description: LEWERE, Sudan  Children with shrapnel wounds lie on metal hospital cots. Thousands of others have been huddling in caves and stony riverbeds, fleeing the fighter jets and bombers prowling the skies. Villages are empty, fields unplowed. At the faintest buzz of a plane, people scatter into the bush, in a panic.

title: Fund-Raising Begins Slowly for G.O.P. Candidates

title: Afghanistan: Family Killed by Roadside Bomb
description: A family of five and their driver were killed by a bomb buried in the road in the district of Marja in southern Helmand Province on Thursday, Afghan officials said. The two parents and their children, ages 3 to 6, were traveling to an engagement party in Lashkar Gah, the provincial capital, the governors spokesman said. Marja, a former Taliban stronghold, was subdued by the United States Marines early in 2010. Abdul Mutalib, the district governor of Marja, said a military operation was underway in the area where the bomb went off.

title: Chvez Says a Cancerous Tumor Was Removed
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez stunned this nation on Thursday night in an unusually concise 15-minute address on state television in which he acknowledged that he has been battling cancer. Mr. Chvez made the revelation from Cuba, where he has been in seclusion at a medical facility for the last three weeks.

title: Massachusetts: Dead Woman Unnoticed
description: State officials are investigating how a woman apparently died at a Fall River pool on Sunday and went unnoticed until Tuesday night. The body of Marie Joseph, 36, of Fall River, was discovered Tuesday around 10 p.m. in the Veterans Memorial Pool in Fall River. The authorities said Ms. Joseph went down a slide Sunday immediately after a 9-year-old boy and collided with him. The mayor of Fall River, William Flanagan, said city inspectors visited the pool, which was open to the public and had several lifeguards on duty, Monday and Tuesday, only to report that the water was cloudy. Pool staff was suspended and state officials closed 24 pools while reviewing safety procedures and training.

title: One Mouth Too Many
description: One day each month in Eastleigh, a run-down suburb of Nairobi with dirt roads and rivering sewers, a young Kenyan woman named Dorothy Gakii starts calling out numbers. Numbaa one! she shouts, using slow and deliberate English. Numbaa two! Gathered before her on long wooden benches in a church meeting hall are several dozen refugees holding scraps of paper that mark their place in line. They are waiting for food  for the sacks of dried beans and rice and maize flour piled against one wall. For the seriously malnourished, there is a nutritional porridge mix labeled, Pure Wimbi.

We fired her, and she paid back the funds in exchange for our not pressing charges. But I cannot get closure if she is not punished for this egregious betrayal. title: Tip of the Week: Saving E-Mailed Photos for Macs
description: Apples iPhoto program, which comes free on most new Macs, can automatically pull in pictures from a connected digital camera, but you can also easily save images attached to Mail messages too. When you open a message in the Mac OS X Mail program and see photos that youd like to add to the iPhoto library, click and hold the cursor down on the small blue Save button in the message header. At the bottom of the drop-down menu that appears, select the Save to iPhoto option to save all pictures into the iPhoto program.

description: Providence Equity Partners agreed on Friday to buy Blackboard Inc., a maker of college coursework software, for $1.64 billion in cash, in the private equity firms latest foray into the education market.

title: Friday Reading: Be Nice to Medical Receptionists
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Vain Glorious | Aesop Takes New York
description: The Australian skin care brand Aesop  Greek for storyteller is a cult favorite among the type of discerning consumers who prefer their jeans dark, their espresso straight up and their bathrooms uncluttered. And like the Aesop products, the Aesop boutiques make innovative use of unusual ingredients, so theres no sense of shopping at a chain when you pop in to pick up your Parsley Seed Anti-Oxidant Facial Serum (which, incidentally, is brilliant for maintaining a glowing complexion through the depths of sticky East Coast summers). Case in point: the first of Aesops four planned New York shops, which opens in the Graybar Passage in Grand Central Terminal next week, will be built primarily from recycled 19th-century newspapers. Locations on Elizabeth Street and University Place will follow by the end of the summer, and a flagship on Bleecker Street will open in December. The Moment recently caught up with the Aesop founder, Dennis Paphitis, to talk about architecture, why art inspires him and what he thinks about all-natural skin care claims.

title: Republicans Downtime Throwdown
description: In politics, sometimes attacking your opponent can give them an opening to attack back. Thats what President Obama did by urging Republican lawmakers to stay in Washington until the debt debate is over.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Nadal Tops Murray for Berth in Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Britain can exhale now.

title: Keynes Film Festival
description: A guy with a beard talks about a guy with a mustache. Videos of the lecture and Q&A.

title: Soar Losers
description: Like everyone who has argued that continuing low interest rates vindicate the Keynesian view of how macroeconomics works, Ive faced a lot of claims that the low rates were artificial, that as soon as the Fed stopped buying bonds rates would soar. Some big-name private-sector people, notably Bill Gross, have made similar claims.

title: The Danger in Counting on Markets to Drive a Debt-Limit Deal
description: Many astute political observers worry that an elegant resolution to the negotiations over the federal debt limit may not be in the making  and that there is a tangible possibility that the United States will default on its debts.

title: Former Brearley Leader Returns as Interim Head
description: The Brearley Schools trustees moved quickly on Friday to contain any damage from the abrupt resignation of its head of school, naming a former Brearley leader as interim head of school.

title: TimesCast | Doping in Sports
description: Sports columnist Jonathan Mahler questions the cost and fairness of prosecuting two Texas sports stars.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: The Accidental Patriot
description: James de Givenchy intended to give his daughter, Stella, a 1940s candy-striped bracelet that he bought online. When the piece arrived, de Givenchy, a jeweler, was so taken with the quality of the plastic that he took it into in his workshop for further study, leaving it next to a pile of faceted lapis. The commingling was purely serendipitous. I thought it would be so much fun, de Givenchy said of the costume bauble-turned-fine jewelry. A very American transformation, dont you think? $10,000. Go to taffin.com or call (212) 421-6222 for an appointment.

title: A High-Tech Twist on a Classic Card Game
description: Remember the card game Uno? Now, Uno remembers you.

title: LAByrinth Theater Finds a Downtown Home
description: LAByrinth Theater Company has a steady home for its newly announced 2011-12 season. The company, which has historically found space all over New York, most recently at the Public Theater, has taken up residence in the newly rechristened Bank Street Theater for the foreseeable future, a spokesman said on Thursday.

title: Just How Many Android Tablet Apps Are There?
description: In my Times column this week, I reviewed Hewlett-Packards new iPad clone, the TouchPad. Since the benefit of owning a tablet is apps, I thought it would be useful to compare the number of apps available for iPad, Android tablets and the new H.P.

title: Regulators Provide $14 Billion Bailout for Bank of Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Russian regulators said on Friday that they had averted the collapse of one of the largest Russian banks by providing a bailout package of 395 billion rubles to Bank of Moscow, suggesting the banks problems with bad loans were more severe than previously acknowledged.

title: TimesCast | Strauss-Kahn Trial Derails
description: Investigators have found major holes in the credibility of the hotel housekeeper who charged that Dominique Strauss-Kahn attacked her.

title: The Science of Song, the Song of Science
description: MANCHESTER, England  In one song that Bjork performed here on Thursday night, the bass lines were zaps of artificial lightning from a Tesla coil in a cage. In another, a sizable Victorian-looking contraption of stainless steel, the Sharpsichord  part giant music box, part harp, part gramophone  used a rotating barrel to play deep, bonging counterpoint.

title: A Small Note on the Stimulus Debate
description: One small followup on the issue of being prematurely right about the stimulus being too small: you might think that hippies like me were basing their views on some wild and crazy, unorthodox version of economics, while the wise, judicious people who thought that $787 billion was just right were using standard analysis.

title: A Response to Mara Hvistendahl (I)
description: The author of Unnatural Selection has kindly written a reply to my column on her book. Not surprisingly, she takes exception to my suggestion that sex-selective abortion poses a problem for pro-choice liberals, arguing that theres no contradiction at all between supporting abortion rights and trying to restrict/ban abortions based on sex:

title: No End in Sight as Minnesotans Grapple With State Shutdown
description: ST. PAUL  The state of Minnesota screeched to a stop on Friday.

title: TimesCast | Paris Reactions
description: Parisians react to the revelations that the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn may be unraveling.

title: Pistons Run a Play Out of Private Equitys Book
description: It looks as if the Detroit Pistons will be the first professional sports team in the United States to get the private equity treatment.

title: Finra Executives Get Big Payday
description: Wall Streets self-policing organization is getting richer  and so are its top executives.

title: Strauss-Kahn Is Released as Case Teeters
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, who is accused of sexually assaulting a hotel housekeeper, was released from house arrest on Friday as the case against him moved closer to dismissal after prosecutors told a Manhattan judge that the credibility of his accuser was in serious question.

title: Empty Plates for Low-Income Seniors
description: Theres a long list of reasons that older people suffer malnutrition and weight loss, a geriatrician recently told a Senate subcommittee on health and aging: smell and taste diminishing with age, high rates of depression, medications that that suppress appetite or upset stomachs, disabilities that make it hard to shop and cook.

title: Exxon Cut Financing to Climate Skeptics, Group Says
description: Greenpeace U.S.A. has issued a report saying that all of the research funding received since 2003 by Willie Soon, an astrophysicist who has been a critic of climate science, came from oil or coal interests like ExxonMobil and the Southern Company, a utility that burns coal.

title: Last Weekend for Mini Mangoes
description: Mini mangoes from Mexico have been at produce markets in Chinatown, but this is your last chance to buy them because the season will end by this weekend. No new supplies are being shipped in.

title: Pitmaster Robbie Richter Leaves Fatty Cue
description: Robbie Richter, the pitmaster of Fatty Cue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has left after a year on the job. He has not revealed his future plans.

title: Why Clemens and Armstrong Arent Worth Pursuing Anymore
description: This is shaping up as a bad month for fallen Texas sports icons.

title: Moroccans Vote for Changes the King Says Will Reduce His Power and Raise Theirs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Moroccans voted in a landslide on Friday to approve constitutional changes proposed last month by King Mohammed VI in a bid to introduce greater political openness and ward off the unrest that has swept the Arab world.

title: In Car Sales, Good Month for Detroit, Not Japan
description: DETROIT  Shortages of cars made by Toyota and Honda and fewer discounts over all made June the worst month so far this year for sales of new vehicles in the United States, but automakers expressed confidence that the industry would rebound later in the year.

title: New Ways to See 3 Classic Parks
description: I LOVE the national parks. Last summer, I was lucky enough to visit three. My travels last July took me first to the Northeast, to Acadia on the coast of Maine, then later out West for a family vacation with my husband, Scott Robinson, and our younger daughter, Hannah, at Yellowstone and Grand Teton. In each, I tried to get off the beaten path.

title: Stan Lee Starts Chinese Superhero Franchise
description: Stan Lee, the comic book creator, has announced a joint venture with a Hong Kong investment company for a new superhero franchise aimed at Chinese and foreign audiences, The Associated Press reports.

title: How Do You Prefer Your Heart?
description: We found ourselves in a dilemma for this weeks issue: four different cover treatments and many different opinions about which one was the most aesthetically pleasing. First we did an internal poll in the art department. The rules were simple, vote on your favorite cover by putting a small wooden chip (broken coffee stirrer) into the matching cup. Only problem was, we had a tie and we needed more votes. So we opened up the judging to the entire staff and 37 staff members from every department voted.

title: With Police Absent, Protests Surge in Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tens of thousands of protesters poured Friday into the streets of Hama, a Syrian city abandoned by the military and security forces, gathering in the countrys biggest demonstration in nearly four months of unrest and staking a festive claim to a region that bore the brunt of a ferocious government crackdown a generation ago.

title: N.F.L. Deal Is Said to Be Weeks Away as Talks Restart
description: N.F.L. owners and players continued to negotiate late Thursday evening, but progress slowed as time dwindled for striking a labor deal that would avoid the disruption of the preseason.

title: What Would Tarzan Think?
description: For those infected with jungle fever (see Pradas chic monkey and banana frocks for spring), the good news is you can follow the trend into fall. The Marc by Marc Jacobs collection, in stores this month, features panthers and antelopes on everything from drop pants to jacquard blazers. The prints are the handiwork of Michael Roberts, who, when hes not working for Vanity Fair as style editor at large, is illustrating childens pop-up books about the jungle. This clutch, for example, with its sleek appliqu ($328), is entirely fierce. Go to marcjacobs.com. For the scarf, $178, go to nordstrom.com.

title: Tracing Unscooped Dog Waste Back to the Culprit
description: Sherlock Holmes had the case of the dog that didnt bark, but it has taken two dozen apartment complexes and a testing company in Tennessee to bring the art of canine detection into the CSI age.

title: The Ride of Frankenstein: Daring, or Just Deranged?
description: IN a world of play-it-safe auto design driven by focus groups, its good to see companies take some chances.

title: Defying the Trend, a Small Town Loosens Its Belt
description: While American cities large and small are grappling with budget deficits of historic proportions  laying off teachers and police officers and closing libraries  the town of Golden Beach, Fla., is doing fine, thank you. The town, nestled along the Atlantic Ocean in Miami-Dade County, has a minuscule unemployment rate, plenty of money and little crime. Among its current or former homeowners are Ricky Martin, Bill Gates and Paul Newman. The town also has a history of exclusion  at one point in the 1980s it closed most of its roads to the outside world as part of an effort to deter crime. These days, the town has entry gates staffed by security officers. Mayor Glenn Singer, elected this year to his fourth term, discusses.

title: Banning Babies in First Class
description: As you depart for whichever backyard, or beach, or local park, or airport marks the start of your Independence Day weekend, an update on Malaysia Airlines announcement that infants will not be allowed up front when the airline introduces its new Airbus A380 aircraft next year. The airline already has such a ban on its 747-400 fleet.

title: On Strokes and (Personal) Sustainability
description: I have a long list of backlogged posts but am taking a brief break from tracking global sustainability to check my personal operating systems.* A stroke will do that to you.

title: Weekend Fare: Fourth of July Edition
description: Free tastes of wine from Italys Veneto region will be served on Friday from 2 to 4 p.m. at Enoteca Di Palo, 200 Grand Street (Mott Street), in Little Italy. From 6 to 8 p.m., sparkling wines from the region will be available at I Tre Merli, 463 West Broadway (Prince Street), in SoHo.

title: By-the-Book Celebration for Chinas Communists on Partys 90th Birthday
description: BEIJING  The party for the Party turned out to be a doctrinaire affair, as President Hu Jintao expounded Friday on the benefits of 90 years of communism with Chinese characteristics while workplaces around the country held red-song singalongs.

title: A Collision of Creativity and Cash
description: When the Walt Disney Company bought Pixar Animation Studios for $7.4 billion in 2006, there was understandable concern that the media conglomerate that drove the famed Disney animation unit into the ground with duds like Home on the Range and Chicken Little would extinguish the creative flame that had nurtured the quirky and much-loved Toy Story and Finding Nemo.

title: Debt Ceiling Date Does Not Budge
description: The Aug. 2 debt ceiling deadline is holding firm. The Treasury Department said Friday morning that its latest estimates still show thats the date the government will exhaust its ability to pay all of its bills, unless Congress agrees to raise the total amount that the United States can borrow.

title: Letter From District Attorney to Defense in Strauss-Kahn Case
description: The letter outlines interviews with the hotel housekeeper who had accused Mr. Strauss-Kahn, and raises questions about her version of events.

title: The Man Who Keeps the Boats Afloat in Flushing Bay
description: Phil McCaughey wiped the dusty sweat off his sunburned neck and pulled a Post-It out of his pocket.

title: Thousands in Cairo Return to Tahrir Square to Protest the Slow Pace of Change
description: CAIRO  Thousands of protesters returned to Tahrir Square here on Friday to voice frustration with what they called the slow pace of change five months after the revolution. The demonstration occurred just days after renewed clashes between protesters and the police left hundreds injured and underscored the lingering distrust between Egyptians and a police force long seen as a pillar of the former government.

title: Pirates Booty Approaches $1 Billion
description: Just a few months ago, the people behind Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides were shivering in their timbers. Would their $250 million movie win back fans, the ones who were fed up with bloated running times and bewildering plots? Or would the audience respond with a great big yo ho hum?

title: A Lesson Not Learned
description: If you can muster some outrage, by all means go ahead and vent it on the N.B.A. Apparently learning nothing from the N.F.L.s ongoing debacle, the N.B.A. motored full steam ahead with its lockout plans on Thursday, another league bent on image annihilation in the name of saving themselves from their own business failings.

title: Josh Ritters Novel of Appalachia
description: Henry Bright is pretty much your ordinary 20th-century West Virginia farmboy, with one notable exception: when he winds up in the World War I trenches in France, he begins hearing voices.

title: A Pacifist in the Family
description: In every presidential election from 1928 to 1948, Americans had the option of voting for Norman Thomas, the perennial Socialist Party candidate. Very few chose to do so. Thomass best result  2.2 percent of the ballot nationwide  was in 1932, and he never came close to that share again. Yet when he died in 1968 at the age of 84, he was remembered as a courageous idealist who, in the words of a tribute in The New York Times, spoke to the feelings that most Americans have about themselves. In other words, he was an advocate for fairness, decency, justice and equality, a man to be admired though hardly one to be voted into office.

title: The Not Quite Unhappy Marriage
description: How does one write a whole book on the boredom of marriage without becoming boring oneself? Pamela Haags Marriage Confidential: The Post-Romantic Age of Workhorse Wives, Royal Children, Undersexed Spouses and Rebel Couples Who Are Rewriting the Rules can, in spite of its exceptionally boppy subtitle, only partly answer that question.

title: A Johns Story
description: Who has not seen the remorseful preachers, politicians, actors and other men in the news, begging forgiveness when caught with their pants down and publicly outed as johns, patrons of the worlds oldest profession? To be a known john is to be trailed by shame and stigma, at least in the United States and Canada. There are millions of johns, but for one to come out voluntarily  with honesty, integrity and pride  is indeed rare. In my nearly 40 years in the world of sex workers, Ive known only one: Fred Cherry. In the 1980s in New York, Cherry sued Mayor Ed Koch for the legal right to pay for sex with prostitutes (a case Cherry ultimately lost). To ascertain if any other such brave johns had slipped my mind, I surveyed a few of my older prostitute friends. No, just Fred Cherry, they confirmed. (Today, I might count Charlie Sheen.) So for the Canadian comic artist Chester Brown to announce in his graphic memoir, Paying for It, that he is a john is truly groundbreaking.

title: Aristotle and the Higher Good
description: Some time in the 1920s, the Conservative statesman F. E. Smith  Lord Birkenhead  gave a copy of the Nicomachean Ethics to his close friend Winston Churchill. He did so saying there were those who thought this was the greatest book of all time. Churchill returned it some weeks later, saying it was all very interesting, but he had already thought most of it out for himself. But it is the very genius of Aristotle  as it is of every great teacher  to make you think he is uncovering your own thought in his. In Churchills case, it is also probable that the classical tradition informed more of his upbringing, at home and at school, than he realized.

title: A Parable of the New India
description: Nations are narratives. Every country is shaped by its particular set of ideas and myths. Inevitably these are simplifications, often clichs, but they hold a country together, imposing a certain coherence on diverse populations.

title: A Novel of Race and Road Rage
description: In Tom Wolfes Bonfire of the Vanities, the mistress of a Wall Street bond salesman mows down a black youth in the South Bronx, and he encourages her to keep driving. In Will Allisons second novel, Long Drive Home, another middle-aged money man tries to cover up his role in a racially tinged fatal accident. In Allisons case, the beleaguered white guy is Glen Bauer, a suburban New Jersey accountant who, offended by the sight of a black teenager in a convertible barreling too fast down his sleepy residential block, swerves briefly into his path to give the kid a scare. Instead, he crashes to his death. Whats more, just as in Bonfire, the accident creates a downward spiral in the protagonists life that seems to have a momentum of its own.

title: Taking Stock of Race in Obamas America
description: Dramatic stories of hardship and injustice have always been at the center of the struggle for racial equality. Homer Plessy refused to ride in a segregated black train car in late-19th-century Louisiana; the World War II veteran George Dorsey and three other African-Americans were killed by a racist mob outside Atlanta in 1946; Emmett Till was lynched by white bigots in Mississippi in 1955; and in that same year, Rosa Parks sparked the Montgomery bus boycott when she would not surrender her seat to a white passenger. These events and many others inspired activists to press for change and convinced average Americans that change was necessary. The worst abuses of the Jim Crow era have been eliminated, but the moral outrage inspired by a personal encounter with a bigot remains the most powerful vehicle for conveying the injuries and indignities of racial inequality. Accordingly, civil rights lawyers seek out plaintiffs whose grievances reflect larger injustices, and activists rally around people who symbolize pervasive social problems.

title: Commanding Hitlers Soldiers
description: In war, the finest generals may win battles, but they are ultimately condemned to defeat if their political masters are fools. One such inferior superior was Hitler, a former corporal who imposed his clumsy strategic visions on the German Army  which obeyed, willingly, to the last mans last round.

title: Terror of Teenage Life
description: If and when you go away to college you can become somebody else; you can kill off your old self and be reborn. So generations of young people have believed. But once they have done it  ditching provincial tastes and hometown boyfriends for a sorority, a fraternity or an undergraduate bohemia  they may trade one conformity for another; they may feel haunted by their former lives. No wonder teenage life, on and off campus, seems to fit stories of vampires, ghosts, the undead. Laura Kasischke is hardly the first to use such figures (as fans of Buffy the Vampire Slayer know) but with her new novel, The Raising, she pursues them almost perfectly. Almost a supernatural thriller, almost a campus satire and almost but not quite a coming-of-age tale, The Raising is also the best of Kasischkes eight novels, the one with the broadest canvas, the most observation, its large cast arranged with a scary economy of detail.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE LAKE  By Banana Yoshimoto.Translated by Michael Emmerich.  Melville House, $23.95.

title: Tennis by the Book
description: Wow, what a tournament we witnessed this week, Johnny Mac! Before we came back on the air, we were both saying that weve been just flat-out blown away by the talent at this years Intertemporal Tennis Writers Classic. Some of the greatest writers in history came and competed and showed us what it means to write extraordinarily well about tennis. This tournament attracts the worlds sharpest minds because tennis is a global sport thats steeped in tradition, and more, its a gentlemanly clash of wills where youre out there alone, and the way you play reveals so much about who you are. Somewhere between chess and boxing lies tennis. So you have to be an elite writer to get through this tournament. Thats why no one was surprised to see Tour get knocked out in the first round. Sure, hes done some nice stories, like his profile of Jennifer Capriati for Vogue, in which he hits with her. Do we have a clip from that? The whole incident takes on the feel of intense aerobics mixed with a back-alley mugging, and youre just deflecting and defending and, eventually, after eight or nine minutes, your arm starts to throb and your lungs start to shriek and each new shot racing at you is like a punch to the chest and you feel her inner bully. Tours a solid player, but in this tournament your forehand is your vocabulary, your backhand is your eye for detail, your ability to turn words into poetry and rhythm is your volley, your use of metaphors and symbolism is your overhead, and your deep understanding of the sport is your all-important first serve. Tour writes passionately and knows tennis, but some whispered that he might have gotten into the tournament only because of affirmative action. Maybe.

title: Death Among Neighbors
description: Nothing brings neighbors together faster than a murder onthe block. Or so says Ruth Rendell, who subjects the residents of anapartment house in Kenilworth (as dreary as only a London outer suburbcan be) to intense psychological scrutiny in her morbidly wittysuspense novel TIGERLILYS ORCHIDS (Scribner, $26) before selecting one of them as her murder victim.

title: Up Front: Annie Sprinkle
description: Annie Sprinkle, who in this issue reviews Chester Browns Paying for It: A Comic-Strip Memoir About Being a John, is no stranger to the documentary urge. From the day I gave away my virginity at 17 I started documenting my sexual experiences, Sprinkle told us via e-mail. I still am, 40 years later.

title: Editors Choice
description: CHILDREN AND FIRE,  by Ursula Hegi (Scribner, $25.) In the fourth of Hegis novels to be set in the German village of Burgdorf, a schoolteacher heroine, seduced by Nazi propaganda, struggles to follow her moral compass.

title: Paperback Row
description: SWEET THUNDER: The Life and Times of Sugar Ray Robinson,  by Wil Haygood (Lawrence Hill, $18.95.) This ambitious portrait places Ray Robinson as a central figure in the rise of urban African-Americans in the 20th century, tracing Robinsons life from his birth in Detroit in 1921 as Walker Smith Jr.; to Harlem and the peak of his success as a prizefighter in the 1940s and 50s; to his humbling final years in Los Angeles before his death in 1989.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: 7 Going on 17
description: Janet Evanovich has had seven books on the hardcover fiction lists over the past three years.

title: Inside the List
description: JERSEY GIRL: Janet Evanovichs Smokin Seventeen jumps past Tom Clancys Against All Enemies to give Evanovich her 12th straight No. 1 hardcover best seller in her Stephanie Plum series. Evanovich may have left her hometown, South River, N.J., for the more scenic climes of Naples, Fla., but her endearingly semi-competent bounty hunter heroine is still running around the Garden State chasing bad guys, juggling boyfriends and serving as a one-woman stimulus program for the used-car industry. Evanovichs Web site includes a memorial page for the ill-fated vehicles that have crossed Stephanies path, from the Chevy Nova in One for the Money (Left for dead, which is O.K. since it had already been vandalized and had no muffler, tailpipe or radio) to the Carpet Car in Hot Six (caught on fire from flaming dog poop in a bag), the Honda CRV in Hard Eight (firebombed by a rabbit) and a maroon Econoline van from Fearless Fourteen, which wasnt really Stephanies, but caught her bad car juju anyway, struck by a russet potato and exploded, as predicted by Gary the Stalker. Normally, Evanovich also holds a summerlong naming contest for next years book (Holy Cannoli Seventeen, anyone?), but she recently announced her next title early, during an interview on the Today show. Yup, you guessed it: Explosive Eighteen.

title: NATOs Libyan War Is Like Fast Food, Qaddafis Son Says
description: In an appearance on Russia Today, an English-language satellite channel financed by the Russian government, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis son Seif al-Islam said that the international intervention in Libya was motivated purely by a desire to control Libyas oil and gas resources.

title: Iraq Cracks Down on Iran-Backed Shiite Militias
description: BAGHDAD  Against a backdrop of rising violence against American soldiers, Iraqi security forces have unleashed a sweeping crackdown on Iranian-backed Shiite militants responsible for most of the lethal attacks, according to American and Iraqi officials.

title: Its July. Do You Know Where Your Beach House Is?
description: EVEN for longtime residents, the crazy quilt of towns, hamlets and villages that stretch along the South Fork of Long Island can be a bit dizzying.

title: Elements of an Ideal Burger
description: Cooking tips for creating the perfect burger, on everything from picking the right bun to shaping the patty to getting the perfect sear on the meat.

title: AMC Shares Tumble on Debut
description: Shares of AMC Networks  the media company spun off from Cablevision that is home to Mad Men and Breaking Bad  fell on their full trading debut on the Nasdaq market on Friday.

title: Vacation Rentals in Non-Hamptons Directions
description: FOR city dwellers who havent fallen under the spell of the Hamptons, there are plenty of other escapes, including popular beaches to the south in New Jersey and lakeside hideaways to the north in the Hudson Valley.

title: Film Festival | Documentaries for Summer Fun
description: Our summer experiments continue! Last week: Historic Headlines. This week: A collaboration with SnagLearning to bring you film festivals of classroom-worthy documentaries, each day on a different theme.

title: Making a Portfolio, and More, at Money Camp
description: WELL-MEANING parents have long sent their children to specialized camps in the hope of bringing out their inner genius  or at least keeping them busy for the summer. But recently, a camp with a different sort of specialty than the usual cheerleading and music and art camps has been popping up  one that aims to teach children money skills.

title: Never Too Far From the Beach
description: PATSY AND CHUCK KOPPEIS have talked to more neighbors in the five months since they moved to the quirky seaside community of Bayville than in the 28 years they lived in Woodbury, 15 minutes away.

title: Comparing Yourself to Others: Its Not All Bad
description: TO compare is to despair, the saying goes, and Ive generally found it to be true. If I try hard enough (and sometimes even if I dont) I can usually find someone who performs better or has more. And I can feel bad about it.

title: Watermelon and Tomato Salad
description: Mark Bittman makes a salad from the Minimalist column archives that combines sweet and savory, tender and crunchy.

title: Election to Replace Weiner Is Set for Sept. 13
description: Fulfilling the wishes of local political leaders, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Friday that a special election to fill the seat of former Representative Anthony D. Weiner would be held on Sept. 13.

title: The Plaza Hotel Reopens Its Tricycle Garage
description: The Plaza Hotel in New York City will revive its Tricycle Garage, which will be good news for Eloise fans  especially those lucky enough to stay at the renovated landmark hotel. Beginning on July 1, the Plaza will offer childrens bike rentals  including Radio Flyer tricycles, bicycles and scooters  for hotel guests and a few lucky New Yorkers.

title: The Minimalist: Watermelon and Tomato Salad
description: I developed this recipe about five years into my stint as the Minimalist. By that point I had already exhausted (or thought I had; I was wrong) most of the obvious candidates for the column five-ingredient pasta dishes, simple marinated meats, 10-minute green salads  and was forced to research and invent recipes that were less conventional but no more complicated. This salad is one of my favorite results of that challenge, and I still make it regularly. It turns out watermelon and tomato make spectacular plate fellows, and theyre even better with a few assertive accompaniments.

title: Richer People Want Fewer Children
description: The economist Justin Wolfers wrote a provocative post last month arguing that children are inferior goods.

title: A French Oddity Turns Heads in New York
description: Alain Daumas dreamed of driving his 1955 Citron Traction Avant down Broadway. On a recent afternoon, his wish came true.

title: Beijing Monasterys Newer Neighbors
description: In a maze of alleys branching out from the 17th-century Lama, or Yonghe, Temple are new cafes and boutiques.

title: Roller Coasters Bring a New Kind of Thrill to Vegas
description: THERE are two kinds of people who travel to Las Vegas: gamblers and roller-coaster riders.

title: Restaurant Report: Lechonera La Ranchera in Puerto Rico
description: Pop out to Lechonera La Ranchera, about 30 minutes outside San Juan, on a Friday afternoon and you can snack on crisp pork chunks and fried plantains, enjoy the air-conditioning, then climb back in your rental car for the drive back, wondering the whole time, perhaps, why you didnt just order takeout at the hotel.

title: On Quebec Fur Traders Trail, With a Paddle
description: WE had two choices: stop and haul our canoes and gear along a four-mile trail running parallel to the river, or paddle into the canyon, with its 19 sets of rapids and near vertical walls. Either way, the decision would be final.

title: Hotel Review: Gansevoort Park Avenue NYC
description: THE UPSHOT

title: In Rome, Monti Is a Quiet Treasure
description: PEOPLE sometimes wander along Via Panisperna in Rome realizing they are lost, but not fretting about it. The view is divine from there, a slice of the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore sandwiched between 19th-century apartment buildings, dilapidated palazzos, the elevated Church of San Lorenzo in Panisperna and stores like Macelleria Stecchiotti, a butcher shop selling some of the best meat in Rome. The owner, Pietro Stecchiotti, a neighborhood notable nicknamed Pol Pot for his occupation and ardent Communist politics, claims to have planted the vines that drape across Via Panisperna in front of his shop, framing a quintessentially Roman streetscape.

title: In Italy, Vineyards by Vespa
description: IS it normal for the carabinieri to be drinking at noon? I asked, gesturing toward five members of the Italian military police swirling and sipping glasses of white wine.

title: Chvez Can Remain Outside Venezuela for Months, Vice President Says
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez, who shocked the nation by revealing that he had a cancerous tumor removed and would continue battling, could legally keep governing Venezuela from his seclusion in Cuba for as long as six months if necessary, his vice president said Friday.

title: July 1, 1898 | The Battle of San Juan Hill
description: On July 1, 1898, United States forces, including Teddy Roosevelts Rough Riders, defeated greatly outnumbered Spanish forces at San Juan Hill and Kettle Hill near the Spanish stronghold of Santiago de Cuba. The victory allowed the United States to begin a siege of Santiago de Cuba, which led to Spanish surrender and the end of the Spanish-American War.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Lost in Space
description: Legion Lost, a tale of the Legion of Super-Heroes, a group of champions from 1,000 years in the future, lands at No. 2 on the hardcover list this week. The group, published by DC Comics, has had a bit of a confounding history. The Legion was created in 1958. They were time travelers from the future who had traveled to the past to meet their heroic inspiration: Superboy. Cut to 1985 when DC published Crisis on Infinite Earths, a limited series intended to streamline the decades of convoluted continuity of its heroes. It was decided that Superman never had costumed adventures as a youth, so the reason for the Legions founding had to be reconsidered. A lot of stories were crafted to give them a new reason for forming  until it was decided, 20 years later when DC published Infinite Crisis  that Superman did have a career as Superboy so the Legion could be inspired by him.

title: Stuck in Dock, Flotilla Activists See the Hand of Israel
description: ATHENS  With the propeller shafts of two ships mysteriously damaged, the Greek authorities holding other vessels in port on government orders and an American boat turned back by the Greek coast guard on Friday just 20 minutes off the coast, the international flotilla to Gaza has stalled.

How does the current round of layoffs and austerity in the financial industry compare with the Armageddon at the height of the financial crisis?

description: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the closing of an elementary school, the same-sex marriage law in New York and a disappearing artist at ground zero.

title: Where Did the Fun Go?
description: A few years ago, just as the recession hit, the Chambre Syndicale, the French fashion authority, decided to separate the June mens shows and the haute couture by a week. The two groups of shows had followed each other, as they still do in January. A week of free time in Europe is no longer regarded by publications with the joie de vivre of the past, so I usually split the time between work and pleasure. At the moment Im in a village in Burgundy, staying at La Source des Fes, a vineyard owned by Thierry Nouvel and Philippe Greffet. The place is as lovely as it is laid back, with delicious dinners, and each night brings new guests  Dutch, Swedes, French. Its the beginning of the European summer.

title: Harlem Stage Announces Fall Lineup
description: Harlem Stage, the multidisciplinary performing arts center supporting artists of color that has made a huge name for itself while managing to weather the recent economic storms, announced on Friday its fall 2011 season of new dance, film, theater and music. Among the highlights are Visible, a new work by choreographers Nora Chipaumire and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, which will have its world premiere Oct. 10-15 at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse. Two new editions of the WeDaPeoplesCabaret will jump-start the Uptown Nights series in September. Carl Hancock Rux is the curator on Sept. 17, with a program featuring Nona Hendryx, the political monologist Reno and the author and producer Nelson George. The Grammy-nominated trumpeter Christian Scott will offer two nights with his quintet on Oct. 28 and Oct. 29. The D.J. Rich Medina will transform the Harlem Stage Gatehouse into a space to celebrate the life of Fela Anikulapo Kuti on Nov. 19 with music, dance and conversation. On Nov. 10, as part of its Harlem Stride  Community Concert series in partnership with the Weill Music Institute of Carnegie Hall, the Grammy nominee Miguel Zenon leads his quintet in a program featuring music by great songwriters from Puerto Rico. Tickets are free. Ticket prices for most Harlem Stage performances are $20 or less; some are free and generally dont go higher than $45.

title: A Camp Option, but Is It Useful?
description: Wealthy families have long realized that their children need to learn about money, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week. They will often send their children to retreats like the one run by Citi Private Bank, which focuses on investing, running businesses and giving money to charity.

title: Hidden Entry
description: Designers have long favored sleek, flush door handles on concept cars. Now they are becoming common on production models.

title: New Americana | Dressing for the Fourth
description: Dressing for a holiday often revolves around a slew of clichs that make us look (and feel) cheesy orange and black, anyone?  as opposed to smartly festive. It certainly doesnt have to. This fourth of July, opt for the unexpected in some coolly patriotic looks like Lanvins lam shorts rather than classic denim, and pair them with bright, playful Superga sneakers. In the evening, go for relaxed Americana by mixing a Sonia by Sonia Rykiel T-shirt with a ladylike Donna Karan silk skirt. For a patriotic dcolletage, wear this red lace bra from Deborah Marquit with a sexy sheer Equipment top. The black and white stripes (as opposed to boring blue and red) are as chic as a Mount Vernon fireworks display.

title: What Cellphone Calls Say About Parent-Teenager Relations

title: Whipped by Winds Over Land Parched by Drought, a New Mexico Wildfire Rages
description: LOS ALAMOS, N.M.  Driven by a relentless drought and surging summer winds, a wildfire continued to burn virtually unchecked in the Jemez Mountains near Los Alamos National Laboratory on Friday, having already scorched tens of thousands of acres in its path and leaving firefighters scrambling to keep pace.

J. K. Rowling, a single mother when she hatched a series of magical boarding-school novels, has ascended to an Oprah-like level of wealth and influence, while Harry, with more than $6 billion in tickets sold globally, has surpassed James Bond as the top-grossing movie-franchise hero.

description: A federal appeals court on Friday struck down Michigans 2006 ban on the consideration of race and gender in public-university admissions and government hiring in the latest round of the decade-long fight over the University of Michigans affirmative action policies.

title: Lonely Voyage of Player, Piano and Audience
description: CRAIG TABORN was deep into a solo expedition one recent evening at the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan, seeming for all the world like someone cracking a secret code. Poised for action at a grand piano, he disrupted an expectant stillness with a turbulent digression. With his left hand he formed the lopsided bass-clef vamp of a piece called Avenging Angel; with his right he improvised complex annotations, firing them off in boldface or sleek cursive. It was taut, transfixing music, sharpened by the austerity of the setting: just Mr. Taborn at the piano, on his own.

title: Seen It Before: CBS Wins the Night With Repeats
description: For CBS, an all-repeat lineup eked out a first-place finish for the network in the ratings on Thursday as CSI and The Mentalist delivered the nights largest audiences in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, 7.8 million viewers tuned in for a rerun of The Mentalist at 10 p.m.. while CSI attracted 6.8 million at 9. Wipeout on ABC led the 8 p.m. hour with 6.5 million viewers, outperforming CBSs combination of The Big Bang Theory (6.6 million) and Rules of Engagement (4.9 million). ABC earned a second-place finish, drawing 6.1 million at 9 p.m. for Expedition Impossible and 5.4 million at 10 for a new installment of Rookie Blue. Fox was third, averaging 5 million for So You Think You Can Dance at 8 p.m. followed by a rerun of Glee (2.9 million) at 9. NBC trailed in fourth with sitcom repeats and a new episode of Love Bites (1.8 million) at 10.

title: Extra Savage
description: I discovered Dan Savage, the subject of my cover story this weekend, in 2004, when I became editor of the alternative weekly paper in New Haven. I did not know much about alt weeklies, and to get ideas I looked around for some of the best. Somebody said I had to check out The Stranger, the bigger of Seattles two alt weeklies. So I e-mailed the editor, who was this Dan Savage guy. I figured that couldnt be his real name; it was probably some alt weekly stunt. But Dan Savage sent me a bunch of issues, and the paper was brilliant: smart, good-looking, edgy. Inside, the editor wrote a really good sex column called Savage Love, and Iasked my publisher if we could drop our syndicated sex column and replace it with Savage Love. Cant, he said. Too dirty. People would object. That was about all I knew of Dan Savage for the next couple years, although occasionally I would see links to Savages work on Andrew Sullivans blog.

title: An Experiment That Evolved Into a Tragedy
description: TALKING animals are a dime a dozen in animated blockbusters. But what about the real thing? And what, for that matter, would it mean for an animal to talk? What indeed separates an animal from a human? These are a few of the questions raised in a new documentary about the life of a chimpanzee named Nim Chimpsky, the subject of a radical language experiment in the 1970s. Project Nim, which opens Friday in New York and Chicago and will be shown next year on HBO, is named after the study, which began in 1973 with an infant Nim living with an Upper West Side family and ended after much trial and tribulation in a Texas animal sanctuary, where he died in 2000.

(And thats saying something in these days and times). It figures, then, that my politically clued-in friends tell me that its an idea gaining lots of support on the Hill, even among progressives.

description: David Borden formed his colorfully named ensemble, Mother Mallards Portable Masterpiece Company, in 1969, when he was experimenting with early Moog synthesizers and Minimalist compositional notions. Mr. Borden has composed prolifically for the group since then, and on Wednesday evening he brought his players to the Issue Project Room for an installment of the spaces Darmstadt Institute: Classics of the Avant-Garde series.

description: LOS ANGELES  How do you take an acclaimed theater festival in one city and turn it into a national franchise, an endeavor that could easily set off turf warfare among artists? Mark Russell thinks he has an answer.

title: I Forgive Canada
Whats Scrabble When You Can Play Novelist?
description: The best after-dinner games need no special equipment to play: no dice, cards, tiles or machines that bleat at wrong answers. Classics like charades and the dictionary game  sometimes called Fictionary, and tweaked for the unimaginative under the brand name Balderdash  call at most for paper and pencils. Theyre D.I.Y. and lo-fi.

title: Ever the Charmer, Brazen and Sly, but at a Faster Clip
description: NEWARK  R. Kelly isnt a singer given to grand ideological gesture, but last year the release of his 10th album, Love Letter, appeared to be making a statement. For almost two decades hes been the id of modern R&B, even as, for several years in the 2000s, he operated under the shadow of child pornography charges, of which he was acquitted in 2008.

title: A New Shirt Closes a Gap in Modesty
description: THE first ladys oft-bared arms aside, dress codes for women in Washingtons bread-and-butter jobs (law, Congress, lobbying) have remained steadfastly more prim than in other cities. Remember the Hillary Rodham Clinton cleavage scandal of 2007, when Mrs. Clinton, a senator at the time, was criticized for showing a flash of dcolletage on the Senate floor? The offending hint of bust was barely visible; she had merely worn a blouse that dipped lower than her clavicle. It didnt happen again.

title: No Pause in Pursuit of Justice (and Ratings)
description: Some people will never serve on a jury. But anyone watching HLNs coverage of the trial of Casey Anthony, the young woman charged with killing her 2-year-old daughter, Caylee, has a visceral sense of what its like to be on duty in that courtroom in Orlando, Fla.

title: Canceled Recess Upends Senators Plans
description: Senators will return to business next week instead of going on their planned recess, because Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, said they have to. But that doesnt mean that everyone is happy about it.

description: With six more hits, Derek Jeter will become the first player to reach 3,000 hits as a Yankee.Meanwhile, Fran Kowalski is hoping to get a hit soon, too. And it all has to do with Jeter. Kowalski, a singer, songwriter and producer, has released Derek Jeters 3,000 Hits, an ode to the shortstops career and his milestone.

title: A Response to Mara Hvistendahl (II)
description: In her reply to my column, the author of Unnatural Selection also disputes my suggestion that her books tone of moral outrage depends on an (implicit) sympathy for aborted female fetuses as well as a concern for the societal impact of sex-selective abortion. I make very clear in my book that the victim is women, Hvistendahl writes  women who in the 1960s and 1970s were used as pawns in a Western drive to reduce birth rates in Asia, women who later aborted female fetuses against the backdrop of patriarchy, and women who, now that they are scarce, find themselves at greater risk of being trafficked, kidnapped, or sold by their parents to men desperate to find wives. Sex-selective abortion is wrong because women should account for half of the human population, and in parts of the world they now account for far less. That alone justifies moral outrage.

Every development in the case was tweeted and retweeted  Mr. Strauss-Kahn (known as #DSK on Twitter) was in the courtroom, he had been released on his own recognizance, the district attorney was about to speak.

title: Ministering to Soldiers, and Facing Their Struggles
description: FORT JACKSON, S.C.  Growing up on a farm in Ohio, the son of an Army medic in World War II, David Bowlus often sneaked into the attic to try on his fathers uniform as if it were a destiny. At 16, on a family trip to West Point, he watched the cadets drill and knew what he wanted for the future.

description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Friday declined to step into a dispute over the Obama administrations cancellation of a planned nuclear waste dump in the Nevada desert, saying the matter must be left for now to federal regulators.

description: Richard H. Poff, a former Republican congressman from Virginia who surprised official Washington in 1971 by withdrawing from consideration for a seat on the Supreme Court rather than submit to the harsh scrutiny he feared his anti-civil-rights voting record would arouse, died Tuesday in Tullahoma, Tenn. He was 87.

description: Now that Thomas Casarella is leaving the Treasury Department as its acting restructuring chief, he intends to catch up on some light reading. Only it doesnt involve picking up the latest James Patterson novel.

title: Many Smartphone Customers Are Still Up for Grabs
description: About 10 years ago I met an advertising executive in New York who explained thedifficultyofadvertising a new brand of deodorant to consumers. Most people never change theirdeodorant, I remember him saying. They pick one brand when they are young, and stick with it for a long, long time. If it works, why switch?

title: Shriver Files for Divorce From Schwarzenegger
description: LOS ANGELES  Maria Shriver has filed for divorce from former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, citing irreconcilable differences as she seeks to end a 25-year marriage that had long captured the publics attention.

title: Slavery in the Modern Age
description: Anyone who thinks slavery ended with the 13th Amendment is not paying attention. According to the latest State Department statistics, as many as 100,000 people in the United States are in bondage and perhaps 27 million people worldwide. The numbers are staggering.

title: Google Executives Throw Themselves Into the Google+ Fray
description: It may be too soon to say whether Google+, the search companys answer to Facebook, will avoid the same disastrous fate as some of its earlier social networking products like Buzz and Wave, but theres no shortage of action on the site among those who have early access.

title: Bayer Settles With Farmers Over Modified Rice Seeds
description: A Bayer AG unit will pay $750 million to settle claims with about 11,000 United States farmers who said a strain of the companys genetically modified rice tainted crops and ruined their export value.

title: Qaddafi Threatens Europe With Attacks
description: BIR AYAD, Libya  In a defiant speech broadcast to an unusually large gathering of his supporters on Friday, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi threatened attacks on Europe if NATO did not halt its bombing campaign, even as he also seemed to leave open a door to negotiations.

title: Players Are Locked Out From N.B.A.s Web Site, Too
description: When the clock struck 12:01 a.m. Friday in New York, Arn Tellem was in his backyard in Los Angeles, hosting a cookout. This is not how an N.B.A. agent typically celebrates the arrival of July.

title: In Ohio, a New Governor Is Off to a Smooth Start
description: In Washington, Congress may still be fighting over the national budget, but in Ohio, where Republicans control the House, the Senate and the governors office, the budget passage has been about as smooth as a knife through butter.

title: Accusers Fellow Guineans Express Bewilderment
description: Hundreds of Guinean men in bright robes and skullcaps knelt on the floor of a Bronx mosque on Friday as their imam boomed out a sermon that seemed tailored for a difficult day.

title: His Aggressiveness Unabated, Christie Keeps His Momentum
description: Democrats said this year would be different, that they would push back harder against Gov. Chris Christie. Mr. Christie also signaled a shift, expressing a desire to be less combative.

title: Dead in the Water?
description: Like they dont already have enough problems.

title: BPs Ex-Chief and Plaintiffs Lawyers Spar Over Safety
description: In testimony before Congress last summer, Tony Hayward, then BPs chief executive, asserted that his company was conducting a full and comprehensive investigation into the causes of the Deepwater Horizon disaster that killed 11 rig workers and spewed millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. He said BP had put in place a sweeping new safety system throughout the company in the wake of lapses in 2006 and 2007.

title: Murray Lifts Game, but Not Enough
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Never mind Rafael Nadals sore ankle or Andy Murrays tender hip. Everything you needed to know about the health of mens tennis was revealed in Murrays news conference after his 5-7, 6-2, 6-2, 6-4 semifinal loss to Nadal on Friday.

title: Change (but Not Too Much) at the Top of the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON  The lush Pentagon parade ground was the same, the sun-drenched view of the Potomac was the same, even the senior military assistant was the same. Welcome aboard, sir, Lt. Gen. John F. Kelly said in a Friday morning salute to his new boss, Leon E. Panetta, after sending off his old one, Robert M. Gates, from the same spot less than 24 hours before.
