title: An Era When the City Roared
description: NEW YORK is now, as it has been since the 1850s, a global city, the archetype city of everyones future, the novelist E. L. Doctorow wrote a decade ago. Its arguable, though, exactly if, and when, the city also became capital of the world and whether it still is. Nonetheless, David Wallace makes a compelling and appealing case in Capital of the World: A Portrait of New York City in the Roaring Twenties (Lyons Press, $24.95).

title: FIFA Addresses a Coachs Remarks
description: Soccers world governing body said it had spoken with Eucharia Uche, the coach of the Nigerian womens national team, about homophobic remarks she made to The New York Times regarding lesbian players on her team.

title: Seven Days and 120 Miles to Go
description: Catskill, N.Y.

title: Hemingway, Hounded by the Feds
description: EARLY one morning, 50 years ago today, while his wife, Mary, slept upstairs, Ernest Hemingway went into the vestibule of his Ketchum, Idaho, house, selected his favorite shotgun from the rack, inserted shells into its chambers and ended his life.

title: Spurned by Lady Liberty, Macys Fireworks Show Stays Put
description: For this years Fourth of July celebration, Macys had hoped to turn its massive fireworks show into a birthday party for the Statue of Liberty, which was dedicated in New York harbor 125 years ago. The shows planners wanted to surround the statue with barges loaded with shells, fire some others off from the base of the statue and even have Beyonc perform on a stage there.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,634 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

title: Pay Workers Fairly and Save Money
description: DESPITE persistent unemployment and stagnant wages, few believe that our cash-strapped government is likely to simply create better-paying jobs. But there is a way for this country to get more from the millions of jobs we already finance with federal dollars, while reducing the cost of entitlement programs.

title: What Gov. Cuomo Left Undone
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo showed that it was possible to get New Yorks chronically inert Legislature to approve several of his top priorities this year. He made history, getting the new law allowing same-sex marriage passed. He started the clean-up of Albanys tainted government with an ethics bill that requires more transparency. And he prevailed in getting a more rational tuition plan to help the states public universities.

title: The Pentagon After Mr. Gates
description: Robert Gates was already a 40-year veteran of the national security establishment when President George W. Bush summoned him to assume command of a demoralized and embattled Pentagon in late 2006. He inherited incoherent spending priorities, a broken procurement process and two disastrously mismanaged wars.

title: For Washington, a Trek to Daylight
description: WASHINGTON  Late for work, Cassandra Jackson hurried through the Washington subway the other week only to confront a broken escalator that was supposed to carry her to the street. Exactly 351 steps later she made it to the top.

title: To Determine Queen, Power Will Be King
description: WIMBLEDON, England  In a match featuring two of the most powerful players in womens tennis, Maria Sharapova faces Petra Kvitova in the Wimbledon singles final on Saturday. For Sharapova, the match is her first Grand Slam final since winning the Australian Open in 2008. Kvitova reached the semifinals here a year ago, and has steadily improved since, but is making her first appearance in a major final.

title: As Nationalism Surges in Europe, Poland Begins Bloc Presidency
description: Once counted among the least enthusiastic members of the European Union, Poland took over its rotating presidency on Friday with an outspoken attack on the leaders of the blocs large countries for pursuing national interests instead of regional concerns.

title: The War Comes to Galveston
description: Commander James Alden was by all accounts a resourceful and clever naval officer, talents he put to use in June 1861 as he and his ship helped establish the sprawling Union blockade against Confederate ports. Aboard his now-oddly named steamer, the South Carolina, he dropped munitions to federal troops at Fort Pickens, near Pensacola, Fla., then sailed west to join the Gulf Blockading Squadron off Louisiana. On July 2 the ship suddenly appeared off Galveston, one of the busiest ports in the South and a boom town riding a wave of cotton exports to Europe. Riding the low Gulf breakers, the South Carolina, brought to Texas President Lincolns Anaconda strategy: strangling the South by sea.

title: The Voices Emerging From College Studios
description: LAST November, the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art assembled a team of 18 gallery owners, curators, collectors and artists for the purpose of making studio visits  not to already-established artists, but to art students in master of fine arts programs across the United States. The results of their travels to nearly 2,000 studios at more than 30 colleges and universities  and of a subsequent selection process that winnowed candidates they would spotlight to 12  can be seen in First Look III, now on view at the museum.

title: A Button-Down Man Sets Out, Trailed by Silliness
description: The story of a stuffy late-19th-century Englishman betting members of his equally stuffy gentlemans club that he can circumnavigate the globe in 80 days has a certain amount of wackiness built in. Or it did, at least, by the time the Jules Verne novel that tells the tale was adapted into Mike Todds all-star 1956 Hollywood movie.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Bloggingheads: Will Race Save Obama?
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Matthew Cooper of National Journal discuss race and Obama's reelection hopes.

title: A Factory Worker Glances Back
description: BEING closely associated with Andy Warhol and his Factory during the 1960s has been perhaps both a blessing and a curse for Ultra Violet, the artist and writer who starred in many of his films. Without Warhol, she would quite likely be unknown today, but her history also gets in her way.

title: How to Succeed in a Pink Power Suit
description: Legally Blonde: The Musical, the lightweight confection now playing at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport, overflows with fluffiness, which is just what is called for in the book by Heather Hach and the music and lyrics by Laurence OKeefe and Nell Benjamin.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: One Fine Day
description: Last week, there was a day I hesitate to call perfect only because I would hate it if the perfect day had already come and gone in my life. But when that perfect day comes at last it will probably resemble the one last week. The western breeze had cleaned the sun and purified the light, which fell moteless on the farm.

title: A Drummer Goes Beyond a Legacy
description: AL FOSTER, a mild-mannered man with a perpetual smile, burst on the scene as the improbably fierce drummer with the Miles Davis band of the early 1970s. The job made his name; it even earned him a $200-a-week retainer, a benefit rare in the world of freelance musicians. But the band, heavy on rock vamps and light on harmonic progressions, was not really his style  and he let Davis know it.

title: Mamets Tale of Blacks and Whites Told in Grays
description: David Mamet must be wishing hed made the hotel chambermaid the accuser instead of just a witness in the rape case that dominates his 2009 Broadway play, Race. Then whatever else todays audiences might make of it, theyd have to salute his uncanny prescience.

title: When States Shut Down for Business
description: A look at state shutdowns over the last decade.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Performers With Talent Beyond Their Years
description: THE 29 actors in this years installment of the New Jersey Youth Theaters summer musical program are a goofy bunch, according to Cynthia Meryl, the organizations co-founder and artistic director. Theyre really silly, she added. But there is a reason for that.

title: A Dream Perfectly Suited for the Outdoors
description: Do you recall the first Shakespeare play you ever saw? Mine was King Lear, which was mighty grim for a 9-year-old. I remember thinking, even as Morris Carnovskys Lear raged away upon the heath, Boy, these storm scenes are awfully long.

title: Kansas: Judge Blocks Abortion Rules
description: A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction on Friday preventing new regulations from taking effect that would have forced the closing of two of the states three abortion clinics. The clinics have been unable to meet requirements of the regulations, which were issued this month and were supposed to take effect on Friday. A third clinic, operated by Planned Parenthood, was granted a license this week. In an hourlong hearing in District Court in Kansas City, lawyers for the state argued the regulations represented an appropriate way to protect the safety of patients, while lawyers for the clinics called them unnecessarily onerous. The judge, Carlos Murgia, noted that one provider had turned down two women seeking abortions because of fetal abnormalities as evidence that there would be irreparable harm if the regulations were allowed to go into effect pending the outcome of the case.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Florida: Rail Project Will Move Forward
description: Gov. Rick Scott on Friday lifted his freeze on the start of construction for a commuter rail system in central Florida. The 61-mile, $1.2 billion project has been strongly backed by the business community and Representative John L. Mica, a Republican who is chairman of the House Transportation Committee, but opposed by Tea Party activists and other critics. Mr. Scott had expressed concern because local governments would be asked to cover any revenue shortfalls after seven years of operation. But he said he felt that he had no choice but to approve the deal, as supporters had threatened to sue the state because the Legislature had authorized the spending.

title: House Ethics Panel Confirms Two Investigations
description: The House Ethics Committee confirmed Friday that it is investigating two lawmakers, Representatives Gregory W. Meeks, Democrat of New York, and Jean Schmidt, Republican of Ohio. The committee said it needed more time for its inquiries, but said that fact does not itself indicate that any violation has occurred. Mr. Meeks is under investigation because of a $40,000 loan he received in 2007 and initially did not disclose from a Queens real estate broker who had been repeatedly investigated for fraud and predatory lending. Ms. Schmidt is being investigated on accusations she accepted free legal services from a Turkish-American group. Joe Jansen, an aide to Ms. Schmidt, said she intends to pay back the Turkish-American group, but has not done so at the request of the ethics investigators. The committee said it would decide how to proceed by Aug. 16.

title: A Fight Over Keeping Boards in the Boardwalk
description: The Coney Island Boardwalk, opened in 1923, has inspired songs (The Drifters Under the Boardwalk), plays (Herb Gardners The Goodbye People) and fiction (Delmore Schwartzs In Dreams Begin Responsibilities). Now, it is inspiring a question of Talmudic complexity: Can a boardwalk be called a boardwalk if it is not made of boards?

title: Sweet, Moist and Gluten-Free
description: When she was an undergraduate, Karen Miller took a cake-decorating class with a friend. She liked it and was good at it, but there was one problem: she couldnt eat anything she made.

title: Prepare to Be Part of the Chefs Family
description: AS you enter Rosas La Scarbitta Ristorante, a new Italian restaurant in Mamaroneck, you will see a message painted on the wall: Come in as a stranger, leave as a member of the family. It would be easy to dismiss it as so much marketing nonsense, but by the time youve met Rosa Merenda, the chef and co-owner (and you will), chatted with her husband and partner, Angelo, and eaten their food, you will indeed feel that youve just had a sweet familial experience.

title: Season of the Grill, and Ross
description: Like summer flowers, colorful dry ross  pink, coral, salmon, near-red, almost orange  abound at East End wineries.

title: Saturday: Dont Believe It For a Second
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert: There will be a Notepad in tomorrows puzzle that says When this puzzle is done, the circles will contain five different letters of the alphabet. Connect each set of circles containing the same letter, without crossing your line, to make a simple closed shape. The resulting five closed shapes together will form a picture of a 117-Across. The five letters can be arranged to name a good place to get a 117-Across. DONT PANIC. Pat Merrell provides a helpful graphic to get us through this.

title: Hearing Set for Galea; Plea Deal Is Possible
description: A Canadian doctor indicted last year on charges he distributed performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes in the United States is scheduled to appear in federal court in Buffalo next week for an arraignment and plea hearing, according to a court filing.

title: Causing a Scene, and Breaking the Mold
description: A HOT new spot, the East Hampton Grill, which opened in May, is lighting up the summer on the East End. Its a scene, but with good reason  the food is terrific.

title: Mets Buchholz Is Dealing With Depression and Anxiety
description: Taylor Buchholz, the 29-year-old Mets middle reliever, has had depression and anxiety since before he was placed on the disabled list a month ago with what the team had previously described as right shoulder fatigue.

title: Burgers, Dogs and History
description: At a different time of year, the whitewashed shack that is Harrys Place might be mistaken for a farm stand or carnival booth. But not between St. Patricks Day and Halloween, when the wooden panels of its hatch windows are slung open and customers line up for the burgers and dogs that have made Harrys a drive-in destination.

title: Geographys of No Matter in This Asian Bistro
description: IN a long, narrow space a few steps below street level on Greenwich Avenue  a space once occupied by the admirable but relatively short-lived Solaia  is a self-described modern Asian bistro. But that phrase barely begins to capture the amazing dishes at Kokoro, whose name means from the heart, said Simon Chik, a co-owner, which is how I would describe the cooking of our chef, Anan Tiwadom.

title: Reads and Reactions
description: In this edition: one pundits serious candidate is another pundits long-shot flake.

title: Billy Costello, Who Won Light Welterweight Crown, Dies at 55
description: Billy Costello, who overcame a troubled youth to become an undefeated light welterweight champion in the mid-1980s despite not putting on boxing gloves until he was 19, died Wednesday in Kingston, N.Y. He was 55.

title: Yankees Robertson Making an All-Star Case
description: The way Dave Robertson remembers it, no more than 150 people lined Broad Street in Rome, Ga., the night before the 2007 South Atlantic League All-Star Game. Sitting in the back of one of the vintage convertibles that ferried athletes along the parade route, Robertson waved to his parents. Then he felt a thud. He lurched forward. His car had collided with the car in front.

title: Ingenious Gelato
description: Tom Parisi offers 18 flavors of gelato daily at his tidy, 800-square-foot shop, Tommy 2 Scoops, in Jersey City. But he does not take credit for the ingenuity of those flavors, which include ricotta honey and parmesan olive oil and are made on the premises ($3.50 a scoop).

title: Greek Specialties and a Beach Scene

title: Ruling Moves Madoff Case to New Court
description: A federal judge on Friday took control of the billion-dollar lawsuit against the owners of the Mets by the trustee for Bernard L. Madoffs victims, ruling that he must decide certain critical legal issues before the case could proceed in bankruptcy court, if it could proceed at all.

title: In Jordan Zimmermann, Nationals See Present and Future Success
description: Last August, the highly touted Nationals prospect, Jordan Zimmermann, made his dramatic return to the major leagues a little more than a year after having Tommy John surgery. Zimmermann, a former second round pick out of Division III University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point, joined a rotation headed by Stephen Strasburg, baseballs most electric pitching prospect.

title: Presidents Health Adds to Uncertainty in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  A senior Yemeni official who was briefed on the health of President Ali Abdullah Saleh said that the presidents injuries would leave him unfit to perform his duties for months, throwing a new degree of uncertainty into a political standoff that has trapped this impoverished desert nation.

title: The Amazing Centristman
description: A superhero who fights crime with compromise.

title: Hail, Columbia!
description: As Union soldiers went off to war, the national figure most often urging them on in political cartoons and political stump speeches wasnt Uncle Sam, but Columbia. Forgotten today even as her name adorns universities, rivers and cities across the country, Columbia was Americas response to Britannia, a secular goddess who personified the national spirit. Both Britannia and Columbia were patterned after other goddess figures: Britannia copied Minervas helmet, for example, and both symbols frequently identified themselves with the Goddess of Liberty by displaying or wearing the liberty cap.

title: Net Lending By Domestic Business
description: A better picture to illustrate the point that cash is not the problem: heres net lending by domestic business:

title: South Carolinas Young Governor Has a High Profile and Higher Hopes
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Nikki Haley, at 39 the nations youngest governor, loves her iPod.

title: And the Bride Wore Armani
description: In recap after recap of the royal wedding today in Monaco, I noticed that when the television camera was on the groom, Prince Albert II, during the vows, you could see Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH, in the background.

title: Greece Jails U.S. Captain in Gaza Flotilla
description: ATHENS  The American captain of a United States-flagged boat in the planned flotilla to Gaza was jailed Saturday, a day after trying to sail out of port, flotilla organizers said.

title: The City in My Mind
description: OFTEN I live in one place but write about another place very much unlike it. I wrote my first novel as a student in India, and I wrote my latest while commuting among Newcastle in England, Minneapolis and Cape Town, where I reside. As befits a writer who lives more in the mind than in my physical surroundings, I base my work on memory, which I enrich with my knowledge of Somalia  where my novels are set  and supplement with my imagination.

title: The D.A. Stole His Life, Justices Took His Money
description: Lincoln Caplan dissects a powerful dissent by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg about prosecutorial misconduct.

title: The D.A. Stole His Life, Justices Took His Money
description: In an important prosecutorial-misconduct case this term, the Supreme Courts conservative majority threw out a $14 million jury award for a New Orleans man who was imprisoned for 18 years, including 14 on death row, for a robbery and a murder he did not commit. One month before John Thompsons scheduled execution, a private investigator discovered that prosecutors had hidden evidence that exonerated him.

title: Sunday Dialogue: The Old, the Young and Medicare
description: Whats in Medicares future? A letter on Wednesday calling for a sharp cut in benefits and a sober dialogue between the generations drew more than 100 responses. This is a sampling.

title: Surrounded by Opinion, the Times Raises Its Voices
description: YOURE sitting in your office at The New York Times and theres a din outside in the street. You crack the door to listen: mass bloviating on a worldwide scale! Opinion journalism in full bellow on television, the Internet and digital ports of call of every description!

title: Bryans Tie Record for Major Doubles Championships
description: WIMBLEDON, England  History was never the carrot Bob and Mike Bryan were chasing. They werent fixated on records the way the golfer Tiger Woods is on Jack Nicklauss record of 18 major titles.

title: Executive Pay, Revisited: Even Higher Than It First Seemed
description: Median pay for chief executives at 200 of the nations largest companies rose 23 percent last year.

title: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
description: Sunday Business asked Equilar, the executive compensation data company, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings. To be included in the revised study, a company must have been incorporated in the United States and must have filed a definitive proxy statement by June 23. The 200 highest-paid C.E.O.s at companies with revenue of $10.78 billion or more were included.

title: We Knew They Got Raises. But This?
description: IT turns out that the good times are even better than we thought for American chief executives.

title: There You Go! Now Drive Safe, You Hear?
description: The drive-through daiquiri stand is a Louisiana institution, a celebration of the states sense of duty in matters of amusement as well as its sense of amusement in matters of law.

title: Setting Sail on Gazas Sea of Spin
description: JERUSALEM

title: Unfinished Business: Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: It has been six months since Congress voted to allow military service by openly gay, lesbian and bisexual Americans, but the law banning their service is still in effect. The Pentagon has not certified that the military is ready for the change, and while that process needlessly drags on, soldiers continue to be discharged for acknowledging their sexuality. The full repeal of this discriminatory policy should be one of the highest priorities for the new defense secretary, Leon Panetta.

title: When a Predator Collides With a Fabricator
description: SO whats the moral of this Manhattan immorality tale?

title: Budget Needs Let Fireworks Fly Lawfully
description: The Fourth of July promises to be more explosive than ever this year in cities and counties where fireworks had been banned for decades.

title: New York and the Planes
description: HERE are a few lines written about New York in 1948, when the city was booming, cabs were hard to get and the best tables even harder:

title: Unfinished Business: The Defense of Marriage Act
description: Last month, with almost no fanfare, the federal government did a very decent thing: It canceled the deportation of a Venezuelan man after he married an American man in Connecticut and claimed legal residency as a spouse. But the government did not say that it was formally recognizing their marriage, because it cannot. The Defense of Marriage Act, which ranks with the most overtly discriminatory laws in the nations history, remains on the books, prohibiting federal recognition of legal same-sex marriages.

title: When Same-Sex Marriages End
description: IF you thought the fight over same-sex marriage has been tumultuous, just wait for the era of same-sex divorce. With New York States new law allowing same-sex marriage, not just for residents but for out-of-staters as well, a bumper crop of weddings is sure to follow  and, eventually and inevitably, a sizable number of divorces.

title: Analysis: Tsonga Lost, on His Own Terms
description: When Jo-Wilfried Tsonga fell behind by 0-40 while serving for the first set at 5-4, I remembered a story about Pancho Gonzalez. He had such confidence in his serve that he thought the odds of coming back and holding serve were still in his favor, even if faced with three straight break points. Sure enough, Tsonga played a deft half volley to save the first break point, then uncorked two monstrous first serves to get back to deuce.

title: Phone-Call Cartography
description: AMERICANS are more connected now than ever. Mobile phones allow people to maintain relationships with friends, family and colleagues across long distances.

title: Games People Play
description: THE Supreme Courts decision to strike Californias ban on selling and renting violent video games to young people raises the obvious question: what are children and teens playing on their computers and digital screens?

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me!
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

title: Unsung Heroes
description: A small gesture can mean a lot. That is the simple but compelling idea animating a drive to gain official honors for the patriots, both civilian and in uniform, who stood up against the Bush administrations immoral torture policies.

title: A Love Still Supreme, but a House in Ruins
description: There is a ranch house out in the middle of Long Island, just south of the expressway in Dix Hills, where the saxophonist John Coltrane lived, started a family and composed A Love Supreme in the spare bedroom. The album is a hymn of praise and thanksgiving by a man who found peace and God after alcohol and heroin. It is the work that helped make Coltrane a jazz immortal.

title: New Yorks Approval of Same-Sex Marriage Spurs Opponents for New Fights
description: Even as gay rights groups cheered New Yorks adoption of same-sex marriage last month, their opponents called the vote an isolated setback and started planning how to use the specter of New York to rally their troops and fill their coffers for the battles ahead.

title: William and Kate, Meet L.A.
description: LONDON

title: The Lonely Polar Bear
description: MY heart goes out to Gus, the famously neurotic polar bear in the Central Park Zoo, who used to swim endless laps around his pool. Hed dive to the bottom in a froth of bubbles, surge across and then surface like a bear obsessed. Hed backstroke to the other side, and with great paws splashing, dive down to the bottom and circle around again. Some wags called him the bipolar bear, but most zoo-goers sensed that he felt bored, pent-up, out of his element and depressed.

title: A Governors Power to Shape the Future of a Nuclear Japan
description: SAGA, Japan  In a nation plagued by weak political leadership, it has fallen to the local governor of an obscure southern prefecture to make a crucial decision that could help determine the future of nuclear power in Japan after the Fukushima Daiichi accident.

title: 20 Years On, Its Dj Vu for Slacker and Austin
description: Christopher Kelly writes a column for the Texas Report.

title: Teamwork and Training in Iraq
description: One of the American military legacies of the war in Iraq will be a well-trained and well-equipped Iraqi special operations force.

title: Taking Lead, Iraqis Hope U.S. Special Operations Commandos Stay
description: BAGHDAD  In darkness and dressed in black, the American and Iraqi Special Operations commandos navigated the dense urban neighborhood here in the capital and approached a house they believed to be a hide-out for two brothers suspected of carrying out assassinations and car-bomb attacks. As the Iraqis bashed in the door, the sound of glass shattering and screams pierced the nighttime stillness.

title: Sunday: My Treat
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Are you thirsty? Ill bet you are. Weve had two puzzles today, and as far as Im concerned, thats a full working day.

title: Crusading From Outside to Lower College Costs
description: If there was a theme to the just-concluded 82nd legislative session it was do more with less, and Representative Daniel Branch, Republican of Dallas and chairman of the House Higher Education Committee, embraced it by attacking the cost of college from multiple angles. He pushed through legislation to try to lower what students must spend on textbooks and to mandate that undergraduate students file  and stick to  degree plans.

title: Edith Fellows, a 1930s Child Star Trailed by Dickensian Woes, Dies at 88
description: Edith Fellows, a child star of the 1930s who was known for playing orphans and urchins but whose own life was more Dickensian than that of any character she portrayed, died on June 26 in Los Angeles. She was 88.

title: Perry Flexed His Muscles to Influence the Session
description: Gov. Rick Perry may or may not try to become the leader of what was once called the free world. In the meantime, he has cemented his reputation as one of the most powerful governors ever to walk the corridors of the Texas Capitol.

title: Thanks to Dewhurst, Speculation Fills the Air
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Time for Oratorical Contraception
description: ELECTIONS routinely start with candidates pledging more debates than theyll ever really consent to, committing to a positivity that sours faster than unrefrigerated milk and promising to listen as much as they talk, a congenital impossibility.

title: Complaints About Proposition 13? It Depends on Whos Not Paying
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: When Myths Get Trains Running
description: San Franciscos $1.6 billion Central Subway is finally arriving. After decades of planning, the city this week chose a construction company that will begin digging the tunnel from South of Market to Chinatown later this year. And it is all because former Mayor Willie Brown Jr., following the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake, promised a subway to Chinatown leaders who feared that their community would suffer when the city tore down the Embarcadero Freeway.

title: U.S. Women Advance to Quarterfinals
description: The United States defeated Colombia, 3-0, and Sweden topped North Korea, 1-0, to advance to the quarterfinals of the Womens World Cup in Germany. Neither team has allowed a goal through two games, but plenty will be at stake when they meet Wednesday in Wolfsburg: the group winner will most likely avoid a date with Brazil in the quarterfinals. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

title: Pedestrian Pathways
description: A clever network of pathways crisscrossing the Berkeley hills helped transform the bare brown hills into some of Berkeleys most beautiful and romantic neighborhoods. The pathways have made life easier for hill dwellers for more than 100 years.

title: Clinics Face Budget Reductions and a New Wave of Patients
description: On a recent Friday morning, more than a dozen patients crowded into a waiting room at CompreCare Health Center in San Jose. Many were Hispanic mothers with young children, there to see an obstetrician, pediatrician or family practitioner.

title: Hezbollah Rejects Charges Over 05 Killing of Hariri
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, vowed Saturday that four members of his group indicted by an international tribunal in the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister would never be arrested. He dismissed the charges as a conspiracy to sow sectarian strife here.

title: Page One
description: The movie, which we just saw. Its about the Times; and Robin and I, at least, found it fascinating. David Carr (whom Ive never met) makes the film through his sheer quirkiness, although it jumps around a lot between the big question of whether news organizations as we know them can survive and smaller stories.

title: Mets Hold Their Breath After Reyes Grabs His Hamstring
description: For weeks now, Jose Reyess name has been a fixture in sentences bursting with superlatives. The best shortstop. The fastest leadoff hitter. The most exciting player in baseball. But on a muggy Saturday afternoon, a chill went through Mets fans as Reyes was linked with a familiar and discouraging concern  a hamstring injury.

title: Expanding Hispanic Students Academic Horizons
description: Amalia Lopez transferred to Tamayo Elementary charter school last year from a neighborhood school, where she says no one talked to her about high school options. It was assumed, said Amalia, 14, that she would attend her neighborhood high school.

title: Fighting the Syrian Regime From a Chicago Office
description: Yaser Tabbara may live half a world away from Syria, where he grew up. But as the uprising there continues, the Chicago lawyer has mounted a one-man legal and diplomatic assault against the Syrian regime to highlight the brutality of its response and help depose President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Tackling Pension Crisis Is a Herculean Task
description: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Black Chicagoans Fuel Growth of South Suburbs
description: One path that so many black middle-class home buyers have followed from Chicagos South Side in recent years ends just off Lincoln Highway, past the entrance to the Newbury Estates subdivision in Matteson.

title: 16-Year-Old Gets Aggressive, and Wins U.S. Junior Title
description: Gregory Young is Americas newest junior champion, and an unlikely one.

title: Saddling Up, and Hitting the Beach
description: An entrepreneur who markets luxury goods online and on paper, and himself on the cocktail party circuit, Jason Binn is the chairman and founder of Niche Media, an array of boutique magazines including Hamptons and Gotham. He is also chief adviser to Kevin Ryan, chief executive officer of the Gilt Groupe. Mr. Binn, 43, shares homes in TriBeCa; Southampton; Aspen, Colo.; and Los Angeles with his wife, Haley, 35, and their daughters, Penny, 5, and CeCe, 3. He often spends Friday and Saturday nights socializing with haute Hamptons luminaries like Christie Brinkley,but summer Sundays are for kicking back with the kids at the beach.

title: Hotels, Horses and Handball
description: Q. An F.Y.I. item published on June 26, The Hotel Next Door, talked about fighting illegal short-term rentals through the citys Buildings Department and its Web site. Can you mention any other ways to fight these violations?

title: The Stolen Stroller: An Urban Bourgeois Problem?
description: THE call came in at 12:55 p.m.: My stroller had been stolen.

title: Park Bowlers Roll Out the Green Carpet
description: FOR the pedicab drivers who ferry tourists around Central Park, it is a favorite sight to point out: an idyllic swath of green near the parks West 69th Street entrance, the exclusive, enclosed preserve of the New York Lawn Bowling Club.

title: When Waves and Sand Evoke Summertime Lust
description: IS it possible to spend a day at the beach  especially in summer  without having ones thoughts drift, even inadvertently, toward romance? It seems unlikely with the sun, the salt air, the sand and sea, and the ample availability of unclothed skin. The following poems about the erotics of the beach were found last week in the Missed Connections section of craigslist.newyork.org. They are reprinted verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: How Tim Pawlenty Is Like RC Cola
description: Regular readers of this blog will know that Ive been of mixed minds on the electoral prospects of former Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota. Ive gone from initial skepticism about his chances to defending him as a top-tier candidate while some other analysts downgraded his status.

title: Noted Leftist Urges Chvez to Release Ailing Judge
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Even as President Hugo Chvez slowly recovers in Cuba from cancer surgery, one of his most prominent sources of intellectual inspiration, the American linguist Noam Chomsky, is asking Mr. Chvez to show compassion for another Venezuelan facing a health battle of her own.

title: In a Journey to 3,000, a Side Trip to Trenton
description: TRENTON  The account of Derek Jeters pursuit of 3,000 hits would be incomplete if it did not include a footnote about Jeters two-night detour through this city for the most talked-about minor league rehabilitation appearance in the tristate area.

title: A Joyful Driver Much Bigger Than That Last Shot
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Eugene Fuller came to Wake Chapel Church on Saturday to say goodbye to a bus driver named Lorenzo Charles, the one with the quick smile who made the hard work of driving a little less of a job for those who knew him.

title: Ruptured Pipeline Spills Oil Into Yellowstone River
description: An ExxonMobil pipeline running under the Yellowstone River in south central Montana ruptured late Friday, spilling crude oil into the river and forcing evacuations.

title: Corrections
description: ARTS & LEISURE

title: Court Hearings in Poordavoud and Anthony Cases
description: Court documents on efforts by Afshin Poordavoud and Ryan Anthony to regain the right to possess firearms after involuntary hospitalizations. Those rights were granted in perfunctory hearings. Later, Mr. Poordavoud returned to court on separate criminal charges after a violent episode involving a gun.

title: Some With Histories of Mental Illness Petition to Get Their Gun Rights Back
description: PULASKI, Va.  In May 2009, Sam French hit bottom, once again. A relative found him face down in his carport talking gibberish, according to court records. He later told medical personnel that he had been conversing with a bear in his backyard and hearing voices. His family figured he had gone off his medication for bipolar disorder, and a judge ordered him involuntarily committed  the fourth time in five years he had been hospitalized by court order.

title: Saturday at the Womens World Cup
description: Sweden once again struggled to score but secured its second straight 1-0 victory on Saturday, beating North Korea in Augsburg, Germany. Midfielder Lisa Dahlkvist scored in the 64th minute. The United States followed with a 3-0 win against Colombia in Sinsheim, sending both the Americans and the Swedes to the quarterfinals. It could have been worse for the Colombians: the Americans missed at least a half-dozen other good scoring chances, and had a 27-12 advantage in shots.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 3
description: Americas debt ceiling and the failed budget talks in Congress will again dominate the Sunday talk shows this week. Guests will debate the nations spending issues and entitlement programs before analyzing the war in Afghanistan and the transforming effects of immigration.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 2, 2011

title: Yanks Get Used to Gee and Then Get to Him
description: For the Yankees hitters, it seems, unfamiliarity breeds contempt, or at least confusion. Facing pitchers they have never seen before has long been a formula for frustration for the Yankees, although they recently have shown an ability to adapt more quickly.

title: Big Banks Easing Terms on Loans Deemed as Risks
description: As millions of Americans struggle in foreclosure with little hope of relief, big banks are going to borrowers who are not even in default and cutting their debt or easing the mortgage terms, sometimes with no questions asked.

title: Battle For Libya | July 2, 2011
description: Young Libyans posed with weapons, toy and real, in Benghazi and Tripoli.

title: Thais Back Ousted Prime Ministers Party in Landslide
description: BANGKOK  The party of the fugitive former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra won an overwhelming victory in a parliamentary election on Sunday that could turn Thai politics on its head and roll back the results of a coup that ousted Mr. Thaksin almost five years ago.

title: Man Charged in Death of His Mother on Upper East Side
description: A man stabbed and killed his mother on Saturday afternoon on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

title: U.S. Men to Play Belgium in September
description: The United States national team will play a friendly against Belgium in Brussels on Sept. 6, a rare overseas foray for Bob Bradleys team.

title: Inaugural Words: 1789 to the Present
description: A look at the history of presidential inauguration addresses.

title: Conflict in Gaza: Day 22
description: Israel bombarded dozens of Hamas targets hours before announcing a unilateral cease-fire in Gaza.

title: A Day of War in Rafah
description: Residents of the southern Gaza town of Rafah say this war feels deadlier than previous ones.

title: The Serie A Summer Rumor Mill
description: Like most of Europes biggest leagues, Italys Serie A is flush in the middle of its summer transfer window. This means the time is ripe for talks, negotiations and hearsay regarding the off-seasons biggest moves.

title: Top 10 Offensive Tackles in N.F.L.
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely - but not strictly - by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats werent acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally dont make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what youre about to read.

title: In Istanbul, Greek History on Display
description: In a rare display of cross-cultural cooperation between countries with a history of enmity, a new exhibition in Istanbul features antiquities from Greece, including marble figurines, clay tankards, weapons, cooking utensils, jewelry and ancient idols.

title: July 3, 1863
description: Update: now that I have a few minutes, what I get from Stephen Sears is that the portrayal in this movie is fairly accurate. The main gap seems to be the thing about the fence: apparently the double fence at the Emmitsburg Road was a big obstacle on the left wing of the attack (Trimble and Pettigrew), where in fact the attack stopped dead right there; on Picketts wing, the fence was much further back and wasnt a big deal.

title: Preserving Land for Northward Migration
description: A new report from a conservation group about the wildlands that surround Glacier National Park in Montana and Canada says that unprotected public lands within the Crown of the Continent ecosystem should be protected to assure that the wildest ecosystem in the country stays that way as the climate changes.

title: Djokovic Overwhelms Nadal for Wimbledon Title
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Rafael Nadal tapped on the microphone and asked, What happened? He was talking about a malfunction that made his speech inaudible to the Centre Court crowd, but he might have been referring to the defeat he had just been handed.

title: Playmaker Is the Piece Argentina Is Missing
description: LONDON  It is hard to imagine how dull soccer might be without Latin players.

title: U.S. Airlines Challenge European Emissions Rule
description: BRUSSELS  When the European Unions highest court hears arguments on Tuesday that Europe should not charge American airlines for their carbon emissions, it will be a showdown between environmental protection and cold cash.

title: Six Tips for Aquatic Photos
description: In 2007 Clark Little took up photography to save money on some seashore artwork his wife wanted. That has turned into a career as an award-winning photographer who was recently honored with the Oceans Photography Award from the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C.

title: Lawn Bowling in Central Park
description: The New York Lawn Bowling Club may look exclusive, behind the fence on their verdant green in Central Park. But they urge onlookers to try out the sport, and join.

title: Mets Exude Caution on Reyess Injury
description: Mets Manager Terry Collins did not have an update on the condition of shortstop Jose Reyes on Sunday morning, but Collins made it clear that Reyes would not return until he is back to full speed, especially with the opportunity next week for him to rest over the All-Star break.

title: Bad Tayloring
description: Noah Smith says something Id been meaning to say about John Taylors recent work. Taylor actually has a pretty good point: its far from clear that the ARRA actually led to much of a rise in government spending, while the tax cuts that made up much of the stimulus were probably largely saved.

title: Women, Uneasy, Still Lag as Cyclists in New York City
description: When Julie Hirschfeld opened a bicycle boutique for women, she envisioned fashion-obsessed customers with a disdain for spandex flooding in to buy bikes and accessories they would model along New York Citys paved catwalks: miles and miles of new bicycle paths. She lined her shop downtown with vintage-inspired bikes, many with Brooks saddle seats; partnered with Kate Spade to sell a $1,100 bicycle the color of freshly cut grass; and sold helmets that would pass more for fashionable hats.

title: Nova Is Sent to Minors to Make Room for Hughes
description: With Phil Hughes set to return from a three-month stay on the disabled list, the Yankees had six pitchers vying for five rotation spots. On Sunday, they made their decision. The odd man out is Ivan Nova, who was sent to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre in a move that paves the way for Hughes to rejoin the rotation, presumably Wednesday in Cleveland.

title: Reader Q. and A.: Restoring Gun Rights for People With a History of Mental Illness
description: In an article in The New York Times on Sunday, Michael Luo examined how states across the country were increasingly allowing people who lost their firearm rights because of mental illness to petition to have those rights restored.

title: To Keep Parking Lots Full, Retailers Offer Gas Deals
description: With gas prices locked at well above $3 a gallon, some retailers and manufacturers are trying to get more shoppers back on the road by picking up some costs at the pump.

title: Djokovic Triumphs at Wimbledon
description: Novak Djokovic dethroned Rafael Nadal at Wimbledon on Sunday with a 6-4, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3 victory in the mens final.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Lost in America'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Albert Brooks's 1985 film about dropping out and hitting the road.

title: The Undead Are Uneasy in the Untamed West
description: Along with the usual credits for lights, sets and costumes, one job title stands out in the program for Death Valley, a zombie western by the AntiMatter Collective. Stephanie Cox-Williamss work is described simply as gore. She does it very well.

title: Blue Jays Bautista Is Top All-Star Vote Getter
description: Blue Jays outfielder Jose Bautista received the most votes in fan balloting for starting spots in the All-Star Game, which is July 12 in Phoenix. Bautista will lead an American League lineup that includes four starters from the Yankees  Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez, Robinson Cano and Curtis Granderson.

title: Bright Uniforms and Brasses Perk Up a Stage
description: The final installment of the New York Philharmonics Summertime Classics series coincided with Independence Day weekend, and Bramwell Tovey, the British conductor who oversees these concerts and introduces the music with amusing commentary, was on hand to apologize (a couple of times) on behalf of his countrymen.

title: Trapped in a Room as the World Explodes
description: Virginia Woolf published A Room of Ones Own in 1929. Why, all these years later, do the portrayals of women trapped in rooms decidedly not their own keep coming? Why are so many of them written by women?

title: Palestinians Unable to Pay Full Salaries of Employees
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian Authority will pay its employees only half their monthly salaries in July, the prime minister told reporters here on Sunday, because of what he said was the failure of donors, including our Arab brothers, to fulfill their pledges.

title: Indignation, Anger and Confusion in France Over Strauss-Kahn Case
description: Days after the revelation that the case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn was on the verge of collapse, France reacted with a mix of Gallic indignation at the American justice system, fevered speculation about his political rehabilitation and visceral anger by some feminists that the former head of the International Monetary Fund was now being cast as a victim.

title: Marital Bankruptcy Filed in Faraway Places
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  The less-than-dutiful executive wife, speaking of her upwardly bound husband, observes that firing people has become sort of a prayer for him. This poetic fusing of corporate cruelty and humble religious faith gives off a small taserish shock. Its a zinger that you can imagine being wielded with bright and withering contempt by a worldly woman with a savage smile.

title: An Alchemist Reaches Out Across Centuries
description: MANCHESTER, England  Whats a rock songwriter  Damon Albarn, of Blur and Gorillaz  doing composing an opera about an Elizabethan alchemist? The best answer might be: conjuring.

title: Djokovics Dream Made Real With Wimbledon Conquest
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It was the final game of an era, and Rafael Nadal punched the strings of his racket as if it were the culprit instead of the faithful companion that had helped him win 2 Wimbledon titles and 20 straight matches here.

title: A Big Voice Full of Blues, Bawdy and Unapologetic
description: When Miche Braden plants herself at the front of the stage, shimmies a little and sings the blues, The Devils Music: The Life and Blues of Bessie Smith finds its reason for being. As Bessie, Ms. Braden has the requisite big voice  she knows when to let it soar and when to keep it at an insinuatingly low simmer  and her committed performance gives you glimmers of what the bawdy-talking, hooch-swilling (she hates the store-bought stuff), unapologetically bisexual Bessie must have been like.

title: From George Washington to Beatniks and Beyond
description: When I lived on West 12th Street, I bought a coffee-table book called Greenwich Village and How It Got That Way. It turned out to be a rich, juicy history, starring American Indians, pirates, artists, anarchists and beatniks.

title: Speed Bumps on the Road to Virtual Cash
description: MONEY is accumulated, traded and transferred online every day, but can there be a form of currency that exists only online and yet has real-world value?

title: Sudanese Seek Refuge From Bombings
description: As the July 9 division of Sudan nears, the government of Khartoum has been relentlessly pounding the Nuba Mountains from bombers for weeks, demanding that rebel fighters disarm.

title: Coast to Coast to Coast to Coast

title: Extreme-Slow-Motion Portraits at Lincoln Center
description: Alan Rickman, Patti LuPone and William H. Macy tend to move pretty quickly between jobs in Hollywood and on Broadway. But the photographer and visual artist David Michalek has managed to slow them down for the next month, using extreme-slow-motion video portraiture to project their images onto the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center Plaza. Beginning Tuesday Mr. Michalek will present Portraits in Dramatic Time, a new video installation that used ultra-high-speed, high-definition cameras to record several well-known theater and film performers in a scene. Then he slows the frames to display each emotion in larger-than-life detail as it is projected onto a screen thats 85 feet wide and 45 feet high. Like Slow Dancing  his first installation of this nature, which featured dancers performing ballet, folk dance and even voguing, krumping and break-dancing in slow motion Portraits represents Broadway, avant garde theater and Chinese opera, as well as several other theatrical genres, enhanced with costumes, production design, makeup and lighting. The installation will be on view at Lincoln Center through July 31.

title: Anniversary Planned for Phantom
description: The 25th anniversary of the London premiere of Phantom of the Opera, the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical about a masked man who haunts a young soprano in a Paris Opera house, will be celebrated with a special production at the Royal Albert Hall in London in October, Playbill.com reported. As the Phantom and Christine, Ramin Karimloo and Sierra Boggess, above, with Mr. Lloyd Webber, left, will lead a cast of 200 people in limited performances on Oct. 1 and 2. Mr. Karimloo and Ms. Boggess, who is currently starring in the Broadway revival of Terrence McNallys Master Class, originated the same roles in the Phantom sequel, Love Never Dies, in the West End of London in March 2010. The original Phantom, which opened there on Oct. 9, 1986, with staging by Hal Prince and Gillian Lynne, is still running. The anniversary show will be directed by Laurence Connor, who has served as associate director of the London production. Ms. Lynne will return to provide musical staging and choreography. Matt Kinley will design the set, with Maria Bjrnsons original design as inspiration. Though this special staging will naturally be drawn from the brilliant original, it will be both a spectacular and unique production, Cameron Mackintosh, who is producing, said in a statement.

title: Clowns and Comedy Open 59E59 Season
description: Ireland comes to Midtown Manhattan in two eccentric new shows opening 59E59 Theaters fall season. In September Cirque de Lgume, a clown duo from Dublin, will use vegetables and physical comedy to create what the company calls pure mayhem. The Inis Nua Theater Company of Philadelphia will mix commedia dellarte, Japanese Kabuki theater and mime to present Dublin by Lamplight, a story of poetry and politics at the National Theater of Ireland in 1904. In October a large church in a small town will become the center of controversy in The Bus by James Lantz, followed by Any Given Monday, an irreverent comedy about a man trying to save his marriage through terrible means, by Bruce Graham, a former writer for the television show Roseanne. Last  but certainly not the least draw for 59E59 audiences  the popular Brits Off Broadway returns to the theater for its eighth New York program. Before the season begins, Throughline Artists, a company that promotes communication between established and emerging playwrights, presents Summer Shorts 5. This festival of short plays brings new works by Alexander Dinelaris (Still Life), Christopher Durang (Miss Witherspoon) and Neil LaBute (reasons to be pretty), among several other playwrights, beginning Aug. 4 and running through Sept. 3.

title: Radiohead in China
description: The rock band Radiohead has made a move to join the world of social networking in China, The Associated Press reported. The group has been critical of the Chinese governments censorship in the past, performing at Free Tibet concerts in December and urging fans through its Web site to campaign for the release of Liu Xiaobo, who won last years Nobel Peace Prize. But the band has started a page on the weibo site of Sina.com, which has been described as the Chinese equivalent of Twitter. The group may not be able to keep up its activism through the site, since Internet content is screened by the government, but so far it has posted only one comment: testing the weibo.

title: Barnes Foundation Meets $200 Million Goal
description: Despite continued litigation to prevent the move of its paintings and artifacts, the Barnes Foundation said last week that it had passed its $200 million fund-raising goal to continue construction on its new home in Philadelphia, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. Of that money $40 million has come in the form of private donations in the past year; $150 million will go toward construction of the Philadelphia building and associated costs; and $50 million will go to the foundations endowment. Proponents of the move have claimed that the current location in Merion, Pa., has hurt attendance and membership. The collection was formerly prohibited from being moved according to a trust indenture created by the founder, Albert C. Barnes, but the indenture was overturned in 2006 by the Montgomery County Orphans Court. The Merion gallery closed on Sunday. Opponents of the move have a court hearing set for Aug. 1 to prevent it.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Strauss-Kahn to Face New Sex Complaint in France
description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn will face another complaint alleging attempted rape, this one in France, according to the lawyer for a French novelist who said in an interview published on Tuesday that she wanted a chance to be heard about her accusation.

description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Blast at Sinai Pipeline Again Halts Gas to Israel
description: CAIRO, Egypt  Unknown attackers blew up a strategic natural gas pipeline that runs through Egypts rugged Sinai Peninsula to Israel and Jordan on Monday, bringing the flow of gas to a halt for the third time this year.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces arrested dozens of people on Monday in a new offensive, their largest foray into a central Syrian city since withdrawing last month, prompting residents to build barricades to block a more ambitious assault, residents said.

description: Parents often worry when their toddlers are slow to start talking, but a long-term study has found that these children have no more emotional or behavioral problems than others by age 5  as long as they are otherwise developing normally.

description: A series of alarming Twitter posts about President Obama appeared on Fox Newss Twitter account for political news early Monday morning, and the Web site for the cable television network said it was a victim of hacking.

title: For Film Graduates, an Altered Job Picture
description: LOS ANGELES  One after another, touring groups of prospective students and their parents stopped late last month to pose for pictures around a bronze Douglas Fairbanks, who wields his sword in a courtyard fountain here at the University of Southern Californias School of Cinematic Arts.

title: Study Links Smoking Drug to Cardiovascular Problems
description: Chantix, the best-selling prescription drug for smoking cessation, was linked to an increased risk of a heart attack, stroke or other serious cardiovascular event for smokers without a history of heart disease compared with smokers who did not use the drug, according to a Canadian medical journal report released on Monday.

title: A big dig for big fossils; reflections on the space shuttle; and the stroke belt in the south.
description: A big dig for big fossils; reflections on the space shuttle; and the stroke belt in the south.

title: Thirst for Fairness May Have Helped Us Survive
description: Among the Ache hunter-gatherers in eastern Paraguay, healthy adults with no dependent offspring are expected to donate as much as 70 to 90 percent of the food they forage to the needier members of the group. And as those strapping suppliers themselves fall ill, give birth or grow old, they know they can count on the tribe to provide.

title: Senegal: Canadian Company to Help Finance Zinc Supplements for Children
description: A Canadian zinc mining company and a Canadian nonprofit devoted to getting vitamins and minerals to children in poor countries recently joined forces to create a new partnership, the Zinc Alliance for Child Health.

title: Statue of Reagan Is Unveiled in London
description: LONDON  Passers-by at the American Embassy, in the heart of Londons upscale Mayfair district, were greeted Monday morning by the disembodied voice of Ronald Reagan drifting through the air from large speakers  a prelude to the unveiling of a $1 million bronze statue of the former president here to commemorate the 100th anniversary of his birth.

description: Female rufous-collared sparrows prefer the bird next door, a new study reports.

title: Days of Strangeness at Dior
description: Things must be very strange these days at the House of Dior, judging by the haute couture show we saw Monday afternoon at the Muse Rodin. All sorts of weird vibes, along with a lack of design leadership, have a way of surfacing in clothes. A runway is like a shrinks couch; stuff just comes out.

title: The Ringside Doctor
description: Dr. Victor Khabie is a boxing fan who performs orthopedic surgery by day and moonlights as a ringside physician.

title: Businessman in Chinese Charity Scandal Resigns
description: BEIJING  A businessman on the board of a company with ties to the Red Cross Society of China has resigned after a nationwide scandal centered on his girlfriend raised questions about corruption in that and other state-run charities, according to an Internet post on Monday by a colleague of the businessman.

title: When Bell Sounds, Surgeon Answers Ringside Calling
description: One recent Friday, the orthopedic surgeon Victor Khabie performed seven operations, grabbed a sandwich and fought traffic to a ballroom in Queens to care for athletes who walked willingly into fists. They call themselves boxers. Khabie calls them patients.

title: For an American, a Victory Carries Added Meaning
description: On the Fourth of July, an American, Tyler Farrar, sprinted to victory in Stage 3 of the Tour de France, confirming the strong form of his team, Garmin-Cervelo, in the early days of the race.

title: As Shuttle Era Ends, Dreams of Space Linger
description: By April 1981 it seemed that the space shuttle Columbia had been part of the Florida landscape forever. Gleaming white in the sun by day and the floodlights that bathed it all night, the cluster of rockets, space plane and giant egglike fuel tank looked like a craggy Matterhorn transposed to the humid coast.

title: A Declaration of Endurance
description: Joplin residents who have been clearing debris from a devastating tornado for weeks want to take a break and have a proper Independence Day celebration.

title: Just One Look | Christian Dior
description: The Christian Dior haute couture show saw a studio bravely soldiering on without a designer at the helm. Yes, the production was every bit what one has come to expect from the Galliano years  a Jeremy Healy soundtrack, makeup by Tyen and Pat McGrath, hair by Orlando Pita and hats by Stephen Jones  but without his wicked wit and madcap historicisms. Was the craftsmanship there? Sure. Here, a red carpet ready ball frock in fiesta pastels.

title: When Take as Directed Poses a Challenge
description: If the label on one bottle of prescription drugs says, Take one tablet twice daily, and the label on another says, Take one tablet every 12 hours, would you realize that you could take both medications at the same time?

title: Poor Care Led to Death of Lawyer, Russia Says
description: MOSCOW  Russias Investigative Committee on Monday acknowledged for the first time that 37-year-old Sergei L. Magnitsky died in pretrial detention because prison authorities denied him medical care, setting the stage for prosecution in a case that has come to epitomize Russias trouble establishing rule of law.

title: Romney Says Obama Made the Recession Worse
description: AMHERST, N.H.  After disputing whether he had previously said President Obama made the recession worse last week former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts said on Monday that President Obama made the recession worse.

title: Greece Turns Back Canadian Ship Aiming for Gaza
description: ATHENS  Greek commandos boarded and turned back a Canadian boat bound for the Gaza Strip on Monday, in the latest setback for the all-but-stymied Gaza flotilla. The Hellenic Coast Guard stopped the boat, the Tahrir, or Liberation, about 20 minutes after it set sail from the island of Crete, organizers said, and impounded it at a military dock. Aboard were 43 activists hailing from Canada, Australia, Belgium, Denmark, Germany and Turkey, said Sandra Ruch, a coordinator for the boat.

title: Romney Has His Own Traveling Soap Box
description: ANDOVER, N.H.  Running for president is all about getting on the proverbial soap box. So when Mitt Romney comes to town, he brings one along.

title: The Then and Now of Memory
description: Researchers have long known that the brain links all kinds of new facts, related or not, when they are learned about the same time. Just as the taste of a cookie and tea can start a cascade of childhood memories, as in Proust, so a recalled bit of history homework can bring to mind a math problem  or a new dessert  from that same night.

title: Bachmann and Gingrich Share an Iowa Parade
description: CLEAR LAKE, Iowa  Michele Bachmann and Newt Gingrich celebrated Independence Day here, but it was Republicans they were searching for as they walked along Main Street on Monday in one of the states premiere holiday parades.

title: Mitt Romneys $5 Lemonade
description: AMHERST, N.H.  It wasnt that long ago that Mitt Romney dug through his wallet in search of a dollar or two, only to find a $100 bill. So his aides cringed a bit when the millionaire presidential candidate stopped at the lemonade stand here along the 4th of July parade route.

title: A Bloodbath in a Country Home, Then a Siege on a Vengeful Man
description: At a sprawling, tree-shaded country house in rural Pennsylvania, a place of serenity that most city dwellers can only dream about as a retreat from the mean streets, two weekending couples, one with a 2-year-old boy, were relaxing on Saturday night when the nightmare strode in from the darkness.

title: Just One Look | Bouchra Jarrar
description: Bouchra Jarrar is one of the few ready-to-wear designers to present a collection on the haute couture calendar. The Balenciaga-alum is beloved for the gamine simplicity of her silhouettes, the refinement of her hand (Jarrars clothes look as good inside as out), and her cool way with a slit. This collection she showed at the Odeon on Monday did not disappoint: 17 minimal looks cut from mens suiting wools, tie silks and tuxedo satins. Here, her take on a smoking with an asymmetric collar and a slinky slash down the back.

title: Mr. Romney, Say Hello to Mr. Huntsman
description: AMHERST, N.H.  There was a bit of anticipation about whether Mitt Romney and Jon Huntsman would interact at the Independence Day parade here in Amherst  at least as much anticipation as there can be for a parade route interaction. (Lets face it, its a slow holiday weekend and the political press can get hungry for drama.)

title: Real Madrid Beckons Rudy Fernandez With Offer
description: The N.B.A. lockout may be in its infancy, but the immediate future is looking grim for a league that was forced to hold a shortened 50-game season in 1999 following a 204-day lockout.

title: After Years of Chasing, Djokovic Finally Leads the Pack
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Novak Djokovic has been the hunter for years now, trying to chase down Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal. But he is No. 1 at last, and when he returned to Wimbledon as the new champion on Monday for his morning-after obligations with the news media, he was asked how it felt to be the rabbit, the one everyone else is chasing.

title: Joffrey Season Threatened
description: The opening of the Joffrey Ballets coming season could be canceled because of a contract dispute between the ballet company, based in Chicago, and the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents the dancers.

title: Summer Vegetable Sauces
description: Tomatoes arent the only vegetable that you can turn into a sauce or condiment. Onions and fennel cook down to a thick, sweet, jammy confit. Roasted peppers can be simmered until theyre soft and saucy, then tossed with pasta, piled onto bruschetta or spooned over fish or chicken.

title: For Many Millions, Psoriasis Means Misery
description: This is the best time of year for many of the 7.5 million people in the United States who suffer from a chronic skin disease called psoriasis. Although lighter clothing worn during the summer months reveals more of their troubled skin, the seasons warmth, humidity and sunshine can heal many of the lesions, at least temporarily.

title: Hes a Vessel Overflowing With Rage (And Hes the Orphan Son of Precious)
description: The Kid, the title character in Sapphires unsettling new novel, is an orphan, an aspiring dancer, an abused child and a violent offender. After being tossed out of school for sexually assaulting another student, he begins a series of peregrinations around the island of Manhattan in search of a self and a vocation.

title: Life Cycle of a Primates Bite
description: Q. Do primates like chimps and apes have baby teeth that they lose?

title: Ice Age Fossils
description: An excavation last fall near Snowmass, Colo., turned up hundreds of bones and bone pieces of mastodons, mammoths and other Ice Age animals and plants.

title: Just One Look | Giambattista Valli
description: Giambattista Vallis first collection of haute couture promised and delivered everything his following of young European monied beauties desire: dollops of feathers, pearls, embroideries, animal prints, flowers, ruffles, and bows. It all worked, even more so than Vallis ready-to-wear, because for unapologetic prettiness he is unbeatable, especially in the simplest gestures  a draped silk cocktail dress in petal pink, or this coral gown and cape, which made its real-life debut last weekend in Grace Kelly blue on her grand-daughter Charlotte at Prince Alberts wedding supper.

title: Pleistocene Treasures, at a Breakneck Pace
description: SNOWMASS, Colo.  Two different time scales collided in this place.

title: Ridgewood, N.J., 9:40 a.m.
description: Baba Ly, 8, prepared to play the president during the Independence Day parade in Ridgewood, N.J., on a float from his school, Travell Elementary. He was assisted by his mother, Aisha Ly, who made sure his tie was straight and his shirt was tucked in.

title: 30 Years of the Space Shuttle
description: An interactive timeline of the 135 space shuttle missions.

title: Researchers Link Deaths to Social Ills
description: Poverty is often cited as contributing to poor health. Now, in an unusual approach, researchers have calculated how many people poverty kills and presented their findings, along with an argument that social factors can cause death the same way that behavior like smoking cigarettes does.

title: As Germany Advances, Some Want Star to Get Out of Way
description: BERLIN  In a commercial playing before movies in German theaters, a group of scruffy men in a bar are debating the best soccer player ever. Pel, says one, Beckenbauer, another. The bartender appeals to a rough-looking biker type at the end of the bar who says, Prinz. Everyone stares, uncertain whom he means. Birgit Prinz, he says resolutely.

title: Europe Faces Tough Road on Effort to Ease Greek Debt
description: FRANKFURT  As Europe turns from its latest short-term fix for Greece to planning a longer-term bailout for the debt-plagued country, the ratings agency Standard & Poors indicated Monday how difficult it would be to offload some of the cost of rescuing Greece onto creditors without also provoking a default that could shock the global economy.

title: In Eyes, a Clock Calibrated by Wavelengths of Light
description: Just as the ear has two purposes  hearing and telling you which way is up  so does the eye. It receives the input necessary for vision, but the retina also houses a network of sensors that detect the rise and fall of daylight. With light, the body sets its internal clock to a 24-hour cycle regulating an estimated 10 percent of our genes.

title: New Study Implicates Environmental Factors in Autism
description: A new study of twins suggests that environmental factors, including conditions in the womb, may be at least as important as genes in causing autism.

title: Pushing Back the Limits of Speech and Music
description: For Brian Eno the biggest surprise in life these days isnt that, at age 63, he continues to be one of the worlds most sought-after record producers, making platinum sellers with the likes of U2 and Coldplay. Or even that he remains a prolific solo artist four decades into his career, turning out three albums in the past two years.

title: Sharp Interplay and Melting Lyricism
description: The pianist Ursula Oppens built her reputation as a new-music specialist, both as a member of the adventurous ensemble Speculum Musicae in its early days and as a soloist who has championed composers as different as Tobias Picker, Frederic Rzewski and Elliott Carter. But Ms. Oppens has never abandoned the standard repertory: anyone who has followed her work over the years may remember her thoughtful account of Rachmaninoffs Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini with the New York Philharmonic in 1977 and will have heard her clean-textured, emotionally intense readings of the Beethoven sonatas more recently.

title: A Little Bit Like a School Orchestra
description: Jaga Jazzist, the Norwegian instrumental jazz-rock band currently touring as a nine-piece, is an off-brand, something to be settled for. Frank Zappas dead; Soft Machine is long gone; Tortoise, the Chicago band from which this one derives the deepest inspiration, tours infrequently. Its got something that isnt particularly common; itll do in a pinch.

title: Numberplay: Happy Birthday, America!
description: Our blog today falls on the Fourth of July, a day for celebration and fireworks. To match the summer mood, we have some light number fare, cooked up by my friend Aziz Inan, who is an absolute whiz when it comes to finding numerical coincidences related to dates. Dr. Inan, an electrical engineering professor at the University of Portland, has appeared in this column before with coincidences related to Palindrome Day, Chopins birthday, Dr. Martin Luther King Day and Bill Gatess birthday. As usual he has a set of wonderful connections with todays date.

title: The Ring Is a Supreme Test for Opera Directors
description: Every production of an opera is a commentary on the work. But how and to what extent a director should make such commentary is the question.

description: In 1952 the physicist Ernest O. Lawrence assembled a group of young scientists to design weapons that were radically different from those being designed at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, the nations original nuclear weapons lab.

title: Roots of Disease Found to Vary by Continent
description: A new survey of the human genome shows that common diseases are likely to have a different set of genetic roots in Africans, East Asians and Europeans.

title: Stubborn Back Pain? Try Massage
description: Massage is a common alternative treatment for chronic low back pain, but most recent studies have found little evidence that it works. A group of researchers designed a study to see if they could find a difference between back pain sufferers who got massage and those who did not.

title: Alleged Zetas Cartel Leader Captured by Mexican Police
description: MEXICO CITY  The federal police captured a reputed founder and senior leader of the Zetas drug gang who may be connected to the killing of an American agent earlier this year, Mexicos security ministry said Monday.

description: Negotiations toward a labor deal that would end the N.F.L. lockout were confronted with a new hurdle Monday when the group of retired players involved in the antitrust lawsuit against the league  angered because they say their interests and representatives are being shut out by both sides in the talks  filed a separate complaint against players and owners.

title: Pay Frozen, More New York Judges Leave Bench
description: There is perhaps no more fitting finale to a long legal career than a judgeship. Ascending the bench after years appearing before it can bring power, respect, personal satisfaction, reasonable hours and, often, free parking. There are the aircrafts operating manual, safety checklists, logbooks for entering airplane performance data, navigation charts, weather information, airport diagrams and maybe a book of KenKen puzzles thrown in for good measure.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When Karl W. Eikenberrys father knew he had only a few months left to live, he told his son his greatest regret was that he would not be around to see what happened next.
