title: Otto von Hapsburg, a Would-Be Monarch, Dies at 98
description: BERLIN  Otto von Hapsburg, the onetime heir to the imperial throne of Austria-Hungary, who during a long career in European politics was a strong proponent of unifying the divided continent, died Monday at his home in Pcking, Germany. He was 98.

title: Administration Offers Health Care Cuts as Part of Budget Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials are offering to cut tens of billions of dollars from Medicare and Medicaid in negotiations to reduce the federal budget deficit, but the depth of the cuts depends on whether Republicans are willing to accept any increases in tax revenues.

title: Violence Erupts as Police Accused of Egypt Killings Get Bail
description: CAIRO  Clashes erupted at a Cairo courthouse on Monday after a judge ordered the release on bail of seven police officers on trial on charges of killing protesters in the city of Suez during the countrys 18-day uprising last winter.

title: How We Picked Our Presidents, 1960s Style
description: Few students of popular culture, amateur or professional, consider the 1960s a period when creativity flourished on American television. Westerns of the kind that did not threaten to obscure the legacy of John Ford prevailed, speaking to the pastoral fantasies of millions of Americans who had vacated decaying cities for the tempered pleasures of suburban life. The same demographic realities could be held accountable for the absurdist escapism of something like Green Acres. Between 1950 and 1960, the United States population swelled by about 28 million; two-thirds of that growth occurred in suburbia. Television had come to occupy a place in 44 million homes.

title: One Classic Ballet, Many Interpretations
description: We dance, of course, for joy. But ballet, with its built-in dichotomy of gender roles (women alone rise on point, men alone may do the partnering), has a romantic tension that can seem poignant, even tragic. The full-length Swan Lake alternates between scenes of celebration (Acts I and III) and romantic tragedy (Acts II and IV), and its classicism can express the tragic dimension in ways that are the very stuff that ballet is made of and yet are singular to this ballet. Its not just romantic and noble, its fateful and laden with doom. And the storm Tchaikovsky composed in Act IV becomes as cosmic as the one in Shakespeares King Lear.

title: Complaints Lead to Ban on Pop-Up Car Markets
description: WALNUT PARK, Calif.  They show up bright and early on Saturday mornings, parking cars and trucks along the side of Pacific Boulevard and polishing them inside and out. Once they have chalked prices onto the windshields (an old Honda Civic for $1,900) they are open for business: a pop-up used car lot on the side of the road.

title: What Does the First Amendment Protect?
description: In the two First Amendment cases handed down last week  one about limiting sales of violent video games to children, the other about Arizonas attempt to make public financing more attractive to candidates  the dissenting justices contend that the protection of speech is not really the issue at all.

title: New CDs by David Weiss and Lloyd
description: Snuck Out (Sunnyside)

title: A Murder, an Arrest and Racial Tensions
description: Give credit where its due. In inaugurating its debut season with James Baldwins rarely staged play Blues for Mister Charlie, New Haarlem Arts Theater hardly played it safe. (Its second show, a revival of the toe-tapping revue It Aint Nothin but the Blues opening later this month, is another matter.) If theater were an Olympic sport, the degree of difficulty on display would earn New Haarlem several points, although not quite enough to offset the spotty execution.

title: Bair Has Been Effective Watchdog at F.D.I.C.
description: The 2008 financial crisis revealed many of the worlds banking regulators to be woefully ineffective. Sheila C. Bairs five years at the helm of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which end on Friday, may offer a potential exception. A potted banking regulators version of the 1989 self-help book, The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People, sums up Ms. Bairs tenure.

title: Whos on the Family Tree? Now Its Complicated
description: Laura Ashmore and Jennifer Williams are sisters. After that, their relationship becomes more complex.

title: Argentina Hopes for a Big Payoff in Its Shale Oil Field Discovery
description: Just east of Argentinas Andean foothills, an oil field called the Vaca Muerta  dead cow in English  has finally come to life.

title: Forensic Analyst Sues Over New Yorker Article
description: The case of a possibly fake art treasure has led to a $2 million lawsuit. Peter Paul Biro, a forensic art expert from Montreal, filed a complaint last Wednesday against David Grann, a writer for The New Yorker, and against Advance Publications, which owns Cond Nast and The New Yorker, over a July 2010 New Yorker article that Mr. Grann wrote about the difficulties of authenticating art. In the article, Mr. Grann examined Mr. Biros methods  unearthing fingerprints on paintings and matching them to artists  and found some inconsistencies in his story. In the suit, filed in Manhattan, Mr. Biro contends that the reporting is a false and defamatory screed against him, written and published with malice and an indifference to the standards of responsible journalism, and that it has caused damage to his reputation, his business and his health. Mr. Biro also sued Dan Rattiner of Dans Papers, a Hamptons weekly newspaper, for his follow-up article. David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, told AdWeek: David Granns reporting on this story and everything else he does is painstaking in both its attention to the facts and tone. We stand with David Grann and behind the story and believe the suit has no merit.

title: African Art Endowment
description: An African bank has announced an endowment for the Tate Modern museum in London to promote African art. The bank, Guaranty Trust Bank, based in Lagos, Nigeria, will support the creation of an African art curator, an acquisition fund for African art, and an exchange project between Africa and London for collectors, institutions and young artists. The sum of the endowment was not announced. This is the beginning of being able to give African art the focus it deserves with audiences around the world, Chris Dercon, the director of the Tate, said in a statement.

title: A Glee Regular Hangs Up His Guitar
description: Even singing football heroes cant linger in high school forever. Chord Overstreet, who plays the guitar-strumming Sam Evans, will not be returning to Glee as a series regular, according to TV Line. The shows creator, Ryan Murphy, has made some casting changes for the coming fall season; he has also promoted Darren Criss, who plays Blaine, an openly gay student, and Harry Shum Jr., as the dancer Mike Chang, to series regulars from guest stars. On Friday Mr. Overstreet, finishing up a Glee stage tour, seemed to make reference to the news on his Twitter feed: well its been a good yr, he wrote, too bad its over, time for summer and starting fresh. He also posted about preparing to record an album. But Gleeks need not despair; Mr. Overstreet may still appear on Glee as a guest star, according to people close to the production, and he is expected to be seen in Glee Live! 3D!, a movie about the tour, to open in August. Three seasons in, Mr. Murphy doesnt intend his characters to be in perpetual high school, he recently told Ryan Seacrest in a radio interview. The show to me is about the way you express yourself as you start to move out into the world as a fresh young person, Mr. Murphy later told TV Line. Do we really want to have an eight-year senior? The only way somebody could stay on the show is if they flunk, and that is always a possibility. I think Brittany is pulling straight Fs.

title: The Collision Over Traffic Cameras
description: LETS stipulate this upfront: Everybody hates motorists who run red lights or who speed recklessly.

title: A Gillibrand Campaign: More Women in Politics

title: Markets Post an Upturn in Europe
description: Stocks rose in Europe, and Greek two-year notes advanced for a fifth day on Monday after officials approved an aid payment to Greece to prevent a default.

title: In a Switch, Craftsman Pitches Its Tools to the Unhandy
description: CRAFTSMAN, the 84-year-old tool brand from Sears, has historically pitched its products to serious do-it-yourselfers, the types who would never consider hiring someone else to build them a deck or change their brake pads.

title: An Agency Builder, but Not Yet Its Leader
description: WASHINGTON  It is conventional wisdom in this town that the first director of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will be anyone but Elizabeth Warren.

title: Fiscal Puzzle: Balancing Wilmingtons Budget
description: The city manager of Wilmington, N.C., proposed a 2012 budget that left a gap of about $7 million between anticipated revenue and spending. To balance the budget, the city must make some difficult choices. Today, youre in charge. Review the options below and close the gap, keeping in mind that spending less now might mean spending more later, and that your decisions will affect your political popularity.

title: Greece: Flotilla Boat Is Impounded
description: Greek commandos boarded and turned back a Canadian boat bound for the Gaza Strip on Monday, in the latest setback for the all-but-stymied Gaza flotilla. The Hellenic Coast Guard stopped the boat about 20 minutes after it set sail from the island of Crete, organizers said, and impounded it at a military dock. Aboard were 43 activists from Canada, Australia, Belgium, Denmark, Germany and Turkey, said Sandra Ruch, a coordinator for the boat. The flotilla had planned to try to breach Israels naval blockade of Gaza. Greek authorities turned back an American boat on Friday that had set sail from a port near Athens. The government had prohibited all vessels from departing Greek ports for the maritime area of Gaza in order to ensure the safety of passengers.

title: Vatican: Ordination of Bishop by China is Condemned
description: The Vatican on Monday condemned the most recent ordination of a bishop in China without papal consent, saying that Pope Benedict XVI was deeply saddened by the illegitimate election that damages the unity of the church. The Vatican said that Paul Lei Shiyin, ordained last week by Chinas state-controlled Catholic Church as the bishop of Leshan, was not recognized as a bishop in the Roman Catholic Church and risked automatic excommunication. Chinas church ordained another bishop in November, a point of deep contention between Rome and Beijing.

title: Pakistan: Victims Brother Testifies in Case of Killing Caught on Video

The video, broadcast on national television, showed paramilitary troops stopping Sarfaraz Shah, 19; accusing him of involvement in a robbery; and fatally shooting him as he begged for mercy. Sarfarazs only crime was that he was strolling in a public park because there was no electricity in our house, his brother, Salik Shah, said after the hearing. The Sindh Rangers paramilitary forces have a license to kill in this city, he said. The brutality has to stop.

title: Tibet: Editor Sentenced to Prison
description: A Tibetan writer and magazine editor, Tashi Rabten, has been sentenced to four years in prison for what Chinese authorities call separatist activities in a Tibetan region of western China, according to a report by the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group based outside of China. Tashi Rabten was the editor of Eastern Snow Mountain, a banned literary magazine. He had been held since April 2010 in detention in an unknown location. He was among a group of young Tibetans at Northwest Nationalities University in Lanzhou, the capital of Gansu Province, who had written about a widespread Tibetan uprising in 2008. Three other Tibetans who worked with Tashi Rabten on the magazine received prison sentences of three to four years in December 2010. EDWARD WONG

title: Winning? Comedy Central Plans Roast of Charlie Sheen

description: Members of Albert Fritschs family descended on Grand Central Terminal on Friday to visit a family heirloom (and 45-pound tchotchke) that is now the three-dimensional centerpiece of the exhibition The Once and Future Pennsylvania Station.

title: Rivera Sits and Panic Ensues
description: Even if you are not a Yankees fan  and thankfully not everyone gravitates to the best team money can attempt to buy. How boring would that be?  you might have to admit they do have the ability to be entertaining no matter where you fall on the love-hate scale. Because there is nothing like a little outbreak of meaningless Yankee panic in early July to make you pour yourself a glass of lemonade, sit back and enjoy. Its kind of like fireworks, only louder.

title: Woods to Skip British Open
description: Tiger Woods announced Tuesday on his Web site that he would not play in the British Open next week at Royal St. Georges in Sandwich, England.

title: In Europe, a Move to Slash Phone Roaming Charges
description: For many tourists, its an experience they will long remember. After taking in the Eiffel Tower in Paris, the Coliseum in Rome or Buckingham Palace in London, they arrive home to something unexpected: a staggering cellphone roaming bill.

title: Pushing Boundaries, Mixed-Race Artists Gain Notice
description: For years Heidi W. Durrow heard the refrain: editors wouldnt publish her novel because readers couldnt relate to a protagonist who was part black and part Danish. But when that novel, The Girl Who Fell From the Sky, was finally published last year (after about four dozen rejections, said Ms. Durrow, who is, of course, black and Danish), the coming-of-age story landed on best-seller lists.

title: Illness Knocks Brian Bedford Out of The Misanthrope
description: Visitors to the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Canada who were hoping to catch Brian Bedford playing Oronte in The Misanthrope this summer will be disappointed. The actor, who has performed at the festival since the mid-1970s, has dropped out because of unspecified medical reasons, according a spokeswoman for the festival.

title: Punk Priestess Still Reigns
description: Scanning the track list atPitchfork, in anticipation of Patti Smiths best-of collection, Outside Society, I was reminded of how much I loved her National Book Award-winning memoir, Just Kids. It describes her early years in working-class Philadelphia, life with Robert Mapplethorpe at the Chelsea Hotel, dating Sam Shepard, Maxs Kansas City, becoming a wife and mother in Detroit. Its not just that shes incredibly cool, effortlessly glamorous in her own raw-edged way, but that she writes so beautifully and incredibly movingly about her love for Robert, both when it was sexual and after it had, for the most part, ceased to be:

title: Step Into | Aloha Rag for Converse
description: The timeless Jack Purcell sneaker gets another update, this time in the hands of the ber-cool retailer Aloha Rag. Launching today as part of Aloha Rags 20th anniversary, the Aloha Rag for Converse Jack Purcell Zip shoe remains true to Converses classic look but is given a bit of edginess. Featuring a calf-leather interior, embroidered skull-and-hearts logo, and zip tongue, the sneaker exudes the owner Tatsugo Yodas aesthetic, which combines punk style with nods to luxury. Only 150 pairs will be made available at Aloha Rag stores in New York and Honolulu and on its Web site.

title: Best Friend and Ex-Teammate to Confront Clemens at Trial
description: One crucial notion setting Roger Clemenss case apart from other drug scandals involving baseball stars is that his former close friend and loyal teammate Andy Pettitte, a man Clemens considered his little brother, could be the most damaging witness against him.

title: The Charges Against Roger Clemens
description: What Roger Clemens is facing at his federal criminal trial, which begins Wednesday in Washington.

title: Credit Cards Without Foreign Transaction Fees
description: If youre planning a trip outside of the United States this summer, you might want to think hard about what credit card you bring along. The list of cards that have eliminated foreign transaction fees, which tack up to 3 percent onto your purchases, is growing, and using the right card can save you money on your vacation.

title: Energy Transfer Says It Is More Aggressive in Pursuit of Southern Union
description: For years, Energy Transfer Equity refused to issue new stock, so firmly convinced in that plan that it even walked away from potential deals in the past.

title: Elizabeth Holtzman Thinks Shes Ideal for Weiners Seat
description: When it comes to New Yorks suddenly vacant Ninth Congressional seat, Elizabeth Holtzman is not exactly playing it coy.

title: French Boat Leaves Greek Waters, but Gaza May Prove Too Far
description: Defying a government order, a small French boat quietly left Greek waters early Tuesday and set course for the Gaza Strip, coordinators announced later in the day, when the craft had reached international waters. It was the first vessel to successfully depart Greek territorial waters aiming to be part of an international flotilla challenging Israels naval blockade.

title: Q&A: Checking iTunes Account Purchases
description: Q.

title: Impromptu for Piano and Taxi Horn
description: Talk about Sounds of the City. On Friday night I had one of those only-in-New-York experiences, a mix of musical gratification and urban racket.

title: A Grand Rapids State of Mind
description: As a former resident of Kalamazoo, Mich., I can only say: Doggone it, Grand Rapids. Youve out-Midwesterned us again. How can you be so goofy and sweet at the same time?

title: Suzukis Kei Cars, Running Mild in New Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  I dont know if its possible for a Honda Element to mate with a toaster, but for the sake of argument, lets just say that it can. The resulting offspring may have been on display at the Meadowlands here over the weekend.

title: Winning? Comedy Central Plans Roast of Charlie Sheen
description: Dave Itzkoff reports on Arts Beat that Charlie Sheen has found a way to get back onto television on Monday night  at least one Monday night.

title: At Duane Reades Newest Outpost, Sushi and Hairstyling
description: Despite the beleaguered stock market, Duane Reade is turning to Wall Street to make a profit.

title: Growing Together
description: When Frank and Carrie Light and their eight children arrived in Steamboat Springs, Colo., around 1900, it was just a wide spot of a few hundred people. Then the towns story and the familys became intertwined.

title: Now Screening | Armani Couture
description: Our runway video of the haute couture collection from Giorgio Armani.

title: Sting Cancels Concert in Kazakhstan After Crackdown on Strikers
description: Sting has thrown his support behind striking oil workers in Kazakhstan, abruptly canceling his concert that was scheduled for July 4 in the capital, Astana, after he learned of a government crackdown on the strikers.

title: Hawk Cam | Bobby Returns, Briefly
The Onion Expands Internationally, if Canada Counts
description: Canadians hoping to get their hands on news parody will soon need to look no further than Toronto. The Toronto Star, Canadas largest newspaper, has teamed up with the Onion to distribute the satirical publication and its sister publication, the A.V. Club, beginning in the fall. With the agreement, Toronto will become the 14th city  and the first outside the United States  where the Onion is distributed.

title: Photo Replay: July 5
description: A view of the day in sports, in the shadows, on the soccer fields and on the roads of France.

title: Now Screening | Armani Couture
description: Our runway video of the haute couture collection from Giorgio Armani.

title: New Toyota Ad
description: A new Toyota ad campaign for the RAV4 sports utility vehicle is aimed at attracting the African-American consumer.

title: Blood Relations: Mystery Writers Collaborate for Charity
description: If you ever tried round-robin story telling, in which one person begins a tale and other participants contribute to the drama, you will appreciate No Rest for the Dead, a new mystery written by 26 professional novelists including Alexander McCall Smith, Jeffery Deaver, Faye Kellerman, R. L. Stine, Kathy Reichs and Sandra Brown.

title: Toyota Turns to a Bulldog to Talk Up the RAV4
description: Toyota will introduce a new ad campaign next week, promoting its RAV4 compact sport utility vehicle to the African-American market.

title: The Mitchell Report: Name by Name
description: Players identified in Major League Baseball's report on performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Roundup: Michigan Admissions, Student Loans and Prospects for Film Graduates
description: Summer is typically a slow season on the admissions news (and news-you-can-use) front. But several articles over the holiday weekend caught our eye, and we wanted to bring them to the attention of those readers  especially future applicants and their families  who may have missed them.

title: Bahamas Bans Shark Fishing
description: The Bahamas on Tuesday joined the growing global movement to protect sharks, betting that the endangered animals are worth more to visiting divers than they are to fishers.

title: An Exhibition From Vaticans Secret Archives
description: ROME  The Vatican will unveil 100 documents from its Secret Archives, including unpublished papers from the World War II era, in an exhibition in Rome next year, it announced on Tuesday. The exhibition, to be held at the Capitoline Museums from February to September, marks the first time that the papers from the Popes private archives have been allowed to leave the Vatican.

title: Same-Sex Spouses in New York Will Get Health Insurance
description: Getting health insurance should become easier for gay couples who decide to marry and live in New York, which recently became the sixth state to legalize same-sex marriage.

title: Restive City of Hama Tests Will of Syrian Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Fired up with zeal, activists say they have set up dozens of checkpoints in the Syrian city of Hama, alerting neighborhood groups with cries of God is great to the approach of feared security forces and throwing up barricades of burning tires and trash bins to block their path.

title: Casey Anthony Not Guilty in Slaying of Daughter
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Casey Anthony, the young mother whose seeming heartlessness at the disappearance of her daughter transfixed America for three years, was found not guilty on Tuesday of killing the girl, Caylee Marie.

title: 7 Fingers Acrobats to Return to New York
description: Its turning out to be quite a summer for French-Canadian, hoop-diving, animal-free circus ensembles in New York City.

title: At the Really Old Ballgame
description: Three strikes and youre dead?

title: Armani Priv: Foreign States
description: Giorgio Armani called his fall haute couture collection an homage to Japan. The designer who helped liberate women from boring executive wear and floppy bow ties confined his homage to traditional Japanese costumes and feminine floral patterns. There was no Goth Lolita moment or anything you might associate with Tokyo street fashion of the last 20 years. He stuck to a silhouette seemingly drawn from the kimono and obi (translated as stiff black patent leather bodices), and one or two models were slowed to a mincing gait. The prints and embroideries were lavish, but as Armani collections go, it was an island unto itself.

title: Just One Look | Giorgio Armani
description: With kimonos and geishas for inspiration, Giorgio Armani presented a beautiful collection for Priv today, one of his finest since launching the haute couture line 6 years ago. Black velvet trouser suits lined and outlined in Japanese floral silks were a perfect mash up of his/hers and east/west, and yet linear, untricksy, and exquisite. The evening dresses were columnar, often obid, and with a hint of pliss or a jacquard petticoat dusting the floor. Here, a big night stunner with sequined bodice, velvet skirt (cut narrow as trousers) and hints of vivid floral silk.

title: Huckabees Daughter to Join Pawlenty Campaign
description: Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the daughter and top political adviser to Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, has joined Tim Pawlentys presidential campaign as a senior adviser, the campaign announced Tuesday.

title: Strauss-Kahn Accuser Files Libel Suit Against N.Y. Post
description: The hotel housekeeper in the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case filed a libel suit against The New York Post on Tuesday over a series of articles it published during the Fourth of July weekend claiming that she was a prostitute.

title: More Law Firms Raid Competitors to Poach Rainmakers
description: The job of unwinding Bernard L. Madoffs huge fraud and recovering money for its victims has been lucrative, reaping hundreds of millions of dollars in legal fees. Late last year, a New Jersey law firm tried to poach the legal team handling that assignment.

title: As Budgets Are Trimmed, Time in Class Is Shortened
description: After several years of state and local budget cuts, thousands of school districts across the nation are gutting summer-school programs, cramming classes into four-day weeks or lopping days off the school year, even though virtually everyone involved in education agrees that American students need more instruction time.

title: Cy Twombly, Idiosyncratic Painter, Dies at 83
description: Cy Twombly, whose spare childlike scribbles and poetic engagement with antiquity left him stubbornly out of step with the movements of postwar American art even as he became one of the eras most important painters, died in Rome Tuesday. He was 83.

title: July 5, 1975 | Arthur Ashe Becomes First Black Man to Win Wimbledon
description: On July 5, 1975, Arthur Ashe became the first black man to win Wimbledon, defeating Jimmy Connors in a shocking upset.

title: Talking About the It Gets Better Project
description: Last fall, the advice columnist Dan Savage and his partner, Terry Miller, decided to post a video to give hope to bullied gay teenagers. Their message was that they also had been bullied as kids, but their adult lives were so much better, and included love, friendship, career achievement, marriage and parenthood.

title: The Dutch
description: SO here is where you want to be right now, all of you who care about good food and the theater of eating it: sitting in a booth in the back of the Dutch, alternating bites of red shrimp and fried green tomatoes with hits of dry Vouvray.

title: Reviewing the Dutch
In Silicon Valley, a Culture Clash Sullies a Romance
description: Private equity has broken venture capitals heart, and V.C. is not taking it well.

title: The Imprisoned Hikers Moms
description: This month marks two years of worry for the parents of Josh Fattal and Shane Bauer, who, along with Shanes fiance, Sarah Shourd, were imprisoned by the Iranian government in July 2009, accused of crossing the border illegally. Writing about them wont end their families worry. But its all I can do to show another parent that I cant pretend to imagine their pain. (For more on their story, read Nick Kristofs blog posts over the years, here, and here.

title: Mix of Old and New in Bids for 2018 Winter Games
description: The host city for the 2018 Games will be chosen Wednesday by the International Olympic Committee among candidates from South Korea, Germany and France.

title: Celebrate Summer: Ideas for Teaching the Season
description: The Learning Network is taking it slow this month, and we hope you are too  though of course we cant help but encourage a bit of learning as you go.

title: Earth Angels
description: The Givenchy couture collection on Tuesday consisted of just 10 outfits, all in white or off-white, with minimal touches of gold, and each far from the everyday, as you expect of couture. The mostly long dresses or delicate tops and boleros were made in fragile tulle and lace embroidered with clusters of tiny knots, caviar beads and feathers. Some styles were bareback. Evening bags covered in superlong silk fringe and mounted on hidden stands made at least a few Americans say: Oh, sweet. Its Cousin Itt.

title: Masters Dream Threesome: Player, Palmer and Nicklaus
description: The Big Three will be reunited at the 2012 Masters, Augusta National Golf Club announced Tuesday. Gary Player will make his debut as an honorary starter next year at Augusta, joining Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus on the first tee to fire the opening shots in the popular Thursday ceremony that is the official opening of the tournament.

title: Rise of World Trade Center Spurs a Retail Revival
description: As 1 World Trade Center starts to claim a place on the Lower Manhattan skyline, the areas retail scene is beginning to revive, with landlords raising rents in anticipation of thousands of new office workers, tourists and residents, commercial real estate experts said.

title: One Last Weiner
description: Im as over Anthony Weiner as any of the rest of you, but as I was catching up on The Nation this weekend, I saw JoAnn Wypijewskis byline on an article about him and felt compelled to read it. JoAnn is one of my favorite journalists. She wrote a nice story for this magazine in 2004 about the disenchantment of black voters with the Democratic Party, but the one that I am most indebted to her for is the riveting account of Nushawn Williams, a young man who infected at least 13 women with H.I.V., which she wrote for Harpers Magazine in 1998. (Not available free online, sorry. Worth buying a subscription to the magazine, trust me.). This is one of the finest magazine stories Ive ever read, in part because it so beautifully and sensitively evokes the desperate straits of Jamestown, N.Y., my fathers hometown. Even without that personal connection, youll find it a deeply satisfying reading experience.

title: Independent Group Bolsters Romneys Fund-Raising Totals
description: When Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, releases his campaign fund-raising filings this month, he is expected to report somewhere south of $20 million in contributions for the second quarter of the year  more than any of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, but somewhat less than might be expected for the candidate who has built the most robust fund-raising operation in the G.O.P. field.

title: Looking at Ken Lay and the Lack of Financial Crisis Cases
description: Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron, died of a heart attack five years ago today. The stunning news came a month after a Houston jury convicted him of securities fraud and three months before his scheduled sentencing.

title: Pitchfork Plans a Festival in Paris
description: The folks who run the Pitchfork Music Festival  the influential three-day summer showcase of indie music in Chicago  have announced plans to stage a fall festival in Paris, headlined by the folk-rock group Bon Iver. The European festival is the latest milestone in Pitchforks remarkable rise as a force in the world of indie rock. Not only has this summer festival, now in its sixth year, become a must-go event for people interested in indie music, but the Web site of the same name has become one of the most prominent brands in online music journalism, widely seen as having the influence to pluck bands from obscurity and jump-start their careers.

title: New Evidence on Shaken Baby Syndrome
description: When I wrote about shaken baby syndrome last winter for the magazine, a Canadian pathologist named Evan Matshes was working on intriguing new research that hadnt yet been published. Matshess paper is just out, in Academic Forensic Pathology, the journal of the National Association of Medical Examiners. It opens a new avenue of inquiry for this difficult and fraught diagnosis.

title: Neelys Barbecue Coming to New York
description: Pat Neely, along with his brothers, opened his first barbecue restaurant in Memphis in 1988. Their chainlet in Tennessee has expanded since then, involving Pats wife, Gina. The couple became Food Network stars three years ago, so now they are poised to make a grand entrance in New York.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kenya, India, South Sudan and Afghanistan.

title: With Help From Others, Newark Is Building for Business
description: NEWARK  Last month, a few dozen people donned hairnets and crowded around a huge oven here to sample a 25-foot matzo, which was billed as the largest ever baked. The event celebrated the completion of the new headquarters of the kosher food giant Manischewitz in this citys industrial East Ward.

title: Pettitte Affidavits
description: Sworn affidavits by the former pitcher Andy Pettitte and his wife, Laura, regarding conversations between Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens about Clemenss alleged use of Human Growth Hormone.

title: As It Campaigns to Build in the City, Wal-Mart Donates $4 Million
description: He called Wal-Mart one of the great corporate citizens in this country. He praised its efforts to conduct background checks before selling guns. He flatly rebuffed suggestions that the company was killing jobs.

title: Fennel Marmalade
description: I cant think of a better accompaniment for this Provenal-inspired condiment than a piece of grilled fish. For a simpler meal, try this marmalade atop a bowl of brown rice or a bruschetta.

title: End-of-Life Care: A Portrait
description: Coming soon to a public television station near you: Consider the Conversation: A Documentary on a Taboo Subject.

title: Reid Shifts Senate Attention From Libya to Debt Limit
description: With Republicans protesting that the Senate should be concentrating on the debt limit standoff this week, Senator Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat and majority leader, on Tuesday conceded the point and abruptly called off a planned debate on Libya.

title: When a Smartphone Is Too Much for Travel
description: With the rise of the iPhone and the Blackberry, its hard to imagine hitting the road without a phone that cant download music, serve up maps or send and receive e-mail. But sometimes a body just needs to make a few calls from the road. Sometimes a body needs a featureless phone.

title: Where Opera Is Stretched Yet Unbroken
description: LONDON  In my life, why do I give valuable time to people who dont care if I live or die? Thats the refrain of Heaven Knows Im Miserable Now, the 1984 Smiths song.

title: For French Tourists, Strauss-Kahn Town House Is Must-See
description: Louis Lelias, 30, skipped up to the door of 153 Franklin Street on Monday afternoon. He smiled broadly and stuck out his fist, extending his pinky and thumb to make a jovial hang loose hand gesture, as his wife snapped a picture.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kenya, India, South Sudan and Afghanistan.

title: Cold Boiled Chicken  la Chinois
description: Time: 1 hour 20 minutes, plus several hours refrigeration

title: Chicken, Simmered and Chilled
description: TRUE confession: I love cold chicken. Cold roast chicken, cold fried chicken, a meaty cold chicken carcass for finger-licking nibbling. And during the long days of summer, I crave cold boiled chicken, brightened with hot pepper, sesame oil and scallions.

title: Chicken for Summer: Cool, Easy and Exciting
description: If the dog days have got you down, cold chicken might be the answer. This Chinese-inspired dish is served straight from the fridge, and only minimal cooking is required. Simmered gently with ginger and star anise, showered with scallions, hot pepper, and sesame whats not to like? What are some of your recipes for cold meals in hot weather?

title: A Fourth, for Many Fourths to Come
description: The subjects on Monday were timeless. There was a backyard barbecue, the National Mall, a neighborhood parade, the Liberty Bell, a swimming pool. And fireworks, of course.

title: Energy Transfer Raises Southern Union Bid to $5.1 Billion
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated

title: That Perfect Florida Tomato, Cultivated for Bland Uniformity
description: Jonathan Lethem has seen the future of agribusiness, and that future is strange. In his novel Girl in Landscape (1998), he imagined humans inhabiting a new planet where meals grow inside potatoes that can be planted and harvested. Among the flavors: meat, cake and tea. Fish, one character announces, as if he were Ferran Adri, is the weirdest one.

title: Zynga Stands Out Among Tech I.P.O.s
description: Technology firms have gone to market this year by the bushel with little earnings in tow. Zynga arrives with income aplenty from online games like FarmVille. And Zyngas profitability is even more bountiful than it first appears.

title: A Rural Homecoming Stirs Trouble
description: Make sure you dont set anyones loins on fire, a Tennessee plumber (Mark Darby Robinson) instructs his significantly younger and poutier female companion (Rachel Korine) midway through Septien. Given the films preponderance of flabby men in saggy underwear  not to mention alarming sexual imagery  viewers with weak stomachs can only hope she complies.

title: In Cuba, the Voice of a Blog Generation
description: Like any other first-time author, Yoani Snchez was looking forward to receiving copies of her book, Cuba Libre, after it was published last year. But when the package sent from Buenos Aires by her publisher arrived in Havana, the Cuban customs service impounded the parcel and, after she complained, sent her a notice explaining its action.

title: Our Opening in Arles
description: As members of the photography world make their annual pilgrimage to Les Recontres dArles in France this week, we are proud to say that The New York Times Magazine Photographs exhibition is one of the years big draws. Our photo director, Kathy Ryan, co-curated the show with Lesley A. Martin, the publisher of Aperture Books.

title: Obama Seeks to Reopen Budget Talks
description: President Obama on Tuesday invited Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders to meet with him in the White House on Thursday, saying that greater progress is in sight on a deal to raise the nations debt limit and reduce the deficit.

title: For Jaguar Drivers, a Letter Brings Its Privileges
description: When I think back to driving school, I cannot stave off the memory of fighting sleep at a cramped desk while being lectured about illegal U-turns and the perils of driving at speed. But at the Jaguar R Performance Academy, which I attended late last month at Monticello Motor Club northwest of New York City, I was wide awake to the instructors message about respecting speed as well as, more thrillingly, how to handle it.

title: The Humbling of a Powerful Frenchman
description: Worlds collide in Rapt, a solid yet fleet French thriller about a society kidnapping and its shockwaves. You see one world in the gangbuster opening that, with a racing camera, follows a sleek, unidentified man as he hurtles through a day in a matter of moments, rushing out of his home, whooshing into an office, bolting from a meeting and all but flinging himself into the arms of one woman before embracing another. This frenetic activity soon jolts to a halt, though, when his chauffeured car is jacked and hes snatched by armed kidnappers who turn him into a victim even as the outside world transforms him into the accused.

title: Chinese Gem That Elevates Its Setting
description: GUANGZHOU, China  It says something about the state of architecture today that the most alluring opera house built anywhere in the world in decades is in a generic new business district at the outer edge of this city, has no resident company and a second-rate program.

title: Drink Up | New Cocktails in Nawlins
description: I came here with AmeriCorps after the storm and never really left. Thats the story of T. Cole Newton, a post-Katrina NewOrleanstransplant and the owner of 12 Mile Limit, a new bar in the Mid-City neighborhood that doubles as Newtons own private cocktail laboratory. This place has been a bar for 90 years, he says, and after the storm it was under two feet of water. The people who used to own the place, he added, threw a lot of wild parties here. Cocktails are the specialty now, immensely creative drinks that celebrate the bartending history ofNewOrleanswhile embracing anewinflux of ideas and characters. Everyone becomes aNewOrleanian, if you give them long enough, Newton says. Miss your flight, youll be here five years.

title: A Buildings Fluid Forms
description: A look at the Guangzhou Opera House, designed by Zaha Hadid.

title: TimesCast | July 5, 2011
description: American intelligence reports say Pakistans spy agency ordered a journalist's death; Casey Anthonys trial was to Twitter as O.J. Simpsons was to cable news; and a British tabloids phone hacking.

title: Fireworks Lift NBC
description: NBC topped the ratings on Monday, a night of mostly repeats and holiday programming, as the annual Macys Fourth of July Fireworks Spectacular attracted its most viewers in 11 years. According to Nielsens estimates 8.6 million people tuned in to the NBC broadcast at 9 p.m., more than for any other program on the night and up from 6.9 million viewers a year ago. CBS ranked second for the night, leading the 10 p.m. hour with its own Fourth of July special, Boston Pops Fireworks Spectacular, which drew 6.6 million viewers, outperforming a repeat of NBCs special in the hour (5.3 million) and a repeat of ABCs Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition (3 million). ABC, in third place, averaged 3.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a rerun of The Bachelorette while Fox was fourth with repeats of MasterChef (2.3 million) and House (1.5 million).

title: Verizon to Drop Its Unlimited Mobile-Data Plan
description: On July 7, Verizon will become the third major mobile phone carrier to ditch its unlimited-data plan and go to tiered pricing, following AT&T and T-Mobile.

title: Time Out to Enjoy All Things Phish
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y.  When your friend volunteers to work at a music festival in exchange for a ticket and ends up with the title of Good Vibe Regulator at a custom-built all-night disco bar modeled after a giant pinball machine, you know youve ended up someplace pretty cool. Last weekend that meant Super Ball IX, the ninth festival by Phish, the eclectically funky rock quartet.

title: Team Players | Bergdorf Goodman and Pomellato
description: These days, high-low collaborations are almost second nature: Versace for H & M, Missoni for Target, Karl Lagerfeld for Macys. (Who doesnt love the chance to purchase some Karl for a fraction of the price?) But two posh partners can produce a pretty sensational must-have, too: See Pomellatos 12-piece exclusive collection for Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Bike-Friendly? Check the Citys Mass Transit System
description: Two things about my colleague Christine Haughneys article on the reluctance of New York-area women to become bicycle commuters were striking. One was the main reason cited: fear. (Excessive sweating followed.) The second was an accompanying  graphic with data from the Census Bureaus American Community Survey indicating which cities have the most bike commuters and from an Australian study looking at gender differences in bike commuting.

title: Smorgasburg
description: A new open-air food court and weekly market, Smorgasburg is a brand extension of the Brooklyn Flea, at East River Waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Q&A: Making the Most of an Evening in Milan
description: A friend and I will be spending a week in Venice in November. We will be flying home to New York City from Milan, and will have just one afternoon and evening there. Do you have any recommendations as to how to spend that short amount of time in Milan? What not to miss and where to have dinner?

title: Brooklyn Market: Woodstock of Eating
description: SMORGASBURG, the open-air market held every Saturday in an empty lot on the Williamsburg waterfront, is like a summer rock festival for food: exciting, overwhelming, sweaty, hot. Youll hit your limit, and then youll want more.

title: Executive Pleads Guilty to Leaking Apple Secrets
description: A technology executive charged with leaking sensitive information about Apple products to hedge fund traders pleaded guilty on Tuesday in Manhattan, the latest guilty plea in the governments crackdown on insider trading facilitated by so-called expert networks.

title: Smorgasburg, How to Eat Through Saturday
description: Every Saturday, an empty lot on Williamsburgs East River waterfront is transformed into Smorgasburg (a mash-up of smorgasbord and Williamsburg), an open-air food festival with more than 90 stands, over 50 of which sell stuff thats ready to eat: chilled soups, grilled meats, Vietnamese salads, fresh juices, cold-brew coffee, ice cream in clever flavors, sesame noodles with a pedigree. In this weeks $25 and Under column, I call Smorgasburg a fitting playground for a food-crazy generation that photographs what it eats.

title: Phish Fest at Watkins Glen
description: The eclectic funk rock quartet performed their ninth festival last week, called Super Ball IX.

title: How to Be a Jerk
description: The owners of the Brooklyn Farmacy soda fountain in Cobble Hill demonstrate how to make a classic egg cream.

title: A Star Sits, but a Nation Moves On
description: POTSDAM, Germany  The raging debate here over the star forward Birgit Prinz appeared all but settled Tuesday night.

title: Just One Look | Chanel
description: Superbly romantic and resolutely urban, Karl Lagerfelds collection for Chanel haute couture was a celebration of nightfall and all its aesthetic offshoots: the shimmer of streetlights on cobblestones; the deep blues and purples that bow to black; the silent army of shadows. To make this clear he built a neon-lit model of the Place Vendome in the Grand Palais with Coco herself atop the obelisk. The clothes were sensational and womanly: jutting peplums, ankle grazing dresses and coats, gloves and boots to elongate every silhouette. Here, on Stella Tennant, a draped and tucked dress in black silk taffeta with a spine of crystal buttons.

You can use it to cook morsels of poultry, seafood, meat and vegetables like a stir-fry, or toss ingredients into it for ratatouille. Its smooth surface releases cooked foods, and it cleans more easily than mesh. A little oil, and youll get a bit of flame-up that enhances the pieces of food as they cook. The handle is removable so you can cover the grill while the food cooks or smokes. Other styles include a bigger chefs pan and a roaster, but the skillet, or fry pan, as it is called, is the most practical.

title: Montana: Assessing Damage From Spill
description: Almost four days after an Exxon Mobil pipeline broke and spilled some 42,000 gallons of crude oil into the Yellowstone River, government officials and wildlife advocates struggled Tuesday to evaluate what the impact to water, birds and fish would be. Some 350 emergency personnel are working to ease the effects of the spill  absorbing pooled oil and conducting aerial flights to spot oiled birds and other damage. Alan Jeffers, an Exxon spokesman, said that so far, none of the towns that take drinking water from the river have stopped doing so. Amy Cilimburg, an organizer with the conservation group Montana Audubon, confirmed that few oiled birds had been spotted and said that the group was concerned about contaminants entering the food chain in the long term. The river rose above flood stage on Tuesday, arousing fears that the oil would be pushed into undamaged areas.

Wadley approved: I think that the day should have been observed with unusual strictness, but it is but natural and right that the feeling should have been more of sober thankfulness and religious prayer than of noisy joy.

Fininvest, the Berlusconis holding company for family assets, was fined $1.09 billion in 2009 for bribery, and a decision by a Milan appeals court is expected this week. title: Why Exercise Makes Us Feel Good
description: Why does exercise make us happy and calm? Almost everyone agrees that it generally does, a conclusion supported by research. A survey by Norwegian researchers published this month, for instance, found that those who engaged in any exercise, even a small amount, reported improved mental health compared with Norwegians who, despite the tempting nearness of mountains and fjords, never got out and exercised. A separate study, presented last month at the annual meeting of the American College of Sports Medicine, showed that six weeks of bicycle riding or weight training eased symptoms in women whod received a diagnosis of anxiety disorder. The weight training was especially effective at reducing feelings of irritability, perhaps (and this is my own interpretation) because the women felt capable now of pounding whomever or whatever was irritating them.

title: A Fount of Soda Knowledge
description: When I was researching the history of the American soda fountain for my story this week, all roads led to Gregory Cohen, probably the countrys leading expert on the institution. Mr. Cohen, 43, grew up in Midwood in Brooklyn, frequenting Chodoshs corner store and soda fountain (long closed, it was a fount of egg creams and memories that now has its own Facebook page. If you grew up drinking ginger yips, he knows that you are probably from Georgia, and on top of that he will mix you one at his soda fountain, Lofty Pursuits, in Tallahassee, Fla. (Its a combination of ginger syrup, soda water, and vanilla ice cream.) His masterwork is a complete taxonomy of soda fountain drinks, compiled from a lifetime of interviews and research in antique manuals like Ice Cream at the Soda Fountain, a two-volume set published by the United States Department of Commerce soon after Prohibition went into effect. To learn the precise difference between a milkshake and a malted, an ice cream soda and a French soda, an ade and a fizz, follow the flow chart.

title: Picasso Work Is Stolen From San Francisco Gallery
description: No bigger than a standard sheet of paper, Picassos Tte de Femme (Head of a Woman) is hardly one of his largest works, but that apparently made it all the easier for a thief to steal it from a gallery in San Francisco on Tuesday. The San Francisco Chronicle reported that the work, a 1965 pencil drawing measuring 10 5/8 inches by 8 1/4 inches, was taken from the Weinstein Gallery in the citys Union Square neighborhood; the robbery was reported to the police at 11:41 a.m. and the work was being offered by the gallery for more than $200,000.

title: World, Not Ended

On one side, it was accused of fomenting currency wars, driving up inflation and/or exchange rates in developing countries. On the other, it was claimed that the program was masking the true effects of the US budget deficit, and that interest rates would soar after it ended.

title: When Grown-Ups Went to See Films About Grown-Ups

To repeat: Kramer vs. Kramer, a film about a divorce, was the highest-grossing film released that year. (To be fair, the fifth-highest-grossing film released that year was about a man going insane in Vietnam.) To further illustrate how tastes in blockbusters have, er, evolved, here are the five top-grossing films of 1979 and the five top-grossing films of 2010.

title: The Divorce Delusion

Shed been told by a priest that this was the best strategy for saving her marriage, so she left not so much to find herself (like Meryl Streeps character) as to find a job, something my father (like Dustin Hoffmans Ted Kramer) had strictly forbidden her to do.

As exquisite a set of dresses as a princess could wish for, especially a youngish princess with a hankering for 30s/70s long lengths, raised waists, and all grown-up grooviness. Security experts recently met at the White House about an ongoing cybersecurity campaign. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Trend Micro's David Perry about what's happening on that front. The news roundup includes hacks on an Apple server and the FoxNews Twitter feed; the Qosimo 3D laptop from Toshiba; the disappearance of Google's Realtime Search; and crowd sourcing to manage traffic when a 10-mile stretch of highway shuts down for 53 hours in Los Angeles. Tuesday, Kaiser Karl dazzled at Chanel with a boucl memory trip down the Rue Cambon. Yet when it comes to reaching new celestial heights, ever-rising star Riccardo Tisci and his petits mains at the Givenchy atelier had the most intricate crystals and dgrad pearls stitched down.

title: Taliban Fighters Attack Afghan Police Posts
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban fighters attacked and overran several Afghan border police posts on Wednesday, killing nearly two dozen police officers in a remote area of northeastern Afghanistan, according to the provincial governor.

title: Increase in Measles Cases
description: An increase in the number of measles outbreaks in Europe, Asia and Africa in recent months is cause for concern at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in the United States. Candice Burns Hoffmann, a press officer for the center, said in a release that the United States was experiencing the highest number of measles cases since 1996, in large part because of unvaccinated travelers recently returned from overseas.

title: Video of British Debate on Hacking Scandal
description: As my colleagues Sarah Lyall and Alan Cowell report, during a debate in the House of Commons on Wednesday, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain agreed that there should be a public inquiry into the workings of the British newspapers following reports that journalists for The News of the World hacked into the voice mailboxes of murder and terrorism victims.

title: Casey Anthony Verdict Brings HLN Record Ratings
description: The conclusion of the Casey Anthony trial in Florida prompted spikes in television viewership on Tuesday, especially for the cable news channel HLN, which drew its biggest total audience in its 29-year-old history.

title: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere

title: On Location | Paris
description: A young couple on a tight budget renovate a two-bedroom apartment with a gallery-like aesthetic.

title: Please, Go to Sleep
description: Bedtime gives us some of our best parenting memories, and some of our worst. There are nights when The Childrens Hour, as Longfellow dubbed it, is the sweet, warm essence of all the reasons you had children, but also nights, as Adam Mansbachs satirical best seller has captured, when you would give anything for them to Go the ____ to Sleep.

title: Americas Got Talent Gets Plenty of Viewers
description: Americas Got Talent attracted its third-largest audience ever on Tuesday as the latest two-hour installment of the NBC reality competition drew 15.5 million viewers and dominated the nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. Only the shows two previous season finales, in 2010 and 2009, garnered more viewers.

title: Options Abound to Protect the iPad
description: It dawned on me three months after buying an iPad 2 that keeping the tablet encased in its original clear packing sleeve was a bit like having my living room furniture covered in plastic: practical, yet tacky.

title: Literature Can Turn Most Lethal
description: The setting: a college classroom in Vermont. The year: 1994. The topic: Unraveling a Literary Mystery. The professor: the most brilliant man in captivity, and he actually is in captivity, confined to prison for the 1982 murders of two female students. If Dr. Richard Aldiss reminds you of Dr. Hannibal Lecter, you are as smart as the nine super-special students in this class.

title: Boating Apps Help Sailors Get There and Back Again
description: Compact GPS devices have transformed boating, helping sailors and fishing enthusiasts find their way to port.

title: Citrons to Rally Through New York for Bastille Day Celebration

title: In Paris, a Home Far From the Tourist Center

title: Canadian Doctor Tied to Professional Athletes Guilty of Drug Charge

The invitation from his campaign to attend an evening reception, on a street where a house was listed recently for $26 million, was more candid: Suggested contribution to Romney for President: $2,500 per person.

title: Sirens, Trucks Gears and Piano Melodies in the Great Outdoors
description: Talk about sounds of the city. On Friday night I had one of those only-in-New-York experiences, a mix of musical gratification and urban racket.

title: Sentence of the Month Bonanza Throwdown Showdown
description: Once again, its time for our monthly clash of the titans, a battle of semantic juggernauts  a sweat-drenched, take-no-prisoners, blood-guzzling thumb-wrestling match between the best of all the immortal clauses I happened to read and tweet in June. Its the historic fourth edition of Shamblandersons Sentence of the Month Bonanza Throwdown Showdown. The stakes, as always, are suffocatingly high. This months winner will face off at the end of the year with Joe DiMaggio, David Foster Wallace, Bill McKibben and others in Shamblandersons Too-Big-To-Even-Be-Believed Best Sentence of the Year Bare-Knuckle Apocalyptic Imbroglio Faceoff. (Im looking into making this a live event at Yankee Stadium or Madison Square Garden. Ill pass on details as soon as I have them.)

title: Libyan Rebels Gain Inches Toward Link to Tripoli
description: QAWALISH, Libya  Rebels opposed to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi seized control of this village in the mountains on Wednesday, extending their hold in western Libya and inching toward a supply route to the capital that they hope to sever.

title: Long Wait for Premiere of Long Play by Ibsen
description: LONDON  Of the roughly two dozen major plays by Henrik Ibsen, it was not masterpieces like Hedda Gabler and A Dolls House that he described as his most important work. Rather it was the little-known Emperor and Galilean of 1873, a deeply personal reckoning with powerlessness that foreshadowed his famous domestic plays, but whose daunting structure  nine hours long, dozens of characters  led Ibsen to classify it as closet drama, meant to be read in private.

title: Feiffers Dancer Returns to Leap Ever So Seriously
description: The ebullient, emotional dancer first came to the publics attention in 1957. Year after year she was moved to express herself: trenchant political criticism, urban anxiety, seasonal highs and lows. You name it, she danced it. Accompanied by sparse words, her lithe, flexible body sprang and collapsed in modern dance poses, creating a choreographed phrase across the newspaper page. And then in 2000, still looking trim in her unitard, she retired.

title: UBS Hires Defense Banker
description: UBS said on Wednesday that it had hired Michael Ruppert, a defense industry banker. Mr. Ruppert, who had worked at Lockheed Martin and Lehman Brothers, joins UBS from Lazard, where he worked in its Washington office. He will be based in New York and report to Karl Knapp.

title: Summer Style | Buttoned Down

And while designers are delivering an abundance of glamour, the front-row look couldnt be simpler- without a trace of the Balenciaga, Chanel and Celine ensembles weve come to expect from the fashion flock. Instead, were seeing a lot of slouchy Oxford shirts and plain, tailored trousers. Does this trio of taste makers  French Vogues editor in chief, Emmanuelle Alt, the model Caroline De Maigret and the heiress Bianca Brandolini dAdda  portend a new austerity? And will it linger into fall? Or is it just simply too hot to dress up?

And of its various full-length vehicles none currently shows the troupe so well as Kevin McKenzies production of The Sleeping Beauty, which has returned to repertory for this final week of the troupes annual eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House. True, the production, new in 2007, has always been seriously flawed; in a ballet that should evoke a peak of civilization, most of Tony Waltons sets and a few of Willa Kims costume designs are all too Disney. The stagings merits, however, have now come into their own.

One of the films recurring motifs is insects  crawling on peoples legs, clustering on their food  and after a while it starts to feel as if the characters in Mr. Pushpakumaras slow-moving, three-stranded story are being treated in much the same way as those anonymous bugs.

title: Noise-Canceling Devices for a Good Nights Sleep

Have you seen those CDs and expensive alarm clocks (usually sold in airline catalogs) that offer the sounds of nature: waves crashing, rain drizzling, and so on? The idea seemed bizarre to me: When I sleep, I want quiet, not noise  not even the pitter-patter of angels dancing in the clouds.

title: Belarus: First, Claps; Then, Arrests
description: In the latest crackdown on a form of protest that has been gathering strength in Belarus, the police arrested scores of people who were standing on sidewalks and clapping Wednesday, human rights groups said. The applauding protests began because authorities in President Aleksandr G. Lukashenkos government take more severe actions against traditional public political expression, like unfurling banners. The clapping protests are organized anonymously on social networking sites for Wednesday evenings and began last month. Some participants stand silently while others clap. Plainclothes police officers typically swoop in and grab those who applaud, sometimes roughing them up. Vesna, a Belarussian rights group, said the police detained about 150 clappers on Wednesday. After past protests, judges have sentenced clappers to 15 days in jail or a fine.

title: WikiLeaks Memoir Postponed
description: A book deal that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, signed only six months ago has fallen through, according to a report in The Guardian on Wednesday, but Canongate, his publisher in Britain, said it was still expecting to publish the book. Canongate did not provide a date for its release, however. According to The Guardian report, Mr. Assange, left, had expressed concern that the memoir could be used against him by prosecutors in the United States. American officials have been weighing whether to try to charge Mr. Assange since WikiLeaks released a trove of State Department cables, but it is unclear where that effort stands. The book deal was announced in December; Mr. Assange said he expected to earn $1.7 million for the memoir, which was being ghostwritten by Andrew OHagan, a novelist. The memoir was originally scheduled for publication in April 2011 in Britain, although Mr. Assanges American publisher, Knopf, did not release a publication date. With projects like these, you never know about delivery, and you never know about timetables, said Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, part of Random House. My understanding is that the book has been postponed.

title: Somalia: About-Face on Aid
description: The Shabab, the Islamist rebel group fighting the government of Somalia, announced that it would again allow aid organizations to operate in the areas the group controls. A rebel spokesman, Mohamoud Raghe, said in a news conference in Mogadishu that the aid groups were going to be allowed to work in order to help bring relief to areas hard-hit by a severe drought. The Shabab said its drought committee would work with the organizations. The rebels in the past accused many aid groups of acting as spies and of being anti-Muslim. title: 36 Hours in Honolulu

The citys "it" factor has been on the rise since President Obama announced, two years ago in Singapore, that his self-described home state of Hawaii would host the 2011 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. This November, the 21-nation Pacific Rim summit may bring as many as 10,000 people to Waikiki, the renowned Honolulu destination on Oahus south shore. While the city primps for the media glare, it also brims with summers delights. Mangoes and sweet summer fruit add splashy colors to the market stands. title: Pattern Boldness | Marimekko
description: Bold stripes and prints may be all the rage right now (think Marni, Jil Sander, Prada), but Marimekko has been doing them for years  60 to be exact, when the designer Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo, took over a small Finnish textile company, Printex, and reinvented it with a graphic sensibility and an optimistic, almost utopian, outlook, not just as a global lifestyle brand but as a way of life. Jackie Kennedy wore a red Marimekko dress on the cover of Sports Illustrated in 1960; the Marimekko unisex Even Stripe T-shirt was a fixture on the rock and jazz festival circuit in the 70s. Today, there is no shortage of new Marimekko material around thanks to collaborations with the likes of Crate and Barrel and Converse; and a free-standing Marimekko shop is scheduled to open in the Flatiron district in the fall. But true believers should get their clicker fingers in shape for July 13, when a trove of vintage Marimekko goes on sale on 1stdibs in conjunction with Katy Kane Vintage and Couture Clothing. The perfect, plain shirtdresses, matching jacket and shorts ensembles in unfussy floral prints and breezy striped shifts all came from a single owner, a Westchester-area homemaker, with very progressive taste. When she found a style she liked, she bought it in multiples. That orange and blue awning stripe shirt a little too bold for your taste? Its also available in ivory and blue. What is more, many of the pieces were never worn and are still wrapped in tissue paper  and are as fresh and new as the day they were designed.

title: A Streamlined Magic Flute, Reimagined by Peter Brook
description: A Magic Flute, not The Magic Flute, is the title the director Peter Brook gives to his enchanting adaptation of Mozarts beloved opera, which opened at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College on Wednesday night. Mr. Brook uses this slight alteration of the original German title to make clear that his pared-down, 100-minute, touchingly intimate version of the opera  performed by just seven appealing singers, two arresting actors and the elegant onstage pianist Franck Krawczyk  is just a take on the original, an exploration.

title: Q & A

title: Sale May Rescue Ruined Greenhouse
description: ITS not really a race, but more of a question: will a sale come soon enough to save Brooklyns Weir-McGovern Greenhouse  or will it fall down first?

title: Dick Williams, Hall of Fame Manager, Dies at 82
description: Dick Williams, the hard-nosed Hall of Fame manager who achieved the rare feat of taking three different teams to the World Series, died on Thursday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 82.

title: Collaborations Bring Cascades of Motion and Emotion
description: LONDON  The ballerina Sylvie Guillem, whose three-choreographer evening, 6000 Miles Away, is being performed at Sadlers Wells this week, has carved out a path for herself unlike almost any other in the dance world. At 23 she left the Paris Opera Ballet, despite being its biggest star. Even then she knew her own mind and her need for freedom, a desire that has been the hallmark of a career that has encompassed a 17-year stint as principal guest artist at the Royal Ballet in Britain and collaborations with artists of all kinds.

title: Bad Week for Gay Rights on the Subcontinent
description: Updated | Friday | 10:14 a.m. Conservatives in India and Pakistan dont tend to agree on much, but this week they have found a sliver of common ground: That homosexuality is a treacherous import, brought to the Asian subcontinent by the West.

title: West 49th Street, 4:07 P.M.
description: Mallory Maskornick was greeted by a summer storm as she emerged from an audition for Godspell at St. Malachys church.

title: His Workout Partner? The City
description: THE EAST RIVER PARK in Lower Manhattan was animated on a recent morning: against a backdrop of the city skyline and the boat-dotted water, groups of children played on lush lawns, sunbathers basked in the suns glow and joggers ran by on the paved path. And at the playground, Charlie Gasparino was in the middle of a grueling workout. Using the monkey bars, he did more than a dozen sets of pull-ups  some including as many as 30  and alternated them with fast-paced push-ups. He was soaked in sweat in just 15 minutes and still had another hour to go.

title: Forms of a God
description: Images from Vishnu: Hinduisms Blue-Skinned Savior, at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Do you remember how to kick it with A Tribe Called Quest? The legendary Tribe took a different approach to hip-hop in the early 1990s, blending Afro-centric rhymes with jazz and promoting social change through its music. This years Brooklyn Hip-Hop Festival, which begins on Monday, seeks to do the same with the help of a Tribe member, Q-Tip, who is the headliner at the festival.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings
description: Classical

title: In Too Deep
description: Its impossible to look cool when youre part of a tour group. Instead of bravely exploring on your own, youve chosen to be led around like a frightened kindergartner. My wife and I were on a tour bus while in Hawaii recently, and our guide made me feel even more uncool because he was very rugged and handsome. After a couple of hours, he announced we were stopping for what he called snack break, as if we actually were kindergartners. He then mentioned that down a nearby path there was a cave we could check out. Not being a terrorist mastermind, Ive never had a huge desire to hang out in a cave. But the opinion of absolute strangers means a lot to me, and I was desperate to differentiate myself from the other travelers in this cool, rugged guides eyes.
