title: Costas and Michaels Team Up to Call Mets-Giants
description: On Friday at 10 p.m. Eastern, Bob Costas and Al Michaels will call the Mets-San Francisco Giants game on the MLB Network. They will announce the first three and the eighth and ninth innings on the network. To accommodate fans in the New York and San Francisco markets, where the MLB broadcast will be blacked out, Costas and Michaels will head to the Mets SNY booth for the fourth and fifth innings and SNYs Gary Cohen and Ron Darling will shift to the MLB booth. When Costas and Michaels work in the Giants CSN Bay Area booth for the sixth and seventh innings, the Giants announcers Mike Krukow and Duane Kuiper will replace them on MLB. Although this is billed as the first game Costas and Michaels have called together, they were boothmates in the movie BASEketball, a 1998 comedy. It will, indeed, be the first baseball game for Michaels since 1995, when he was at ABC Sports.

title: Amylin to Resubmit Diabetes Treatment to F.D.A.
description: Amylin Pharmaceuticals, a biopharmaceutical company, said its experimental diabetes treatment Bydureon will be resubmitted for regulatory approval in the United States this quarter. The company, based in San Diego, and its partners, Eli Lilly & Company of Indianapolis and Alkermes of Waltham, Mass., announced late Thursday that a study requested by the Food and Drug Administration did not tie Bydureon to dangerous changes to heart rhythm. The data were released in summary form on June 24. The F.D.A. rejected Bydureon, a longer-acting form of the companies Byetta medicine, in October over concerns that high doses might cause heart risks. The companies said Thursday that they planned to refile their application with the new data on heart rhythm in the third quarter, sooner than expected.

title: Googles Chairman to Testify Before a Senate Panel
description: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, has agreed to testify at a Senate subcommittee hearing on the companys dominance of the Internet search industry, yielding to the panels demands. Mr. Schmidt will testify in September, the company said Friday. Were happy to accommodate the subcommittee, said Mistique Cano, a spokeswoman for the company. The move resolves a standoff between the company and the Senate Judiciary antitrust subcommittee, which had threatened to subpoena Mr. Schmidt or Googles chief executive, Larry Page. The subcommittee plans to examine whether Google is using its position as owner of the worlds most popular search engine to hurt competition in the Internet industry. The Federal Trade Commission, the European Union and the State of Texas are looking into accusations by Internet companies that Google favored its own services in search results and increased ad rates on its rivals.

Open since last summer, Runion Surf Bar, named for a French-owned island off the coast of Madagascar and decorated with boards Mr. Wilson frequently pulls down to ride out in East Hampton, has become a hub for Broadway actors, employees of Billabong and Quiksilver, creative-industry workers from the area and surfers looking for quirky takes on beach food and tropical cocktails. title: Alabama: Suit Fights Immigration Law
description: Civil rights groups filed a class-action lawsuit on Friday against a new state law that cracks down on illegal immigration, saying it would violate the constitutional rights of United States citizens. The law, which supporters described as the toughest of its kind in the nation, requires public schools to report students immigration status, makes it a crime to give a ride to an illegal immigrant and bars all contracts with those immigrants. This law revisits the states painful racial past, said Mary Bauer, legal director of the Southern Poverty Law Center, one of the groups bringing the suit.

title: Massachusetts: Mob Bosss Girlfriend Will Ask for Release From Jail
description: Catherine Greig, the longtime girlfriend of James (Whitey) Bulger, will ask to be released into home confinement at a federal court hearing on Monday, according to papers filed by her lawyer. Ms. Greig, 60, went on the run with Mr. Bulger in 1995 and was captured with him in California last month. She is charged with harboring a fugitive, a crime that carries a maximum sentence of five years. Her lawyer, Kevin Reddington, wrote in a court filing on Thursday that Ms. Greig was not a criminal but a traveling companion to Mr. Bulger, 81, a former Boston crime boss charged in 19 murders. Ms. Greig, he wrote, is a kind, gentle person with a loving personality. Ms. Greig and her twin sister would put up their homes as collateral, according to the filing.

Manana Manjgaladze, Mr. Saakashvilis spokeswoman, said the case is about a serious leakage of information from our institutions, not about journalism or media activities. A civil rights group, the Georgian Young Lawyers Association, asked the Interior Ministry to publicly justify the secrecy concerning the case. One of the four remaining detainees, Giorgi Abdaladze, a freelancer, has announced a hunger strike, according to his lawyer. The police released a fifth, a photographer for The Associated Press, early Thursday.

title: Rwanda: Sentencing in Genocide
description: A Dutch court of appeal has sentenced a Rwandan refugee to life in prison for his role during Rwandas 1994 genocide. The refugee, Joseph Mpambara, 43, an ethnic Hutu businessman, led an attack on an Adventist compound in Muganero where Tutsi families had sought shelter, and hundreds were killed during the resulting bloodbath, the court said. He also was involved in holding up an ambulance that was carrying two Tutsi women and their children who were hacked to death with machetes, the three judges found.

title: France: Inquiry of Official Delayed

A decision is now expected on Aug. 4. At issue is her intervention in a legal battle between the businessman Bernard Tapie and the Crdit Lyonnais bank. As finance minister, Ms. Lagarde cut short legal proceedings and chose independent arbitration instead. Mr. Tapie was awarded about 400 million euros.

In fact, the only real conversation Id had with him before then was when I tried to lure him to come work with me at Bloomberg Businessweek. description: We interrupt the Derek Jeter 3,000 watch for some news with potentially much more importance for the 2011 Yankees: Alex Rodriguez has a meniscus tear in his right knee.

title: Italy Premier Loses Appeal on a Fine
description: ROME  A Milan appeals court on Saturday ordered one of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis family holding companies to pay $798 million to a rival group as compensation for its corrupt activities in a takeover battle, further weakening the prime minister.

title: After Years of Struggle, South Sudan Becomes a New Nation
description: JUBA, South Sudan  The celebrations erupted at midnight. Thousands of revelers poured into Jubas steamy streets in the predawn hours on Saturday, hoisting enormous flags, singing, dancing and leaping on the back of cars.

title: With Suzuki, Theres Less Than Meets the Eye
description: It was April 2001, and I had gone to Oakland Coliseum to see what the big deal was with the new Seattle Mariners outfielder Ichiro Suzuki.

title: Rodriguez Must Decide: Surgery Now or Later
description: Even as a diminished version of himself for the last few weeks, Alex Rodriguez has still gotten hits, reached base and played strong defense at third base. But Rodriguez is paid for his all-around game, including speed and prodigious power. Without those, he is not the same.

title: A Severe Case of Portfolio Whiplash
description: MARKETS continued to zigzag in the second quarter as investors sought risk, then shunned it, then sought it again  depending on whether they were unnerved by economic and political developments or hopeful for benign resolutions to them. Ultimately, not much was resolved, but there may have been more sleep lost than money, as stocks were little changed and bonds recorded modest gains.

title: This Time, Japans Gloom Runs Deeper
description: TOKYO

title: Not-So-Representative Investors
description: SHOW me a new study about water on the moon, or why pregnant women dont tip over, and Im happy as a pig in whatever it is that pigs like. Im just a big fan of science.

title: A Snatched Cat, and Then a Snatched Flier About a Snatched Cat
description: Melvin Bukiet walked out of his five-story town house on West 108th Street on Tuesday and went the half-block to Broadway to drop a letter in the mailbox.

title: Variety: A Tougher-Than-Usual Cryptic
description: Administrivial Chance-To-Win-Valuable-Prizes Update: If you are planning to be in the New York City area on or about the date of August 6 between the hours of 11AM and 5 PM, sign yourself up for Lollapuzzoola 4, the crossword tournament that is just about the most fun you can have with a sharp #2 pencil. Your hosts, Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer, tell me that the constructors of the puzzles you will be wrestling to the ground are Mike Nothnagel, Elizabeth C. Gorski, Andrea Carla Michaels, Tony Orbach, Doug Peterson, and Byron Walden. There will also be non-tournament games by Neville Fogarty, Allison Cimmet and Todd McClary. Click here to sign yourself up for an amazingly fun day!

title: Chinas Rapid Growth Doesnt Ensure Stock Gains
description: ECONOMIC superlatives abound about China. Its the worlds biggest auto market. Its the largest producer of steel and, of course, the largest exporter. Yet there has been nothing extraordinary lately about the performance of China-focused mutual funds.

title: An Inflation Hedge Carries Its Own Risks
description: INVESTORS who placed bets on mutual funds specializing in inflation-protected Treasury securities were among the bond markets biggest winners over the last two years, even as other Treasury funds struggled.

title: Behind the Rush Into Exchange-Traded Funds
description: EXCHANGE-TRADED funds have clearly come of age.

title: Investment Tips for the Accident-Prone
description: ITS one of the oldest jokes on Wall Street:

title: Best Seat in House? Its in the House
description: After a few brief flirtations during the week, I was finally ready for my annual affair with France, with cycling. By 8 a.m. on Saturday, I put myself in front of the television to catch the entire eighth stage of the  Tour de France  the cities and villages, the mountains and seacoasts, and, oh, yes, the riders.

title: Welcome to South Sudan!
description: A warm welcome to the worlds newest country, South Sudan, after a tumultuous independence struggle of more than 50 years that cost more than 3 million lives. South Sudanese deserve the celebration theyre enjoying in Juba and around the country.

title: Stepping (Carefully) Into Junk Bonds
description: AFTER posting impressive double-digit returns for the last two years, high-yield bonds rose at a much slower pace in the first five months of this year and stumbled in June, ending the second quarter with a gain of only 0.65 percent. .

title: Mets Tejada, Ex-Neighbor of a Stadium, Now Works in a Big One
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On any particularly windy day in Santiago de Veraguas, Panama, a right-handed hitter with prodigious power could hook a foul ball down the left-field line at Estadio Omar Torrijos Herrera and, with the proper roll, almost reach the back of Ruben Tejadas childhood home. Almost.

title: Shreds of Moon History on the Block
description: It was two weeks before the liftoff of the Apollo 11 mission when Thomas Mosers boss walked into his office at NASA and announced, Were putting a flag on the moon.

title: At a Paper Set to Close, Defiance and Foreboding
description: LONDON  With the tremors of The News of the World scandal still spreading across the landscape of British life, the newspapers staff assembled on Saturday for the papers last working shift before it is shut down by the Murdoch empire as part of its strategy for limiting the damage to its worldwide brand.

title: For Years, the Tabloids Sting Kept British Politicians in Line
description: LONDON  In 2004, Clare Short, a Labour member of Parliament, learned what could happen to British politicians who criticized the countrys unforgiving tabloids. At a lunch in Westminster, Ms. Short mentioned in passing that she did not care for the photographs of saucy, topless women that appear every day on Page 3 of the populist tabloid The Sun, owned by Rupert Murdochs News Corporation. Id like to take the pornography out of our press, she said.

title: Two Lockouts, Each With a Different Playbook
description: The N.F.L.s labor dispute commenced in March with all of the subtlety of an eight-man blitz. Within hours, the players had dissolved their union and sued the league, and the owners had imposed a lockout.

title: Ways to Shine in a Challenging Market
description: FRETFULNESS overtook optimism among stock investors in the second quarter. Many markets started the year strongly. Then, as spring turned to summer, recession worries rumbled back in the United States, debt continued to dog Europe, and inflation fears re-emerged in some emerging economies. The Standard & Poors 500-stock index lost 0.4 percent for the quarter, and several key international markets, including China and India, also chalked up losses.

title: Investment Income? Use Your Imagination
description: THE Federal Reserve says its winding down its quantitative easing program, but it makes no such claims for the regular kind of monetary easing, keeping short-term interest rates near zero.

title: Somehow, the Unemployed Became Invisible
description: GRIM number of the week: 14,087,000.

title: Cultivating His Plants, and His Company
description: This interview with  Jack Dangermond, founder and president of Esri, which offers geographic information systems, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: McIlroys Bandwagon Needs to Slow Down
description: The next day, Rory McIlroy had to play the final round of the 111th United States Open, but with an eight-stroke lead at 14 under par, he was already being rushed to canonization by some golf people. Padraig Harrington even proclaimed that McIlroy, the boyish-faced Northern Irishman, would someday surpass Jack Nicklauss record of 18 major victories. And when McIlroy was told about Harringtons prediction during his postround interview at Congressional that Saturday evening, he half-smiled in embarrassment.

title: Science to Art, and Vice Versa
description: NATHALIE MIEBACH uses science to make art. A sculptor who lives in Brookline, Mass., she translates weather data and other scientific measurements into three-dimensional objects that accurately display temperature variations, barometric pressure and moon phases, among other things.

title: The Therapist Will See You Now, via the Web
description: SEE a therapist without leaving your home?

title: Choices for Greece, All of Them Daunting
description: WITHOUT outside help, Greece is probably insolvent right now. In evaluating the countrys prospects, its worth asking what it would take for Greece to pay all of its bills and what kind of damage we might expect along the way.

title: Picking the Lock of Googles Search
description: BOB STROM is the owner of Ballard Lock & Key, which provides locksmith services in Seattle. If you live in the area and find yourself locked out of your car or home, here is an essential piece of information about Mr. Stroms company: it really exists.

title: Virtual Bridge Allows Strangers in Mideast to Seem Less Strange
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Moad Arqoub, a Palestinian graduate student, was bouncing around the Internet the other day and came across a site that surprised and attracted him. It was a Facebook page where Israelis and Palestinians and other Arabs were talking about everything at once: the prospects of peace, of course, but also soccer, photography and music.

title: Dont Fret. Just Ask for What You Need.
description: YOU cant be afraid to ask, my Uncle Art used to say when recounting tales of his successful 40-odd-year career selling mattresses up and down the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Energy at an Early Age
description: I GREW up in Manchester, England, an industrial city. My father, a carpenter, had an accident at work, severing the top of two fingers. With the settlement he received, he bought a grocery store that sold beer and wine, and when I was 10, I helped in the shop after school. Before that I delivered newspapers. I always had money as a kid, but never enough time to spend it.

title: Healing Power of a Game
description: Japanese high school teams use baseball to try to forget their disaster for at least a little while.

title: In Japan, High Schoolers Use Baseball to Help Forget
description: OFUNATO, Japan  Entering this port city by car these days means confronting natures fury and its fickleness all at once. The tsunami that hit Japans northeastern coast four months ago tore through the modest downtown, gutting buildings, crushing cars like beer cans and sweeping shops out to sea.

title: Executive Pay, Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeter Reaches 3,000 Hits With Home Run
description: Derek Jeter became the 28th player in baseball history to reach 3,000 hits on Saturday, with a home run in the third inning at Yankee Stadium off the Tampa Bay Rays David Price. In doing so, Jeter became the first player in the Yankees storied history to reach the hallowed number.

title: Alabama, 1963: The Heart of Civil Rights in America
description: A look at the civil rights struggle in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963.

title: Chinas Struggle With Inflation Continues as Price Index Rises
description: SHANGHAI  In the latest sign that China is still struggling to tame inflation, the government said Saturday that the consumer price index rose by 6.4 percent in June, the highest rate in three years.

title: Long-Hitting Tseng Cultivates Following on the Course and on the Leader Board
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  The best player in womens golf is winning majors at a pace that puts her ahead of Tiger Woods. At 22, Yani Tseng is 3-up on her contemporary Rory McIlroy in major victories, with four to his one.

title: Solutions for Saving the Space Program
description: How to keep NASA in business.

title: Teenager Cements His Status as the Best in the Netherlands
description: If there was any doubt about Anish Giris status as the Netherlands biggest chess star, it was put to bed by his showing in the Dutch national championship. He finished two points ahead of his nearest competitor, Ivan Sokolov, in the 10-player field.

title: Before Bruce, Clemons Was a Big Man on Campus
description: As the hard-charging, flashily dressed tenor saxophonist in Bruce Springsteens E Street Band, Clarence Clemons achieved legendary status as a master musician and performer.

title: Derek Jeter Joins an Exclusive Club
description: Derek Jeter became the 28th major league player, and the first as a Yankee, to record 3,000 hits. He hit a home run off David Price in the third inning.

title: The Republic of South Sudan
description: After more than five decades of guerrilla struggle and two million lives lost, the Republic of South Sudan, Africa's 54th state, declared its independence.

title: The Boss on Stage, but Saddie Out in Right
description: One summer night in 1973, two friends who had not met since high school bumped into each other outside a bar on the Jersey Shore: Bruce Springsteen was walking in, his old baseball teammate was walking out. They went back inside, had a few drinks and reminisced.

title: Videos of Celebration in South Sudan
description: As my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman reports, the Republic of South Sudan declared its independence from its neighbor to the north on Saturday. The move was greeted with a flood of celebration in its streets and rounds of congratulations from leaders across the globe. News organizations descended on Juba, the countrys capital city, to chronicle the birth of the worlds newest nation.

title: A Yankees Legend From the Beginning
description: The Timess Tyler Kepner takes a look at what many Yankee fans call The Jeter Era.

title: Webber on Pole and Paddock Notes at Silverstone
description: SILVERSTONE, England  There seems to still be a little bit of a hangover from the Canadian Grand Prix, which was one of the wildest  and the longest  races in Formula One history. First we had the uneventful European Grand Prix in Valencia two weeks ago, and now we have had two days of action at Silverstone with no surprises.

title: Webber on Pole and Paddock Notes at Silverstone
description: SILVERSTONE, England  There seems to still be a little bit of a hangover from the Canadian Grand Prix, which was one of the wildest  and the longest  races in Formula One history. First we had the uneventful European Grand Prix in Valencia two weeks ago, and now we have had two days of action at Silverstone with no surprises.

description: Re Surrounded by Opinion, The Times Raises Its Voices (July 3):

title: 30 Seconds With Ron Artest
description: Did you hear the one about the basketball player who wanted to try stand-up comedy? Its not a joke, at least not to the Lakers Ron Artest, who will deal with another kind of rim shot when he hosts a comedy show called Ron Artest: The Ultimate Comedy Tour at Carolines on Broadway in New York on Friday.

title: Scandals Redefine Rules for the Press in Europe
description: PARIS  A widening phone-hacking scandal is prompting a broad reassessment of the balance between press freedom and privacy in Britain, even as France grapples with the consequences of its tradition of protecting the powerful.

title: Jeter Reaches Fabled 3,000, and Its a Blast
description: The pursuit of a sports milestone can seem like a march to the inevitable. Fans have known for years that barring a catastrophic injury, Derek Jeter would reach 3,000 career hits. The only question was how.

title: Presidential Candidates Warn About Debt Deal
description: DES MOINES  The decision by House Speaker John A. Boehner to scale back budget talks with President Obama unfolded as Republican presidential candidates were campaigning against any outcome that smacks of compromise, underscoring divisions in the party over whether to raise the federal debt limit.

title: Why Are Wages Still Rising? (Wonkish)
description: One reason comparisons between current events and the 1970s are so wrong  and fears that stagflation is just around the corner are so wrong (and have been wrong for three years running)  is the absence of any surge in wages:

title: Aide to Leader of Georgia Tied to Spying
description: MOSCOW  The personal photographer of President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia was shown Saturday on Georgian television confessing to selling information to a man he suspected of being an agent for Russia.

title: Legal Tactic Raises Issues for Juveniles
description: In April 2010, three boys, ages 12, 12 and 13, were accused of raping a 12-year-old female classmate in the gymnasium of their San Francisco middle school. Last month, the allegations against two of the boys were found to be true by a juvenile court judge, and they now await sentencing. The third boy is free and could have had his case dismissed  despite a detailed confession to the police  because a psychologist chosen by his lawyer said he was not competent to face a judge.

title: After Making History, Jeter Makes the Yankees Winners
description: With one out in the third inning Saturday, space was at a premium on the rail of the Yankees dugout. Players and staff members crowded shoulder to shoulder, jostling for what they hoped would be the best view of history. Manager Joe Girardi was at one end, arms draped over the railing in his familiar pose; second baseman Robinson Cano was at the other end, a towel across his shoulder and one leg raised on the steps.

title: The Library Is Closed, but You Can Still Get Books
description: At San Joses Seven Trees Library, books are coming and going, even though the building is closed.

title: South Korean Wins Her Fifth World Title
description: Kim Ju-hee of South Korea defeated Fahpratan Looksaikongdin of Thailand by unanimous decision on Wando Island, South Korea, to become the Womens International Boxing Council light flyweight champion, making her the holder of five world titles.

title: Let Be: An Answer to Hamlets Question
description: We could imagine a five-minute version of Hamlet.

title: Flamboyant Financier Refocuses After Fall
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Major Health Problems Linked to Poverty
description: PHARR  Laura knows what comfort feels like: Before leaving Reynosa, Mexico, for Texas a few years ago, she lived with her in-laws in a house with bedrooms and flushing toilets, with electricity and a leak-free roof.

title: The Plunge
description: A point of pride in Point Richmond, the Plunges big indoor pool has brought joy to residents for three-quarters of a century. After being closed for nine years, it reopened as a state-of-the-art facility in August 2010. EVAN WAGSTAFF

title: School Counselors Fear They Will Bear Burden of Budget Cuts and New Exams
description: In the fall, the anticipated consequences of a $4 billion reduction in state financing to school districts will begin to become apparent to Texas students and their parents: fewer teachers, bigger classes and sparse extracurricular programs.

title: Commentary: Jeters Pursuit of 3,000
description: Mike Tanier provided live commentary of todays Yankees-Rays game. Derek Jeter had five hits, eclipsing the 3,000 career hit milestone.

title: In Tsunami-Torn City, Seaside Playgrounds Become Debris Dumps
description: SENDAI, Japan  There is still a traffic jam these days along Hama Kaido, the two-lane road that parallels this citys former coastal playground for miles. But the minivans and sedans that once roamed in search of picnic grounds, golf courses and horse stables have been replaced by thousands of dump trucks.

title: Erotic Vagrancy, Anyone?
description: WASHINGTON

title: For Fans of Robert Ellis, Vivid Contrasts in a Stylish CD
description: Robert Ellis is running his thumbs over the case of his new CD, Photographs. Ornately framed vintage pictures of his parents adorn the cover, and the 22-year-old from Houston is trying to demonstrate that each frame is finely embossed.

title: More Than 20 Shot Dead in Monterrey, Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  At least 20 people were killed  even the hot dog vendor outside  when armed men sprayed gunfire on a bar in Monterrey, Mexico, late Friday, the latest sign of the business hubs slide into violence in the past year and one of three slaughters over the weekend.

title: A Sordid Cast Around Casey Anthony
description: AS a reflection of the criminal justice system, the not guilty verdict for Casey Anthony  who in all likelihood bore responsibility for her 2-year-old daughters death, but will never pay for that particular crime  was reassuring. Juries are supposed to presume the innocence of even the vilest defendants. Evidence must outweigh emotion. And in the end there simply wasnt enough lucid, specific proof that Anthony had murdered her little girl.

title: 3,000 and Counting
description: Derek Jeter collected his 3,000th career hit in the third inning of Saturdays game, becoming the first player to record the milestone as a Yankee.

title: Action! Romance! Social Justice!
description: SUMMER reading often consists of mindless page-turners, equally riveting and vacuous. So as a public service Im delighted to offer a list of mindful page-turners  so full of chase scenes, romance and cliffhangers that you dont mind the redeeming social value.

title: Instant Music Gratification
description: I saw Gil Scott-Heron perform, for the first time, in the fall of 1994. Like any scion of radical parentage, I was well acquainted with Herons sprawling catalogue. Still, even for me, a young man who reveled in the track listings of limited releases, the rangy Heron had packed a few surprises. In the midst of old favorites, he uncorked a haunting and somber ode to the civil rights activist Fannie Lou Hamer. If he gave the title I missed it, which is possible given that I was mesmerized by the songs elegiac simplicity. I tried to commit every note to memory, but ultimately, I was left with shards of lyrics, pieces of melody and a deep intense longing for a song I couldnt name.

title: The Worst Time to Slow the Economy
description: It was not surprising to hear the Republican presidential candidates repeat their tiresome claim that excessive government spending and borrowing were behind Fridays terrible unemployment report. It was depressing to hear President Obama sound as if he agreed with them.

title: Redistricting Squeezes G.O.P. Class of 2010
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Way Above the Shuttle Flight
description: As the space shuttle carries out its final mission to the space station orbiting 220 miles above the globe, NASAs plan to conduct far more important research from a telescope that would be perched almost a million miles from Earth is in trouble.

title: Laid-Off Art Teachers Turn to Their Craft to Express Themselves
description: Katrina Barge, an artist who was among the 1,000 public schoolteachers laid off last summer, sat up a bit straighter as she described a recent painting. Its called Though Im Broken and Bruised, Theres Hope in This Pain, she said.

title: Etgar Keret
description: Whats interesting? The Sunday Review asked Etgar Keret, an Israeli short story writer and filmmaker who lectures at Ben-Gurion University of the Negev in Beersheba and at Tel Aviv University. Last year he received the Chevalier Medallion of Frances Ordre des Arts et des Lettres.

title: Texass Progress on Juvenile Justice
description: Just four years ago, the Texas juvenile justice system was awash in allegations of brutality, neglect and sexual abuse by staff members. Thanks to leadership by Gov. Rick Perry and thoughtful, decisive action by the Legislature, a state juvenile justice system that was in chaos a few years ago is making impressive strides.

title: Even Better Beach Reading!
description: My Sunday column offers my own list of the Best Beach Reading Ever  essentially a list of my favorite works of fiction, in the sense of great page-turners that also brim with literary value or illuminate social justice themes. I listed my top 10, and I invite you to tell me where I erred  and which of your favorites I left off. This is your chance to recommend to other readers what novel to take on a summer vacation. Go for it.

title: Wait Wait . . . Dont Tell Me!
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

title: Dim and Dimmer
description: The House is scheduled to vote this week on a daft and destructive measure that  in the name of individual freedom  would repeal national energy efficiency standards for light bulbs enacted by Congress in 2007. Though utterly without merit, the bill stands a fighting chance in a legislative body where ideology now routinely trumps common sense.

title: Mideast Countdown
description: It pays to be skeptical when it comes to Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts. Were not getting our hopes up when the United States meets on Monday with the United Nations, the European Union and Russia on this quixotic quest. The State Department said the group will take stock of where we are  which is not exactly encouraging. Negotiations have been stalled since last fall.

title: Long Live Harry Potter
description: All was well. Those are the final words in the last of the Harry Potter books. Since 2007  when the seventh and final volume was published  weve known how the series ends. This Friday, legions of Harry Potter fans will witness his struggle to make all well again when Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 opens across the universe.

title: Sunday Dialogue: What to Do to Make Our Schools Better
description: A lively debate about charter schools, high-stakes testing and impoverished students arose as David Brooks criticized Diane Ravitch, she answered back and readers joined the fray.

title: American Adventurism
description: To the Editor:

title: Sail On, Sailor
description: In winter, they are missing. But as spring gives way to summer, the sailboats return, one by one, taking up their moorings in the Hudson River, anchored against the tide. Traffic on the West Side Highway hurtles past them, tugs and barges make way midstream, their wakes lapping against these hulls at rest. Some days, the sailboats look near enough to be some quiet enclave of the West 80s. But no matter how close they seem, there is always a faraway-ness to them.

title: Afghan Bodyguard Kills Two From NATO Coalition
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A bodyguard for Afghanistans intelligence service killed two members of the NATO-led coalition on Saturday morning when he opened fire on a convoy heading out to train police officers, Afghan officials said.

title: In Defense of Antidepressants
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: Anne LaBastille, Advocate, Author and Woodswoman of Adirondacks, Dies at 75
description: The gratifying struggle for Anne LaBastille was how to balance her yearning for the serenity of solitude in the wilderness with her mission to let the world know, as best she could, that it must preserve wilderness.

title: Rahm Emanuel and Unions Square Off Over Work Rules
description: Over the past five years, the office of City Halls inspector general fielded about 200 complaints alleging that city truck drivers were loafing or sleeping at job sites. But the drivers were most likely not shirking any duties, said Inspector General Joseph Ferguson. And that, he said, is the real problem.

title: Shocker! Tabs Wont Change!
description: AS anyone in Congress or corporate America can attest, nothing spurs reform like a good old-fashioned crisis. But will the upheaval in Britain over illegal hacking of voice mail by The News of the World lead to any buttoning up in the Dumpster-diving, cash-for-trash world of tabloid media?

title: Gen. Tsos Default Chicken
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Mandate? Not Really
description: YOU may remember a brief time in 2009 when Washington seemed once again to be the most consequential city in the political world  a place where leaders might finally set aside childish things, as the young president urged, and set about dragging government into the future.

title: The Art of the Interview
description: THERES a startling moment in Janet Malcolms new book, Iphigenia in Forest Hills, her account of the trial of a Russian-speaking migr accused of murdering her husband. Having endured the paranoid harangue of a law guardian whom she suspects of being partial to the prosecution, Ms. Malcolm picks up the phone and calls the defense attorney: Then I did something I have never done before as a journalist. I meddled with the story I was reporting. I entered it as a character who could affect its plot.

title: Redemption in Birmingham
description: CHRIS McNAIR, symbol of the civil rights struggle in Birmingham, Ala., reported to federal prison last month, bereft of the media respect that has been his companion for most of his 85 years. In 1963, Mr. McNairs 11-year-old daughter, Denise, died along with three other black Sunday school girls in the Ku Klux Klan bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church. Mr. McNair, then a school-teacher turned photographer, transcended his anguish to become an agent of community healing, a popular politician whom white people appreciated for his policy of not bringing up his childs martyrdom.

title: Is Sex Pass?
description: WHAT could be more eternal than sexuality? The fog of longing, the obsession with the loved ones voice, smell, touch. Sex is discombobulating and distracting, it makes you immune to money, politics and family. And sometimes I think the younger generation wants to give it up.

title: Fred Newman, Writer and Political Figure, Dies at 76
description: Fred Newmans influential role in New York life and politics defied easy description.

title: A Taste Test for Hunger
description: CONSIDER this paradox: according to conventional wisdom, hunger is supposed to decline as a countrys wealth increases. Yet in China and India, hunger appears to be growing even as incomes increase at phenomenal rates.

title: The Good Short Life
description: BALTIMORE

title: The View From the Broadcasters Booth
description: As the 2011 Cubs sink into oblivion, followers of the team can console themselves with one thought: at least Ron Santo was spared.

title: Sunday: Body Enhancement
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  My first reaction to the theme of this puzzle when I first understood what was going on was ruh roh. I had gotten the circled letters I, M, and P at that point, figured out where Ben Pall and David Kahn were probably going with it, and thought, Well, it was nice knowing them.

title: Tough Calculus as Technical Schools Face Deep Cuts
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Despite a competitive economy in which success increasingly depends on obtaining a college degree, one in four students in this country does not even finish high school in the usual four years.

title: Hands-On Learning
description: Matthew Kelly, 19, is bright but struggles in traditional high school. Vocational courses have awakened a passion for machining and made math more relevant for him. Produced by Purple States.

title: In Vizquels Mold, but All His Own
description: CLEVELAND  The shortstop for the Cleveland Indians is a dazzling defensive player from Venezuela who switch-hits, wears No. 13 and first belonged to the Seattle Mariners. This was true in the 1990s, when Omar Vizquel helped the Indians to two American League pennants. It is true again today, with Asdrubal Cabrera.

title: Queens Grocery Worker Slain in Robbery
description: It was around closing time when a masked man with a gun walked into a Queens grocery on Friday night and, as a robbery attempt failed, fatally shot a 65-year-old clerk as he ran for the front door, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Is Deferring Millions in Pakistani Military Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is suspending and, in some cases, canceling hundreds of millions of dollars of aid to the Pakistani military, in a move to chasten Pakistan for expelling American military trainers and to press its army to fight militants more effectively.

title: Award Watch
description: With the season more than halfway finished, lets take a look at the leaders for the major awards. Check back at the end of September to see if these choices hold up.

title: Porous and Violent, Afghan-Tajik Border Is a Worry for the U.S.
description: HAMADONI DISTRICT, Tajikistan  Using a raft made of scrap wood and the inner tube of a truck tire, four armed men recently crossed the river from Afghanistan to a tiny, nameless border settlement here and kidnapped the two adolescent sons of a local army recruiter.

title: Answer for Invasive Species: Put It on a Plate and Eat It
description: With its dark red and black stripes, spotted fins and long venomous black spikes, the lionfish seems better suited for horror films than consumption. But lionfish fritters and filets may be on American tables soon.

title: Worshiping at the International House of Prayer
description: The International House of Prayer, a Christian ministry founded by Mike Bickle, has rapidly blossomed into a movement.

title: Where Worship Never Pauses
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The worship music, throbbing soft-rock appeals performed by live bands, has continued here without pause, day and night, since May 1999. Voices calling to Jesus or pleading with God to help tornado victims or make Congress ban abortion resound in an auditorium that is the physical and spiritual heart of the International House of Prayer, a Christian ministry rapidly blossoming into a movement.

title: 15 Strikes, 1 Inning
description: On June 24 against Colorado, A. J. Burnett became the first Yankee to record four strikeouts in an inning. A week later, a Yankees prospect outdid him.

title: For Price and Jeter, Not Their First Historic Meeting
description: As of Saturday, the first and last home runs that the Tampa Bay Rays David Price has allowed in the majors have come off the bat of Derek Jeter. Price, of course, will give up more, but he has forever linked his name to Jeters as the pitcher who gave up the Yankee captains 3,000th career hit.

title: With Final Putt, Wie Makes the Cut
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.  After she punctuated her second round with a 35-foot putt, Michelle Wie pumped her right arm as if she was hand-cranking ice cream. Wie stood over the putt on the final green knowing she had to drain it to have any chance of making the 36-hole cut at the United States Womens Open.

title: All-Stars Galore
description: One number to remember this All-Star week: 82. That was the record number of players recognized as All-Stars in Anaheim last summer. If many more players follow the lead of the Yankees Mariano Rivera, Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez, who all dropped out of Tuesdays game because of nagging injuries, there could be a new mark.

title: Back to Nature, After a Detour Into the Unnatural
description: The little girls giggled at the fashion show bounty. Imagine yourself as a homesteader, said the sign above their heads at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge visitor center here. They obliged, holding floral calico dresses against their chests, gauging fit.

title: Wichita Doctor Takes Up Fight for Abortions
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Not long ago, Dr. Mila Means, the physician trying to open an abortion clinic in this city, received a letter advising her to check under her car each morning  because maybe today is the day someone places an explosive under it, the note said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,641 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Suffering From Dementia
description: In March of 2007, Alan Schwarz visited with Sylvia and her husband John Mackey, who was suffering from dementia at the time. The Hall of Fame tight end died this past week.

title: A Player Defined by Greatness and Illness
description: As John Mackey described the biggest game he won, he merely demonstrated all he had lost.

title: The Dawning of Africas 54th State
description: Many of those who turned out to celebrate the independence of South Sudan, overcome with emotion, spoke of their fathers, mothers, sons and daughters killed in the long struggle to break free from the Arab-dominated north.

title: OToole Prepared for Reality of L.P.G.A. Tour on a TV Show
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.  The first two rounds of the 66th United States Womens Open featured intermittent play sandwiched between weather delays totaling more than eight hours. Many of the golfers found it hard to summon their best performances at the Broadmoors East Courseafter sitting around for hours  or in some cases, a full day  between shots.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Olmsteds Southern Landscapes
description: Frederick Law Olmsted is rightly remembered as an eminent landscape architect, but in 1861 it was his work as a journalist and an administrator that brought him acclaim.

title: Ronaldinho Soldiers On
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In January, Ronaldo de Assis Moreira, the buck-toothed soccer virtuoso and bon-vivant who was the worlds best soccer player five years ago, signed to play for Brazils most popular soccer team, Flamengo. In March, Ronaldinho Gacho wanted to indulge in the Rios famous Carnival and organized his own street bloco (crew), called Samba, amor e paixo (samba, love and passion) and in short order produced an offshoot party with his followers.

title: Japans Late Goal Shocks Germany
description: Japan scored one of the biggest upsets in the history of womens soccer Saturday, defeating the two-time defending champion Germany, 1-0, in overtime of the World Cup quarterfinals and thwarting German expectations of winning a third title on home soil.

title: Police Officers Held in Killing of Egyptian
description: As part of a sequence of actions intended to appease protesters, Prime Minister Essam Sharaf of Egypt said Satruday that he has ordered the suspension of all police officers accused of killing demonstrators during the protests that led to President Hosni Mubaraks ouster.

title: Boehner Scales Back Deficit Talks, Citing Tax Increases
description: WASHINGTON  Citing differences over tax revenues, House Speaker John A. Boehner said on Saturday night that he would pull back from joint efforts with President Obama to reach a sweeping $4 trillion deficit-reduction plan tied to a proposal to increase the federal debt limit.

title: Corrections: July 10
description: NATIONAL

title: Battle For Libya | July 9, 2011
description: Sights from rebel-held territory, as life goes on amid war.

title: A Fan Holds History in His Hands, Briefly
description: Christian Lopez and his girlfriend, Tara Johnson, were shopping at a Petco on Friday when they noticed the torrential rain pouring outside. Since Johnson had bought tickets to the Yankees game on Saturday as a birthday present for Lopez, the couple immediately began thinking that a Friday rainout might increase the chances they would get to witness Derek Jeters 3,000th career hit.

title: Rain Suspends Play at United States Womens Open
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.  This is fast becoming the United States Woe-mans Open as the golfers grudgingly let Mother Nature play through.

title: Documents: Scouting Reports on Jeter
description: Few things are ever certainties in the M.L.B. draft, but Derek Jeter was about as close as it came.

description: July 9, 2011

title: Terry Collins Lauds Jeter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Terry Collins, who has managed many games against Derek Jeter, both with the Anaheim Angels from 1997 to 1999, and with the Mets this year, did not seem overly surprised by the way Jeter reached 3,000 hits Saturday.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 10
description: As President Obama convenes another round of debt ceiling negotiations with Congressional leaders on Sunday, lawmakers and administration officials will talk about whats at stake on the Sunday shows.

title: Japan Joins France in Womens World Cup Semifinals
description: Karina Maruyama scored from a tight angle in the 108th minute as Japan stunned host Germany, 1-0, in the quarterfinals of the Womens World Cup, posting one of the biggest upsets in the history of womens soccer. Japan will be joined in the semifinals by France, which eliminated England on penalty kicks are the teams played to a 1-1 tie. Read the article, and come back to comment.

title: Video: Suffering From Dementia
description: In March 2007, Alan Schwarz visited with Sylvia and her husband, John Mackey, who had dementia. The Hall of Fame tight end died this past week.

title: Spectacular or Ordinary: Rethinking Ichiro
description: Ichiro Suzuki has been a widely celebrated player since he broke into the majors in 2001, immediately winning both the Most Valuable Player and Rookie of the Year awards.

title: No Replay for Hairston as the Mets Fall to the Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  About an hour after he had hit a pinch-hit home run against Giants closer Brian Wilson on Friday night, Scott Hairston, his wife and some friends sat at a local restaurant to celebrate. He was not recognized by the other patrons, even after he had crushed the spirits of many of them.

title: Is It Panic Time for the Copa Amrica Favorites?
description: The 12 teams in the Copa Amrica have all played two of their three first-round games. Costa Rica, Venezuela and Peru all have wins under their belts. Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay do not.

title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Meets With Chinese Counterpart
description: BEIJING  The United States top military officer met with Chinese officials in Beijing on Sunday, in the first such trip in more than four years and a sign of revival in what has for years been a stagnant military relationship between the two powers.

title: Dual Berlin Shows Highlight the Photographer Brassa
description: In Berlin, the National Gallery has dedicated a double exhibition to Brassa, the famed Hungarian artist born Gyula Halasz. One show focuses on street pieces by the artist, shown without context, the other on his relationships with his contemporaries. The shows, jointly titled In the Studio and On the Street, run through Aug. 28.

title: Retracing a Ride to a Fatal Duel on July 11, 1804
description: The question was, have you ever taken a murderer across the Hudson?

title: Feel The Pressure
description: Regular readers of this blog know that I make a big deal of the failure of interest rates to rise despite massive government borrowing. Theres a reason for that: what happens to interest rates is a key indicator of which economic model, and hence which economic policies, are right.

title: Emphatic Farewell for British Paper Caught Up in Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  Reporters leaving the newsroom of The News of the World for the final time on Saturday night were told by the police to leave their desks, including their notebooks, untouched. They were allowed to keep only their cellphones.

title: Alonso Grabs Victory from Vettel on Ferrari Anniversary at Silverstone
description: SILVERSTONE, England  Sebastian Vettels domination took a little dip on Sunday at the British Grand Prix, but this time it had nothing to do with a weakness of the driver or the car.

title: Alonso Grabs Victory from Vettel on Ferrari Anniversary at Silverstone
description: SILVERSTONE, England  Sebastian Vettels domination took a little dip on Sunday at the British Grand Prix, but this time it had nothing to do with a weakness of the driver or the car.

title: For Deutsche Bank, Talk of a Shared Chief Position
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Banks next move on who will succeed Josef Ackermann as chief executive after he retires remains far from resolved.

title: Obama Leans on G.O.P. for a Deal on Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama tried on Sunday to revive the chances for a sweeping budget agreement to reduce the nations deficit and repair its perilous finances, but Congressional Republicans continued to balk, insisting on a more modest deal to avert a default on the national debt.

title: Panetta Says Iranian Arms in Iraq Are a Concern
description: BAGHDAD  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Sunday that weapons supplied by Iran had become a tremendous concern for the United States in recent weeks in Iraq, where more American troops died in June in combat-related episodes than in any month since June 2008.

title: Scores Are Killed as Train in India Derails
description: NEW DELHI  Dozens of people were killed and more than 100 were injured when a train headed for the capital here derailed in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh on Sunday.

title: At the Ed Sullivan Theater, a Stupid Human Trick
description: Updated 3:11 p.m. | Most visitors to the Ed Sullivan Theater enter by way of a ticket to David Lettermans Late Show.

title: Envoy Meets With Leader of Yemen on Accord
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama sent his counterterrorism chief to Saudi Arabia over the weekend to meet with Yemens badly injured president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, with the envoy telling him that the only way to get American aid flowing again was to sign an accord that would effectively remove Mr. Saleh from power.

title: Horrible Bosses Is Another Naughty Hollywood Hit
description: Another weekend, another splash in the cinematic sewer. Paramounts Transformers: Dark of the Moon remained a huge No. 1 at North American theaters with $47 million in ticket sales ($261 million to date). But it was the unexpectedly strong performance of Horrible Bosses  noted by critics for its homophobia and misogyny  that caught Hollywoods attention.

title: Italian Debt Adds to Fears in Euro Zone
description: LONDON  Top European officials planned to meet on Monday to wrestle with threats to the currency union as fears mounted that Italy could become a victim of the debt crisis even as discussions stalled over a second bailout for Greece.

title: The Grand Illusion
description: So, no Grand Bargain. Jonathan Cohn has it right:

title: Bears With a Treehouse and Tidy Tales for Children
description: Bear Country, which Stan and Jan Berenstain created for their popular Berenstain Bears childrens book series, resembles human sitcom land a few decades ago. Each story about the Bears  Mama, Papa and their cubs, generically named Brother and Sister  features a nagging problem that homespun wisdom neatly and sweetly solves. With titles like The Berenstain Bears and the Messy Room and The Berenstain Bears and Too Much TV, the books promise gentle laughs, lessons and escapades, but nothing too naughty  the Cosbys with fur.

title: Where The Money Went
description: Somehow I missed the BEAs very useful page tracking the Recovery Act and how it is translated into taxes and spending. (Thanks to the commenter who mentioned it). Its especially useful for thinking about what the Obama stimulus really involved  and what it didnt.

title: With Grit and 10 Players, U.S. Women Oust Brazil
description: It has become a defining characteristic of American soccer, the certitude that even when skill and tactics are insufficient, and referees decisions are contrary and damaging, somehow resolve can prevail.

title: A Compass for Conservative Politics
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Without the soupy South Florida humidity and the fastidiously clipped lawn, the Newsmax headquarters here would be a lot like one of those diners in New Hampshire and Iowa where autographed pictures of politicians cover the walls.

title: Womens World Cup: U.S. Wins in a Shootout
description: Down to perhaps its last gasp, the United States womens national team got the tying goal from Abby Wambach on a late header to force a penalty-kick shootout Sunday and the Americans incongruously and incredibly eliminated Brazil in the quarterfinals of the Womens World Cup in Dresden, Germany. These girls just bring out the best in each other, United States Coach Pia Sundhage told ESPN after the match.

title: Sons of Rosemarys Baby: Birth of the New Horror
description: As a cultural commodity that got any respect, the horror movie was dead by the early 1970s. The collapse of the studio system, the aging of its stars, the decline of Grade-A monster movies like 1931s Frankenstein into rubber-suit rip-offs aimed at the teenage trade  all were stakes driven into a once vibrant genre. By 1975 a scary movie was called by any other name. Time magazines cover story on Jaws ran 3,300 words, and not one of them was horror.

title: A Job Change for Boston Curator
description: George T. M. Shackelford, chairman of art of Europe and curator of modern art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is moving to Texas to become senior deputy director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. A leading scholar of late 19th- and early 20th-century French art, Mr. Shackelford is co-organizing Degas and the Nude, with Xavier Rey, curator of paintings at the Muse dOrsay in Paris. The show is scheduled to open on Oct. 9 in Boston before going to Paris.

title: After Another Yankees Victory, News of a Big Loss
description: It had been a gorgeous weekend for the Yankees, with Friday nights dreary rainout quickly brightened by the euphoria of Saturdays Derek Jeter extravaganza.

title: Jimmy Roselli, Italian-American Singer, Dies at 85
description: He was a skinny Italian-American kid from Hoboken, N.J., who could croon like an angel. Before long, his singing made women swoon and grown men cry. For decades, he sang standards to adoring crowds worldwide, including, notably, My Way.

title: Rethinking Addictions Roots, and Its Treatment
description: There is an age-old debate over alcoholism: is the problem in the sufferers head  something that can be overcome through willpower, spirituality or talk therapy, perhaps  or is it a physical disease, one that needs continuing medical treatment in much the same way as, say, diabetes or epilepsy?

title: Rodriguez to Have Surgery, Will Miss Four to Six Weeks
description: Shortly after the Yankees beat the Rays, 1-0, Sunday, the team announced that the All-Star third baseman Alex Rodriguez will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right knee Monday at the University of Miami Hospital in Florida. Expected recovery time is four to six weeks, the Yankees said.

title: 100 Missing After Riverboat Full of Russian Families Sinks
description: MOSCOW  A riverboat filled with families cruising on the Volga River sank on Sunday, and about 100 people were missing hours later, feeding fears that the episode could be the countrys worst such accident in recent history.

title: Landing an Overtrick via Some Dental Work
description: Pair events are in some ways artificial because overtricks can count for so much. Chicago or teams, where making or breaking the contract is paramount, is a purer form of the game. Occasionally, though, that quest for the overtrick produces some good technical play, as in the diagramed deal from a 12-board fast pairs on Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com) on June 30.

title: Answering Questions on Baseballs Role in Japans Recovery
description: Ken Belson is writing a three-part series on high school baseball in Japan and the steadying influence it has had for some in the wake of the tsunami and earthquake that hit the country in March and the nuclear crisis that has followed. The first article in the series appeared in Sundays Times. Ken will answer reader questions this week about the series and his reporting in Japan.

title: The Long and the Short of It
description: A number of people have been telling me about David Brooks and Ruth Marcus agreeing that theres not much government can do about short-run economic performance, that we need to focus on long-run solutions. Its a common sentiment inside the Beltway.

title: Fans Pick M.L.S. All-Star First XI
description: A poll of M.L.S. fans, at least the ones who voted online, via text message and on Twitter, named the leagues First XI for the All-Star Game, on Sunday. The Galaxy put four players on the list, the Red Bulls three.

title: The Old Internet Neighborhoods
description: It took my husband and me eight months to conceive our first child. Much of that time was passed in bored agitation, like a long wait at a Verizon Wireless store. To pass the time, swap information, and quiet my mind, I turned to an online message board for women who are Trying to Conceive  TTC, one of the first message-board acronyms I learned. Then, rapidly, I learned the rest of the lingo known to the voluble and surprisingly large community of women who turn to the Internet to ask intensely personal questions: TWW (two-week wait), BFN (big fat negative) and OPK (ovulator prediction kit).

title: Delivering Squalls of Grunge Anew
description: First came the drone: a buzzing swarm of electric guitar tones. A clear, arching guitar line rose out of it. Then bass and drums clobbered their way in with a riff, and Chris Cornell lofted his voice into the moaning, chantlike melody of Searching With My Good Eye Closed, intoning, Im on my way/Lookin for the paradigm. After 14 years between tours, Soundgarden was back in full force, its paradigm intact, when it performed on Friday night at the Prudential Center in Newark. Sorry for the long wait, Mr. Cornell told the crowd.

title: Tanglewoods Season Opens With Good Friends Like Verdi and Bellini
description: LENOX, Mass.  James Levine has long been a mainstay of Tanglewood, though he will not appear at the Boston Symphony Orchestras summer home this season; shortly after resigning as the ensembles music director in March Mr. Levine cancelled all engagements here. But the show went on with aplomb at Tanglewoods rainy opening night on Friday, with Charles Dutoit celebrating the 30th anniversary of his debut with the orchestra and conducting an all-Italian program of operatic and symphonic works.

title: A Return to Rossinis Days of Yesteryear
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  Great minds have long grappled with one of operas enduring mysteries: Why did the composer Gioachino Rossini, at the height of his fame and his creative powers in 1829, stop composing operas and effectively retire after the premiere of Guillaume Tell at the Paris Opera that year?

title: Syncopated Tap Rhythms Tattooed Onto the Floor
description: Historical film footage of tap-dancers is often less than ideal: the images grainy or full of wavy lines, the sound muddy or distorted, the camera sliding all over the place. And still its usually enchanting. Even on recordings and whether doing the simplest steps or telling the silliest jokes, the older generations of hoofers have an undeniable presence and artistry. You cant stop watching.

title: Injuries and Triumphs Color a Ballet Season
description: History often happens during American Ballet Theaters eight-week spring season, principally because of its stars. This season, which ended Saturday, was distinguished by three guest artists in particular: Alina Cojocaru (from the Royal Ballet of London) in three roles, with her enchanting radiance and heart-catching fragility, and Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev (the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow), each in two, with their ardent vitality and astounding elevation.

title: Wall St. Banks Expected to Post Weak 2nd-Quarter Results
description: Only a few short months ago, JPMorgan Chase traders were on such a roll that they did not have a single losing day in the first quarter.

title: Behind the Mask, Giving Hints of How Its Done
description: On Thursday night Sbtrkt was at Camp Bisco, the annual festival  organized by the Disco Biscuits and held in upstate New York  that rounds up the progressive end of the jam band and improvisational electronic music spectrum. On Friday night he was at Wrongbar, a sleek spot in Toronto, where the hip-hop superstar Drake stopped in for a quick collaborative performance.

title: Monday: Response to a Bad Pun
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome to the Department of Redundancy Department, where we try to describe things adjectively in a way that means the same thing as the noun were describing. Synonomously speaking, of course.

title: Check In, Swim Out: A Floating Hotel as Art
description: As boat christenings go, this one was rollicking. In lieu of a Champagne bottle smashed against a hull, there was late-night bourbon and diving off the roof of the Queen Zenobia into dark waters lighted with natural phosphorescence. Nine strangers in bathing suits floated on an overwhelmed inflatable raft; a couple held hands on a pair of deck chairs; a moose head in a houseboat was decorated with a headlamp and a bra. Though the official ceremony would come later, on Friday night the Boggsville Boatel and Boat-In Theater, New York Citys newest and perhaps loopiest tourist outpost, was open for business.

title: Mind Over Crime for a Superpowered Team
description: Alphas, a series beginning Monday night on Syfy, is an uneasy hybrid: a science-fiction action series that also wants to be a heart-tugging law-and-order procedural, the type where the crime-fighting team represents a bickering but affectionate family.

title: Despite Violence, U.S. Firms Expand in Mexico
description: MATAMOROS, Mexico  When the latest bloody headlines from the drug war in Mexico reach headquarters in New York, Ken Chandler, the manager of an American electronics manufacturing plant here, jumps on the phone.

title: Carmakers Goals Stretch Credulity
description: The worlds carmakers are indulging in pipe dreams again. Carlos Ghosn, Nissans chief executive, predicted in June that the company would sell 82 percent more vehicles globally in 2016 than last year. Alan R. Mulally, the chief at Ford Motor, earlier projected a 50 percent bump, while Ferdinand Pich, chairman of Volkswagen, is shooting for just a tad less growth than that. If the rest of the industry is as optimistic, in about five years manufacturers will be producing almost 20 million more cars than market forecasters expect will be sold.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include trade deficit for May (Tuesday); import prices for June (Wednesday); retail sales for June, the Producer Price Index for June and business inventories for May (Thursday); Consumer Price Index for June, industrial production and capacity utilization for June, and Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for July (Friday).

title: If You Build It
description: As part of an art installation, adventurous guests can now spend the night in their very own boat and sleep under the stars in Far Rockaway.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: In Harlem, a Rally to an Accusers Defense
description: As the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn teetered on the brink of collapse, several supporters of his accuser gathered in Harlem on Sunday to urge the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., to pursue the case vigorously.

title: ABC Sends Greetings to Hallmark Movies
description: The Hallmark Hall of Fame movie franchise has a new home on network television: ABC. A multiyear agreement, announced last week by Hallmark, came two months after CBS decided not to renew its deal to show the feel-good movies at greeting-card-buying times of the year. In a twist the Hallmark Channel will show the movies a week after they have their premieres on ABC. Our agreement to follow ABC premieres with encores on Hallmark Channel is an exciting, unprecedented use of broadcast and cable, Brad Moore, the president of the Hallmark Hall of Fame, said in a statement. The first movie on ABC, Mitch Alboms Have a Little Faith, will be shown in December.

title: Stars Announced for Next Bond Film
description: After being held back for years by financial troubles at MGM Studios, the 23rd James Bond film has begun casting in earnest, with Javier Bardem and Ralph Fiennes, both confirmed to appear, according to The Daily Mail. Mr. Bardem, who won an Academy Award in 2008 for his villainous turn in No Country for Old Men, has been previously quoted by The Los Angeles Times as saying that he was in talks to play the nemesis of Daniel Craigs 007. Mr. Fienness role was not specified. Directed by Sam Mendes and partly financed by Sony, the film is slated for release on Nov. 9, 2012, and is to begin shooting this year.

title: Fire Stops Rihanna
description: A concert performance in Dallas by the singer Rihanna ended abruptly on Friday night after a small fire broke out above the stage. The fire occurred during the hit song California King Bed, forcing concertgoers to evacuate the American Airlines Center as sparks rained down on the stage from the rafters, according to the Web site Celebuzz! Although no official makeup date has been announced, Rihanna expressed her frustration on her Twitter account with a promise that she would return. No injuries were reported.

title: Barry Bremen, Professional Impostor, Dies at 64
description: Barry Bremen, a novelty-goods salesman who achieved a kind of flash celebrity in the 1980s as a ubiquitous impostor who slipped past security to shag fly balls in the major leagues, shoot baskets in the N.B.A. and accept somebody elses Emmy Award on national television, died on June 30 in Phoenix. He was 64.

title: A New WNET Site Goes Live
description: A few weeks behind schedule, WNETs MetroFocus Web site is set to make its official debut Monday, joining the ranks of Gothamist, DNAinfo, NearSay and numerous others in keeping tabs on local news, culture and urban life in New York City.

description: The Boggsville Boatel is a floating hotel-movie theater-art installation in Queens.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review Master Class
description: Terrence McNallys 1995 play Master Class imagines what happens when the opera diva Maria Callas leads an emotional master class for several students at the Juilliard School in the early 1970s. The new Broadway revival, which opened on Thursday, stars Tyne Daly as Callas (Zoe Caldwell, who played the role in the original production, won a Tony Award).

title: Yankees Robertson Added to All-Star Team
description: By Sunday morning, Yankees reliever Dave Robertson had basically given up on making his first All-Star team. He had made plans to spend the All-Star break in Connecticut with his wife, Erin, and was looking forward to maybe doing some fishing during his three days off.

description: Harness Racings biggest star, See You at Peelers, ran her unbeaten streak to 19 races on Saturday, winning a division of the $145,208 New York Sires Stakes and setting a new track record at Vernon Downs for 3-year-old fillies.

title: Petraeus Confident as He Leaves Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Just days away from the end of his tour as the supreme military commander in Afghanistan, and the end of a 37-year military career, Gen. David H. Petraeus said he was leaving in the belief that his plan to turn around the war and hand over security to the Afghans could be achieved.

description: IF sex sells, then nudity cannot be far behind. At least that is what Zappos, the online retailer, hopes with its new advertising campaign featuring naked models doing everyday things like jogging, hailing a cab and playing Frisbee in public.

title: The U.S. Capitol at War
description: When Thomas U. Walter returned to Washington at the beginning of July 1861, he found an appalling mess. For 10 years he had served as the architect in charge of building the new Senate and House wings of the United States Capitol and the cast iron dome that would crown the rotunda. When war broke out, Congress was not in session and the building was empty. The Union Army took it over.

title: Message From a Charter School: Thrive or Transfer
description: In 2008, when Katherine Sprowals son, Matthew, was selected in a lottery to attend the Harlem Success Academy 3 charter school, she was thrilled. I felt like we were getting the best private school, and we didnt have to pay for it, she recalled.

title: Cautionary Lessons From States Shutdown
description: ST. PAUL  The shutdown of the State of Minnesota has forced the opening of a new hearing room here, where pleas have flowed forth, one after the next, for a week.

title: Injuries in Descent Force More Cyclists From Race as Safety Becomes Goal
description: ST.-FLOUR, France  The first week of the Tour de France was filled with harrowing scenes of twig-thin riders splayed out on the pavement, bleeding from the head or clutching broken limbs.

title: Music Site Lets Users Play D.J. to Virtual, and Discerning, Crowds
description: The hottest new club isnt in Los Angeles or New York. Its on a Web site called Turntable.fm, where big-headed cartoon characters populate the D.J. booth.

title: Accusations of Abuse by Priest Dating to Early 1940s
description: WINSLOW, Ariz.  Alfred Moya was stopping at a restaurant in rural Gallup, N.M., on his way home to Phoenix in the summer of 2007 when he happened to glance at a newspaper article about children who had been sexually abused by a priest.

description: To the Editor:

title: Roland Petit, Choreographer, Dies at 87; Conquered Ballet Taboos and Hollywood
description: Roland Petit, Frances leading choreographerafter World War II, who swept away time-honored ballet taboos and whose mix of entertainment and art also made his work popular in Hollywood, died Sunday in Geneva. He was 87 and had lived in Switzerland for more than a decade.

title: Cozy Ties Mark Newspapers Dealings With Scotland Yard
description: LONDON  On Jan. 9, 2003, Rebekah Wade, until recently the editor of The News of the World, was summoned to an unusual meeting at Scotland Yard, the headquarters of the Metropolitan Police Service here. Detective Superintendent David Cook, the lead investigator in a gruesome cold-case killing of a man found with an ax in his head, confronted Ms. Wade with a worrying accusation: He and his family were being followed and photographed, he said, by people hired by her newspaper.

title: Black News in New Focus
description: NBC News and Interactive One, a network of Web sites aimed at African-Americans, plan to announce a partnership on Monday that will combine the editorial and sales resources of both properties. The partnership will focus on aligning NBCs African-American news site, TheGrio.com, and Interactive Ones news Web site, NewsOne.com.

title: Syrian Opposition Leaders Boycott a Government Dialogue Opening
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian officials on Sunday formally opened what they described as a national dialogue aimed at a transition to multiparty democracy, but the countrys opposition leaders boycotted the event, calling it a sham to mask the governments brutal crackdown on the pro-democracy protests that have shaken Syrias ruling Assad family.

title: A Yankees Team That Is Powerful, Yet Vulnerable

title: Despite Criticism by an Owner, Positive Feelings
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the wake of public criticisms from Fred Wilpon, the Mets principal owner, in a May edition of The New Yorker, the team held a meeting in the cramped visitors clubhouse at Wrigley Field. Carlos Beltran, one of the players singled out by Wilpon, spoke to his teammates and the coaching staff.

title: A Tabloid Shame, Exposed by Earnest Rivals
description: The phone-hacking scandal that is mushrooming in Britain, with arrests, skullduggery and influence peddling, would be a delicious story for The News of the World if it were not about the newspaper itself. Instead, the hunter became the hunted, and last Thursday Rupert Murdochs News Corporation summarily slid the 168-year-old News of the World under a double-decker bus. Its final issue was Sunday.

title: For Boehner, Lofty Budget Goals Checked by Reality

Boehner told his fellow Congressional leaders and President Obama that he did not spend 20 years working his way up to the top job on Capitol Hill just for the cachet of the title  he wanted to accomplish something big.

title: Not a Typical Pizza Place Anymore
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J.  Four years ago, Arturos, a corner pizzeria here, resembled countless others that sold slices and takeout pies to customers who were not asking who grew those tomatoes, where, or how.

title: No, We Cant? Or Wont?
description: If you were shocked by Fridays job report, if you thought we were doing well and were taken aback by the bad news, you havent been paying attention. The fact is, the United States economy has been stuck in a rut for a year and a half.

description: SANDWICH, England  Even with the Dungeness nuclear power plants towering over the horizon to the northwest, walking back in time on the Sunday before the British Open at Royal St. Georges is as easy as a stroll through the town where the sandwich was invented.

title: Labour Party Vows to Fight Murdochs Bid to Take Over Satellite Company
description: LONDON  The $12 billion bid by Rupert Murdochs News Corporation to take over Britains most lucrative satellite broadcast company, British Sky Broadcasting, ran into fresh trouble on Sunday when the opposition Labour Party promised to take the battle against the takeover to a vote in the House of Commons  a step that, if successful, could deal a fatal blow to the bid.

title: Quick Action Helps Google Win Friends in Japan

description: ROANOKE, Va.  Doctors save lives, but they can sometimes be insufferable know-it-alls who bully nurses and do not listen to patients. Medical schools have traditionally done little to screen out such flawed applicants or to train them to behave better, but that is changing.

title: The Method to Their Madness
description: The Republican Partys strategy in the debt-ceiling negotiations has baffled centrists and vindicated liberals. For months, the partys leaders have repeatedly turned down deals that would cut spending significantly because their members wont compromise on taxes. To moderates, this intransigence is inexplicable: Are they crazy? To the left, its all-too-predictable: See, we told you they were crazy!

title: Facundo Cabral, Singer of Conscience, Dies at 74
description: Facundo Cabral, an Argentine singer-songwriter who was one of the most eloquent voices of protest against military dictatorships in Latin America from the 1970s onward, died on Saturday, shot to death while on tour in Guatemala. He was 74 and lived in Buenos Aires.

title: An Aggressive Ruling on Clean Air
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday issued a welcome and overdue rule compelling power plants in 27 states and the District of Columbia to reduce smokestack emissions that pollute the air and poison forests, lakes and streams across the eastern United States. The regulation reflects the E.P.A.s determination to carry out its mandates under the Clean Air Act despite fierce Congressional opposition, and bodes well for progress on a host of other regulatory challenges the agency faces.

description: Coney Island, like many parts of New York, is just too big to get all abuzz when a civic crisis befalls one sector of the citizenry.

title: Offering Slow, Small Changes, Moroccos King Stays in Power
description: RABAT, Morocco  With the pace of democratic change stalled or staggering under violent crackdowns in the Middle East and North Africa, Moroccos recent decision to alter its Constitution provides what some see as an alternative to the bloody confrontations that have marked the Arab Spring.

title: Rival Claims to Sea Territory Made by Israel and Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM  Israel is to submit a claim to the United Nations in the next few days demarcating its maritime boundary with Lebanon, officials here said Sunday, amid a dispute between the countries over an area of the Mediterranean Sea that is potentially rich with energy resources.
