title: Dangerous Omissions
description: The gunman in the Virginia Tech massacre, Seung-Hui Cho, should never have been allowed to buy the weapons he used in the 2007 rampage. He had been found mentally ill and ordered into treatment by a court, yet that record never made it into the database of the National Instant Criminal Background Check System used for screening prospective gun purchasers.

title: Dropping the Ball on Health Exchanges
description: In the frenzied final days of New Yorks legislative session, an important health care measure fell by the wayside. The Republican-led State Senate failed to pass a bill to establish a health insurance exchange where individuals and small businesses would be able to buy coverage starting in 2014. An identical bill had already passed the Democratic-led Assembly.

title: Jeters Moment
description: Heres the thing about Derek Jeter: Hes great and we love him, with an admiration that has little to do with statistical milestones and big round numbers. He got his 3,000th hit on Saturday, as a million flashbulbs popped and documentary cameras rolled and cheers and emotion washed over Yankee Stadium. It was an extraordinary moment, mixed with relief. His chase for an abstraction was finally over, and he could go back to the day-in, day-out job of being Derek Jeter, Yankee shortstop. Thats the great long trip hes still on, and were just glad to be along, never mind what the hit odometer says.

title: More Words to Come About Casey Anthony
description: The Casey Anthony book blitz has begun. St. Martins Press said it had acquired a book about Ms. Anthony, the Florida mother who was found not guilty last week of killing her 2-year-old daughter, Caylee. Inside the Mind of Casey Anthony, by the forensic psychiatrist and television pundit Keith Ablow, will be released this year. Dr. Ablow delivers a cogent, comprehensible way of understanding exactly how Casey Anthonys psyche may have developed and how her psychological development and the dynamics within her family ended the life of Caylee Anthony, a spokesman for St. Martins, part of Macmillan, said in a statement. Whether readers liked or hated the jurys verdict, Dr. Ablow will answer the question, Why is Caylee Anthony dead? Dr. Ablow has been discussing the case on Fox News for three years. He was the co-author, with Glenn Beck, of The 7, which was released in January by Threshold Editions, part of Simon & Schuster.

title: Inside Titos Nuclear Bunker
description: During the convulsions that upended Yugoslavia in the 1990s, a secret came to light near the Bosnian town of Konjic. There  it turned out  the dictator Josip Broz Tito had constructed a labyrinthine bunker complex 900 feet below ground to protect him and his inner circle in the event of a nuclear attack. Today, it seems as remote as Yugoslavia itself.

title: Plaques in Prague Commemorate Holocaust Victims
description: The small bronze cobblestones can be easy to miss, but they are scattered, in plain sight, all over the streets of Prague and numerous other cities across Europe. Collectively these simple, handmade stone plaques, called Stolpersteine (stumbling blocks), conceived and designed by the German artist Gunter Demnig, comprise one of the largest Holocaust memorials in the world. They serve as poignant public markers, announcing to passersby that the buildings the stones are set in front of were once the homes of men, women and children who were carted away and murdered by the Nazi regime during World War II.

title: Aretha vs. the Monkees
description: Something about the middle of May makes Aretha Franklin call me. For details on the most recent occurrence, see my profile of her in this weekends magazine. The first time, though, was more than 43 years ago, on May 18, 1968, a rainy day on Long Island and the day I received my First Communion. There was actually a trinity of holy events: the ceremony itself, with long lines of boys in navy blue suits and girls in white veils; then the family pancake breakfast at Howard Johnsons; and finally, a trip to the local record store, where to mark the special occasion I was being allowed to pick out an entire album instead of my usual single.

title: Sole Mates | Shoe Saving Tips From the Pros
description: During summer months, the feet are most on display. And while many of us go out of our way to pamper our toes with pedicures, our shoes can take the real beating. Just because you arent tromping through snow and slush doesnt mean your footwear doesnt need T.L.C. Just ask David Mesquita. Along with his father, Carlos, David owns Leather Spa, New Yorks go-to shoe repair. Pre-treating shoes is actually a bigger part of our business than repairing destroyed ones, says David, who sees some 500 pairs a day. Here, the Mesquita men share their tricks and tips for taking care of all types of footwear before the damage is done.

title: Ah, How the French Celebrate
description: As best as one could tell, the most famous Frenchman in New York  you may also safely call him the most notorious  was not to be found at Bastille Day celebrations held on Sunday along East 60th Street. We didnt make it to a similar event held on Smith Street in Brooklyn, where the French population is said to be growing. But we assume he wasnt there, either.

title: The Concentrated Pain of Job Loss
description: I wanted to add one other explanation  to those Catherine Rampell cited, in her much-discussed Sunday article  for why unemployment has not become a larger political issue. Given how high unemployment is, there are surprisingly few people who have experienced unemployment in the last couple of years. This is the flip side of the historically high average length of the unemployment: joblessness is concentrated among a subset of the population, rather than affecting a larger group of people for shorter periods of time.

title: Orient Express
description: Travel to several Middle Eastern countries may be discouraged, but for three weeks in July, Shubbak, the first festival of contemporary Arabic art in London, offers near-full immersion in the regions art scene, with some 70 exhibitions, plays, readings, film screenings and dance performances across the city. The daily news reports of political and social developments in the region have understandably influenced how people think about Arab countries, explains Londons mayor, Boris Johnson, who is sponsoring the festival. Shubbak offers something new, showing that the quality of contemporary art coming out of the region is brilliant and challenging.

title: The Myth of the Allergy-Free Dog
description: Dog lovers with a pet allergy have a big problem when it comes to having a dog in the home. But the usual solution  getting a breed known to be hypoallergenic  may not be a safe bet. In fact, there may be no such thing as a low-allergy or allergy-free dog, according to a new report. The study found that the quantities of dog allergens in homes with supposedly hypoallergenic breeds are no different from those in homes with dogs widely considered non-hypoallergenic.

title: Old Stories, Spun Anew
description: LONDON  If a cloud of sawdust seems to hang over the Old Vic Theater these days, thats because Kevin Spacey is chewing his way through the scenery there like an atomic termite. In a ripping old-fashioned star turn as Shakespeares Richard III, Mr. Spacey gives fierce and flashy physical life to every twist of a power-mad mans corkscrew mind. Richard may be slowed down by a hunched back and hobbled gait, but this performance spins a classic, much-interpreted character until were all dizzy.

title: Writer Remains Literary Voice of Knockemstiff
description: KNOCKEMSTIFF, Ohio  There used to be a road sign, pocked with bullet holes, marking the beginning of this little village in southern Ohio, but someone stole it a few years ago, and there hasnt been much urgency about putting up another. The residents already know where they are, and not many strangers pass through. One of the two main roads in town, Shady Glen, eventually runs out of pavement and turns to dirt.

title: Are Jobless Benefits Keeping the Unemployed Complacent (and Invisible)?
description: In an article on Sunday, I wrote about why our unemployment crisis has been largely ignored by Washington. Among the major factors I cited were that unemployed workers are less likely to vote than their employed counterparts. title: Stone Arabia
description: She always said it started, or became apparent to her, when their father brought him a guitar for his tenth birthday. At least that was the family legend, repeated and burnished into a shared over-memory. But she did really think it was true: he changed in one identifiable moment. Up until that point, Niks main occupations had been reading Mad magazine and making elaborate ink drawings of dogs and cats behaving like far-out hipsters. He had characters  Mickey the shaggy mutt who smoked weed and rode motorcycles; Linda the sluttish afghan who wore her hair hanging over one eye; and Nik Kat, his little alter ego, a cool cat who played pranks and escaped many close calls. Nik Kat addressed the reader directly and gave little winky comments about not wanting you to turn the page. Denise appeared as Little Kit Kat, the wonder tot. She had a cape and followed all the orders Nik Kat gave her. Nik made a full book out of each episode. He would make three or four copies with carbon paper and then later make more at some expense at the print shop, but each of the covers was created by hand and unique: he drew the images in Magic Marker and then collaged in pieces of colored paper cut from magazines. Denise still had Niks zines in a box somewhere. He gave one copy to her and Mom (they had to share), one to his girlfriend of the moment (Nik always had a girlfriend), one was put in a plastic sleeve and filed in his fledgling archives, and one went to their father, who lived in San Francisco.

And I was reminded that for certain roles, a touch of the phony is just whats needed to create an illusion of authenticity.

title: On Experts and Global Warming

Plato scorned democracy, rating it the worst form of government short of tyranny, largely because it gave power to the ignorant many rather than to knowledgeable experts (philosophers, as he saw it). But, if, as we insist, the people must ultimately decide, the question remains: How can we, nonexperts, take account of expert opinion when it is relevant to decisions about public policy?

title: In Mogadishu: A Lifeline For Somali Rape Victims
description: Why did you come here when no one else does? The African Union communications director asked us over dinner at its compound in Mogadishu. Good question. We were warned against it, especially by war-zone regulars. Its been called the most dangerous cityor placeon earth. In fact, we had to delay our trip for two weeks due to multiple suicide bombings and riots inside the area controlled by Mogadishus transitional government (TFG). So, why go? I gave the short answer, Were supporting a local social entrepreneur in launching a sexual violence hotline.

title: Additional Letters: Searching for Perspective
description: Following up on the reader letters that appeared in my print column for this week, here are some additional letters via e-mail to my last three columns, Surrounded by Opinion, the Times Raises Its Voices, On NYTimes.com, Now You See It, Now You Dont and Where Words Can Never Do Justice.Thank you, stateless soul, for your informative discussion of feedback on the new Sunday Review in the Times July 3. I cannot convey how much I dislike the new format. I, like the feedback you mentioned, sorely miss the political cartoons and the late-night television gag lines. The weekly news is dire enough without taking away our opportunity to laugh while we are informed. The political cartoons were always the first thing I turned to on a Sunday morning. Wouldnt Art Buchwald turn over in his grave to see you eliminate his lifes work?

title: Loves Flames Amid a City in Flames

The warring Capulets and Montagues show occasional signs of pathological pyromania, and the buildings of Verona appear to be wallpapered in mesmerizing images of flames.

title: New York Live Arts Announces Fall Season
description: New York Live Arts, the new artistic initiative created this year by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and Dance Theater Workshop, is offering something new for artists and audiences this fall. For theatergoers, the group plans to present works from more than 40 artists, including a Replay Series that looks back at artists most significant and popular works. The performers include Big Dance Theater, John Jasperse, John Kelly, Yvonne Meier, Richard Move and Reggie Wilson. For artists, New York Live Arts has begun a two-year residency that offers a rarity in the art world: salary, health benefits and a commission for a work. The first artist to benefit is Yasuko Yokoshi, a Hiroshima-born choreographer who came to the United States in 1981.

title: Everyone Elses Problem
description: Half of U.S. social program recipients believe they have not used a government social program,  according to a paper by Suzanne Mettler, a professor at Cornell, posted on Boing Boing. And, yes, that includes everyone who has ever taken a mortgage deduction, taken out a student loan or collected Social Security upon retirement. If youre wondering why its so difficult to come to an agreement on the debt ceiling and taxes, it may be because, as Cory Doctorow writes, we live in a society of people who subsist on mutual aid and redistributive policies whove been conned (and conned themselves) into thinking that they are rugged individualists and that everyoneelse is a parasite.

title: Still Fighting Fire With Fire to Honor the Fallen of 9/11
description: The 10th anniversary of 9/11 is near, summoning not only horrible memories of that cataclysm but also the anxiety of measuring up. Ten years on, there still arent enough words, gestures, ceremonies or moments of silence to match the wound. Not paying attention is unthinkable, but its even harder to think of an adequate tribute.

title: British Distiller Diageo Shifts Its Focus in Acquisitions to Fast-Growing Markets
description: LONDON  Baijiu, a popular Chinese spirit known for its harsh and fiery kick, might not be everyones preferred drink, but the management at Diageo liked it so much that it pursued a takeover of a baijiu maker in China for two years.

title: Illicit Love and All Its Consequences
description: As bad ballets go, Alexei Ratmanskys two-act Anna Karenina is one of the best. It tells its potted version of Tolstoys novel with a fair bit of narrative clarity; it manages many complex changes of scene deftly; its dcor and costumes (by Mikael Melbye) are generally elegant; its extensive use of video projections (by Wendall Harrington) is unusual and effective; and most of its leading characters are immediately identifiable and distinct. title: How Kevin McCarthy Wrangles the Tea Party in Washington

McCarthy pulls on some ratty gym clothes, descends three flights of stairs and exits the building, where, when the weather is agreeable, he meets up with about a half-dozen other G.O.P. members on their mountain bikes. Together they cruise along the Mall, past the Lincoln Memorial, across a bridge and along the Potomac River. An hour later, McCarthy will shower in the House gym, head off to breakfast with some other gaggle of Republicans, attend the morning management meeting with Speaker John Boehner and Eric Cantor, the majority leader, huddle throughout the day with his whip staff and committee chairmen and conservative advocacy groups and random needy or disgruntled members until its finally evening and time to round up a bunch of other Republican colleagues for a dinner that can go on for several hours because McCarthy takes it upon himself to draw the others out from their professional shells with questions like, Whats the most embarrassing thing that happened to you at college? or What was the first concert you went to? By 11 at night, he is back on his office couch with his BlackBerry and the next days briefings, some 2,300 miles from his wife and son and daughter in Bakersfield, Calif.  and then asleep, in a federal building, by 1 a.m.

Now, it seems, all is right in her world again. Read Jer Longmans article here, and come back to comment.

Hidden behind the walls of the Palace of Justice, in the Ile de la Cit, the historical heart of Paris, the spot (8, Boulevard du Palais, 33-104-407-1238) makes a magical site for glorious music.

On live national television, in front of some 200 reporters at Podium C in the N.F.L. scouting combine media center, Newton is fielding (fending off) rapid-fire questions about expectations for the N.F.L., his character, his level of football focus, his baggage.

title: A Bit of Scotland by the Sea in England
description: SANDWICH, ENGLAND  The first challenge is to procure the keys. The next is to fit through a doorway designed for the shorter men of the 12th century. All that remains is to climb a tight, winding stone staircase and then a wooden ladder that leads to a final door and, at last, like Dr. William Laidlaw Purves more than a century ago, you are atop the Norman bell tower at St. Clements Church, squinting in the direction of the beach in search of prime golfing land.

After one reader wondered what prevents those companies from dropping health insurance now, another, adam of Washington, wrote a thoughtful response that is worth reprinting at length. The premium calculator he describes was developed by the Kaiser Family Foundation and allows users to enter demographic data and generate an estimate for how much insurance will cost when purchased on the exchanges created by the health care overhaul. title: City Operas Troubled Vision Quest
description: At this point the troubles of the New York City Opera are more and more confounding. During the news conference on Tuesday at the Guggenheim Museum, George Steel, the companys embattled general manager and artistic director, tried to exude a positive vibe about City Operas intention to leave Lincoln Center and take productions to various locales around the city, from Brooklyn to East Harlem to Central Park. The companys stage will be New York City itself, he said, a theater with eight million seats.

title: Victims Family Appears Amid Rage at Tabloids
description: LONDON  On the day when Rupert Murdoch retreated from the biggest media takeover bid in Britains history, the wider significance that many here see for the way that power in the country is wielded found its most poignant expression in the sight of an ordinary family standing silently, subdued but assuaged at last, at the door of 10 Downing Street.

title: Parties Cant Agree on the Consequences of Default
description: The fact that politicians in Washington cant agree on how to raise the debt ceiling is hardly surprising. The fact that they cant agree on what happens if they dont may be more significant.

title: Big in Berlin
description: Its not as though anyone in Berlin really needed proof, last week, that the citys once-hip central Mitte neighborhood had officially jumped the shark  two years worth of boutique hotel and Mavi-store openings, plus skyrocketing rents and a mass exodus of the gallery scene, had all been fairly obvious clues. But as the local fashion crowd milled around on Wednesday night outside the opening of Andreas Murkudiss sprawling concept shop, newly and thrillingly relocated to a remote stretch of Potsdamer Strasse once ruled by drug dealers and prostitutes, there seemed to be only one sentiment on everybodys lips: Goodbye, and good riddance. Murkudis may have helped pioneer the Mitte retail scene when he began selling Margiela and Yohji from three minimalist storefronts inside a courtyard off Mnzstrasse in the early 2000s, but with a few notable exceptions  the recently opened Gestalten bookshop, the Kunstwerke contemporary art museum  its no longer the place that in-the-know young people go to hang out and discover things. Its the place they go when they need something from American Apparel.

title: In South Korean Sports, a Culture of Corruption
description: SEOUL  On the day South Koreans rejoiced over the selection of Pyeongchang as the host city of the 2018 Winter Olympics, prosecutors continued to peel back layers of a long-hushed dirty secret of the nations sports landscape.

title: Japan Premier Wants Shift Away From Nuclear Power

title: Missing Boys Dismembered Body Found; Suspect Says He Panicked
description: Updated, 12:35 p.m. | The search for a missing 8-year-old Brooklyn boy ended early on Wednesday when investigators discovered what they believed to be his dismembered remains in an attic refrigerator of a Brooklyn man and in a trash bin on a street, the police said. The man, who made incriminating statements, was being questioned and was expected to be charged, the police said.

title: Lets Ban Books, Or at Least Stop Writing Them
description: There was exciting news last month among the Twitterati. Brian Stelter, The New York Times prodigy and master of social media, announced to his 64,373 followers that he is going to write a book. The obvious question: Whats up with that?

description: When your screenwriting debut is viewed as a a bellwether for the viability of female-oriented comedies and becomes one of the biggest successes of the season, its safe to say the film industry wont let you stay idle for very long. So it goes for Kristen Wiig, the star and co-writer of Bridesmaids, the $150 million hit, who could be spending her summer unwinding to the music of Wilson Phillips and chowing down on cheap Brazilian food but is instead moving on to her next project.

description: MILAN  The setting can seem a lot like quarantine. The entrance, through several holding pens and sets of automatic doors, leads to an enormous, vaulted, semiprivate room, the patient stretched out to the right. A bedside crowd coos appropriately.

description: 9:54 a.m. | Updated The New York Times Company said Wednesday that it would pay back the $250 million loan from Carlos Slim Hel, a Mexican telecommunications billionaire, on Aug. 15, freeing itself from one of its larger financial obligations.

title: In California, a Not-So-Special Performance for Democrats
description: The Democratic candidate, Janice Hahn, won last nights special election in Californias 36th Congressional District, an ethnically diverse but generally well-off district in along the Santa Monica Bay in Los Angeles. She will succeed a Democrat, Jane Harman, who retired in February to become head of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

title: I Am Not a Statistic': The Invisibility of the Unemployed
description: Ive received a lot of interesting e-mail in response to my article over the weekend about how the unemployed became invisible. But one from an unemployed woman named Tina Friedman was particularly striking. She talked about how, paradoxically, hearing about the huge numbers of unemployed workers may desensitize people to the jobs crisis.

These are the geniuses who think that they can take their eyes off the road for a few seconds to thumb-type on a small keyboard while doing 65, and not become a threat to themselves and everyone in their path.

They had watched their father hit a three-run homer to power the National League to a 5-1 victory over the American League in the 82nd All-Star Game and now they were going to sit beside him at the news conference as he discussed being named the games most valuable player.

title: Ben Sisario on a new piracy crackdown; the state of hacking; news.
description: Bettina Edelstein speaks to Times culture reporter Ben Sisario about why the music and movie industries are joining forces with big Internet service providers to crack down on copyright infringement. And Trend Micro's David Perry is back to chat with J.D. Biersdorfer, this time about the state of hacking and the shadowy groups involved in recent exploits. The news roundup includes a Google-iRiver e-book reader; an HTC smartphone with a direct line to Facebook; imported tech components preloaded with malware; another big hack from Anonymous; the Windows XP 1,000-day countdown; and a study on Americans and their smartphones. J.D.'s tip of the week: using the backup program in your operating system.

title: World Cup Semifinals: United States 3, France 1
description: Live coverage and analysis of the United States semifinal game against France in the Womens World Cup in Mnchengladbach, Germany. The Americans are coming off one of the most dramatic victories in U.S. Soccer history, their penalty-kick win over Brazil in the quarterfinals. The French also advanced on penalty kicks, beating England. Check back frequently for updates.

title: Oprah to Take Top Post at Her Network

description: Danielle Chiesi, the hedge fund trader who pleaded guilty this year to charges of insider trading, agreed to pay $540,535 to settle a related civil action brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Her payment includes $500,000 of improper gains and $40,535 of interest. Ms. Chiesi, a central figure in the prosecution of Raj Rajaratnam, is scheduled to be sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan on July 20. Read more

title: Damaged Synagogue Is an Architectural Milestone Too
description: The fire that roared through Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun on Monday night not only upended an important religious body but also badly damaged a milestone in the development of synagogue architecture. The restrained neo-Classical design speaks of a turning point in the early 1900s when Jews no longer felt bound to incorporate Moorish elements in their places of worship as a way of distinguishing them from Christian churches.

title: Whither the Government Sedan?
description: With about 600,000 federal cars and trucks under his watch, President Obama wants the government fleet to lead by example by adopting hybrid, electric or other advanced powertrain technologies in coming years. On Tuesday, Mayor Bloomberg unveiled an N.Y.P.D. cruiser based on the Chevrolet Volt, part of a 70-unit order of plug-in hybrids and electric vehicles for New York.

description: BEIJING  Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and recently imprisoned dissident, said Wednesday that he had agreed to become a visiting lecturer at the Berlin University of the Arts in 2012, but that he did not know whether Chinas government would allow him to leave the country to work there.

description: IWAS looking for Cary Grant with high notes, the director Doug Hughes said, describing the job requirements for the role of the not-so-Grim Reaper in his Roundabout Theater Company production of Death Takes a Holiday. A gift for light comedy, a gift for sincerity  gifts that dont often coexist  and a great singer. Its a combination of elements you might have in a studio star of the 30s, 40s or 50s.

title: London Theater Journal: Surprised by Betrayal

Thats the impression given by Kristin Scott Thomas in the first scene of Ian Ricksons terrific new production of Harold Pinters Betrayal, which I saw Tuesday night at the Comedy Theater. Ms. Scott Thomass impeccably chiseled features  a glamorous alabaster mask in films like The English Patient  appear almost to be melting here, involuntarily rearranging themselves as she tries to settle on a single, composed expression.

description: DUBLIN  The Roman Catholic Church in Ireland was covering up the sexual abuse of children by priests as recently as 2009, long after it issued guidelines meant to protect children, and the Vatican tacitly encouraged the cover-up by ignoring the guidelines, according to a scathing report issued Wednesday by the Irish government.

title: Live From Manchester
description: Back in 2009, Hans-Ulrich Obrist, the co-director of Londons Serpentine Gallery, described the burgeoning Manchester International Festival (MIF) as a tribute to the British architect Cedric Price, who, in the 1960s had an idea to build a flexible, interdisciplinary arts space in East London. Prices Fun Palace, as he called it, was never realized, but its spirit thrives in this biannual 18-day festival, now in its third incarnation. This year, Alex Poots, the festivals director, has come up with another stellar lineup of music, theater and visual arts events to match the citys reputation as both a creative incubator and provocateur.

title: Red Bulls Sign Rost, Veteran German Goalkeeper
description: Going against the conventional wisdom in Major League Soccer that asserts paying big money for a goalkeeper rarely makes sense, the Red Bulls on Wednesday used their third slot for a designated player to sign Frank Rost, 38, whose contract with Hamburg of the German Bundesliga had expired.

title: Tensions Escalate as Stakes Grow in Fiscal Clash
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, warned on Wednesday of a huge financial calamity if President Obama and the Republicans cannot agree on a budget deal that allows the federal debt ceiling to be increased. Moodys, the ratings agency, threatened a credit downgrade, citing a rising possibility that no deal would be reached before the governments borrowing authority hits its limit on Aug. 2.

title: Rag & Bones Urban Art Project
description: If youve been in Soho this past week, you may have noticed the monster-size rooster applied to the side of Rag & Bones Houston Street store (73 East Houston Street). Curious? So were we. Turns out the designers Marcus Wainwright and David Neville have invited visiting artists to tag their buildings wall as part of a continuing project. (Brooklyns ballpoint-pen extraordinaire Nicholas Forker started the series in May with an installation called Action Man.) Whats up now is a piece by the graffiti street artist Gaia. Here, a video of the three-day installation reveals him applying a wheat-paste backdrop of Peter Bruegels The Triumph of Death, then painting the rooster on top. As in many of Gaias neighborhood paintings, in which animals recur as protectors of the streets, this rooster is just looking out. Not that anyone is calling New Yorkers chicken.

title: Egypt Purges Mubarak-Era Police Officers
description: CAIRO  Egypts transitional military government announced the early retirement of more than 600 senior police officers on Wednesday. It was an effort to mollify thousands of protesters at a six-day-old protest in Cairos Tahrir Square who have been demanding swifter justice for those complicit in wrongdoing under President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted in February.

title: As Immigration Audits Increase, Some Employers Pay a High Price
description: David Cox was at his desk in September 2009, when his receptionist announced an unexpected visitor, a special agent from Immigration and Customs Enforcement, also known as ICE. Mr. Cox is chief executive of L. E. Cooke Company, a fourth-generation, family-owned nursery in Visalia, Calif., that grows deciduous trees and shrubs. The agent handed Mr. Cox a letter and informed him he had three days to produce I-9 employment-eligibility forms for all current employees. Mr. Cox said the agent was pleasant and nonthreatening, but he noticed she carried a gun.

title: Car2go, Daimler-Backed Sharing Program, to Go Electric in San Diego
description: San Diego will soon be home to an all-electric, one-way car sharing service from Car2go, the Daimler subsidiary. The first of its kind in the United States, the program would allow members to rent the Smart Fortwo Electric Drive by the minute in a city that is becoming a focal point for E.V. launches.

title: What If You Suspect an Employee is Undocumented?

It cites the example of David Cox, who runs a family-owned nursery in Visalia, Calif., that was one of 1,444 businesses audited by ICE in 2009. Last year, 2,196 businesses were audited.

title: Turkish Police Say 15 Suspects Plotted Attacks
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey  The police have detained 15 suspected Al Qaeda militants on evidence that they had plotted to attack foreign diplomatic targets including the United States Embassy in Ankara, Turkey, the Anatolian News Agency reported on Wednesday.

title: Will Anything Be Done About Falling Fans?
description: Following the death of the Texas firefighter Shannon Stone at a Rangers game last week and the potentially tragic near spill of another fan at the Home Run Derby at Phoenixs Chase Field, there is no indication that Major League Baseball will order up a full-scale review of ballpark safety.

title: An Appraisal:  Sherwood Schwartzs Modern Families
description: Sherwood Schwartz passed away Tuesday at the ripe old age of 94. Sherwood Schwartz might be one of those names that you recognize, but you cant remember from where. He created two of the most beloved sitcoms of the 1960s and 70s  Gilligans Island and The Brady Bunch. You may write these off as shlock, just like the critics did, but Im sure you can recite the theme songs  both written by Schwartz, himself. He always said, Tell them everything they need to know in the theme song.

title: The Fictions of Asylum Seekers  in Fiction
description: The case of Dominique Strauss-Kahn and the hotel housekeeper has thrown a spotlight on the fictions of asylum seekers, with the revelation that the West African woman who accused Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault fabricated details of her asylum application to the United States.

title: Patient Plan Behind Tender Offer for Temple-Inland
description: International Papers $3.3 billion offer for Temple-Inland should be termed a patient hostile. The company has officially begun a tender offer for Temple-Inlands outstanding shares. But this is a mere placeholder, and International Paper is settling in for what could be a long fight.

title: Anxiety Hovers Over Iraqi Commandos
description: BAGHDAD  A photographer and I recently embedded with an Army Special Forces unit that operates from a corner of Camp Victory, the United States militarys vast complex near the airport. Such embeds are extremely rare and this one took many months to secure  while the regular Army welcomes reporters with nearly unimpeded access, the Special Forces are leery of journalists. This was underscored by the long list of ground rules they require reporters to adhere to in order to protect operational secrecy.

title: Mercedes Hopes a Good Walk Brings Spoils
description: FRANKFURT

title: A Mountainside Homestead
description: A three-bedroom Cape Dutch style homestead near Cape Town is on the market for $1.4 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Cape Town
description: A CAPE DUTCH STYLE HOMESTEAD NEAR CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA

title: Viewers Choose Talent Over Big League Bats
description: 4:34 p.m. | Updated Americans, it seems, like talented people who can jump over beds of nails and ride motorcycles in cages more than they like the best sluggers and pitchers in baseball.

title: When Its O.K. to Skip a Loan Payment
description: Its generally a bad idea to skip mortgage and other loan payments. Late payments damage your credit score and add late fees to your monthly total.

title: When a Sex Offender Isnt
description: Boy meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love. After dating for a year, they have sex, and the girls mother thinks they are moving too quickly. The girls mother calls the police, hoping they will scare boy and girl a little. Instead, he is arrested and put on the Texas sex-offender list, since he is 19 and she is 16, which is a year shy of the states age of consent. Boy avoids jail, is put on probation, and is forced to move out of his home because the law says he cant live in the same house as his 12-year-old sister. Eventually, boy and girl marry, have four daughters and, 15 years later, he is still a registered sex offender who is not allowed to coach his childrens soccer teams, get a job at a major corporation or leave the state without registering with law enforcement.

title: Scouting Report
description: LIMITED EDITIONS

title: Shopping Snapshots for July 14
description: Marchesas jewelry collection channels the look of Miriam Haskell, the Olsen twins create a chic minimalist line of handbags and more.

title: People-Powered
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#320", 592, 420, true, chameleonData);

title: Assemblyman Hikind on Kletzky Killing
description: Assemblyman Dov Hikind speaks about the death of Leiby Kletzky and the fact that the suspect is from the Jewish community.

title: European Leaders Delay Summit Meeting Over Greece
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders on Wednesday delayed a proposed summit meeting in an effort to bridge crucial differences over the role of private investors in a second Greek bailout.

title: On Electric Cars, City Hopes to Lead by Examples
description: It may have been the only auto showroom in city history to feature shirtless roller skaters, tip-seeking jugglers and an on-site churro vendor.

title: Counting Down to the Primetime Emmy Nominations
description: Youve watched the shows, admired the actors, writers and producers, posted your reactions on Twitter and Facebook, read the recaps and commented on the criticism. But none of it matters until the television industry decides the best work of the 2010-2011 season, the only way it knows how: by handing out awards.

title: Despite Benefit Disparities, Middle Class Supports Mortgage Deduction
description: A couple of weeks ago, David Streitfeld and Megan Thee-Brenan of The New York Times reported on the results of a Times/CBS News poll on homeownership in the United States. The poll found continued support for government subsidies for homeownership, including the mortgage interest deduction. Noting broad, bipartisan support for the deduction, Mr. Streitfeld and Ms. Thee-Brenan acknowledged that  almost no one favors discontinuing the mortgage tax deduction, a prized middle-class benefit that has been featured on some budget-cutting proposals.

title: Two Studies Show Pills Can Prevent H.I.V. Infection
description: Two new studies released on Wednesday add to the growing body of evidence that taking a daily pill containing one or two AIDS drugs can keep an uninfected person from catching the fatal human immunodeficiency virus.

title: Amid Minnesota Crisis, Pawlenty Faces Scrutiny
description: On the presidential campaign trail, Tim Pawlenty, who in January completed two terms as governor of Minnesota, runs largely as an implacable foe of government spending, saying he drew a line in the sand in his home state and stood tough against Democrats during a government shutdown in 2005.

title: Model and Front-Runner
description: THE first thing that registers in a glance at the new advertising campaign for Thierry Mugler A*Men fragrance is that the model, shown running across the page, appears to have neon laser beams shooting out of his rump.

title: Small Health Woes Increase Dementia Risk
description: A runny nose, fallen arches and dentures arent risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a persons risk for dementia.

title: The Downtown Crowd Finds an Uptown Perch
description: ITS the dining version of the scene where the Gale house judders down in Oz. Monochrome up until that point, the world is suddenly, gorgeously Technicolor once Dorothy opens the door.

title: Google+ Improves on Facebook
description: Google, the most popular Web site on earth, is worried about the second-most popular site. That, of course, would be Facebook.

title: Nothing Sells Like a Duchess
description: RELATING to the period of June 30 to July 10  known in these quarters as The Great North American Fashion Tour of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, and Her Many, Many Designer Dresses (Including Some Previously Worn)  this reporter received no fewer than two dozen e-mails from publicists seeking to give credit to the designers who made the clothes she was wearing.

title: The Caucus | The President's Fundraising
description: July 13, 2011 - Nicholas Confessore reports on President Obama's large fundraising haul: $86 million.

title: Asked & Answered | Errol Morris
description: In his latest film, Tabloid, Errol Morris, the celebrated documentarian behind The Fog of War, the Oscar-winning portrait of Robert McNamara, and The Thin Blue Line, which helped get a man off death row, turns his famous Interrotron on a former Miss Wyoming whose stranger-than-fiction escapades twice invited the scrutiny of tabloid newspapers. In the late 1970s, a beauty queen named Joyce McKinney followed the object of her affections, a plump Mormon missionary named Kirk Anderson, to England, where she may or may not have abducted him at gunpoint. Through the Daily Express, McKinney claimed that Anderson consented to a three-day tryst at a cottage in Devon and was later brainwashed by the Mormon Church. With headlines like Manacled Mormon, the Daily Mirror told a different story, one that painted McKinney as an S&M-practicing predator who chained Anderson to a bed and forced him to have sex with her with the hope of getting pregnant. McKinney fled the country in an outlandish disguise and, three decades later, made the news again, this time for persuading a South Korean doctor to clone her beloved pit bull, Booger. The Moment sat down with Morris in SoHo to discuss his mad meditation on obsession, hysteria and the tabloid rag.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Afghanistan and Spain.

title: Colorized
description: Stealing a page from the sneaker playbook: dress shoes with color.

title: Elvis Would Be Proud
description: SNEAKERHEADS, rejoice.

title: Town & Country Man Eases Into His New Home
description: JAY FIELDEN cut a lean figure as he paced his glass-walled office on the 33rd floor of the Hearst Building. Occupying that space, the top editors perch at Town & Country, is a bit, he said, like being a gerbil in a cage.

title: Gone With the Wind
description: This matter is best disposed of from a great height, over water. I hear that line from North by Northwest when I see George Steinmetzs images from this years Dfi Wind competition off the coast of Gruissan, France. When one of them ran in last weekends magazine, Steinmetz became the first photographer to make a repeat appearance in Look. Back in early March, Steinmetzs picture taken from high over frozen water  the setting for a pond hockey tournament in Wisconsin  marked the debut of Look as a regular feature. Here, above and below, are some additional photos from his windsurfing shoot.

title: Sex on the Moon
description: Prologue

title: Supposition as Research: A Sort-of-True Story About NASA and a Thief
description: Here is the no-frills version of the Thad Roberts story: Mr. Roberts aspired to a career with NASA and became an intern at the Johnson Space Center. In 2002 he stole a 661-pound safe that contained priceless Moon rock samples. He was caught by an F.B.I. sting as he tried to sell this loot to mineral collectors. He was sentenced to eight years and four months in prison.

title: Homes for $800,000
description: An 18th-century house in eastern Maryland; a contemporary house in central Vermont; and a 1911 house in St. Louis.

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: CHESTERTOWN, MD.

title: Creem Set to Return to the Newstand
description: It has been more than two decades since rock fans could pick up a copy of Creem magazine at a newsstand and submerse themselves in the fabled publication where critics like Lester Bangs and Dave Marsh helped define a generation of popular musicians. But there are plans afoot to resurrect the printed magazine this fall, The Associated Press reported this week.

title: France Loses to the U.S., With Typical Elegance
description: The proper thing to do  even before praising American resilience and Pia Sundhages coaching  is to respect France.

title: A Fantasy Book Revives Store Sales
description: Amid the growth of the e-book business and online retailers like Amazon, sales of print books in brick-and-mortar stores have been suffering all year.

title: Summer Office Hours on The Choice
description: Like many readers of The Choice, your blogger has been taking  and will continue to take  some time away from the keyboard this summer to recharge, and plan for the school year ahead.

title: Returning Upriver With Very Few Fish
description: John S. Sparks, curator of ichthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, writes about his expedition to Madagascar, where he studied native freshwater fish.

title: Kickoff
description: The opening-night party for the Bread & Butter urban and street fashion trade fair looked like something out of Burning Man.

title: A Flying Giselle, Coming Right at You
description: Films of the two-act Romantic ballet Giselle go back almost 80 years. The clips of black-and-white silent film of Olga Spessivtseva (1932) and Margot Fonteyn (1937) used to be rare as gold dust; now you can see them on YouTube. The ancient film technology, however, makes anyone watching today frustrated by its obvious inadequacies. So its dismaying that the new Giselle in 3D, featuring one of the finest casts achievable today, makes even more basic cinematic errors. The performance, recorded at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, features Natalia Osipova, from the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, as Giselle amid an otherwise all-Mariinsky cast. The filming is by the British company Can Communicate, a title that turns out to be somewhat optimistic.

title: Pawlentys Playbook for Skipping Marriage Pledge
description: Heres a political puzzle: How do you decline to sign a pledge defending marriage if you are a Republican presidential candidate? Now, consider you need to win Iowa, where conservative voters have proven their affinity for candidates who are demonstrative about their faith. And those voters already have made it know that they feel that the candidates are focusing almost exclusively on the economy at the expense of social issues.

title: Summer Styles | Sirens
description: The hazy and humid days of summer are upon us, and it seems many are coming down with a case of scarlet fever. Rather than run around in barely there ensembles, women are wearing clothes that get attention for their vivid color. The English television presenter Fearne Cotton keeps things casual in cheery off-shades, while the actress Charlotte Poutrel goes glamorous and the model Karolina Kurkova dazzles in floor-length silk. The heat is on.

title: The Truths That Only Repetition Reveals
description: There was Mike Scheidt, the guitarist and singer from the doom-metal trio Yob, at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night. He was playing a pattern, long-form and superficially simple. Doom tends to stay slow and precise; he cycled a few chords, or sometimes only one, over and over.

title: Dump Your Printer to Escape the Madness
description: First, we kill all the printers.

title: Arias With a Twist to Return to New York
description: Arias With a Twist, a night of song, dance and leggy life-sized puppets created by the performer Joey Arias in collaboration with the puppeteer Basil Twist, will return to New York for a four-week run at the Abrons Arts Center beginning Sept. 14.

title: NBC Names Jennifer Salke Its Entertainment President
description: NBC filled a long dormant top spot in its entertainment division Wednesday when it announced that Jennifer Salke would join the network as president of entertainment.

title: Readers Favorite Local Drinks
description: The Times asked readers on Facebook to share their favorite local drinks, like the Mexican Martini of Austin, Tex. Beers, cocktails and spirits are all eligible. Below are a few highlights; add yours to the mix in the comments section below.

title: Do You Use a Big Green Egg?
description: When I lived in Atlanta in the late 1980s, I learned to cook Thanksgiving turkeys, Fourth of July pork shoulders, and Sunday night burgers on the Big Green Egg. When I moved to Oxford, Miss. in 1995, I had to leave my Egg behind. It wouldnt fit in the moving truck.When my mother in law, Marley Hobbs, age 88, moved two doors down a couple years ago, she saved enough room in her moving truck for her Egg. Of late, Ive been borrowing hers more frequently, while pondering the purchase of a Primo, one of those glossy black oblong models. Sure, theyre expensive. But, after reporting my story on them, I want one more than ever.

title: Pact on Adoptions Ends a U.S.-Russian Dispute
description: MOSCOW  More than a year after an adopted-child abandonment scandal led Russian officials to threaten a ban on adoptions of Russian children by Americans, the United States and Russia have reached an agreement that will allow such adoptions to proceed under heightened scrutiny.

title: Daytime Show About Women Isnt Soap Opera
description: There is sweet surrender in watching the American soccer team at the Womens World Cup. Its a daytime television event that forces viewers to set aside routine tasks  and attitudes built up over a lifetime.

title: The Cloyne Report
description: Report by Commission of Investigation into the handling by Church and State authorities of allegations and suspicions of child sexual abuse against clerics of the Catholic Diocese of Cloyne.

title: Sniffing Out a Diamond Ruse, Then Finding a Steppingstone
description: Bridge Base Online broadcasts the best bridge from around the planet. But the toughest job is arranging commentators, experts who type about the bidding and play as it occurs.

title: Foursomes Boundless Musical Map
description: Brooklyn Rider has found a handful of fascinating ways to keep its repertory both fresh and broad. Its involvement with Yo-Yo Mas Silk Road Project has helped this quirky string quartet understand musical styles beyond the Western mainstream and has put it in contact with potential collaborators who play non-Western instruments. Because a couple of the quartets members compose and arrange, they can supplement commissions from other composers with works of their own. And every now and then the group fills out its playlist the old-fashioned way: by looking back at the conventional repertory and spending some quality time with, say, a Mozart quartet.

title: New Service Offers Music in Quantity, Not by Song
description: Daniel Ek, the 28-year-old co-founder and public face of Spotify, the European digital music service, paced around the companys loftlike Manhattan office on Tuesday afternoon, clutching two mobile phones that buzzed constantly.

title: Keys to Easier iPad Typing
description: While the iPad is great for reading, its not quite as good for writing, unless you are exceptionally skilled with the virtual keyboard. The obvious answer is to add a real keyboard, which a number of companies are happy to provide.

title: Judge Halts Landmarks Alterations
description: A state Supreme Court judge has ordered renovations halted at a landmark office building at Fifth Avenue and 43rd Street that preservationists call a model of modernism. A former bank that was originally part of the Manufacturers Trust Company, it was designed by Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in the era of the gray flannel suit.

title: Union Leaders Give Players Support to Play Overseas
description: If the locked-out N.B.A. players choose to take their talents overseas, they will do so with the spirited support of their unions leadership.

title: Q&A: Sending Certain File Types (or Not) By Gmail
description: Q.

title: Horseplay for the Staid Mariinsky
description: The Mariinsky Ballet, which many of us remember as the Kirov, is generally known as the elevated, refined, instructive, grand, and most serious of ballet companies. It has often danced its 19th-century ballet repertory with a peculiar mixture of mannered authority and unspontaneous condescension. Yet in Alexei Ratmanskys 2009 version of The Little Humpbacked Horse, its positively frolicsome, fresh as a daisy, endearingly friendly, cute as can be, bubbling over with high spirits and even giggly.

title: As Clemenss Trial Begins, Government Details Its Evidence
description: WASHINGTON  Opening statements in the perjury trial of Roger Clemens, one of baseballs greatest pitchers, began on Wednesday in federal court, with the government insisting it had overwhelming proof that Clemens lied when he told Congress that he never used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Track Your Stolen Hardware With These Apps
description: In light of the recent arrest of a TSA agent at the Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International airport who is said to have stuffed a passengers iPad down his pants, now might be a good time start thinking about tracking your hardware on the road.

title: G.O.P.s No-Tax Stance Is Outside Political Mainstream
description: The back-and-forth of the debt limit negotiations can be perplexing. But the facts driving the debate are quite straightforward. Any deal, or any workaround to a deal, will need to be approved by a majority of the House of Representatives. The Republicans in the House of Representatives are extremely conservative on fiscal matters and are significantly out of step with the public as a whole. Given that Democrats continue to control the Senate and the White House, and that their votes may be necessary in the House as well, this makes compromise nearly impossible.

title: On Debt, Death, Taxes and Temperatures
description: A few days ago, I had a short e-mail exchange with Vaclav Smil, a master analyst of risks and resources, on strokes and aging, climate policy, the global debt crisis and a few other light subjects. Ive excerpted our chat below in the form of a dialogue.

title: Galleon Case Figure Settles With S.E.C.
description: Danielle Chiesi, convicted of insider trading as part of the case against the Galleon Group hedge fund, agreed to pay $540,000 to settle related allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: The Voice of a GPS Device on Your Phone, at a Price
description: App shopping is a fairly painless diversion, thanks to all the $1 programs on the market. But in one important category, voice-guided navigation for drivers, the stakes are higher. You can spend $70 on one, or you can take your chances with something cheap or free.

title: Shooting Twice, at Once
description: When shooting stills and video simultaneously, Doug Mills, a staff photographer in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, has tried a creative trick or two. He once strapped the video camera around his neck, using his stomach to hold it in place. The results, he said, were freewheeling and dangling and very difficult to work with.

title: Calls for Congress to Investigate the Conduct of the News Corporation
description: Public criticism of the News Corporations conduct in the British hacking scandal has crossed the ocean to the United States  and crossed the floor to the Republican side  as half a dozen members of Congress urged the government to investigate possible misconduct, including violations of a law that guards against foreign corruption.

title: Import Prices Fall for First Time in a Year
description: Prices of goods imported to the United States fell in June for the first time in a year as oil and food expenses retreated, the Labor Department said Wednesday.

title: Secrets of a Garlic Grower
description: DIXON, N.M.

title: Shopping for Bottle Openers With Iacoli & McAllister
description: The partners behind the Seattle product design firm set out to find appealing tools for uncapping bottles.

title: Bottle Openers
description: ON hot, sticky days, theres something reassuring about having a bottle opener close at hand: you will not be locked out of liquid refreshment. But a distinctive opener goes beyond the mechanics of removing bottle caps, adding something extra to summer festivities.

title: An Antiques Store Docks at Sag Harbor
description: La Maisonette, a new antiques store in Sag Harbor, offers an industrial setting  polished concrete floors and walls painted sea blue and misty gray  for French and Belgian antiques.

title: The How-Tos of House Painting
description: EVERY summer, thousands of homeowners entrust their homes to college-age painters, possibly on the theory that if youre smart enough to matriculate, you can smear paint on a flat surface. Seriously, how could you mess it up?

title: Sales on Gus* Modern, Steuben and More
description: Steuben is discounting some pieces up to 30 percent, through Friday (the Bamboo bud vase, originally $750, will be $525; the Petal Cut ice bucket, regularly $600, will be $420); 667 Madison Avenue (61st Street), (800) 783-8236 or steuben.com.

title: For a Famed Los Angeles Architect, a Day of His Own
description: John Lautner settled in Los Angeles in the late 1930s, spending much of his career there and designing some of the citys most celebrated examples of modern architecture. Now the city is recognizing the life and influence of the architect, who died in 1994, on what would have been his 100th birthday, by declaring July 16 John Lautner Day.

title: Tyler Florence on His Kitchen of the Year
description: Tyler Florence is used to wearing many different hats: hes not just a chef, hes a Food Network TV personality, a columnist for House Beautiful magazine, a restaurateur, a cookbook author and the owner of his own chain of kitchen stores in Northern California. And next week, Mr. Florence will be in New York showing off his skills in another food-related discipline: kitchen design.

title: A Table of Patchwork Walnut
description: Jason Roskey, a furniture designer who runs the Brooklyn company Fern with his wife, Maggie Goudsmit, started out as a visual artist making mixed-media pieces and collages. And the Orchard low table, his latest creation, seems to reflect that: the tabletop has what he calls a patchwork construction of salvaged claro walnut from orchards in Northern California.

title: Houses Made of Sticks and Stones
description: Meticulously and gorgeously wrought, Clark Sanderss stone house and straw-bale structures in the Catskills are his calling cards.

title: A History of Design Gets an Update
description: The second edition of A History of Design from the Victorian Era to the Present (W. W. Norton; $50) is being published this week, more than four decades after the first edition. The new book, by Ann Ferebee and Jeff Byles, is a capsule history of design in a nutshell, with all the major players and the major pieces, said Nancy Green, the editor of both editions (the first was published by Van Nostrand Reinhold, in 1970).

title: In the Catskills, Building Stone by Stone, Bale by Bale
description: EAST MEREDITH, N.Y.

title: Jawbone Will Sell a Health-Tracking Bracelet
description: Jawbone, a company best known for its line of sleek, futuristic-looking Bluetooth headsets and music accessories, is taking a big leap away from the audio industry.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Piracy and Hacking
description: Internet service providers and the music and movie industries are joining forces to fight copyright infringement. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Ben Sisario, a Times media reporter, about a new joint effort to crack down on downloads of pirated content with repeated warnings for offenders and eventually, tougher measures, like slowed-down connections and blocked browsing.

title: Girl Power Wins at Googles First Science Fair
description: If Googles first science fair is any indication, the top scientists of the future will be women. Google has announced the fairs winners, and they are all young women.

title: With Boys Killing, Parents Confront Worst Fears
description: They are the road rules of parenting, the self-defense tips of childhood, the maxims passed down for generations: Dont talk to strangers. Dont sit in the last car of the subway train. If you are lost, look for someone in a uniform. If something bad happens, scream!

title: Baseball Gets Records on Pitchers Procedure
description: Major League Baseball officials said Wednesday that they had finally received copies of medical records for a novel stem cell procedure that Yankees pitcher Bartolo Colon underwent in the Dominican Republic last year to help his ailing shoulder and elbow.

title: Issues Holding Up Debt Ceiling Agreement
description: Issues holding up debt ceiling agreement.

title: Tablets Continue to Dent PC Sales
description: Modest growth returned to the computer industry in the second quarter following a dip earlier this year, although consumer appetite for tablets continued to dampen demand for desktop and laptop PCs.

title: Phantoms of the East River
description: Fast, sleek, elegant  can anyone tell me what that is? our guide calls out, pointing at the sky. We have just pulled out of New York Harbor, wind lifting the flaps of our purses and murses, the financial district glittering at our backs.

title: TimesCast | Three Bomb Attacks on Mumbai
description: Three bomb blasts shook the city of Mumbai at the height of the evening rush hour, killing at least 20 people.

title: The Republican Case for Compromise
description: North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: New Thai Government Is Delayed by Legal Challenges
description: BANGKOK  Efforts to form a new government in Thailand are being snarled by a docket of legal challenges and what critics say are the slow workings of the countrys Election Commission.

title: Clouds Around Karzai Darken the Road Ahead
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At midday, the glare and dust obscures Afghanistans horizon in what seems a metaphor for the position of the Afghan president as political and economic crises mount on every front: it is increasingly hard to see how he will find his way.

title: A Murdoch Discount in News Corp. Stock
description: Rupert Murdochs political influence may be surpassed by his impact on the value of the News Corporation. The stock routinely trades more cheaply than media rivals, largely because the company, which is listed in the United States, is run at Mr. Murdochs whim. As a result of the British phone-hacking scandal, the Murdoch discount has widened to 30 percent.

title: President Hints at Fresh Start for Sudan, but Many Are Skeptical
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  It is a grand title, carrying the suggestion of a new era, a new dawn. Now that the southern part of Sudan has split off and formed its own nation, many politicians here in the north, including President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, have a new way of referring to what remains of their country. They call it the second republic.

title: N.C.A.A. Inquiry of Auburn Isnt Over, Exchange Reveals
description: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C.  Last month, when athletic officials from the Southeastern Conference met in Destin, Fla., the annual gathering had an eye-popping moment.

title: Private Equity Princes Reach Deal for 76ers
description: A group led by Joshua Harris, a co-founder of the private equity firm Apollo Global Management, announced late on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to buy the Philadelphia 76ers basketball team from the sports company Comcast-Spectacor.

title: Battle For Libya | July 13, 2011
description: Hospital staff dealt with rebel casualties in Zintan, Libya, while schoolchildren learned the Tamazight language in Yafran.

title: Some Rural Lawmakers Defy Power Erosion
description: RITZVILLE, Wash.  State Senator Mark Schoesler might seem a marginalized man at first glance. In this ever bluer state, he is deep red Republican. In his dusty hometown here in rural eastern Washington, the population is in perpetual decline and Main Street resists revival. Although it has been nearly 20 years since Mr. Schoesler became a state lawmaker, fewer and fewer of his colleagues in Olympia, the capital, have a clue about what he does for a living.

title: A Loss That Hurts, but Not Too Much
description: The Yankees were able to win 14 of 18 games with Derek Jeter on the disabled list because Nick Swisher thrived and Robinson Cano flourished and Eduardo Nunez emerged and Mark Teixeira slugged. And yet none of their regular players hit better during that three-week stretch than Alex Rodriguez, who batted .356.

title: Amazon Takes On California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazon, the worlds largest online merchant, has an ambitious and far-reaching new agenda: it wants to rewrite tax policy for the Internet era.

title: Austria: Anthem to Undergo a Wording Change
description: The main political parties in Parliament agreed to change the lyrics of the national anthem within several months to include a reference to women. After decades of debate, one passage of the text is expected to be altered from the current Home you are to great sons to Home of great daughters, sons. The move must be formalized by a parliamentary vote in the fall.

title: Judge Delays Decision on Bulgers Girlfriend
description: BOSTON  Prosecutors insisted that Catherine Greig actively helped James (Whitey) Bulger evade capture for 16 years, despite knowing his criminal past. The defense countered that Ms. Greig was a kind and simple woman who had been tightly controlled by Mr. Bulger and deserved to be released on bail.

title: Rebels Briefly Lose Control of Western Libyan Town
description: QAWALISH, Libya  Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi counterattacked and briefly recaptured this front-line town from opposition forces on Wednesday, but they were beaten back by a large rebel force late in the day.

title: Yankees Fans Generosity Is Returned, With $50,000 to Ease His Debt
description: A week ago, Christian Lopez was living an unremarkable life. He had a job, a girlfriend, a significant student loan debt. Then fate (he retrieved Derek Jeters 3,000th hit) and choice (he simply returned the ball to the Yankees shortstop) changed all that.

title: All-Star Game Viewership Hits Low Point

title: For Carl Andre, Less Is Still Less
description: THE work of Carl Andre, one of the only Minimalists to accept the term, is often as barely there as sculpture can get. In the first book to survey his ascetic half-century career, a maximalist doorstop published this month by Phaidon, the art historian Alistair Rider relates the story of a German artist who enthusiastically sought out Mr. Andres work at a gallery in 1967, only to become confused when he couldnt find it. This was because the work, 100 square plates of hot-rolled steel arranged in a rectangle almost completely covering the gallery entryway, was directly beneath his feet. He had mistaken it for the flooring, a mistake that comes with the territory in Andre country, where art  as Mr. Andre has said  gets perilously close to zero, meant to be experienced as much with the body as with the eyes and mind.

title: Holbein Sells for More Than $70 Million, Says Dealer
description: A German billionaire has paid more than 50 million euros ($70 million) to buy an oil painting of the Madonna by Hans Holbein the Younger, Bloomberg News reported. Reinhold Wuerth, a manufacturer of screws and other industrial hardware, bought the painting from the heirs of the princes and landgraves of the state of Hesse, according to an e-mailed statement sent Thursday by Britta Fischer Public Relations on behalf of the Wuerth Collection, Bloomberg reported. The Staedel Museum, where the painting has been displayed since 2003 on long-term loan, said in a statement that it had tried to buy the work itself, but that its offer of 40 million euros ($57 million) was rejected. Christoph Graf Douglas, the art dealer who handled the sale, would not give the final purchase price but said it was more than 50 million euros. The painting, The Madonna With the Family of Mayor Meyer, from 1525-28, depicts the mayor of Basels familyto whom it belonged for nearly 100 yearsat the feet of the Madonna.

title: 36 Hours in Bar Harbor, Me.
description: THERE are summer resorts that get busier and more chic over the years. And then there are the ones, like Bar Harbor, Me., that feel deliciously frozen in time. Dont look for Starbucks, McDonalds or Ralph Lauren here. Fashion shoppers stop at places with names like Cool as a Moose. Carmen Verandah and the Thirsty Whale are among the evening hot spots. Bar Harbor is the largest town on Mount Desert Island, and nearby Acadia National Park encompasses some 50 square miles. The rest of Mount Desert belongs to residents and a tony array of summer tenants: Brooke Astor summered here, as did myriad Rockefellers and, once upon a time, the town of Northeast Harbor had so many Philadelphia families that it was dubbed Philadelphia on the rocks. They all came lured by the striking setting of mountains, woodlands, lakes and ocean waves crashing against granite cliffs. Then and now, Mount Desert has served as a glorious nature camp for biking, hiking and boating. At days end, a visitor can cozy up with a blueberry beer and lobster. Evening strollers can watch sailboats drop anchor and the mist slip down over the hundreds of islands that dot the water.
