title: At the Table, Like Father, Like Son?
description: My boyfriend of five years, with whom I try not to nitpick, has terrible table manners. He eats standing up, with his fingers, and picks food off my plate without permission. When I raise the subject, it results in hurt feelings and no improvement. Then I spent time with his family: His dad eats the same way. Since my boyfriend finds his fathers table manners gross, would it be helpful to point out their similarity?

title: After Rent Rise, Time to Pull Up Stakes
description: NOT all that long ago, rental prices were low enough for Jeni Aron to afford an alcove studio in a luxury doorman building, Hudson Crossing, on Ninth Avenue and 37th Street. She enjoyed a nicely furnished lobby, a landscaped patio, a storage room for her bicycle and a 24-hour gym that she used early in the morning.

title: Republican Attacks Persist for Consumer Bureau
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans threatened Thursday to roll back the scope and authority of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau even before it officially opens for business next week.

title: Was It Love? The Manacled Mormon and His Kinky Weekend
description: By virtue of its title alone, Tabloid, Errol Morriss astonishing new documentary, achieves a degree of serendipitous timeliness. Mr. Morris, as usual unseen, though occasionally heard shouting questions from off screen, trains his prying, voracious eyes on England in the 1970s. It was a time ripe with newspaper sleaze that offered premonitions of the present day, even as the prevailing vices, carnal and journalistic, may seem quaint by current standards.

title: The Guilty Pleasure of a Drive Through Central Park
description: Go through the park, Dudley Moore slurs to his chauffeur in the 1981 film Arthur, his character giddy and drunk and in need of simple and profound pleasure. You know how I love the park.

title: In Sunny Rome, Solving a Murder Involves Sharp Suits and Sexy Talk
description: Michael Dibdin, the British crime novelist and professional Italophile, died four years ago, having left behind 11 novels centered on Aurelio Zen, the stylish Venetian detective whom he dispatched throughout Italy to solve murders typically executed against the backdrop of political corruption, Mafia wrongdoing and aristocratic entitlement.

title: The Appeal of Adjustable Rates
description: THE 30-year fixed-rate loan has earned its reputation as the sensible, conservative move in the aftermath of the financial crisis, especially with near-low interest rates. But despite risks, some borrowers still are getting or keeping adjustable-rate loans, which have even lower rates.

title: Rupert Murdoch Defends His Company and His Son
description: In an interview with The Wall Street Journal, a newspaper he owns, Rupert Murdoch defended the way his son James has handled the phone-hacking scandal and said that News Corporation had responded to the misconduct by its tabloid journalists extremely well.

title: Burdened in a Ravaged South Africa
description: Life, Above All, a grave and quietly moving story about a South African girl of extraordinary character, does something that few painful dramas accomplish: It tells a tale of resilience without platitudes about the triumph of the human spirit or without false promises about an unclouded future. The battle fought by its 12-year-old heroine, who struggles to save her family and best friend from prejudiced neighbors who often look like a mob, may be over when the movie comes to its stirring close, but theres no end to the fight.

title: Nathan Lane to Star in The Iceman Cometh in Chicago
description: Nathan Lane will play one of the stages great dramatic characters  the doomed salesman Theodore (Hickey) Hickman  in the Goodman Theaters revival of Eugene ONeills Iceman Cometh in spring 2012, the Chicago-based theater announced on Thursday.

title: Signs of Improvement in Age-Restricted Market
description: STARTING in 2009, the bottom fell out of the age-restricted housing market in New Jersey, as people 55 and older made the decision to age in place rather than try to sell their longtime homes in an uncertain real estate environment.

title: More Wall Street Banks Grab Groupon I.P.O.
description: Wall Street is lining up for a piece of Groupons initial public offering.

title: Porches Reclaim Their Place
description: UNTIL recently, Lynn Hock, a designer with an architectural degree, was a midcentury modernist  definitely not an old house person, she said. But that changed this spring when, after years of looking for a home in the Hudson River village of Hastings-on-Hudson, she and her husband, Jonathan Hock, a documentary filmmaker, walked up the steps of an 1851 Gothic Victorian with a broad, welcoming porch laced with gingerbread trim  and fell in love.

title: Condemning Slavery With a Paintbrush
description: Misinformation has spread widely about Robert S. Duncanson, an African-American painter. Before and during the Civil War he specialized in portraits of abolitionists and landscapes as exotic as Roman ruins and Kashmir glades. Art historians rediscovered him in the 1920s, but soon muddied his biography with legends and typos.

title: Illustrating Damsels in Distress and Emissaries From Our Deep, Dark Ids
description: Mayor La Guardia was appalled. Out for a walk one day in Manhattan in 1942, he happened upon a store displaying a copy of a periodical called Spicy Mystery. In lurid hues and slashing graphic style, its cover pictured a curvaceous, terrified young woman in a partly shredded dress hanging by bound hands from a hook alongside slabs of meat. She was menaced by a demented, knife-wielding brute of a man who looked back over his shoulder at whoever was holding the gun that cast its shadow on him. Shocked and dismayed, the mayor vowed to ban all such scurrilous literature from his fair city.

title: Building New, Looking Older
description: OYSTER BAY

title: Earle S. Altman
description: Mr. Altman, 79, is the chairman and a founder of ABS Partners Real Estate, a brokerage, management and consulting firm that also invests in commercial property.

title: Q & A
description: Personal Liability of Board Members

title: Harmonies From Outer Space
description: There was a time when a cappella was one of musics best-kept secrets. Relatively few people were aware of just how sophisticated the genre had become or how many sounds the best a cappella singers could draw on: not just standard notes, but vocal percussion, orchestral imitation and more.

title: Keeping Score: Sizing Up Trade Needs in the A.L. East
description: For the last three seasons, the Red Sox, the Yankees and the Rays have jockeyed among themselves for the American League East title and the A.L.s wild-card berth, with each team missing the playoffs once. In 2011, these three teams are again atop the East, with the Red Sox leading at the All-Star Game break and the Rays having the most ground to make up.

title: Always Moving, Always Frozen
description: In those rare lulls when theres no live dance to see in New York  summer brings a few  theres still dance in its galleries. At the Metropolitan Museum, I start on the ground floor with the Hellenistic bronze of a veiled and masked dancer, less than nine inches tall. A masterpiece of implication, it firmly shows, by means of surface alone, the lines and twists of the dancing figure beneath layers of fabric. At the Museum of Modern Art, in Matisses painting La Danse, five nude women create an image of primeval dance as they circle before an empty blue sky and a green grass sward.

title: Opera Star Tries Doin What Comes Naturlly
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.

title: Taking a Look at the Governor, Back When He Was a Democrat
description: Gov. Rick Perry, a no-apologies conservative known for slashing government spending and opposing all tax increases, is about as Republican as you can get.

title: News Corp. Hires Top Criminal Defense Lawyer
Prime Suspect: Returning to the Source
description: The pursuit of happiness is relentless on American television. Even the most willful, irascible loners find true love in the end. Brenda, the bossy and single-minded homicide detective played by Kyra Sedgwick on The Closer, got married. Mary, the misanthropic United States Marshal played by Mary McCormack on In Plain Sight, is expecting a baby.

title: Intense Drama, Via the Catwalk
description: Although summer is considered the off season for New York theater, theres always plenty to see from Memorial Day to Labor Day. Hair is back, swinging its free-loving tresses on Broadway, where Maria Callas is also giving life lessons courtesy of Terrence McNally and Tyne Daly in Master Class. Visiting Britons from the Royal Shakespeare Company are mounting five full-scale productions at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: A Festival With a Lot of Wiggle Room
description: I try never to let a summer go by without spending some quality time at Tanglewood. But as much as I enjoy the atmosphere (and most times, the performances) at the Boston Symphonys weekend concerts at the Koussevitzky Music Shed, for me the most stimulating programming is the annual Festival of Contemporary Music, now held at Seiji Ozawa Hall.

title: Nobody Wins the Debt Default Blame Game
description: The chances of a default on the United States debt are still fairly small. The prices for credit default swaps, financial instruments that pay investors in the event that a default happens, imply just a 0.05 percent chance, or 1-in-2,000, of a default occurring within the next year, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Riding in Cars With Music
description: Get me to my car, stat. Windows down. Sun roof back. Radio blaring, damaging the already tender speakers. Its where music sounds best, where a new song jumping out of the radio can be enough to put nearby drivers at risk. Two a.m., F.D.R. Drive, Make It Rain bouncing off the car frame  thats when things make sense.

title: N.B.A. Lays Off 11 Percent of Workers
description: More than 100 N.B.A. employees were laid off this week, heightening the sense of economic distress as the leagues owners and players haggle over a new labor agreement.

title: A Few Hours for the Best of Youth
description: One of the perks of my job is that I get a lot of free DVDs in the mail, and one of the frustrations is that there is never enough time to watch them. This summer, though, I am determined to find a few hours for Zazie Dans le Mtro. This 1960 Louis Malle film, released by the Criterion Collection in June, is one of the movies that made me who I am today.

title: A Great Guide (Apologies to Its Author)
description: Pauline Kael died 10 years ago this summer, only a few days before 9/11; most remembrances of her were lost in the haze and fury. Ive been thinking about Kael a lot recently, missing her bawdy and crackling voice, wondering what shed say if she were alive to weigh in on, say, Black Swan or The Social Network. (I suspect shed have smacked both around, while finding things to enjoy about David Fincher and Aaron Sorkins work in the Facebook movie.)

title: The All-American
description: John Kerry surprised a lot of people when he endorsed Barack Obama for president in early 2008. Kerry was a longtime friend of Obamas chief rival, Hillary Clinton. He had served in the Senate for a quarter-century and had built a reputation as a cautious, incremental figure  like Clinton herself. But for Kerry the time had come for a decisive break with the past. I felt very strongly we needed a new narrative for the country, he told me during a long conversation last fall.

title: An Artist Shows His Train of Thought
description: It has become something of an annual tradition at the Matthew Marks Gallery to invite one of its artists to organize a summer exhibition, and this year it is Thomas Demand. He has taken over the gallerys West 22nd Street space in Chelsea, reconfiguring it with an installation of labyrinthine walls based on a drawing by the artist Martin Boyce and presenting a show opening Tuesday called La Carte dAprs Nature.

title: A House Tour for Cinephiles
description: When he arrived in Los Angeles, the architect John Lautner said that he was so shocked that he was physically ill for a year. It was so ugly, he said of the city where, for the next 50 years or so, he nonetheless built some of the most celebrated buildings of the 20th century.

title: 4 Charged in Smuggling Egyptian Antiquities
description: Federal authorities announced on Wednesday that they had broken up an international ring that had been smuggling Egyptian antiquities into the United States. The Immigration and Customs Enforcements Homeland Security Investigations department said it was the first time that a cultural property smuggling network had been dismantled in the United States.

title: Taxi Fare for the Uncommon Man
description: Having seen Simon Russell Beale memorably embody the most noble of princes (in the title role of Hamlet), the baddest of all lieutenants (as Iago in Othello) and the most fatuous of fops (in Dion Boucicaults London Assurance), I am looking forward to his portrayal of someone to whom superlatives do not apply. Thats Jimmy MacNeill, the willfully anonymous London taxi driver of Bluebird, a 1998 play by Simon Stephens receiving its American premiere this August in an Atlantic Theater Company production.

title: $4 Million Welcome for Lynch at Bank of America
description: Gary Lynch, the former chief legal officer at Morgan Stanley who decamped to Bank of America this year, received a stock award worth approximately $4 million from his new employer, a regulatory filing showed.

title: BIRGIR ANDRESSON AND POUL GERNES: Bolt Out of the Blue
description: Sean Kelly Gallery

title: Walkout Sours Global Whaling Conference
description: A meeting of the International Whaling Commission ended in disarray on Thursday when Japan and its allies used the most basic of procedural maneuvers to kill a proposal to protect whales in the southern Atlantic: they walked out.

title: LEIDY CELESTE NICOLE
description: Museum 52

title: House Tour: Greenport, N.Y.
description: A city couple used their instincts, travels and professional background to salvage a rundown North Fork property.

title: KATHERINE BERNHARDT, ALFRED JENSEN, CHRIS JOHANSON, CHRIS MARTIN, ANDREW MASULLO ANDJUDITH SCOTT
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: House Tour: Greenport, N.Y.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom house on a tiny waterfront lot.

title: HAAS & HAHN: Painting Urbanism:Learning From Rio
description: Storefront for Art and Architecture

title: Why Is Contemporary Art Addicted to Violence?
description: Well-meaning laments about violence in the media usually leave me wanting to bash someone upside the head with a tire iron. To begin with, the reformist spirit is invariably aimed down the rungs of cultural idioms, at cartoons, slasher films, pornography, rap music and video games, while the carnage and bloodletting in Shakespeare, Goya and the Bible get a pass. Low-culture violence is literal, while high-culture violence is symbolic or allegorical and subject to critical interpretation. Low-culture violence coarsens us, high-culture violence edifies us. And the lower the cultural form, or the ticket price, or  lets just say it  the presumed education level of the typical viewer, the more depictions of violence are suspected of inducing mindless emulation in their audiences, who will soon re-enact the mayhem like morally challenged monkeys, unlike the viewers of, say, Titus Andronicus, about whose moral intelligence society is confident.

title: For 9/11, a Flag and a Day of Service
description: Members of Congress on Thursday made stitches in part of the National 9/11 Flag, a torn and discolored American flag that hung at the World Trade Center site in the weeks after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: EVERYTHING MUST GO
description: Casey Kaplan

title: For Justified, No Best Drama Nod but No Complaints
description: Justified, the Kentucky crime drama on FX, is appearing on various Emmy snub lists, but dont expect to hear any complaining from Walton Goggins, the excitable actor who plays a cagey ex-con on the series.

title: CATCH THE MOON IN THE WATER: Emerging Chinese Artists
description: James Cohan Gallery

title: Biggest Coal Company and Coal Country Collaborate on Mega Mine
description: A newly announced partnership between the worlds biggest private coal mining company and coal-burning country cuts against recent efforts to paint China green because of its push on manufacturing wind turbines and solar panels. All of its efforts on renewable energy come atop ongoing expansion of its use of coal.

title: McCartney at the Plate
description: When the Beatles played at Shea Stadium on Aug. 15, 1965 (and again on Aug. 23, 1966), I was a little puzzled, maybe even a little miffed, at their choice of location. As an 11-year-old I had what I figured was a clear idea of what was right and proper, and to me the spanking new Shea Stadium was the home of the Mets, an upstart team that seemed destined forever to inhabit the basement in the National League standings, and not, therefore, the kind of place that deserved the Beatles magic. As I saw it, the Beatles were to music as the Yankees were to baseball, and if they were going to play at a baseball stadium, Yankee Stadium was the place for them.

title: A Brazilian Master of Genre Mixes
description: The Brazilian songwriter Tom Z doesnt make a habit of performing in New York or in the United States. The last time he toured was in 1999, backed by the Chicago instrumental band Tortoise. And theres no one like him in Brazilian music or, for that matter, anywhere. So its a coup that the Lincoln Center Festival has booked him for a concert at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday.

title: Authority, From God to Dad
description: The first and only time I saw The Tree of Life, Terrence Malicks solemn contemplation of God, family and creation, the mostly older audience at the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas remained as silent and motionless as a church congregation rapt in prayer. I quickly adjusted to the reverential mood of a film whose monumental images of erupting volcanoes and churning seas, as many have observed, recall Stanley Kubricks 2001: A Space Odyssey.

title: The Conductor Will Also Direct
description: The main reason I am looking forward to the Mostly Mozart Festivals production of Don Giovanni is that the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer and the Budapest Festival Orchestra are top-notch Mozart performers. The orchestra was formed in 1983 by Mr. Fischer and the brilliant pianist Zoltan Kocsis, who recruited talented, eager and adventurous young Hungarian musicians.

title: Visiting the Original Birdland
description: It has not escaped my attention that birds are some of the greatest musicians in the world. One afternoon last year in Washington Heights, I stopped for a while to listen to a little songbird up on a street lamp, throwing down a long and miraculous series of patterns in what sounded like changing keys: ol, you poet, you beast. Best thing I had heard all week.

title: For Dark Skies, a Dark Show
description: One of the most pleasurable summer vacations I ever had was spent in an early-19th-century farmhouse in Westport, Mass., one week in August some years ago, when the rain was so blessedly relentless that I had no choice but to watch the first three seasons of The Wire, virtually without interruption. Id come with a file full of recipes and big shellfish ambitions, but once I was introduced to the Barksdales, McNulty, Omar, Bunk, the Baltimore waterfront and Hamsterdam, cooking seemed like a dismal waste of time.

title: A Who Is It? More Than a Whodunit
description: The Chameleon fictionalizes an especially colorful chapter in the believe-it-or-not true story of Frdric Bourdin, a French-born serial impostor and master of disguise who assumed scores of identities, especially those of missing teenagers. The movie focuses on one of his alter egos, Nicholas Barclay, a 13-year-old Texan from a working-class background who vanished without a trace in 1994 and reappeared three years later.

title: A Prescient Novel Retains Its Power
description: A decade after 9/11, its worth rereading Don DeLillos 1997 masterpiece, Underworld, to appreciate how uncannily the author not only captured the surreal weirdness of life in the second half of the 20th century but also anticipated Americas lurch into the terror and exigencies of the new millennium.

title: The Me My Child Mustnt Know
description: On a recent weekend morning, I set out with my son to do errands. As we drove from the post office to the health food store, he began fiddling around with the radio, looking for NPR. I reached over and turned it off. He turned it back on. I turned it off again. He shot me a look, puzzled. After all, he knew I enjoyed the fact that, at age 12, he was a fan of public radio.

title: Saluting a Radio Man Whos One of a Kind
description: He put us all on the map. Without his support, youd be looking at an empty stage.

title: At the Met, a Canvas Ahead of Its Time
description: The one thing I want to do this summer is swing by the 20th-century galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and spend some time with Strasse auf Helgoland II, a nearly abstract street scene painted in 1924 by the Romanian artist Arthur Segal (1875-1944), who was affiliated with everything from Post Impressionism to Cubo-Futurism, with German Expressionism and Dada in between. Glowing, dramatically shaded geometric planes in tones of brown, blue and green extend outward to cover a wide and ersatz wood frame in this astute and irreverent synthesis of modernist tendencies and tics. It never fails to jolt my eye or remind me that art history is essentially nonlinear and full of overlooked treasures awaiting rediscovery.

title: His Horizontal Life
description: Randy Kennedy narrates a look at three ground-hugging works by the Minimalist sculptor Carl Andre.

title: Past Meets Present in Walk After Dark
description: Middle of the night is my time, always has been, especially in New York in the summer. The city looks better, sounds better, feels softer, or at least a little less specific. I think and remember better late, or imagine I do.

title: Fed Chief Hedges Remarks on Possible New Stimulus
description: A day after he helped lift markets with his testimony, Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, tempered his words. And in reaction, the markets, too, pulled back.

title: Materials and Their Space
description: A look at the work of the Minimalist artist Carl Andre.

title: Up Front: Laura Kipnis
description: In books like Against Love: A Polemic and How to Become a Scandal, Laura Kipnis has combined sharp analysis with blistering wit to challenge prevailing notions about love and sex, power and desire, hubris and retribution in American life. On our cover this week, she reviews The Art of Cruelty, by Maggie Nelson, a wide-ranging inquiry into the aesthetic and ethical questions raised by images of brutality in our culture.

title: An Unlikely Pair, Making Musical Sense
description: Anton Bruckner had a steadfast circle of supporters, including some significant conductors and composers. But, as his obituaries in 1896 made clear, he was more widely seen as a strangely solitary Austrian church musician with oversized ambitions whose sprawling symphonies were earnest yet awkward and self-indulgent works. Bruckner faced setbacks and adversity, and feared that his music would never be appreciated.

title: An Evangelist, an Atheist and an Act That Tests Faith
description: The American culture war, that combustible, stupefying cocktail of religion, sex, politics and everything else that gets people hot and bothered, represents a rich vein of satiric and dramatic potential. George Ratliffs Salvation Boulevard, adapted from a novel by Larry Beinhart (Wag the Dog), suggests that it may sometimes be too rich. The movie, set in and around a Sun Belt megachurch with a charismatic pastor, is a console full of jammed and disconnected hot buttons.

title: BHP Billiton to Buy Petrohawk for $12.1 Billion
description: 9:16 p.m. | Updated

title: The Hot List: A Single Pleasure Ere Summer Fades
description: Just one thing, you tell yourself, as the summer slips by like so many summers before it. If you manage to do nothing else for your own pleasure in this season of unclaimed hours, you will read that book, see that movie, watch that show, gaze at that painting, listen to that guitarist. Even people who do these things for a living  the New York Times arts critics  cant always organize their cultural calendars to include what they most want to do. We asked them to share the single item in, or closely related to, their critical discipline at the very top of their summer bucket list. Here are their selections.

title: A Desolate Croon That Seethes and Hints at a Bands Next Phase
description: Maynard James Keenan works in mysterious ways. He juggles three bands: Tool, Puscifer and A Perfect Circle, the one he brought to Hammerstein Ballroom on Wednesday night. Hes a frontman who stays out of the spotlight: on a platform separate from the rest of the band, set back on the stage, lighted so that he is just a silhouette. And he tours at whim. A Perfect Circles most recent album, eMOTIVe (Virgin), was released in 2004.

title: A Tree That Shelters Animal Life and Maybe Even a Dead Parent
description: Sadness and longing haunt the films of the French director Julie Bertuccelli, whose gorgeous second feature, The Tree, is set in Queensland, Australia, on the outskirts of Brisbane. Here, on the edge of the outback, the environment is so luminous that every outdoor shot has an aura of magical realism.

description: For Children

title: Interest Rate Stories
description: Something Ive been meaning to write: there are two different stories about why deficits might drive up interest rates. Theyre not at all the same  although members of the pain caucus have deliberately blurred the distinction. And for policy purposes its quite crucial to understand what were talking about.

title: Internet Use Affects Memory, Study Finds
description: The widespread use of search engines and online databases has affected the way people remember information, researchers are reporting.

title: Hundred Acre Gang Is Back in Town
description: It may be easiest to describe Winnie the Pooh, an ever so slight, entirely charming new Disney animated feature, by saying what it is not. It is not Cars 2.

title: Ties That Bind: Life-Sustaining Friendships Transcending Lifes Brutalities
description: For those who may have wondered if foot binding, wife beating and a crooning Hugh Jackman could fit into one movie, heres the short answer: no. At once preposterously genteel and sadistic, Snow Flower and the Secret Fan, adapted from the Lisa See novel, turns on two sets of female friends, the first in early-19th-century China, the second in modern Shanghai. What joins all four women, beyond filmmaking folly, is love, feet and the sort of extravagant misery that routinely turned movie theaters into rain forests, drenched with the tears of audiences and characters who were cinemas ladies of perpetual suffering.

title: Making Rating Shops Look Good
description: Mortgage securities destroyed the reputations of credit rating agencies. Could sovereign debt restore them?

title: A Kidnap Thriller Cuts It Close
description: A troubled marriage swerves toward catastrophe in Daylight, an unusually delicate psychological thriller that favors suggestion over exposition.

title: Seeking Your Harry Potter Photos
description: Can you show us your best Hermione? Your finest Dumbledore? Your slickest Snape? The final film in the Harry Potter series opens at midnight tonight and for fans, plenty of magic is likely to happen both onscreen and off. Are you planning to see the film and will you be dressing up? Were taking photo submissions of all the wizardly costumes you come across. Submit them to http://submit.nytimes.com/harry-potter.

title: Pakistan: Bail for Terror Suspect
description: A Pakistani court granted bail on Thursday to the person suspected of being the mastermind of a deadly 2009 attack on the Sri Lankan cricket team. The suspect, Malik Ishaq, left, had been kept in jail since 1997 on a series of terrorism charges, and he was showered with rose petals by hundreds of waiting supporters as he left prison. We will peacefully continue our mission, Mr. Ishaq told reporters, saying his hard-line Sunni group, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, would continue to pursue its anti-Shiite struggle through legislative means. The group is suspected to have been a central player in several terror attacks in the Punjab Province of Pakistan, and had been linked to the March 2009 attack, which killed six police guards and two bystanders in the eastern city of Lahore and halted international cricket competitions in Pakistan. The date for the trial has not been set.

title: A Kindhearted Man in a Small Town
description: Justin Lerners debut feature, Girlfriend, is set and shot in his Massachusetts hometown, and the story is built around a man in his 20s named Evan, a character inspired by, and played by, a local actor with Down syndrome, Evan Sneider. As you might expect, the film is eminently respectful in its handling of this kindhearted, sexually curious protagonist, at times irritatingly so, as when the camera goes coy and turns away to focus on autumn leaves during one particularly physical encounter.

title: Reprieve of Sorts in a Costly Blunder
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Cult of Running
description: Maybe youve been corralled by someone who wants to bend your ear for 90 minutes about his fantasy baseball team or his Hummel figurine collection, though youre not a fantasy baseball player or figurine collector. Such people seem not to grasp the cutoff point between Im willing to hear a little bit about your obsession and Youve gone on too long and entered a zone thats of interest only to other people like you.

description: To the Editor:

title: With Deal on Rookie Wages, N.F.L. Lockout Nears the End
description: An agreement in principle that would end the four-month-long N.F.L. lockout is within reach for the first time after negotiators for players and owners finally settled on a rookie wage system, clearing one of the last major hurdles that had separated the sides, a person briefed on negotiations said Thursday.

title: A Soldier and a Fractured Fairy Tale
description: Shot on 16-millimeter film out in the forest on what must have been a tiny budget, Alex Ross Perrys Impolex deploys the open-ended, low-affect style favored by many young do-it-yourself filmmakers to a grab bag of genres. Taking place just after World War II, it follows the wandering of a handsome, sulky young soldier named Tyrone (Riley OBryan) who has found a German V-2 rocket. The movies title is an acronym for the explosive-monitoring program in which he is participating, and its plot follows a thread laid down in Thomas Pynchons novel Gravitys Rainbow.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,647 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

title: Sluggish Market Stalls Funds That Thrive on Direction
description: Managed futures funds, which bet on the ups and downs of stocks, bonds, commodities and currencies, have been crowing for years about their performance during the financial crisis.

title: Exposing Industrial Agriculture
description: To the Editor:

title: Anarchists and Tasseled Loafers
description: Amid shattered glass and the black smoke of urban pyres, I found myself in a riot some years ago  the anarchists-led assault on the World Trade Organization meetings of 1999. At the height of what became known as The Battle of Seattle, I bumped into an otherwise mild-mannered, libertarian-leaning friend on the streets, gasping at the bitter taste of tear gas. He was ecstatic.

title: Just About Anything for Love
description: The unlikely convergence of an opportunistic blonde, a nerdy lottery winner and a clutch of missing persons forms the spine of Lucky, an off-kilter romantic comedy suggesting that women  like Meat Loaf  will do just about anything for love.

title: Provenge, a Prostate Cancer Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Tom Vander Arks New York-Area Charter Schools Falter
description: After years spent directing the distribution of more than $1 billion from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation into hundreds of schools across the nation, Tom Vander Ark set his sights on the New York area, with a plan to create a network of charter schools of his own.

title: The Caucus | Travels With John Kerry
description: John Kerry has carved out an important role in President Obama's foreign policy. James Traub profiles him in this week's Magazine and reflects on traveling overseas with the Senator.

title: Japanese Team Comes of Age, and Lifts a Country

title: The Insider | Paul Kominek
description: The Travel Almanac, the newest of a growing crop of compact niche magazines (see: Apartamento, Boat and Afterzine), looks at the art of travel through the perspectives of artists, musicians, writers and filmmakers who are well, well-traveled. The journal was founded two years ago by Paul Kominek, a musician and sometime D.J. from Germany, with the help of his friend John Roberts, an American musician who, like Kominek, lives in Berlin. By using the topic of traveling as an overarching theme, it gave us an amazing excuse to ask high-profile artists or cultural icons questions that avoid the obligatory What do you do? and How did you get started? and instead ask about different aspects of their lives that we personally find more interesting, says Kominek. The first volume, on Japan, debuted this spring. The cover is printed on textured German cardstock, the interior pages on creamy Swedish drawing paper. It features tips from the likes of David Lynch, James Murphy and Javier Peres, as well as some handsome photographs of traditional Japanese inns, called ryokans. title: Tale of a Puerto Rican Plantation Mistress
description: If the American South had Scarlett OHara as its Civil War antiheroine, the English-speaking Caribbean of the 1800s had Annie Palmer. The real-life mistress of a Jamaican sugar estate during the final days of slavery, Palmer was the subject of legend and many lurid novels, most enduringly 1929s White Witch of Rosehall. Lore says (most likely inaccurately) that Palmer practiced obeah, or sorcery; bedded slaves, then killed them; and murdered three husbands. She set the standard for cruelty and debauchery in a woman presiding over a plantation.

title: Inventing the Interstate
description: When On the Road was published, in 1957, it may have seemed a rousing dawn chorus for an awakening generation of postwar seekers, but it was also an encomium of sorts  for the year before, construction had begun on the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways. You cant do what I did anymore, Kerouac would later say. And as noted in Why Kerouac Matters, by the New York Times reporter John Leland, even as Kerouac was writing, the author glimpsed that his kind of rambling may soon be obsolete as America enters its High Civilization period and no one will get sentimental or poetic anymore about trains and dew on fences at dawn in Missouri.

title: How the Robber Barons Railroaded America
description: Type of the modern! emblem of motion and power! pulse of the continent! Walt Whitman sang in praise of the railroad. When he published those lines in 1876, the vast network that connected West to East was being widely hailed as the muscular marvel of the industrial age. It sped the bounty of farms and factories across the land, spawned hundreds of towns and cities along its routes, pioneered in marketing and managerial organization, and employed a huge and growing labor force. The men who created and ran the transcontinentals  Leland Stanford, Collis P. Huntington, Jay Gould, Mark Hopkins, Charles Francis Adams Jr., among others  were as famous in their era as such high-tech moguls as Bill Gates and Steve Jobs are today. Their entrepreneurial daring did much to transform the United States into a prosperous, developed nation.

title: Such a Slick Package, but Gearbox Is a Drag
description: TO the long list of things that have gone awry despite the best of intentions, add the 6-speed automatic transmission in the 2012 Ford Focus  an otherwise admirably redesigned compact car.

title: Blue Period
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#23", 592, 395, true, chameleonData);

title: Modern Dance, in Your Hand
description: DANCES for an iPhone began the way most dances dont: with an injury. But Richard Daniels, who at various times has worked as an arts administrator, a producer and a choreographer, was incapacitated and recovering from shoulder surgery in 2008 when the idea was born.

title: A Melancholy Werewolfs Existential Howl
description: Its easy to see why werewolves might feel under-celebrated these days. While vampires and zombies have stormed the multiplexes and best-seller lists, and Dr. Frankensteins monster has completed its cultural infiltration by transforming into the ubiquitous information appliances of daily life (if my smartphone doesnt count as artificial life run amok I dont know what does), werewolves have been largely left to idle at the side of the literary road. Where are these Freudian howlers of the night? Theirs has been rather a raw deal.

title: Opening the Doors to Serve a Good Cause
description: BUILDING a portfolio of vintage cars can put a collector in the same situation as a dog that chases cars: what do you do once youve accomplished your goal?

title: Chevy Convertibles: He Collected the Full Set
description: Ankeny, Iowa

title: In New York, the Suddenly Buff Prewar Building
description: THE apartment house at 815 Park Avenue, built in 1916, features classical swags on its facade, large arched windows and a softly lighted lobby hung with museum-quality oils in elaborate frames. Converted to a co-op some 30 years ago, 815 Park seems like the ultimate prewar apartment building, little touched by the passage of time.

title: Injured Romeo Undergoes Knee Surgery
description: Sam Troughton, the actor playing Romeo who was injured on Tuesday during the Royal Shakespeare Companys performance of Romeo and Juliet at the Park Avenue Armory, has undergone arthroscopic surgery on his knee, according to Nada Zakula, a spokeswoman for the company. She said she did not know if he would be able to return to the role on Sunday, when the next performance is scheduled. The play is being presented as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Solar Power for Darker Times
description: Amid the fretting over whether the renewable energy business will be dominated by foreign companies, a California venture that creates solar plants that can run around the clock has cut a deal to build a big plant in Spain, a country that is one of the most aggressive users of solar power.

title: An Alzheimers Mystery Novel
description: Unreliable narrators come in many shapes. There are madmen, mystics, seducers, nafs  Nabokovs Humbert Humbert, the ghost-prone governess in The Turn of the Screw and Poes self-defeating paranoiac in The Tell-Tale Heart, for starters. And then there is Dr. Jennifer White, who narrates Alice LaPlantes first novel. By the time Turn of Mind begins, she is losing her wits to Alzheimers disease and is the prime suspect in her best friends murder. She is as unreliable as they come.

title: SRTs Boss, Ralph Gilles, Mulls a Replacement for Dodge Magnum
description: ROSAMOND, Calif.  Could the station wagon make a comeback at Chrysler?

title: Missing Artworks Said to Be Found in Home of Accused Picasso Thief
description: A man who was arrested in the theft of a Picasso drawing from a San Francisco gallery last week was keeping a virtual museum in his apartment, including 11 works stolen from New York galleries and hotels, according to the police.

title: In Ukraine, Churches With a Distinctive Allure
description: IN western Ukraine, the side of the highway offers more unusual scenes than many performance-art pieces. On one spring day, an old woman cradled what looked like a baby but was actually a newborn lamb dressed in baby clothes. On another day, a young woman strutted down a dirt road in a micro-mini and precarious heels. Nearby, a pair of young dandies cruised in an ox cart.

title: Infidelity Keeps Us Together
description: Congratulations to Dan Savage and his mantra Good, Giving and Game. And thanks to Mark Oppenheimer for bringing it beyond the alternative weeklies to a wider audience of mainstream, heterosexual couples (Married, With Infidelities). Honest communication with your partner surely is something to strive for in a long-term relationship, although it may be difficult at first for some women to define what they want, let alone articulate it.

title: Devil in a Black Dress
description: Paz de la Huerta has an uncanny ability to attract enemies (and ghosts).

title: The Would-Be Prince of Port-au-Prince
description: Wyclef Jean was in a rare state: nervous. He was trying to stick to his new role of wonky Haitian statesman, but the road kept distracting him. We were driving through Port-au-Prince as dusk fell, and he would interrupt his own discourse on trade rules or egg imports to ask the driver why a fire was burning on the roadside or to complain that our headlights were tempting danger or to mumble that the police escort, which he suspected of working for the opposition, shouldnt sound its sirens.

title: Bonus Feature: The Very First No. 1 Song
description: Here we go with the Top 40 hits of the nation this week! These words, spoken by Casey Kasem, kicked off the first broadcast of American Top 40, which aired on July 3, 1970, and it was carried by seven radio stations. Kasem, who would become one of the most recognizable broadcasters of his era (as well as providing the voice for Shaggy on Scooby Doo), was the host of the show until 1988, when he was replaced by Shadoe Stevens. (Despite his name, Stevens was in no way affiliated with Scooby Doo.) Stevens remained until 1994, when ABC canceled the show; it was reborn, under a new owner, in 1998, with Kasem once again as host. Ryan Seacrest joined the show as host in January 2004.

title: Human Hairballs R Us
description: One summer Sunday years ago in Philadelphia, I stumbled onto the Mtter Museum. Back then maybe a few hundred people a year bothered to visit. A new director would soon parade human hairballs, pickled organs and Victorian surgical equipment from the museums collection on Late Night With David Letterman, and after that the Mtter joined institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Liberace Museum in Las Vegas as beloved American attractions. But that Sunday it was still empty and neglected, a little forbidding from the outside.

title: A Rats Tale
description: I was 6 when my brother John leaned across the kitchen table and casually whispered that he had killed Santa Claus.

title: Parental Guidance
description: Unable to have biological children, my husband and I went to an adoption agency and were matched with a pregnant woman. She says she signed up because she and her husband cant afford another child. Adoption will cost around $25,000, of which $8,000 goes to her. My conscience keeps asking me why I dont just give the $25,000 to the birth mother and let her take care of her own child. My rational mind says this was her choice, and we need each other equally. What do you say? NAME WITHHELD, CHARLOTTE, N.C.

title: Well, Here It Comes! The Biggest Song in the U.S.A.!
description: Can you name the No. 1 song right now?

title: July 17  23
description: Art

title: Who Made This Mess of Planet Earth?
description: The Australian paleontologist and biologist Tim Flannery has earned his broad-brimmed field hat. Flannery is the discoverer of dozens of mammal and dinosaur species, extant and extinct, across Australia and Melanesia. In books like The Future Eaters (about the devastation wrought by the settlement of Australia) and The Weather Makers (about climate change), he has won accolades as a vivid chronicler of ecological history with an uncommonly broad sweep and an increasingly activist bent.

title: Are Parents Too Involved in Childrens Sports?
description: One of the best parts of summer is getting children outside and active. The head-butting march of the United States womens soccer team this particular summer underscores the power of getting physical.

title: After 8 Decades, Tiny Toad Resurfaces in Asia
description: The Borneo rainbow toad, with its long spindly legs, looks a bit like an Abstract Expressionist canvas splattered in bright green, purple and red. But when this amphibian was last seen, in 1924, the painter Jackson Pollock was just 12, and the only image of the mysterious creature was a black-and-white sketch.

title: From Honus to Derek, Memorabilia Is More Than Signed Bats
description: THE best birthday present I ever received came from my wife. She gave me a baseball from the 2009 World Series signed by Derek Jeter, the New York Yankees shortstop. I treasure it because hes my favorite player but also because my newborn daughter slept in my arms while I watched the Yankees win that World Series.

title: This Unit Definitely Has a Purpose
description: Remember the book The Purpose Driven Life? A new division of a major public relations agency is being driven by purpose.

title: Time-Travel Adventure to Save the Life of Doctor Who
description: SALFORD, England  The 15 schoolchildren knew they werent in danger, but theater still worked its magic as they spied the six-foot-tall stone monster behind them in the corridor of a spaceship. When the dusky lighting went black, and a pulsing strobe light began to illuminate the monster closing in, they let out a collective shriek and fled through a portal that, mysteriously, opened onto a tented fairground where a sign announced the date: 6 July 1888.

title: Is There a Perjury Epidemic?
description: James B. Stewart dedicates his new book to all who seek the truth. But in his view, the ranks of committed truth-seekers are shrinking before our eyes. Mounting evidence suggests that the broad public commitment to telling the truth under oath has been breaking down, eroding over recent decades, a trend that has been accelerating in recent years, he declares. Perjury has infected nearly every aspect of society.

title: After Test Results, European Banks Are Urged to Bolster Reserves
description: LONDON  About two dozen European banks were put under official pressure Friday to bolster their reserves, as the results of financial stress tests created more skepticism over the regions will to deal with its festering financial crisis.

title: Novelist John Banville, also known as Benjamin Black; Esmeralda Santiago on her new book, "Conquistadora"; notes from the field; and best-seller news.
description: This week, a conversation with novelist John Banville, who also writes crime fiction under the name Benjamin Black; Esmeralda Santiago on the setting and characters of her new book, "Conquistadora"; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Living In | Bushwick, Brooklyn
description: Bushwick takes its name from the town the Dutch established in 1660, Boswijck, or heavy woods. Annie Monguea and Irving Elgodo on Harman Street in front of the the Pa-La Loma Bicycle Club.

title: A Call to Play Ball in Japan Followed Much Fretting
description: SENDAI, Japan  High school baseball players across Japan dream of playing for the national title in Koshien Stadium, yet few ever go. Teams from Tohoku High School  a sports powerhouse whose alumni include Yu Darvish, the best pitcher in Japan, and Kazuhiro Sasaki, the former closer of the Seattle Mariners  expect to go. They have made 40 trips to the tournament, but have never won.

title: Rupert Murdoch Apologizes to Victims of Phone Hacking
description: Updated | 1:44 p.m. Since, remarkably, Rupert Murdochs personal letter of apology for the phone hacking scandal will run in its pages as a full-page ad on Saturday, The Guardian has obtained the complete text and posted it online.

title: London Theater Journal: Aging, Acting and Acting Up
description: One of the pleasures (and pains) of going to the theater for many years is watching actors get older and grow up - or not, as the case may be. Take Rupert Everett. The rakish, indignantly handsome Mr. Everett made his mark in theater 30 years ago in his early 20s in Julian Mitchells Another Country, portraying a rebellious child of privilege with an aristocratic profile and a smoldering case of the sulks. As time passed, whenever Mr. Everett (who became a minor film star) returned to the theater, he continued to portray much the same person, but in a state of arrested development, like the drug-addicted, mother-fixated son in Nol Cowards Vortex (1989) or a debonaire middle-aged but boyish Charles Condomine in Cowards Blithe Spirit, on Broadway two years ago.

title: Margaret Drabbles Complete Stories
description: The discursive spaciousness of Margaret Drabbles voice and vision lends itself to the long form, as her 17 splendid novels demonstrate. This may help to explain why her complete short stories make up so slender a volume. Drabble, it seems, just didnt have enough time to write short stories (with apologies to Mark Twain). Of those collected here, 14 in all, the earliest dates from the 1950s, the most recent from the 1990s. Some are reed slim, but many glimmer with the irony, lyricism, moral vision and (despite their page counts) amplitude we associate with Drabbles novels. They reflect back to us the last half of the 20th century, albeit in Drabbles often 19th-century voice.

title: The Vanguard Alights
description: THIS sprawling neighborhood in northern Brooklyn was one of the boroughs first European settlements, and has been known for many things over its long history: for its farms, then for its breweries and factories, then for the blight and crime that descended in the decades after those employers closed.

title: Weekend Fare
description: This Sunday marks the first of the New Amsterdam market specials, an occasional series that will bring chefs and food purveyors to New Yorks original market district, located at the Old Fulton Fish Market on South Street and Peck Slip in Lower Manhattan. From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the market, Russ & Daughters will sell the short-seasoned Hollandse Nieuwe, or New Catch Holland Herring, with traditional garnishes: chopped raw onion and cornichons ($8). P&H Soda Company will sell house-made soft drinks ($3) to accompany the herring, and for dessert, Marja Samson is making poffertjes ($5), a traditional Dutch street food. Starting at noon, Pasanella and Son (115 South Street, across the street from the market) will pour small, complimentary shots of aquavit.

title: After Ecclestone, the Future of Formula One According to Whitmarsh
description: Last weekend we published an interview with Bernie Ecclestone, the commercial boss of Formula One, on topics such as the digital future of Formula One and the future ownership of the series at a time when there are bids in the air.

title: After Ecclestone, the Future of Formula One According to Whitmarsh
description: Last weekend we published an interview with Bernie Ecclestone, the commercial boss of Formula One, on topics such as the digital future of Formula One and the future ownership of the series at a time when there are bids in the air.

title: C.F.D.A./Vogue Fashion Fund Finalists Announced
description: The Council of Fashion Designers of America and Vogue have announced the finalists for this years C.F.D.A./Vogue Fashion Fund award.

title: Compromise in Minnesota Is Quick Fix on Budget
description: For days, the Democratic governor of Minnesota watched his states shutdown drag on, but insisted that, on principle, he could not go along with Republican lawmakers plans for the states budget.

title: Poetry Chronicle
description: FLIES  By Michael Dickman.  Copper Canyon. Paper, $16.

title: Paperback Row
description: NINE LIVES: In Search of the Sacred in Modern India,  by William Dalrymple (Vintage Departures, $16.) Dalrymple explores the stupefyingly diverse religious world of the subcontinent through interviews with nine remarkable individuals, including a Jain nun ritually starving herself to death; a mystic who inhabits a cremation ground, drinking from skulls; and a sculptor of Hindu idols who believes he is creating live deities.

title: A Girls Postcards From Italy
description: Picture books that involve and engage young readers in the experiences of people packing up their lives and heading off to a new country, a new culture, a totally new way of living have always interested me. Perhaps because my own Italian grandparents did exactly that in the early 1900s. My father was born in Fall River, Mass., only a month or two after his parents settled into their new home.

title: How to Be a Bicultural Schoolgirl
description: Lets call them the original Gossip Girls. In Cristina Garcas first young adult novel, three wealthy and adventurous ninth-grade girls from different worlds converge upon a Swiss boarding school for a summer of discovery. Vivien Wahl is the Miami-reared daughter of a Jewish Cuban exile father. Shirin Firouz is from Tehran, the treasured girl and math genius in a family of older brothers. Ingrid Baum is a bad girl queen bee from Canada, the daughter of German immigrants.

title: Bookshelf: America
description: THE CROSSING  By Donna Jo Napoli. Illustrated by Jim Madsen.  40 pp. Atheneum. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

title: Story of an Evangelical Girlhood
description: Lacey Anne Byer, the heroine of Melissa Walkers Small Town Sinners, is a born good girl: the 16-year-old daughter of the childrens pastor at the House of Enlightenment, an evangelical church in a working- and middle-class enclave in the South  something like Dillon, Tex., in Friday Night Lights. Lacey even has a Tyra-like spitfire, a girl named Starla Joy, and a lovable Landry-like geek, Dean, for best friends.

title: Editors Choice
description: ABSOLUTE MONARCHS: A History of the Papacy,  by John Julius Norwich (Random House, $30.) Norwich, a writer of popular histories, finds that the truly great popes were outnumbered by the corrupt, the inept, the venal, the lecherous and the mediocre.

title: Inside the List
description: ADVANCE MAN: A few weeks ago, I promised to eat my complete Harry Potter library if A Dance With Dragons, the eagerly awaited fifth installment in George R. R. Martins Song of Ice and Fire fantasy series, didnt enter the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. Thats probably still a safe bet, though I did wonder if I should start firing up the barbecue after it was reported that Amazon Germany had accidentally shipped some 180 copies of Dragons ahead of the strict July 12 publication date, thus imperilling Martins carefully orchestrated siege of the global book market. (This weeks list reflects sales through July 9, though let it be noted that Dragons went into its sixth printing based on pre-orders alone. Charge!)

title: Appeals Court Upholds Building Ban on Architect
description: A Manhattan appeals court upheld a decision on Thursday that essentially prevents the famous  to some, infamous  local architect Robert M. Scarano Jr. from doing business in New York.

title: Sorkin to Co-Host CNBCs Squawk Box
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin, the best-selling author and columnist at The New York Times, has been hired by CNBC to be the co-host of the morning financial show, Squawk Box. Here is the internal announcement from his editor in the business section, Larry Ingrassia:

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell Repeal Isnt a Quick Fix
description: Very soon, the military will signal that it has prepared itself for the repeal of the dont ask, dont tell policy. This policy, in effect since the early days of the Clinton administration, allows gays and lesbians to serve as long as they do not identify themselves as such in public. Before signing the repeal into law, President Obama asked the military to take a reasonable amount of time to teach and train its soldiers about the policy changes. The military responded with a goal of training all currently serving soldiers by July 15. So far, that training has been delivered to nearly 95 percent of the military. Repeal could be final by the fall.

title: The Jam | Nguzunguzu
description: The third installment of Sean Hanrattys summer playlist is brought to you by the Los Angeles producers (and former violinists) Daniel Pineda and Asma Maroof, a k a Nguzunguzu. The group, which takes its name from a traditional Solomon Island figurehead used to protect against supernatural forces during canoe trips, offers a unique blend of R&B, house, cumbia and tribal music. They are known for improvising with, well, really weird sounds achieved through electronic instruments and a room full of synthesizers, as well as for an energy that Hanratty says is incredible. Pineda and Maroof, who have worked closely with the Sri Lankan songstress M.I.A., recently kicked off a tour with Gang Gang Dance and Total Freedom, and will be at Santos Party House on Thursday, July 21. (They are rumored to be playing theCapsule after-party on Monday, July 18!?)

title: Chevys for All Seasons, Especially Summer
description: Dennis Albaugh of Ankeny, Iowa, has amassed what may be the definitive collection of open-top Chevrolets.

title: Brave New World Thats as Familiar as the Machine It Fights With
description: I have played the future of mobile gaming. It is called Shadow Cities.

title: Is the Six-Man Rotation Here to Stay?
description: In 1972 the Los Angeles Dodgers bucked seven decades of baseball precedent and added a fifth starting pitcher to their rotation. The quintet of Don Sutton, Claude Osteen, Al Downing, Tommy John and Bill Singer portended the future, and by the end of the decade the once revolutionary five-man rotation was adopted leaguewide.

title: Downtown Theater to Take a Chance on Celebrated Cymbeline
description: Commercial theater producers seeking to make money off Shakespeare usually stick to tried-and-true audience draws like Hamlet or Macbeth, but even those can be financially risky without a celebrity in the title role. (Last seasons critically acclaimed Merchant of Venice, starring Al Pacino, narrowly turned a profit.) Next month, however, a group of commercial producers will try to make a go of Cymbeline, one of Shakespeares trickier tragic romances  though with a staging that received strong notices from  critics this winter.

title: Reader Favorites: Your Twitter #fiction5
description: Well, well have to agree to disagree: Lolita, which finished first in the survey of the magazine staffs favorite fiction books, only managed to eke out 11th place on Twitter. Last week, after publishing our original post of our favorite fiction, we asked you to weigh in on Twitter under the hashtag #fiction5. Jer Thorp, the data artist in residence at The New York Times, gathered 4,500 tweets that used the hashtag #fiction5 over the following few days. He compiled the list below of your Twitter picks and presented us with the top contenders.

title: Lead in New York Tap Water Is Back to Normal
description: The proportion of homes in New York City with elevated lead levels in their tap water is back to normal, city officials said this week, but all residents are still urged to run their tap water for at least half a minute before drinking or cooking with it.

title: White Flight From the Nursing Home
description: The number of older Americans living in nursing homes continues to fall, and the proportion of residents who are black, Hispanic or Asian has climbed sharply. But dont expect cheers from the Brown University researchers whove tracked this major shift in long-term care.

title: As the Clock Runs Down, the Taylors Look Back On Friday Night Lights
description: For almost all of the critically lauded but ratings-challenged run of Friday Night Lights  which ends Friday on NBC  clear eyes and full hearts couldnt win with Emmy voters.

title: Bound in a Gay Union by a State Denying It
description: IVE never had perfect timing. When New York finally legalized same-sex marriage last month, I had just gotten out of my lesbian union and married a guy.

title: Long Story Shortlist: Rockets, Robots and Aretha
description: For the second week running, weve collected the best long-form journalism in The Times. A new shortlist will be posted every Friday afternoon on The 6th Floor blog, as well as on our Longreads page. If you follow #Longreads on Twitter, youll be able to find our picks that way too.

title: Twitter Messages Land Broker in Trouble
description: Stock brokers are on notice to watch what they tweet.

title: Consumer Watchdog Is All Ears for Ideas
description: If you want to try your hand at playing regulator, nows your chance.

title: Icahn, a Deal Maker With a Spotty Record
description: Carl C. Icahn may have bid $10.2 billion for Clorox. But as his letter to the consumer products company makes clear, he is not necessarily interested in owning the detergents maker.

title: Google Offers Marketing Ideas, by the Book
description: Google seems to be able to do just about anything, at least if the robust earnings report the company issued on Thursday is any indication. So perhaps it is not surprising that Google is also getting into the business of writing e-books.

title: House Votes to Block Funds for Light Bulb Standards
description: The House on Friday voted to withhold funding to enforce part of a 2007 law that increases efficiency standards for light bulbs.

title: Blurred Vision
description: The redesigned Ford Focus includes some promising touches, but is undermined by a balky transmission.

title: How to Build a Better Regulator
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I look at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureaus efforts to become a sort of open-source regulator, where consumers help make the rules and suggest tweaks to regulatory works in progress.

title: Newark Museum Gets $1 Million Grant for African Art Collection
description: The Newark Museum has received a $1 million grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to support initiatives related to its African art collection. The grant will allow the museum to hire a new assistant curator, doubling the size of its African art department, and to engage additional scholars for research, the museums director, Mary Sue Sweeney Price, said in a telephone interview.

title: DealBook Portraits: Elizabeth Warren
description: Once a Wall Street lawyer, Elizabeth Warren was selected by President Obama to set up the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. She talks about her work to organize the bureau amid heavy opposition.

title: The Wrong Perversity
description: Ryan Avent is upset, rightly, at the way that Obama keeps invoking the confidence fairy, in effect buying in to the doctrine of expansionary austerity  even as a growing body of research grinds what little plausibility the doctrine had into dust.

title: Valuing Baseball Memorabilia
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about the market for baseball memorabilia. In the wake of Derek Jeters 3,000th hit, he was trying to understand the market for signed baseballs and bats, jerseys and photos. What sorts of items appreciate? And, he asked, how do you know if what you have is valuable?

title: DealBook Portraits: Elizabeth Warren
description: Elizabeth Warren has spent nearly a year setting up the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The all-consuming project has led her to meet with dozens of politicians and bankers from every state.

title: Summer Cherry Season, Short and Sweet
description: The season for summer cherries is as brief as it is sweet. But if you find yourself with an abundance of cherries this month, Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to enjoy them.

title: Designers Revisit Copyright Protection
description: Lets see here. On Wednesday, ABS by Allen Schwartz began selling a series of royal-wedding-inspired dresses that includes a fairly good copy of the Alexander McQueen gown worn by Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, for $1,100. That same night, Representative Bob Goodlatte, a Virginia Republican, reintroduced legislation seeking to grant copyright protection to designers, presumably discouraging exactly that kind of knockoff fashion. And on Friday, the Proenza Schouler designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez went to Washington to plead their case before Congress.

title: Complete 2011 Fantasy Football Rankings
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: He Sexts, She Sexts More, Report Says
description: THE GIST Women are more likely to sext than men.

title: Embracing the One-Piece, Beyond the Pool
description: THE Australian native Rose Byrne has been acting since she was 13 years old. A regular on the television drama Damages, which is now on DirecTVs Audience Network and which had its fourth-season premiere on July 13, Ms. Byrne is having a banner summer at the box office. Shes a cast member in the comedy Bridesmaids and X-Men: First Class. Ms. Byrne turns 32 on July 24.

title: Photo Replay: July 15
description: The day in sports included a hole in one at the British Open by Tom Watson, swimming in Shanghai and surfing in South Africa.

title: Protesters and Police Clash in Amman
description: Supporters of Jordans government have attacked antigovernment protesters to stop them from gathering in a main square in the capital.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Ghost Stories
description: Theres major turnover on the manga list this week with eight new additions. Only Naruto, a regular of the list, and Vampire Knight, about an academy whose evening students are creatures of the night, remain from the previous week. Ive had difficulty reading manga: the traditional right-to-left layouts often confuse me and many series that are at Volume 50 or higher make me feel late to the party. Of the new books this week, Dengeki Daisy has a Ghost or Sixth Sense vibe to it. The series is about Teru Kurebayashi, who after the death of her brother has been receiving comforting messages from the mysterious Daisy, who communicates through her brothers cell phone. Spooky! Volume 5 enters our list at No. 8 this week.

title: The Caucus | Debt Talks and Voters
description: July 15, 2011 - Jeff Zeleny on political positioning as debt talks becomes increasingly contentious. Also, James Traub reflects on traveling with John Kerry for his Magazine profile of the senator.

title: For Hasidim, First Call for Help Often Isnt to 911
description: The call from the missing boys mother came in at 6:14 p.m. on Monday, not to the citys 911 hot line or to the local police precinct, the 66th, but to a gritty tire repair shop on a desolate stretch of Wallabout Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Summer Movies: Some Have a Blast
description: Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. Here they discuss summer movies great and not, Michael Bay and le cinema du popcorn. You can write them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Caucus Video: Politics and the Debt Negotiations, Reflections on Traveling With John Kerry
description: Jeff Zeleny on the political positioning as debt negotiations becomes increasingly contentious. Also, James Traub reflects on traveling with John Kerry for his magazine profile of the Massachusetts senator.

title: Pitchfork: Measuring the Growing Debate

title: Letters: The Siren Call of Cuba
description: To the Editor: Re the July 10 Practical Traveler column (New Ways to Visit Cuba, Legally): For years, my architect husband has yearned to visit Cuba for its artistic heritage. As a playwright, Id like to go to experience firsthand the Cuban ethos. We have no interest in tourist traps or in political machinations. As travelers who like to create our own agenda, the thought of visiting lock-step with a gaggle of folks on a tour program makes us cringe. We certainly are not equipped to overthrow any government, so we are at a loss to understand why we cant just choose our form of transit and travel to Cuba, bringing back sketches and snapshots and memories. Someone, please explain why we are kept from doing this. Anne Russell Wilmington, N.C.

title: Asked & Answered | Raf Simons
description: The Belgian designer Raf Simons named his three-day mini-festival Transmission to convey how the participants convert the dynamic contradictions and contagious energy of Berlins creative scene into art. Transmission is the first installment of The Avant-Garde Diaries, a series of Mercedes-Benz sponsored cultural events to be curated by Simons that the car company will host in cities all over the world. For Berlin, Simons selected a group of artists who are inspired by the city but who are not necessarily based here, including the graphic designer Peter Saville, the industrial designer Konstantin Grcic, the Scottish dancer and choreographer Michael Clark, the British writer Jo-Ann Furniss, These New Puritans (a band from Southend-on-Sea), the Belgian artist Peter de Potter and New Yorks very own Fischerspooner. Transmission also features a sampling of Simonss favorite horror films. The show is physically situated in the Berlin Congress Center, with events running from noon to midnight. Theavantgardediaries.com, a digital magazine, will broadcast the key events for non-Berliners and introduce readers to the artists involved. Simons sat down with The Moment just hours before the opening to discuss Berlins significance as a contemporary creative hub.

title: The Minimalist: Chicken Salad With Skordalia
description: The Greek dip skordalia is most easily described as eggless mayonnaise, but its so much better than that. Unlike real mayonnaise  an emulsion of egg (or just yolk), vinegar and lots of oil  skordalia consists mainly of nuts, with just a little oil and moistened bread, or potato, as a binder. Pure these ingredients with garlic and stock or milk (the latter is creamier, obviously), and you end up with a thick, silky and, most importantly, intensely flavorful sauce thats terrific with crudits.

description: In an interview in May, back when Jerry Seinfeld was finally getting around to launching his official Web site, this standup and sitcom star told The New York Times that his joining Twitter was about as likely as his running out of offbeat observations on airline travel: Thats stand-up with a net, Mr. Seinfeld said at the time.

title: U.S. Reruns Visa Lottery After Computer Error on First One
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department on Friday published the results of a new lottery to give residents visas to 55,000 foreigners around the world, running the drawing for the second time after a computer error forced officials to cancel the first one.

title: Harry Potter and You
description: We asked and you shared. Readers from around the world have submitted their Harry Potter photos. Check out a photo gallery here. Were still looking for fan photos, so please submit them here.

title: A View Inside King Kongs Perch
description: I am pressing against a secure wall, not daring to step away. The wind is whipping against me  or is it howling? My feet feel rubbery on the narrow walkway. I think of those balconies on the upper floors of colonial homes in old ports, where pacing wives would gaze out to sea, seeking the long-overdue ships of sailor husbands: widows walks. If this particular walk were open to an anxiously pacing public, I can only imagine how many new widows and widowers would be left behind. But I look out, and the vision is literally breathtaking, the Hudson shimmering in the west, and a patch of green off to the north  Central Park  lying just beyond some half-hearted high-rises.

title: When Cricket Was a Symbol, Not Just a Sport
description: AMERICANS would sooner watch a spelling bee than a cricket match. No, really: ESPNs broadcast of the Scripps National Spelling Bee draws an average of four million viewers, while the networks online coverage of 2011 World Cup Cricket generated some 1.3 million hits here. So what does that bode for a politics-ridden documentary about a cricket team  from the West Indies, no less, a part of the world that most Americans associate with pia coladas, not postcolonial politics?

title: A Concept Is Minimal. The Works Sure Arent.
description: Franz Welser-Mst and the Cleveland Orchestra have taken up residence at Avery Fisher Hall for a series  part of the Lincoln Center Festival  called Bruckner: (R)evolution, in which Bruckner symphonies are juxtaposed with works by John Adams. It is an odd pairing, built on Mr. Welser-Msts interesting assertion that Bruckner is the grandfather of Minimalism.

title: The Songs of Now Sound a Lot Like Then
description: ONCE pop music was something by which you could tell the decade, or even the year. But listening to the radio nowadays is disorienting, if youre searching for a sound that screams, Its 2011!

title: Battle for Libya | July 15, 2011
description: The United States formally recognized the rebel leadership in Libya as the countrys legitimate government on Friday.

description: There has been a flurry of headline-grabbing developments in the slow-moving financial and fiscal crises on both sides of the Atlantic.

description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reviews the 2012 Ford Focus, the first all-new Focus since the 2000 model year.

description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Haul: Big Money From Big Donors
description: Twenty-seven fund-raisers collected more than $500,000 each in contributions for President Obama and the Democratic Party in the past three months, helping Mr. Obama collect a record haul of campaign cash as he starts his re-election effort.

title: Best Way Not to Win a Pious Mans Heart? Dance of the Seven Veils
description: Since 1896, Oscar Wildes Salome has provided opportunities for lush decadence  and who could object?  with its despotic voluptuary King Herod and the petulant title character. Now the Flea Theater is presenting a production of the play by the Black Moon Theater Company that teeters between a severe modernism and Wildes baroque verbal flourishes.

title: Bloggingheads: Obama and Taxes
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Tim Carney of the Washington Examiner debate the politics of taxes.

title: CBS Edges Rivals
description: CBS eked out a victory as the top-rated network on Thursday night as 6.5 million viewers tuned in to Big Brother at 9 p.m., more than any other program on the night, according to Nielsens estimates. ABCs Wipeout had an audience of 6.4 million at 8, but ABC was second for the night over all. CBS also drew 6.4 million viewers at 10 for a repeat of The Mentalist, while it broadcast back-to-back reruns of its sitcoms The Big Bang Theory (6.3 million) and Rules of Engagement (4.9 million). Fox was third with So You Think You Can Dance at 8 (5.2 million) followed by a repeat of Glee (2.9 million), and NBC finished fourth with low-rated comedy reruns and Love Bites at 10 (2 million).

title: Cain Raised $2 Million and Contributed $500,000
description: Herman Cain raised $2 million during his first quarter as a presidential candidate, according to his campaigns Federal Election Commission filing.

title: Republicans Hold Up Vote on Extension of F.B.I. Term
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations plans for Congress to smoothly extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller III as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are derailing, raising an outside chance that he may have to step down temporarily early next month.

title: Clashes, Some Deadly, Intensify in a Tumultuous City in Central Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Fighting between security forces and armed opposition tribesmen intensified on Friday in the city of Taiz. At least seven people were killed, including a high-ranking security official, in yet another sign of the breakdown in stability that has been pushing Yemen to the brink of chaos.

title: The Revolution Is Not Over Yet
description: Tunis

title: Catching Counterfeiters, a Real Cat-and-Mouse Game
description: The salesman found a bit of shade on the corner of Hester and Baxter Streets in Chinatown and waited. Not for long. A young woman approached, and he pulled a dog-eared pamphlet from the pocket of his cargo shorts.

title: How Clergy Helped a Same-Sex Marriage Law Pass
description: Early in the week that ended with New York enacting same-sex marriage, the Rev. Anna Taylor Sweringen stood in a hallway just outside the State Senate chambers. She wore her clerical collar and held a sign saying, Equality now. Around her gathered ministers and rabbis of similar sentiment, all in Albany to lobby and pray for the right of gay couples to wed.

title: Food Companies Act to Protect Consumers From E. Coli Illness
description: The federal government has spent years considering whether to take steps to help keep dangerous strains of E. coli bacteria out of the food supply, a question that has become even more urgent in the face of a deadly wave of E. coli sickness that swept through Europe and raised alarms on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: A Bad Economy Could Harm House Republicans
description: If you are a Republican trying to keep your job in Congress, your feelings about President Obama notwithstanding, would you rather the economy be better or worse?

title: Hes a Con Man With a Heart of Gold
description: There are several plays battling it out in Tryst, at the Irish Repertory Theater. Trouble is, none have enough oomph to win the fight. Part melodrama, part thriller, part comedy and part romance, the script wanders through the genres, offering a story thats frequently interesting yet ultimately unfocused.

title: Pitchfork: Tune-Yards and EMA
description: CHICAGO  The first two saxophones of the Pitchfork Music Festival belonged to Merrill Garbus, a k a Tune-Yards. The sax matters now more than it has at any time since the recently departed Clarence Clemons was at his peak. But unlike some of her kitsch-minded contemporaries, who use the instrument to connote post-wink post-irony, Ms. Garbus makes her sax players work, using their meaty lines to thicken her one-woman ukulele-and-drums-and-howls cornucopia. Hers is hard, muscular, construction-site soul, and the frenzied saxophones behind her highlighted how much sweat making this music generates.

title: No Jail Time in Trial Over N.S.A. Leak
