description: BALTIMORE  A former spy agency official accused of leaking classified information to a newspaper walked out of court a free man on Friday, sentenced to a years probation and community service, after hearing the judge excoriate the government for its handling of the case.

title: Plenty to Say at the British Open
description: SANDWICH, ENGLAND  They came in by the dozens to the press tent on Friday at the British Open. A sampling of what they said:

title: No Matter How Debt Debate Ends, Governors See More Cuts for States
description: SALT LAKE CITY  The rancorous debate in Washington over whether to raise the federal debt ceiling is alarming many of the nations governors from both parties, who fear that whatever the outcome, much-needed money will almost certainly be drained from their states.

title: Only a Few More Yards to Cover for N.F.L. and Players
description: After a flurry of deal-making over a two-day span, the N.F.L. is on the verge of a new labor agreement with its players, with just a few ancillary issues left to be settled, a person briefed on the negotiations said Friday. It was a good day, the person said.

title: Los Angeles Puts It in Park as Freeway Project Starts
description: LOS ANGELES  In an atmosphere that veered from summer-camp giddy to dark anxiety, Los Angeles began Friday evening to close down 10 miles of one of its most storied and heavily traveled highways, Interstate 405, in a construction project that will test whether this region can, for a weekend, change the highway habits that have defined it for more than 50 years.

title: On the Street | Voil
description: The French house of Louis Vuitton simply changed the colors of its popular winter brown-check bag to ivory and beige  and a summer success was born.

title: Held in Document Theft, Americas Presidential Historian Faces New Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON  Barry H. Landau, author and well-known presidential memorabilia collector, displayed his connections like pearls on a necklace.

title: A Whole Different Pitch for the U.S.
description: FRANKFURT  Pia Sundhage has sought to motivate the United States womens soccer team less with classic speeches than with classic rock.

title: Foreclosure Protesters in Spains Cities Now Go Door to Door
description: MADRID  When the police arrived recently to evict Mara Jos del Coto Maeso, 53, they found the street in front of her ground-floor apartment crowded with protesters, and they retreated.

title: A Book Party for the Dead
description: The big names on the invitation for a book party at the St. Regis New York hotel were all dead. Salvador Dal, Alfred Hitchcock and Diana Vreeland had once lived or lived it up here on East 55th Street, we were told. Had they been among the guests on Wednesday at a party for the release of It Happened Here by Lesley M. M. Blume, a book chronicling the St. Regiss creative history, they would no doubt have reveled again.

title: John C. Truesdale, Labor Relations Board Chief, Dies at 89
description: John C. Truesdale, who rose from field investigator to executive secretary and ultimately chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, died on July 3 in Martinsburg, W.Va. He was 89.

title: For a Bereft Street Corner in Queens, a Red-Letter Day
description: The dominant physical presence in Jackson Heights, Queens, is the elevated No. 7 train over Roosevelt Avenue, but many residents have become familiar with a couple of smaller, whimsical neighborhood features.

title: Blundering Toward Recession: Beyond the Debt Stalemate
description: Catastrophic. Calamitous. Major crisis. Self-inflicted wound. Those are some of the ways Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has described the fallout if Congress fails to raise the debt limit by the Aug. 2 deadline.

title: Kicking Up the Dust in an Arizona Desert Town
description: QUARTZSITE, Ariz.  Like many folks in this blink-and-miss-it town on the western edge of the state, Ed Foster moved here to escape the hustle and bustle. He is delighted that the main drag is just a couple of miles long, bookended by gas stations. It doesnt take much more than a working sewer and water hookup to make him happy.

title: Blundering Toward Recession: Urgency and Sense Elude the House
description: The increasingly urgent cries to resolve the debt-ceiling stalemate  from Wall Street, bond rating companies, the Federal Reserve chairman, the White House, the Senate and pretty much everyone else  seem unable to penetrate the soundproof bunker built by House Republicans. Their leaders announced on Friday that they would waste precious days next week on a hopeless crusade for spending caps and a balanced budget amendment.

title: For Strauss-Kahn, 2 Concerts, and a Stay, in the Berkshires
description: On the day Dominique Strauss-Kahn was released from house arrest, the paparazzi followed him to an Upper East Side restaurant. (One tabloid said the bill for his party of four came to $700.) Later some tabloids, cable channels and Web sites said he was spending the Independence Day weekend in the Hamptons. (He wasnt.)

title: A Look Into the Oceans Future
description: There is simply no exaggerating the importance of the oceans to earths overall ecological balance. Their health affects the health of all terrestrial life. A new report by an international coalition of marine scientists makes for grim reading. It concludes that the oceans are approaching irreversible, potentially catastrophic change.

title: After Long Battle, Safer Cribs
description: BAYONNE, N.J.  At the back of a cavernous warehouse along a rough-and-tumble waterfront here, an area has been swept clean of boxes and forklifts to make way for baby safety.

title: Day of Reckoning
description: Never apologize. Never back down. Never lose.

title: An Opera on the Loose
description: The New York City Operas schedule for the coming season is not quite busking in the streets, but close. The company, which used to present as many as 20 productions in a season at Lincoln Center, will present four, which will be staged at BAM, El Museo del Barrio, and the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College. If the opera management has its way, the chorus and the orchestra would be demoted from full-time employment to freelance status.

title: A Tip Becomes a Twitter Torrent
description: For nearly 24 hours through Friday afternoon, a slice of the sports world was engaged in a Twitter uprising to force ESPN to end its reported suspension of Bruce Feldman, one of its college football writers. Thousands of Twitter posts were expended in the #freebruce campaign, which rose to No. 4 on Twitters trends list, a wild geyser of pro-Feldmanism.

title: Lottery Numbers
Making Murder Count
description: New Orleans

title: Fallback Plan Moving to Fore as Budget Talks Stall
description: WASHINGTON  With talks on a big budget deal at a stalemate, Congressional leaders turned Friday to negotiating a fallback plan for raising the debt limit as President Obama and House Republicans intensified their efforts to win over public opinion for the long battle ahead.

title: School Officials and Union Agree on Pilot Program for Teacher Evaluations
description: In a step toward reshaping how all teachers in New York Citys 1,700 public schools are judged, the Department of Education and the city teachers union agreed on Friday to a pilot teacher-evaluation system that will take effect next year in 33 struggling schools.

title: Talk of Passports, Not Passes, in Idled N.B.A.
description: This summer was supposed to be an opportunity for Jeremy Hazell to impress clubs with his play for an N.B.A. summer league team and earn an invitation to a training camp in the fall. From there, he would have worked to earn a spot on the team and the guaranteed contract that would go with it.

title: Fleeing Somalias Drought
description: Thousands of people fleeing a drought in Somalia are arriving at the worlds largest refugee camp in Dadaab, Kenya.

title: Transcripts of Veterans in Crisis
description: In a wing of a Veterans Affairs hospital in Canandaigua, N.Y., a small staff runs a national Internet chat service for veterans.

title: Bachmann Off to Fast Start on Funds, but Plays Catch-Up
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Michele Bachmann collected nearly as much money in two weeks as several of her rivals for the Republican presidential nomination raised in more than two months, according to financial reports filed Friday, but President Obama outpaced all candidates by activating a network of high-dollar donors and grass-roots supporters.

title: Two Buildings, Many Stories
description: With the demise of 11 and 9 Second Avenue, another piece of an older, messier New York dies, one made remarkable by the fact that it has existed for so long.

title: In the East Village, Waiting for the Wrecking Ball
description: IN the beginning, there were two buildings.

title: Colon Says Hes Fine, and Video Backs Him
description: TORONTO  In an alcove off to the side of the Yankees clubhouse, Joe Girardi sat in front of a computer on Friday afternoon and cued up video from Thursdays game, preparing to watch all 42 pitches thrown by Bartolo Colon. Girardi studied them frame by frame, looking for evidence that Colons left hamstring was bothering him: a shorter leg kick, a tentative landing. Then he compared Colons mechanics to a start from earlier this season.

title: A Bronx Oasis With a Gritty, Industrial Past
description: ELIZABETH GOMEZ feels a little protective about her beach. Its a tiny crescent of sand, tucked between a thicket of reeds and some gently lapping waves, where she and five friends stretched out on blankets one recent sweltering Saturday, savoring their seclusion.

title: Sommelier Stole Art Openly, Police Say
description: A man with a larcenous bent and modest means, eyeing some trifle in a shop, might just walk in, grab it and walk out. But if this thief has very refined, very expensive tastes, coveting something like, say, a Picasso, how does he manage to steal that?

title: Fleeing Somalia's Drought
description: Thousands of people fleeing a drought in Somalia are arriving at the worlds largest refugee camp, in Dadaab, Kenya.

title: Rangers Re-Sign Boyle
description: The Rangers announced that they agreed to terms on a contract with the restricted free-agent center Brian Boyle. Re-signing the 6-foot-7 Boyle, who scored 21 goals last season, leaves the Rangers with two restricted free agents still to sign, the top-six forwards Ryan Callahan and Brandon Dubinsky.

title: Murdochs Reporters Report on Murdoch
description: One of the more bizarre aspects of the scandal at the British newspaper division of the News Corporation is that it has forced journalists at news organizations owned by the company to report extensively in recent days on the man who is, ultimately, their boss, Rupert Murdoch.

title: Misery Follows as Somalis Try to Flee Hunger
description: DADAAB, Kenya  The people start trudging in at dawn, more than a thousand every day, exhausted, sick and starving, materializing out of the thin desert air to take their places at the gates of the worlds largest refugee camp, here in northern Kenya.

title: For One Day, a Break From Cake
description: Vincent Buzzettas parents wanted him to be a pharmacist or a doctor, but instead settled for watching their chocoholic son become a cake-baking prodigy with his own shop, the Cake Artist, in West Brighton on Staten Island. Mr. Buzzetta, 21, who graduated from the French Culinary Institutes pastry program at 18, now also has his own reality series on WE tv, Staten Island Cakes. He lives in the Old Town neighborhood of Staten Island with his parents, brother and sister, all of whom weigh in loudly on the frenetic show. ROBIN FINN

title: Bachmann Off to Strong Start in Money Race
description: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota collected nearly $1.7 million in her first two weeks as an official candidate for president, an early indication of her appeal to the Tea Party conservatives who she views as her core supporters.

title: Returning Home From War
description: Listen as two veterans who receive care at the Veterans Outreach Center in Rochester, a veteran who now works there and an administrator talk about their experiences.

title: Marathon Swimmers Complete Their Trek
description: DAVID BARRAS seven-day swim from the Rip Van Winkle Bridge to the mouth of the Hudson River ended on Thursday with help from a roaring current.

title: At Kentucky Speedway, a Pileup Off the Track
description: Nascars president, Mike Helton, answered 14 questions Friday at a news conference at a racetrack in Loudon, N.H. Nine questions, and his opening comments, dealt with a colossal traffic jam, not caused by stock cars, before a race last Saturday about 900 miles away in Kentucky.

title: Saturday: Their Word Is Law
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Ive said it before and Ill say it again: if you can get through a Saturday puzzle with your life and your dignity intact, you are bound to come out a smarter person. Today was such a day for me, and I hope it was for you, too. But I came awfully close to this being a D.N.F. (Did Not Finish, for those of you who are new here) for me. That would have been a shame, primarily because I happen to love Patrick Berrys puzzles, and secondly, because I cant really write intelligently about the puzzle if I dont finish, and that ticks off my editors like you cant imagine.

title: The Journal Becomes Fox-ified
description: Its official. The Wall Street Journal has been Fox-ified.

title: Rodriguez Drops Option Worth $17.5 Million
description: Francisco Rodriguez had been saying for months that he did not care about his $17.5 million vesting option for 2012, and on Friday the reason for that became clear.

title: E-Book Revolution Upends a Publishing Course
description: FOR decades, even after it was renamed and relocated from its original home at Radcliffe, the Columbia Publishing Course seemed unchanging, a genteel summer tradition in the book business, a white-glove six-week course in which ambitious college graduates were educated in the time-honored basics of book editing, sales, cover design and publicity. Not this summer.

title: A Voice for Those Silenced in a Mobsters Reign
description: BOSTON  Heads turned as the lanky man made his way to the courtroom pews reserved for those who suffer because of the criminal Whitey Bulger. The face of an altar boy masked his rage, and a shirt of powder-blue covered his tattoos, including one evoking the Celtic cross that adorns his fathers gravestone.

title: Why Subway Rats Arent Electrocuted by the Third Rail
description: Q. There is a small triangular park in the Brownsville neighborhood in Brooklyn called Zion Triangle. Why the odd name?

title: Ahead of Election in March, Putin the Reformer Steps Up
description: MOSCOW  In what appeared to be a calculated pre-election appearance, Prime Minster Vladimir V. Putin on Friday reflected on his 11 years in power and acknowledged that elements of the system he created needed to change.

title: They, Too, Sing America
description: Last week I spent a few days in the Deep South  a thousand miles from the moneyed canyons of Manhattan and the prattle of Washington politics  talking to everyday people, blue-collar workers, people not trying to win the future so much as survive the present.

title: Marching to Sundhages New Pitch
description: If the United States is feeling any pressure heading into Sundays Womens World Cup final against Japan, it is almost certainly not coming from Coach Pia Sundhage. Since taking over after the disastrous ending to the 2007 World Cup, Sundhage has brought a glass-is-half-full spirit that has been a big part of the teams rebuilding. Read Jer Longmans article here, and come back to comment.

title: Beware of Siren With Smartphone
description: Apparently there are some dangers to those Greek islands cruises that the travel agents dont tell you about.

title: Beloved French Rocker Gets Back to Work After Brush With Death
description: PARIS

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Yanks Rotation Begins to Show Wear and Tear
description: TORONTO  In January, the Yankees signed Freddy Garcia not for the accomplishments on his rsum  18-game winner, 2-time All-Star, veteran of 12 major league seasons  but for the four words found under the skills section: knows how to pitch. That is a compliment of the highest order, a celebration of smarts and guile and resolve, all attributes needed to survive, and thrive, in the rough-and-tumble American League East.

title: Hairspray, the 60s and the Greater Good
description: For all its many pleasures as tuneful entertainment, Hairspray is a musical that giddily celebrates subversive values.

title: Sharks, Butterflies and a Ballroom
description: BRYAN DeLUCA, the executive director of the Long Island Aquarium and Exhibition Center, in Riverhead, knows exactly what has traditionally made the attraction, formerly Atlantis Marine World, a popular place to visit.

title: High Crimes (With Laugh Track) and a Summer Share
description: Veanne Cox could probably play an entire episode of Law and Order all by herself. She has no problem enacting a courtroom scene without the help of other actors, rotating at rapid speed among the roles of court officer, lawyer and two witnesses, to hilarious effect.

title: End Gets a Bit Nearer for the Mets
description: The Mets flags atop Citi Field remained a vivid blue and orange Friday, but after a loss to the Philadelphia Phillies, they seemed to gain a decidedly whiter hue. The Mets have not given up on the season just yet, but they moved a step closer.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Greek Gods Under Disco Lights
description: An old pleasure dome known as the Carousel House on the Asbury Park boardwalk is currently home to the New Jersey premiere of Xanadu, the daffy, delectably tuneful musical drawn from one of the worst movies ever made.

title: A Cynical View of Careless Generosity
description: Enter the F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater just before a performance of Timon of Athens, and you are faced with something like a Dickensian store window at Christmastime. Downstage, you find actors dressed in shabby period elegance, transformed into mechanical toys, clicking in and out of the limited movements and poses that their 19th-century works allow them.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around New Jersey. Items may be submitted by mail to the New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Festival Carries the Torch of the Grateful Dead
description: DEADHEADS may not lack an instinct to gather, but they do require a good reason for doing so. For decades, Jerry Garcia, the Grateful Deads frontman, gave them one.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: A Farmers Market at a Historic Homestead
description: IN 1801, John Jay, who had served his country as president of the Second Continental Congress, minister to Spain during the American Revolution, secretary for foreign affairs under the Articles of Confederation, a key negotiator of the Treaty of Paris, first chief justice of the Supreme Court, two-term governor of New York, and a co-author of the Federalist Papers, retired  and who could blame him?  to 750 bucolic acres in Katonah.

title: Nets Williams SignsWith Turkish Team
description: With a signature, a photo and a three-sentence Twitter post, Deron Williams sealed his commitment to a Turkish basketball team.

title: The Catch of the Day, by the Pound or the Plate
description: ISLAND PARK, N.Y.

title: Slumps in Consumer Spending
description: What consumers are cutting back on.

title: More Than a Name Suggests
description: Summer entertaining without having to use the oven or stove is much easier if you live in the vicinity of No. 109 Cheese and Wine. This handsome shop, with a stonework wall offset by a guacamole green color scheme, carries a wealth of gourmet treats in addition to some 150 varieties of cheese.

title: Turkey: Army Strikes Back at Rebels
description: Turkey launched a military offensive in the predominantly Kurdish southeast in retaliation for an ambush by Kurdish separatists that killed 13 soldiers on Thursday. Army helicopters were joined by civilian village guards in the operation, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported. The army provided no details on the number of troops involved. The attack on Thursday, near Diyarbakir, was the deadliest ambush by Kurdish separatists in recent years, and Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan vowed that the rebels would pay a heavy price.

title: Austrian Cuisine, Ready for Summer
description: AUSTRIAN restaurants, with their robust cuisine, dont normally come to mind as good choices for summer dining. But Austrias white wines  exquisitely refreshing in the warm weather  combined with lighter-than-usual fare make the Watch Factory Restaurant in Cheshire well worth a visit.

title: Venezuelan Leader to Return to Cuba for Next Phase of Cancer Treatment
description: President Hugo Chvez said Friday that he would return to Cuba to begin a new phase of cancer treatment including chemotherapy. Mr. Chvez, 56, said he would go to Havana on Saturday to begin what weve called the second phase. He had surgery in Cuba last month to remove a cancerous tumor from his pelvic region. He acknowledged Wednesday that he required further treatment for cancer but has not said what kind of cancer he has. On Friday, he said he was sending a letter to the president of the National Assembly to secure authorization for his trip, as required by the Constitution.

title: A Pizzeria From Another Era
description: Many of the food outlets in Lawrencevilles Mercer Mall (Chevys, Arbys, Hooters) can be found, duplicated, in malls across America. But Red Moon Pizza, which has been in business for more than 30 years, is related to no other pizza parlor of that name.

title: A Resort Restaurant Focused on Simplicity
description: WHEN Janine Cinseruli was 16, she began a restaurant career that took her to Chicago, Miami and the East Village in Manhattan before she left it all behind to flip houses in Asbury Park. Or so she thought. Then a friend told her about a popular restaurant in Ocean Grove (the home of a 142-year-old Methodist camp meeting) whose owner wanted to sell.

title: Animal Collectives Music Fills the Space at Pitchfork
description: CHICAGO  Filling space is of optimal importance at a festival on the scale of Pitchfork. Union Park is the size of a few city blocks, and there are three stages: the two biggest at one end, separated by a few hundred feet, and the smallest at the opposite end.

title: At Black Labels Bike Kill, Freedom Via Mayhem
description: Julie Glassberg spent more than a year with the New York chapter of the Black Label Bike Club, capturing the postindustrial landscapes its members inhabit.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Russia: Abortion Restrictions Signed
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev has signed into law the first steps intended to restrict abortion in Russia since the collapse of Communism. The changes require abortion providers to devote 10 percent of any advertising to describing the dangers of abortion to a womans health, and they make it illegal to describe abortion as a safe medical procedure. The changes, which will take effect in 30 days, were signed by Mr. Medvedev on Monday and announced Thursday on the Kremlins Web site. Parliament is expected to consider tighter restrictions on abortion in a separate bill this fall.

title: California: Dont Ask, Dont Tell Is Back, Temporarily
description: A federal appeals court has temporarily reinstated the policy that prohibits openly gay men and women from serving in the military  but prohibited any investigation, penalties or discharges under the rule. A three-judge panel on the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit had, on July 6, ordered the military to end the policy. The judges issued the three-page order late Friday in response to an emergency request by the Obama administration to let the Department of Defense continue its repeal process in an orderly fashion. The government provided considerably more detailed information about the repeal in its most recent filings, including statements that the military would be presenting its certification to repeal the policy to the president and top military officials in a matter of weeks. Dont ask, dont tell will officially end 60 days after certification.

title: Pig, Pig and More Pig
description: A concoction called Bacon Explosion rolls bacon and sausage together and can be baked or cooked in a smoker.

title: At Black Labels Bike Kill, Freedom via Mayhem
description: Julie Glassberg spent more than a year with the New York chapter of the Black Label Bike Club, capturing the postindustrial landscapes its members inhabit.

title: Freedom, via Mayhem
description: TAKE a dash of Mad Max, add a pinch of Jackass, sprinkle both over a wet batter of art students, bicycle messengers, anarchist welders and militant anti-globalist vegans, then let the mixture bake for, say, a decade in the oven of Brooklyn, and the resulting dish should taste a little like the Black Label Bike Club.

title: Japan Operator Shutting Down Nuclear Reactor After Malfunction
description: TOKYO  Japans second-largest nuclear operator said Saturday that it was manually shutting down a reactor in central Japan after a technical malfunction.

title: In Worley, Phillies Have a Valuable Spare Starter
description: With the array of aces at the Philadelphia Phillies disposal, it would almost be unfair if they were to unearth a future front-line starter to plug in at the back end of their star-studded rotation. But in Vance Worley, the Phillies might have found just that.

title: Jerry Ragovoy, Writer of Soulful Ballads, Dies at 80
description: Jerry Ragovoy, who wrote or collaborated on some of the most soulful ballads of the 1960s, including the Rolling Stones hit Time Is on My Side and the Janis Joplin signatures Piece of My Heart, Cry Baby and Try (Just a Little Bit Harder), died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: A Friday Night Lights Farewell
description: There are few series I can think of whose conclusions occasion feelings of sorrow. The Sopranos ended amid confusion and awe. We may miss the narrative and the ingeniously black comedy of it all, if not the actual characters, none of whom you really want tucking you into bed at night. The same can be said of Big Love, another of the greatest family dramas ever on television. Though we may miss its intelligent social commentary, we do not necessarily pine for the people in it to re-enter our lives. HBO renders characters ambiguously; we are not supposed to fall in love with each and every one of them.

title: Francisco Villagrn Kramer, Guatemala Official, Dies at 84
description: Francisco Villagrn Kramer, a politician and an internationally known legal scholar who went into self-imposed exile in the United States after joining and then defying Guatemalas right-wing military government in the late 1970s, died Tuesday. He was 84.

title: Corrections: July 16
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Travis Bean, Aluminum Guitar Maker, Dies at 63
description: Travis Bean, a machinist who earned a nugget of rock n roll immortality by making electric guitars with necks fashioned out of aluminum instead of wood and selling them to members of the Grateful Dead and the Rolling Stones, died on July 10 in Burbank, Calif. He was 63.

title: A Gentle Reminder of Paul McCartneys Survival and Vitality
description: The cheerful, childlike doggerel of Hello Goodbye  I dont know why you say goodbye/I say hello  struck an unexpected note as Paul McCartney sang it on Friday night to start his two-night stand at Yankee Stadium. Who is this Derek Jeter guy? Mr. McCartney asked. Somebody said hes got more hits than me.

title: Sergio Agero, the Son-in-Law of God, Escapes Long Shadows
description: Whats the dinner conversation like these days at Sergio Ageros house when his in-laws visit?

title: Classic Ad: See the U.S.A. in Your Chevrolet
description: This week we present what might be the most classic of all car ads: Dinah Shores famous ode to Chevy, which sponsored multiple incarnations of her television show for more than a decade in the 1950s and 60s.

title: East London Festival Puts Culture on the Water
description: Regents Canal was built in the early 19th century to carry coal and other goods across northern London. Although its commercial days are long over, it has found a new life as a popular site for boat trips and other leisure activities  among them the Shoreditch Festival, which will run in Londons East End from today to July 24. The festival puts on a colorful  and free  program of entertainment, including theater, dance and musical performances, as well as exploration of East Londons waterways.

title: The Weekend Word: Fallbacks
description: Todays Times

title: Vatican Excommunicates Chinese Bishop
description: ROME  A Chinese bishop ordained without papal approval was excommunicated for accepting his new post, the Vatican announced Saturday.

title: Use a Bigger Fork and Youll Eat Less
description: By now youve probably heard  from nutritionists, diet books and TV personalities  that bigger plates encourage people to eat more food. A new study, published in The Journal of Consumer Research, finds that the size of your utensils has the opposite effect: using a bigger fork leads people to eat less.

title: Clinton Chides Turkey on Rights Record
description: ISTANBUL  In a series of pointed statements, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized Turkey, a close NATO ally, on Saturday, for its mixed record on press and other freedoms.

title: The Political Economy of the Lesser Depression
description: Everyone in the forecasting business is scrambling to mark down both their estimates of second-quarter growth and their forecasts for later in the year. Goldman Sachs (no link) was pretty optimistic a few months ago; now theyve grown quite pessimistic:

title: Los Angeles Freeway Is Closed and Life Goes On
description: LOS ANGELES  The warnings had been grim: a knot of traffic stretching from the Pacific Ocean to downtown Los Angeles. Motorists struggling to make it from West Los Angeles across the Sepulveda Pass into the San Fernando Valley. A display of gridlock that would drain even the most hardened Los Angeles commuter, all caused by the weekend closing of a 10-mile stretch of Interstate 405.

title: Clarke Leads a Blustery Third Round
description: SANDWICH, England  A Saturday that began with heavy rain, high winds and high scores at the British Open ended with clear skies, low scores and very high hopes for a clear-cut leader and a group of fast followers who all have something to prove.

title: Innocence Is Lost With Mets Deal of Rodriguez
description: My 5-year-old son woke up Wednesday a child. Mommy had let him stay up way past bedtime to watch the first three innings of the All-Star Game. He munched on Cheerios awaiting another glorious day at summer camp. Then he saw the thick type at the top of the newspaper.

title: In Central Florida, a Chorus of Happy Trails to Anthony, Minus the Happy
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When Casey Anthony stepped out of jail on Sunday after nearly three years inside, the Orange County Sheriffs Office whisked her to ...

title: Who Pays Rick Perrys Travel Bill?
description: Gov. Rick Perry has been burning up the miles since he won re-election last year. He is on track to have made nearly 50 stops in 21 states by November.

title: Murky Waters This Year in Free-Agent Pool
description: At some point, perhaps soon, the N.F.L. and its players will reach a new labor agreement, and the great free-agent gold rush of 2011 will begin. But for now, for as many as 500 free agents, there is no blueprint, no courting or being courted, only anticipation for what comes next and more labor pains induced in the form of unemployment.

title: For Retired Players, No Seat at the Table
description: The N.F.L. legend Jim Brown added his voice to the growing chorus of retired players who feel that they have been discarded like worn tires.

title: Reshuffling Blurs Picture, Jeopardizing Conferences
description: Being the commissioner of the Central Collegiate Hockey Association, one of the nations leading conferences, is ordinarily a pretty good deal. The conference, which has existed since 1971, sends multiple teams to the N.C.A.A. mens hockey tournament every year and has won 9 of the past 27 national championships.

title: Variety: A Past-its-Peak Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you watch a lot of television, there comes a point in most series where the entertainment level drops precipitously, and that is the point where the show is said to have jumped the shark. It might be a case of a specific character doing something that just strains viewers credulity, or the entire storyline might just lose its oomph. Either way, its a clear signal to everyone involved that it might be time to re-tool the show or pack up their toys and go home.

title: Womens World Cup: This Time, a Show Worth Watching
description: When the Womens World Cup was played the United States in 1999, I went to the opening game at Giants Stadium, eager to be supportive. The atmosphere was great, the soccer dreadful. So slow, so clumsy  the women looked as if they were trying to play soccer under water. In 2003, and in 2007, I had trouble making myself watch on television.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Vincent Nobile: A Drag-Racing Whiz Kid
description: Vincent Nobile is 19 years old, just completed his first year as a business administration major at Adelphi University and lives with his parents in Dix Hills on Long Island. Nobile played shortstop in high school, and his bedroom is decorated with Yankees memorabilia.

title: So Much Potential, So Far to Go for Young Basketball Prospect
description: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C.  When the 7-foot-4 center Sim Bhullar walks through airports, people flock to him and ask him to pose for pictures. When he recently visited India, where his parents were born, so many approached him at the Sikh shrine known as the Golden Temple that he was ushered into an office. People hung on the bars of the office windows to catch a glance.

title: World Cup Finalists Size Up Their Opponents
description: FRANKFURT, Germany  If it wasnt yet apparent how confident Japan had grown after victories over Germany and Sweden in the Womens World Cup, it became clear when Coach Norio Sasaki was asked about potential American vulnerability in Sundays final.

title: Abby Wambach Stands Tall for U.S.
description: FRANKFURT  Abby Wambachs halftime instructions to a teammate were simple and insistent: Just put the ball on the back post. Well get a goal.

title: Last Golfer in Becomes Odd One Out
description: SANDWICH, England  Safely inside the interview tent with water still dripping off the bill of his cap, Matt Millar, the first man to finish on Saturday, looked over his shoulder toward the British Open course where he had just shot a 10-over-par 80.

title: A Day of Apologies for the Murdochs, and of New Questions for Cameron
description: LONDON  As Rupert Murdochs newspaper empire on Saturday published full-page ads in every national newspaper in Britain under the words We are sorry, the government of Prime Minister David Cameron released information documenting the prime ministers close ties to Murdoch company executives that continued even as the phone-hacking scandal grew.

title: 2nd Loans, 2nd Wave of Losses
description: HAVE you heard the good news? Big banks are making more money than we thought.

title: Fostering a Culture of Dissent
description: This interview with  David Sacks, founder, chairman and C.E.O. of Yammer, which offers workplace communication tools, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Law School Economics: Ka-Ching!
description: WITH apologies to show business, theres no business like the business of law school.

title: Interstate 405 Closed to Traffic
description: A 10-mile stretch of one of the nations busiest freeways has turned into a virtual ghost road in Los Angeles.

title: Light-Eyed Players Deal With Glare, and Doubts
description: During the third inning of a March 17 spring training game, Chicago White Sox shortstop Alexei Ramirez hit a soft fly ball to left field. Milwaukee Brewers outfielder Mark Kotsay had his sunglasses on, as he always does, but as he ran in toward the ball it disappeared into the glare of the harsh Arizona sun.

title: Stain From Tabloids Rubs Off on a Cozy Scotland Yard
description: LONDON  For nearly four years they lay piled in a Scotland Yard evidence room, six overstuffed plastic bags gathering dust and little else.

title: Seeing Promise and Peril in Digital Records
description: TECHNICAL standards may seem arcane, but they are often powerful tools of economic development and social welfare. They can be essential building blocks for innovation and new industries. The basic software standards for the Web are striking proof.

title: Arab Spring, Start-Up Summer?
description: LIKE so many other young people in Cairo, Yasmine el-Mehairy saw no future in Egypt. What she saw was a dead end.

title: From Yankees Rotation to Nationals Bullpen, and Thriving
description: When the Yankees sent Tyler Clippard to the Washington Nationals at the winter meetings in December 2007, Clippard had never heard of the pitcher he was traded for.

title: The Wages of Virtue and Vice
description: VICE and virtue are engaged in a titanic struggle on many fronts, and vice often appears to have the upper hand. Just read the headlines. Scandals in politics, sports, business and journalism seem to be popping up everywhere.

title: Getting the Most Out of Social Security
description: SOCIAL SECURITY may be the most beloved of all the governments programs, partly because it requires so little thinking. You pay taxes while you work, then you and your spouse collect until you die.

title: Bring Your A Game
description: I WAS born in Fort Wayne, Ind., and moved to Dayton, Ohio, when I was 6. I colored paper doilies as a child and sold them around the neighborhood. In high school, I worked as a temp, which gave me experience in different companies. I also worked at McDonalds and as a babysitter.

title: Working Separately, Together
description: THE grass is always greener on the other side of the cubicle. Corporate types curse during long commutes and feel shackled to their desks when the weather outside is gorgeous. If only they could work from home and have a more flexible schedule.

title: Girardi Shows Signs of Frustration
description: TORONTO  Manager Joe Girardis frustration with his teams poor play in the first two games here seemed to boil over Saturday morning when he all but accused the Blue Jays of using off-the-field means to steal the Yankees signs. The day after applauding their resourcefulness in divining Russell Martins signals from second base, Girardi turned testy when asked why he told Martin on Friday night to use complicated signs even with no one on base.

title: Compelling Tales, Rarely Told Well
description: THIS is going to be awkward. Ive spent weeks, in fact, debating whether and how to say this in print. But its something thats irked me for years. And while occupying this chair these last months, its a feeling thats only strengthened: The fact is, I find the quality of too many business books, well, underwhelming. There. I said it.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: A tabloid closing in London, Captain America at the stock market, the results of stress tests on European banks and more.

title: German Group That Cited Putin as Role Model Cancels Prize After Outcry
description: BERLIN  A German nonprofit group canceled its annual prize ceremony on Saturday after its decision to honor Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sparked a public outcry.

title: Election Cycle Emerges as the Year of the Pledge, but Some Candidates Resist
description: This is the year presidential candidates are being asked to take the pledge.

title: At Two-Year Colleges, Less Scrutiny Equals Less Athletic Equality
description: Los Angeles Southwest College has a new athletic field house and football stadium, but almost no female athletes.

title: Union Yields on Benefits in Deal With Cuomo
description: New York States second-largest union of public workers, facing hundreds of layoffs that had been scheduled to take effect within days, agreed on Saturday to significant wage and benefit concessions in order to save the jobs of its members.

title: J. Terrence Lanni, Ex-Chief of MGM Mirage, Dies at 68
description: J. Terrence Lanni, a gambling company executive who helped turn a single casino into the industry giant now known as MGM Resorts International, died on Thursday night at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 68.

title: Making Sustainable Surfboards
description: Danny Hess of San Francisco left his job as a building contractor to devote himself to creating environmentally friendly and long-lasting surfboards.

title: The Man Who Financed the Civil War
description: Washington, D.C., July 17, 1861

title: Injured Romeo Will Miss Sundays Performance
description: Sam Troughton, the star of the Royal Shakespeare Companys production of Romeo and Juliet, is recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his knee and will miss Sunday nights performance at the Park Avenue Armory, a spokeswoman for the company, Nada Zakula, said.

title: A Witness to 3,000, Again
description: The clip will be replayed for generations, along with the call from Michael Kay on the YES Network:

title: Dalai Lama and Obama Meet to Talk About Tibet
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama met privately with the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, at the White House on Saturday, despite a warning from Beijing that the meeting would risk damaging relations between China and the United States.

title: Sabathia Reminds the Yankees What Theyre Not Missing
description: TORONTO  The Yankees have their flaws, as the first two games of a series here against the Blue Jays showed, but on days when C. C. Sabathia pitches, none of them seem to matter. Let others fret about an understaffed bullpen, a wobbly third baseman or an unsteady rotation. With Sabathia on the mound, the Yankees do not worry. They just watch, marvel and win.

title: Brian Wilson: Part-Time Closer, Part-Time Statistician
description: As a starting pitcher in high school, Brian Wilson said, he kept the scorebook on the days he did not pitch. At Louisiana State, he kept the scorebook on days he manned the radar gun in the stands. Many pitchers perform these duties.

title: Pacific Pinball Museum
description: Alameda Island, the site of a former military base, can feel like a 1950s-era small town, with its Craftsman-style homes and neighborhood bars. The addition of a pinball museum, where old-fashioned bonks are more common than electronic beeps, has only heightened that effect. Michael Schiess, a former museum exhibit builder, opened his Alameda pinball palace in 2001, attracting devoted pinheads and casual players alike.  ANDY WRIGHT

title: Spectators Will Escape to Alcatraz for the Cup
description: Alcatraz, the fog-shrouded rock transformed from an island prison into one of San Franciscos most famous landmarks, is about to get a new identity  best seat in the house for the Americas Cup.

title: Scientists Fight a Deadly Oak-Tree Disease
description: On a hot summer day in 2008, a pair of plant disease researchers made an extraordinary discovery as they toured a hillside forest in San Mateo County: a stand of trees that had not been infected by the killer disease known as sudden oak death.

title: Latest BART Shooting Prompts New Discussion of Reforms
description: After a white BART police officer shot and killed an unarmed black man shortly after New Years 2009, the transit agency agreed to 127 policy changes recommended by an independent auditor. They included arming officers with Tasers and providing crisis-intervention training for the BART police force.

title: At the Break, the Sox Are in Sorry Shape
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Today is Sunday. It Must Be Time for a News Conference
Foreclosure? Many Pets Are Losing Their Homes
description: People are not the only victims of the dismal economy. Pets are also being forced to cope. Several Chicago-area animal shelters report a sharp uptick in the number of abandoned dogs and cats in the last four years. We certainly have seen an increase in dogs surrendered, said Dr. Robyn Barbiers, executive director of the Anti-Cruelty Society. In its last fiscal year, ended June 2010, the shelter received 854 dogs. This year, the number jumped to nearly 1,000.

title: Young Mans Death Rattles Indiana Beach Community
description: It was a Fourth of July like any other in Long Beach, Ind., an idyllic lakeside getaway frequented by well-heeled members of Chicagos Irish community  a Norman Rockwell scene in the words of several local residents  complete with a parade and fireworks over the golf course.

title: A Texan in Washington Who Hasnt Gone Native
description: Ross Ramsey, managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Jailbreaks Make for Good TV, but Remain Rare
description: Robert Dudley and Rickey Taylor wanted out of the Ector County Jail, apparently quite badly. Twice this year, using makeshift digging tools and squeezing through dark tunnels inside the jail in Odessa, they nearly succeeded, taking advantage of weaknesses in the West Texas facility.

title: Four Hidden Beach Getaways, All Within State Lines
description: Tell someone youre vacationing on the Texas coast, and youll probably get a sympathetic smile. This is a fair reaction in a state with more than 350 miles of coastline and, no offense to Gods country, a lot of underwhelming beaches.

title: On the Rise in Tajikistan, Islam Worries an Authoritarian Government
description: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan  Islam is blossoming in Tajikistan. Beards are in style. Headscarves, too. Bazaars are doing a booming trade in prayer rugs, religious audio recordings and gaudy clocks featuring Muslim holy sites.

title: Sunday: The End Is in Sight
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  I really, really liked this one. Who knew there were so many familiar phrases that had a letter or letters within them that made the same sound as the last word in the phrase? Daniel A. Finan has found them for us, matched them up according to letter counts, and created a puzzle that just rocks, themewise. I would have liked it even more if there hadnt been so much jumping around (See X Down to get a hint to the answer to Y Across), but all in all, I enjoyed myself.

title: The V.A. Tries to Get Beyond Its Culture of No
description: The Veterans Affairs Department says that it is not only making strides in treating post-traumatic stress disorder and brain injuries and in preventing suicides, but is also upending its reputation for bureaucratic delays and unresponsiveness.

title: A New Try at Curbing Piracy
description: After years of trying to stop illegal downloading of music and videos by suing their fans, enticing them to pay through easier formats, and encrypting digital files, the music and movie industries hope they have found an effective approach to fighting copyright theft. This month, several major Internet service providers, including Verizon, Comcast, AT&T and Time Warner Cable, agreed to help movie studios and record labels identify Internet users who downloaded copyrighted content illicitly, warn them about the piracy and punish recalcitrant abusers.

title: Correspondence Between The New York Times and Scotland Yard
description: Documents show The New York Timess request for information about the phone-hacking scandal at The News of the World that was sent last year to Scotland Yard, and its response.

title: Are They Learning?
description: A cheating scandal in which scores of teachers and principals in Atlantas public schools falsified student test results has thrown the system into chaos and made its name synonymous with fraud. This shameful episode has destroyed trust in the schools and made it impossible to determine how much students are learning and whether the system is doing its job.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

title: Clashing Views on the Future of Natural Gas
description: A NEW YORK TIMES article last month, Insiders Sound an Alarm Amid a Natural Gas Rush, warned across two columns at the top of the front page that high expectations for companies drilling shale gas might be headed for a fall. It was the kind of story you wish The Times had written about Enron before it collapsed. Or about Bernard Madoff.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Seeking a Path Through Depressions Landscape
description: Do antidepressants work? Doctors and patients respond to a letter on Wednesday that questioned their liberal use.

title: The Critique of Pure Horror
description: WITH gruesome television series about vampires, werewolves, serial killers and zombies earning huge ratings, and a new cinematic bloodbath opening seemingly every week, the cultural appetite for horror raises a curious question: why do so many of us enjoy being disgusted and terrified?

title: Should Cities Drive Food Trucks Off the Streets?
description: ATLANTA

title: Oliver Sacks
description: Whats on your mind? The Sunday Review asked Oliver Sacks, a physician, author and professor of neurology and psychiatry at the Columbia University Medical Center.

title: Books and Other Fetish Objects
description: I GOT a real thrill in December 1999 in the Reading Room ofthe Morgan Library in New York when the librarian, Sylvie Merian, brought me, after I had completed an application with a letter of reference and a photo ID, the first, oldest notebook of Isaac Newton. First I was required to study a microfilm version. There followed a certain amount of appropriate pomp. The notebook was lifted from a blue cloth drop-spine box and laid on a special padded stand. I was struck by how impossibly tiny it was  58 leaves bound in vellum, just 2 3/4 inches wide, half the size I would have guessed from the enlarged microfilm images. There was his name, Isacus Newton, proudly inscribed by the 17-year-old with his quill, and the date, 1659.

title: Patrolling Cancers Borderlands
description: THREE recent events highlight the extraordinary task that lies ahead for cancer prevention.

title: How to Pull Off a Vanishing Act
description: ITS starting to look likely  given news reports about her interest in fake names and disguises  that if Casey Anthony gets out of jail as scheduled this weekend, she will do her best to avoid the public eye and join the list of runaways that has recently included James (Whitey) Bulger, Ratko Mladic, Osama bin Laden and certain state senators from Wisconsin.

title: Terrorism and the Law
description: The prosecution of a Somali national accused of supporting Al Qaeda is now headed for trial in a federal court, where it belonged all along. The Obama administration finally made the right decision over the usual self-serving objections of grandstanding senators from both parties. But it is troubling that the administration delayed this step for almost two months.

title: Our Broken Escalator
description: YAMHILL, Ore.

title: The Clash of Generations
description: ATHENS

title: Were Spent
description: THERE is no shortage of explanations for the economys maddening inability to leave behind the Great Recession and start adding large numbers of jobs: The deficit is too big. The stimulus was flawed. China is overtaking us. Businesses are overregulated. Wall Street is underregulated.

title: Four With Links Between Scotland Yard and News International
description: Four With Links Between Scotland Yard and News International

title: Growing Up, Then Going Home
description: Since 2009, unemployment among recent college graduates has risen, while starting salaries have fallen. The median student debt load for those who graduated from 2006 to 2010 is $20,000. Not surprisingly, 40 percent of 20-somethings move back in with their parents at least once. Here are some dispatches from the home front.

title: Why Would Anyone Miss War?
description: SEVERAL years ago I spent time with a platoon of Army infantry at a remote outpost in eastern Afghanistan, and after the deployment I was surprised that only one of the soldiers chose to leave the military at the end of his contract; many others re-upped and eventually went on to fight for another year in the same area. The soldier who got out, Brendan OByrne, remained a good friend of mine as he struggled to fit in to civilian life back home.

title: Lawmakers, Armed and Dangerous
description: WHILE all the country gaped last week at the acrimony ensnarling the federal government, Arizonans were treated to an additional, equally bizarre spectacle. Youll be shocked to hear that a firearm was involved.

title: Drought: A Creeping Disaster
description: FLOODS, tornadoes, earthquakes, tsunamis and other geological phenomena have left a trail of destruction during the first half of 2011. But this could be just the start to a remarkable year of bad weather. Next up: drought. In the South, 14 states are now baking in blast-furnace conditions  from Arizona, which is battling the largest wildfire in its history, to Florida, where fires have burned some 200,000 acres so far. Worse, drought, unlike earthquakes, hurricanes and other rapid-moving weather, could become a permanent condition in some regions.

title: Pitchfork: Too Hot to Mosh, or Wear Black
description: CHICAGO  Its hot. Dont-wanna-move hot. Watch-a-band-for-10-minutes-then-find-3-minutes-of-shade hot. Popular outfit for boys: tank top, cut-off jeans, Vans with no socks. Popular outfit for girls: sundress, sandals, wide-brimmed hat.

title: Education, Education, Education
description: My Sunday column is a despairing bleat at the cutbacks in education budgets around the country  including my old school, Yamhill-Carlton High School, here in Yamhill, Oregon. In years of writing about poverty, Ive come to believe firmly that there are no perfect solutions either in America or abroad  but the closest thing to a silver bullet is an excellent education system. And it is so frustrating that thats still whats missing in so many communities.

title: Ethnic Music Tests Limits in China
description: BEIJING  They have toured Europe, played alongside marquee names like the band Coldplay and earned plaudits in the international press. But here in China, the growing popularity of the Mongolian rock band Hanggai has not exactly inspired adulation from the authorities.

title: Why Are Prosecutors Striking Out?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Fighting for Folk
description: Hanggai, an ethnic Mongolian folk-rock band in Beijing, wants to show its audience that music made by minorities in China isn't always so traditional.

title: Italy Versus Japan
description: A question (to which I dont have the full answer): why are the interest rates on Italian and Japanese debt so different? As of right now, 10-year Japanese bonds are yielding 1.09%; 10-year Italian bonds 5.76%.

title: Photo Replay: July 16
description: The day in sports, including heavy rain at the British Open and the beginning of the FINA Swimming World Championships.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Faces Military Limits
description: With the militarys ban on openly gay troops expected to end this fall, advocates for gay and lesbian service members are already looking ahead to the next battle: winning equal benefits for same-sex married couples.

title: 'We're All Heterosexual'
description: John Becker, a gay-rights activist, posed as a patient seeking therapy at a Christian mental health clinic owned by Marcus Bachmann, Michele Bachmann's husband, and secretly taped the sessions.

title: Options for Gay Patients
description: John Becker, a gay-rights activist, posed as a patient seeking therapy at a Christian mental health clinic owned by Marcus Bachmann, Michele Bachmann's husband, and secretly taped the sessions.

title: Dealing With Rentiers
description: Not the best quality video  but Robin and I saw this production, and it was awesomely good.

title: G.O.P. Freshmen Say Debt Concerns Them More Than Re-election
description: WASHINGTON  For years, legislation to raise the federal debt limit offered plenty of political theater on Capitol Hill, with the party out of power using it to rail against the party in power. As a senator, Barack Obama said in 2006 that a bill to raise the debt limit was a sign of leadership failure.

title: Hairston Fills in With a Career Day, and the Mets Thwart Hamels Again
description: Despite delivering a long home run Friday, Carlos Beltran was racked with a fever and flulike symptoms Saturday, to the point that he could not make it to Citi Field. Considering he is the Mets leader in home runs, runs batted in and extra-base hits, his loss seemed a daunting one.

title: Battle for Libya | July 16, 2011
description: Libyan rebels said their steady advance on Brega was slowed Saturday by the discovery of defensive trenches around the city that had been filled with flammable chemicals by retreating troops loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Chvez Puts His Trust in Castro for Care
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela boarded a plane bound for Cuba on Saturday to receive more treatment for a cancer whose details still remain a mystery to the outside world.

title: Fowler and McIlroy: a Growing Gap
description: SANDWICH, England  Hailed as the present and future of golf after his romp at the United States Open, Rory McIlroy has not even been the best mop-topped 22-year-old at this British Open.

title: Geoff Fisken, New Zealand Sheep Farmer and Scourge of Japanese Pilots, Dies at 96
description: Growing up on New Zealands North Island in the 1920s, Geoff Fisken seemed destined for a quiet life working on the vast sheep farms his father owned. But he became fascinated by airplanes when his father, Robert, began flying on his trips around the country. At 14, Geoff flew solo in a biplane.

title: An Alarming New Stimulant, Legal in Many States
description: Dr. Jeffrey J. Narmi could not believe what he was seeing this spring in the emergency room at Schuylkill Medical Center in Pottsville, Pa.: people arriving so agitated, violent and psychotic that a small army of medical workers was needed to hold them down.

title: For Bachmann, Gay Rights Stand Reflects Mix of Issues and Faith
description: ST. PAUL  In March 2004, with Massachusetts soon to allow gay couples to wed, Michele Bachmann delivered a dire warning to her fellow Minnesotans: The children of their state were at risk.

title: Christian Counseling by Hopefuls Spouse Prompts Questions
description: LAKE ELMO, Minn.  The receptionists at Bachmann & Associates, the Christian counseling center run by the husband of the presidential hopeful Michele Bachmann, were polite but firm in turning a reporter away the other day. A new sign was on the door. Bachmann & Associates, it said, prohibits all soliciting, filming and photography in this building. NO MEDIA.

title: Charter School Battle Shifts to Affluent Suburbs
description: MILLBURN, N.J.  Matthew Stewart believes there is a place for charter schools. Just not in his schoolyard.

title: New Stable of Wealthy Donors Fueled Obama Campaigns Record Fund-Raising Quarter
description: President Obama recruited roughly 150 new elite donors, raising as much as a half a million dollars each, to help propel him to a large and early lead over his Republican opponents in the race for campaign cash, according to campaign filings released last week.

title: Copa Amrica Semifinals: Argentina Is Out
description: Argentina was eliminated from the Copa Amrica quarterfinals by Uruguay in a penalty kick shootout on Saturday night, a fitting and maddening denouement for the host country in a tournament in which its talented team alternated between fabulous and (more often) frustrating.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 17
description: The looming debt deadline continues to cast shadows over the Sunday talk shows, but this time the discussion is spreading to include the outlook on the state and local levels. A few presidential candidates are also dropping in to share their opinions on how the nation can get out of its budget fix.

title: After Decades in Top Ranks, a Shot at the Title, Finally
description: Players usually reach their peak in their 20s, so how is it that the grandmaster Boris Gelfand is getting his first crack at becoming world champion when he is 43?

title: Ardis James, Who Established Center on Quilts, Is Dead at 85
description: Ardis Butler James, a Nebraska-born philanthropist who with her husband established what is now the largest public collection of quilts in the world, encompassing humbly elegant bed coverings by anonymous 18th-century hands and avant-garde wall hangings by celebrated 21st-century artists, died on July 7 in Stamford, Conn. She was 85.

title: Egypt Military Aims to Cement Muscular Role in Government
description: CAIRO  The military council governing Egypt is moving to lay down ground rules for a new constitution that would protect and potentially expand its own authority indefinitely, possibly circumscribing the power of future elected officials.

title: Assessing the Future in the Race for Top Amateur
description: SANDWICH, ENGLAND  An amateur who shoots a 65 in his first British Open round, makes the cut with ease and draws praise from none other than Tom Watson should be a lock for the silver medal awarded to the tournaments leading amateur.

title: When Did You Lose Your Fan Innocence?
description: As we are constantly reminded, major league sports are, at heart, a business. Many personnel decisions are based on dollars and cents, not legacies and fan favorites, and it is often the fans who take these decisions the hardest.

title: Collecting Quilts
description: Ardis James and her husband, Robert, established what has become the worlds largest public collection of quilts, at the University of Nebraska, Lincoln.

title: Mistake, Then Disaster for Phillies in a Drubbing
description: His shoes off but his gray game shirt still on, his head propped up by his big left hand, Philadelphia first baseman Ryan Howard sat stonily at his locker after the Phillies were drubbed, 11-2, by the Mets on Saturday. Howard had made a mistake that sent the game reeling out of control.

title: Corrections: July 17
description: SPORTS

title: Pitchfork: Mini-Explosions to Break Up the Soft Rock
description: CHICAGO  It takes a lot of experience to know what sort of stage banter works during a festival slot. It takes a whole lot more experience to throw all of that hard-earned knowledge out the window and just trust your inner motor.

title: Agudelo and Bravo Added to M.L.S. All-Star Team
description: Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber added Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo and Sporting Kansas City captain Omar Bravo to the leagues all-star team with his two picks Saturday.

title: Abby Wambachs Head for the Game
description: Jer Longman looks at how Abby Wambach got so good at heading the ball, and how that skill has meant success for the United States womens national team. Read the article here  dont miss the graphic charting how many of Wambachs World Cup shots have come on headers  and come back to comment.

title: An Arrest and Scotland Yard Resignation Roil Britain
description: LONDON  Britains top police official resigned on Sunday, the latest casualty of the phone-hacking scandal engulfing British public life, just hours after Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdochs News International, was arrested on suspicion of illegally intercepting phone calls and bribing the police.

title: Holding Steady on Dreary Day, Clarke Captures His First Major
description: SANDWICH, England  On Sunday at Royal St. Georges, just before Darren Clarke tapped in the putt that would seal it all, the one that would mean the wait was over, that the British Open was his and the 20-year quest had come to an end, he stepped back, grinned, and spoke to himself.

title: Penny-Wise Policy
description: Mark Thoma sends me to Jonathan Schwarz making the case that Obama knew perfectly well that the stimulus should have been bigger. Im not sure that lets his advisers completely off the hook; theres a big difference between saying, well, the macroeconomic case says this should be bigger, but smaller is OK, and saying  as they should have, and maybe some did  that a weak stimulus runs a large risk of setting us on a path toward a lost decade.

title: In Athens, Clinton Praises Greece for Tackling Its Debt
description: ATHENS  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday emphasized Washingtons strong support for Greeces commitment to right its debt-ridden economy through tough austerity measures, and she thanked the government for its contributions to NATO-led operations in Libya anddiplomatic efforts in the Middle East.

title: Rained Out in Vancouver
description: International soccer teams generally love coming to North America in the summer, but generally do not like playing on our fake grass, the plastic artificial surfaces in some big, big stadiums.

title: For FIFA Executives, Luxury and Favors
description: PARIS  The titans of international soccer are used to pampering. Motorcades. Police escorts. Five-star hotels. Lavish dinners. Cash allowances of $500 a day, and an additional $250 for their wives or girlfriends.

title: Times Editors Respond to my Shale Gas Column
description: Included below is a response from The Times national desk on my column Clashing Views on the Future of Natural Gas.

title: Mystery Mortgage Economics
description: As most of our attention is focused on the debt-ceiling crisis, another issue is coming to a head: whether prosecutors will rush to let banks off the hook for mortgage abuses in return for a modest settlement, without having done anything like a complete investigation.

title: Perry  More Comfortable With Idea of a Run
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas says that he is getting more and more comfortable every day with the idea of running for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Both Sides Confident on Debt Talks Despite Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  Top Republican lawmakers and the Obama administrations budget director predicted Sunday that an agreement would be reached before the federal government defaults on its debt in early August, but both sides continued to squabble over the details of competing proposals, offering little evidence that a deal was at hand.

title: Egypts Antiquities Chief Says He Will Lose His Job
description: Zahi Hawass, Egypts antiquities minister, who has been under fire for his ties to the Mubarak regime, will lose his job in a cabinet reshuffle intended to appease the protesters in Tahrir Square, he confirmed to The New York Times by text message on Sunday. The full details of the cabinet changes have not yet been confirmed. Mr. Hawasss pending departure was reported by an Egyptian newspaper, Youm7, and Mr. Hawass confirmed the reports accuracy. Youm7 quoted him as saying that protesters outside his office tried to beat him as he left on Sunday.

title: Former Ohio Attorney General to Head New Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Sunday that he would nominate Richard Cordray, the former attorney general of Ohio, to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, passing over Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard law professor who was the driving force behind the agencys creation.

title: Freeway Project Finishes (Surprise!) Ahead of Schedule
description: LOS ANGELES  Start your engines. Its safe to come back.

title: Japan Celebrates a Victory Worth Staying Up For
description: TOKYO  Fans here spilled into the streets at 6:45 a.m., hugging and cheering after Japan defeated the United States in the Womens World Cup final to lift the spirits of a country still reeling from the earthquake and tsunami that struck on March 11.

title: Womens World Cup Final: Japan Stuns U.S. in Shootout
description: Japan won the Womens World Cup for the first time on Sunday, stunning the United States in a penalty kick shootout after the teams played a pulsating 2-2 tie in Frankfurt, Germany.

title: Creditors See Talks Advancing on 2nd Greek Rescue
description: The group representing Greeces private creditors said Sunday that progress was being made in working out the involvement of international banks in the next Greek bailout.

title: Get Them From The Greeks
description: Ive complained a lot about the Hellenization of our economic discourse  the insistence, in the teeth of evidence, that America is just like Greece in budget terms. Now comes Lindsey Graham to promote the fallacy. So lets talk, again, about why its nonsense.

title: Millions of Muggles Propel Potter Film at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  And now we know the spell for raining cash.

title: Lawyer Says Mubarak Is in a Coma, but the Report Is Quickly Contradicted
description: CAIRO  Conflicts about the deteriorating health of former President Hosni Mubarak reached a new peak on Sunday, when his lawyer announced he had suffered a stroke and slipped into a coma, only to be contradicted hours later by state television and hospital officials who said he had a temporary bout of low blood pressure.

title: Karzai Adviser Is Killed at Kabul Home
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A close adviser to President Hamid Karzai was killed on Sunday night after two gunmen stormed his walled home here. It was the second killing in less than a week of one of the presidents trusted but controversial political allies.

title: Waiting for Harry, Chinese Filmgoers Get Patriotic Epic
description: BEIJING  It has been something of cruel summer for Chinese movie audiences. The latest installments of Hollywood blockbusters like Transformers: Dark of the Moon and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 have been delayed, and it is doubtful that American-made crowd pleasers like Horrible Bosses and The Hangover Part II will ever arrive in theaters. In the meantime countless moviegoers have been driven into cinemas as part of a government campaign to promote a sprawling epic about the Chinese Communist Party.

title: When Subways Werent Sardine Cans
description: In a City Room post accompanying his article about the rise in weekend subway ridership, Michael M. Grynbaum asked readers to recount their memories of the city subway system of the 1970s and 1980s, when riders had plenty of leg room on weekends, but had to contend with plenty of problems, too. Below, some of the more interesting reader responses, edited for style and space.

title: From a Long Toss From Shea to a Mets Closer
description: Pedro Beato vividly recalls the day he arrived in New York City from his native Dominican Republic.

title: Scotland Yard Chiefs Resignation Statement
description: As my colleagues Alan Cowell and Ravi Somaiya report, the commissioner of Londons Metropolitan Police Service, Sir Paul Stephenson, resigned his post on Sunday, as damage from a phone-hacking scandal moved to the highest levels of British public life.

title: After Brooklyn Boys Murder, Father of Etan Patz Has a Suggestion
description: Stanley Patz has been conditioned to expect his telephone to ring whenever a child goes missing, so he was bracing when he heard about the disappearance of an 8-year-old boy, Leiby Kletzky, last week in Brooklyn.

title: Hughes Pitches More Like His Old Self in a Win
description: TORONTO  A man wearing a gray uniform with New York on the front and No. 65 on the back stood atop the Rogers Centre mound Sunday. He looked like Phil Hughes, but it had been so long since the Yankees saw him fire fastballs and curveballs with precision against major league hitters that it seemed possible an impostor had replaced him.

title: Media Response to the Arrest of Rebekah Brooks
description: News of Sundays arrest of Rebekah Brooks, the former chief of Rupert Murdochs media operations in Britain, was greeted with a mix of righteous indignation that she had clung to power for so long, barely concealed glee by some of Mr. Murdochs rivals and conspicuous understatement in at least one of the tabloid newspapers that Ms. Brooks once edited.

title: Illuminating Californias Proposition 8 Trial, Onstage
description: A new play based on the Proposition 8 trial over same-sex marriage in California, written by the Academy Award winner Dustin Lance Black (Milk), will be performed in a staged reading on Broadway in September and then produced at Carnegie Mellon University, Northwestern, the University of Michigan, and elsewhere.

title: Reality Hits Hard, but the Short-Handed Mets Dont, in a Sloppy Defeat
description: One day after bullying an All-Star pitcher on the leagues best team, the Mets on Sunday painted a slightly more accurate portrait of how a third-place team missing its four best hitters should look.

title: This Carmen Seeks Liberty in a Bullring, With Strokes of Fate
description: The most important feature of the Mariinsky Ballets season at the Metropolitan Opera House last week is what it didnt contain. Its 50 years since the company (then named Kirov) first danced in New York and the West. Hitherto its visits have featured a large proportion of the 19th-century ballet classics. Not so this time. Of its three recent programs in New York, two were of ballets created in the 21st century, while the third was a pair of ballets from 1947 and 1967.

title: High Kicks, Mugging and Poses in the Park
description: Oh, SummerStage. You mean so well. You invite us out to sit under the stars. You offer a variety of refreshments and seating options and let us come and go as we please, asking only unobtrusively for a small donation.

title: A Captivity No Novelist Could Invent
description: I would love to be a writer someday, Jaycee Dugard wrote in her journal in 2002. I love to write. I have no idea what I would write about.

title: Inspired Play From an Award-Worthy Career
description: There are two new inductees to the American Contract Bridge Leagues Hall of Fame, Russ Arnold of Sunny Isles Beach, Fla., and Eric Kokish of Toronto.

title: The Price of Typos
description: Some readers like to see portraits of authors they admire, study their personal histories or hear them read aloud. I like to know whether an author can spell. Nabokov spelled beautifully. Fitzgerald was crummy at spelling, bedeviled by entry-level traps like definate. Bad spellers, of course, can be sublime writers and good spellers punctilious duds. But its still intriguing that Fitzgerald, for all his gifts, didnt perceive the word finite in definite, the way good spellers automatically do. Did this oversight color his impression of infinity? Infinaty?

title: Gun-Totin Brnnhilde
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  Not three months after singing her first Brnnhilde in the Metropolitan Operas new production of Wagners Walkre, the soprano Deborah Voigt is performing the title role in Irving Berlins Annie Get Your Gun here at the Glimmerglass Festival. Though a wide-ranging repertory is an admirable quality in an artist, it is quite a leap from Wagners Ring to a classic Broadway musical. Coming into this production, Ms. Voigt risked looking foolish.

title: The Old, Inexorable Story of a Kings Disintegration
description: The Royal Shakespeare Companys production of King Lear, directed by David Farr, can be strongly recommended for hypersensitive souls. Have you always found the play to be too devastating to endure, its serial acts of cruelty too relentless to witness? Do you share Samuel Johnsons moral outrage at the death of Cordelia in the last act? Hie thee to the Park Avenue Armory, where this competent but immaculately unwrenching production of Shakespeares harrowing tragedy is providing more than three hours of placid traffic on the stage.

title: To Pique Interest, Start-Ups Try a Digital Velvet Rope
description: Demand for Googles new social networking service, Google+, has been intense since its debut last month in a limited test mode. To get in, you must be invited by someone who is already a member, so Facebook and Twitter are peppered with requests for invitations to the service, and they have even been sold on eBay.

title: Such Stuff as Dreams Are Made on: A Tribute to Cunningham
description: Lets be pessimistic. Lets say that when the Merce Cunningham Dance Company shuts down after Dec. 31, his choreography will very seldom be seen again. What will have left the world with it? Many different answers arose while watching the all-day Merce Fair on Saturday. This, as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, occupied seven separate spaces in the Frederick P. Rose Hall. It was called a fair because a wide range of goods was on offer. Cunningham died two years ago this month; this day was the last of his companys many Lincoln Center appearances over the years.

title: The Sacred and the Humane
description: Human Rights are all the rage. They have become, currently, a very popular arena for both political activism and rampant discourse. Human rights, as we all know, are the rights humans are due simply by virtue of being human. But there is nothing simple here, since both human and rights are concepts in need of investigation.

title: Monday: Attack From Above
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I realize that some of you solve the puzzle when it comes out the day before, but for the sake of making my point, lets pretend that its Monday morning and you are settling in to solve with your first cup of coffee. Youve spent the weekend wrestling with the tough Friday and Saturday grids, and youve devoted most of your Sunday to finishing the big puzzle and the variety. A challenge is a wonderful thing, but now you need something to ease you into your week.

title: TNT Ends the Run of Ray Romanos Men
