description: Fans of TNTs Men of a Certain Age fretted this month that the show might not make it to a third season, and it turns out they were right to worry: the channel said on Friday that it was canceling the drama after two seasons. This was an extremely difficult decision for us, TNT said in a statement that read in part, While the show has featured great storytelling and impeccable performances, the audience simply hasnt built to the point where we can continue the series. The series  which averaged fewer than three million viewers in its second season  starred (above from left) Ray Romano, Andr Braugher and Scott Bakula as men who confronting life in their 50s, making the show something of an anomaly on TNT, which is best known for its crime procedurals. Mike Royce, a creator of the show, told AOL TV that he thanked TNT for trying: Its different from their other shows. But even though its different, they took a huge chance on it, and they gave it two seasons. The bottom line is that we would have gotten three episodes on a broadcast network.

title: Bessie Nominations to Be Announced
description: The 2011 New York Dance and Performance Awards, also known as the Bessies, will be presented on Oct. 24 at the Apollo Theater, organizers are to announce at a news conference on Monday. For the first time nominees in the outstanding production categories are being announced in advance. For outstanding production of a work performed in a location with more than 400 seats, the nominees are Thirteen Diversions by Christopher Wheeldon, performed by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House; Quartet by Merce Cunningham, performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Joyce Theater; and The Bright Stream by Alexei Ratmansky, performed by American Ballet Theater at the Met.

title: Hertz to Buy Donlen, a Fleet Leasing Company
description: Hertz Global Holdings agreed on Sunday to buy the Donlen Corporation, a vehicle leasing and management company, for $250 million in cash. Hertz will also assume Donlens $680 million of debt.

title: Tom Cruise Agrees to Play Jack Reacher
description: Never one to shy away from controversy, Tom Cruise, below, has agreed to play Jack Reacher in One Shot, an action thriller based on the best-selling series of books by Lee Child, according to Deadline.com. Reacher, a decorated military officer turned drifter, is described in the novels as standing 6 foot 5 and weighing 250 pounds; Mr. Cruises reported height is 5 foot 7. The physical discrepancy has already created some discontent among fans of the series, though Mr. Child has publicly supported the casting. Reachers size in the books is a metaphor for an unstoppable force, which Cruise portrays in his own way, he said. The movie, which is scheduled to begin filming in the fall, will be directed by Christopher McQuarrie, whose writing credits include Valkyrie and the coming Mission: Impossible  Ghost Protocol, both starring Mr. Cruise.

title: Scrambling and Personalizing the Rock Timeline
description: Guitars, guitars, guitars. They droned and scrabbled, pinged and screeched, buzzed and pealed through Saturday afternoon at the Village Voice/4Knots Music Festival, a free indie-rock concert at Pier 17 at South Street Seaport on Saturday afternoon. With just one stage and six bands, it was the pared-down successor to 10 years of the Siren Music Festival that The Voice used to present at Coney Island.

description: LONDON  European banks for years bolstered their balance sheets with assets considered safe and secure: the sovereign debt of European countries.

description: FRANKFURT  Japan won its first Womens World Cup on Sunday in a triumph built on hope, renewal, patience, composure and no small amount of good fortune, lifting a stricken country and somehow winning a match that the United States frequently dominated but could never control.

description: LOS ANGELES  If Louis B. Mayer haunts the Irving Thalberg Building, once his seat of power at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, he may recognize more than the walnut walls. The building is now the home of Sony Pictures Entertainment, and there are signs that Mayers old studio system is being revived.

The move was a protest against the presence on the bill of the foulmouthed, spiteful and fantastic Los Angeles rap collective Odd Future, whose appearance on this festival bill largely full of tasteful indie rock became a flashpoint for debates about violent and hateful imagery and messages in music. Rumors of a protest during the groups performance swirled.

title: Yemenis Organize Shadow Government
description: Even as antigovernment protesters in Yemen struggled to revitalize their movement, sketching somewhat shaky plans over the weekend for a transitional government, they produced a show of their core strength, taking to the streets in huge numbers on Sunday to protest the rule of President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

description: While many were transfixed by the womens World Cup final on Sunday afternoon, Greenhill & Company was doing something different: releasing its latest quarterly earnings.

description: They were three fabric scraps trimmed from the flag later planted on the moon by Neil Armstrong during the Apollo 11 mission. They never made it to the moon, but rather were discarded in a trash bin and recovered by Thomas Moser, a NASA engineer. And now  mounted to a poster with a nice photograph, and signed by Mr. Armstrong himself  they have sold for $45,000.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Security forces massed on Sunday near a key town in eastern Syria where dozens of soldiers have defected to join the four-month-old uprising against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, according to activists and residents there.

title: A Ferocious Gift Lures Anglers to Christmas Island
description: As a non-fish-eater, I was taken aback when Peter Kairaoi, the lead guide for Christmas Island Outfitters, took a healthy bite from a dead and rather pungent milkfish he was shredding and tossing into the water for chum. description: YOU may not need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows, as Bob Dylan put it, but it seems that Madison Avenue needed a census taker.

description: TEL AVIV, Israel  Jewish and Arab, straight and gay, secular and religious, the patients who come to Assuta Hospital in Tel Aviv every day are united by a single hope: that medical science will bring them a baby.

description: LOS ANGELES  Never, never tell jokes about a man with easy access to weapons of mass destruction, Peter Chernin, a former News Corporation official, once light-heartedly warned of Arnon Milchan, who has long tantalized Hollywood with his dual identity as a producer of popular movies and a businessman tied to the arms industry.

description: Nearly a month after the State Legislature passed a bill drastically expanding access to taxi service in New York City, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has yet to signal whether he will sign the measure  providing hope to the citys larger taxi fleet operators who oppose it.

description: It has now been 12 full years since the United States won a Womens World Cup of soccer, and it will be four more years before the women have another chance.

description: For years they have operated in the shadows, often far from Wall Street, trading stocks at warp speed and reaping billions while criticism rose that they were damaging markets and hurting ordinary investors.

title: Tickets for Final Shows by Cunningham Troupe
description: The Park Avenue Armory is announcing Aug. 15 as the on-sale date for the final six performances of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, along with world premieres by Shen Wei Dance Arts and Streb Extreme Action Company, completing the armorys first full season of artistic programming. Tickets to all three can be can be purchased at armoryonpark.org. According to the last wishes of Mr. Cunningham, tickets to his companys performances, which will be Dec. 29 to 31, are to cost $10. Announced before his death in 2009, the planned two-year legacy tour has traveled to more than 50 cities worldwide and signals an end to nearly 60 years of creativity from a master of modern dance and choreography. Rounding out the lineup, the new work by Shen Wei (Nov. 30 to Dec. 4), artist in residence at the armory, will combine digital projection with handmade scenic elements. Tickets will be $35. Streb (Dec. 14 to 22) will incorporate ziplines, bungee cords and trampolines for Kiss the Air!, a work that will make full use of the armorys 55,000-square-foot performance hall. Tickets are to cost $30.

This week, Film Forward, a Sundance Institute initiative, and FilmAid International, a humanitarian aid organization, are bringing a festival to Kenyas sprawling Kakuma and Dadaab camps, home to hundreds of thousands of refugees.

title: Superheroes, Surveyed and Sized Up
description: Theres nothing cool anymore about acknowledging the coolness of comic books. Popular culture is so far beyond that moment when comic characters  specifically those gifted, costumed adventurers known as superheroes  shed their reputation as fetish objects for children and marginalized adults and entered the mainstream. Were now well into an era when every summer weekend brings the opening of an X-Men or Green Lantern movie. Colorful crime fighters vivid uniforms and rippling physiques are used to sell everything from pro football apparel to Broadway musicals, while the characters themselves, untethered from their decades-long narrative traditions, are reduced to mere commodities. Forget about rescuing Lois Lane or Aunt May  now it is the superhero himself who needs saving.

title: Murdoch Aides Long Tried to Blunt Scandal Over Hacking
description: LONDON  Two days before it emerged that The News of the World had hacked the cellphone of a murdered schoolgirl, igniting a scandal that has shaken the media empire of Rupert Murdoch, his son James told friends that he thought the worst of the troubles were behind him. And he was confident that the News Corporations $12 billion bid for the satellite company British Sky Broadcasting would go through, according to a person present.

title: Drawing Dance: Cunningham at Dartmouth
description: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the fifth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Dartmouth College.

title: News Corp. Braces for Legal Trouble in the U.S.

Sullivan Jr. of Williams & Connolly, one of the most aggressive criminal defense lawyers in the country.

title: Breaking Bad Cooks Up Record Numbers
description: Despite a 13-month absence after an excruciatingly tense Season 3 cliffhanger, Breaking Bad set a ratings record in its return to AMC on Sunday night. According to Nielsen, an estimated 2.6 million people tuned in to witness the further misadventures of the meth dealers Walter White (Bryan Cranston) and Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) and to learn whether Jesse actually killed a fellow meth cooker. That number was 32 percent greater than the viewership for last seasons premiere, and was the highest total in the series history.

description: For the second week of our Summer Reading Contest, we received 72 entries  many of which, we noticed, came from just three schools, identified by student writers as BSGE, VCHS and RHS. description: One thing I didnt have room to get into in the text accompanying this weeks popsicle matrix is what you might call the meltiness factor. Created by Eight Inc., the designers behind the state-of-the-art Apple stores, this soaring modernist space eschews the traditional behind-the-counter retail approach in favor of a more user-friendly shopping experience. Eight large watch tables allow for accessible, easy viewing from all sides, whiledigital screens embedded in walls feature informative, up-to-the-minute videos. The store also features its own Rolex boutique  New York Citys first  which occupies almost a third of the space. To celebrate the new Madison Avenue location, Tourneau has launched a new line of timepieces, the TNY series, with the clean lines and strong look of the city that inspired it. title: You Say Pretentious as if Its a Bad Thing

Netflix occasionally suggests I stream her 2005 film Me and You and Everyone We Know, probably because I have viewed other so-called indie films. (Its quirky  like Clockwork Orange and Withnail and I?) So I started to watch it. The movie begins with July doing a kind of spoken-word piece, and I knew I had heard her voice before. After a few maddening minutes, it hit me: Shes the one who did The Arky Girl.

title: In Washington, Bocce and Barolo
description: At Vinoteca, a wine bar in the U Street corridor of Washington, D.C.s, the Districts popular bocce ball scene meets open-air snacking. Vinoteca itself is a perfectly fine wine bar, if a bit hushed and dimly lit, but the real action is happening around back: a clustered courtside next to a mock-rustic bocce ball lane made of tile and crushed oyster shells. Bocce  a game that can be described as shuffleboard with balls, or curling sans ice  is enjoying something of a youthful renaissance these days in Washington, spearheaded by the DC Bocce League, an organization with teams across the D.C. area and a membership roll that includes staffers, interns, pollsters, wonks and all manner of Washingtonian young professionals. They play mostly in outdoor parks and on lawns, but these sites have nothing on the backyard at Vinoteca, which could be a miniaturized village square in Torre del Greco, were it not for the condo developments towering above or the Rite Aid across the street. Such open-air surroundings are best accompanied by offerings from the outdoor grill: fresh barbecued monkfish in romesco, warmed olives and almonds, a bluefish tuna sandwich on rustic bread and assorted Mediterranean sausages. Perhaps best of all is the playful by-the-glass wine list, including a dry assyrtiko from Santorini, Greece, and a viognier from nearby Rappahannock Cellars, in Virginia.

title: Zimbabwe: Charges Are Dropped Against Energy Minister
description: The state withdrew a charge of criminal abuse of office on Monday against Energy Minister Elton Mangoma, a leader of the Movement for Democratic Change that has opposed President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Mangoma had been scheduled to go on trial on Monday. The state also further downgraded charges against Munyaradzi Gwisai and five other activists who had been accused in February of plotting to topple Mr. Mugabe after watching videos of the uprising in Egypt. The original treason charge has been replaced by a charge of conspiring to commit public violence and participating in a gathering to promote violence. They are scheduled for trial on Aug. 22.

title: Vatican and Malaysia Normalize Ties
description: The Vatican and the predominantly Muslim nation of Malaysia established diplomatic relations on Monday, a sign that the Southeast Asian nations government was opening to religious minorities after interfaith tensions had shaken the countrys Catholic community. The Holy See announced the agreement after Pope Benedict XVI and high-ranking Vatican officials met with Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia at Castel Gandolfo, the popes summer residence outside Rome. In recent years, tensions have been high between Catholics, who make up about 3 percent of Malaysias population, and the Malaysian government. Catholics have complained of vandalism against churches and the governments confiscation of Malay-language Bibles because of a ban on the use of Allah as a Malay-language translation for God.

title: Yankees Waiting to See How Much Colon Has Left
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  In another two starts, Bartolo Colon should surpass the 100-inning mark, which he has not done since 2005. The Yankees were concerned about his durability heading into the season, and his struggles over his last two outings  13 runs and 16 hits in six and a third innings  raised the possibility that he is nearing his expiration date. That issue has come into focus with the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline less than two weeks away.

title: Court Orders Thailand and Cambodia to Withdraw from Disputed Temple
description: The top judicial body of the United Nations ordered Cambodia and Thailand to withdraw troops from a disputed temple on Monday and established a demilitarized zone along their mountainous border. The two countries have fought each other numerous times in recent years near Preah Vihear, an ancient hilltop temple that stirs nationalist sentiments in both countries and where Cambodian troops are seen in the photo above. Both sides said they would comply with the order by the International Court of Justice in The Hague. However, the Thai military has in the past criticized concessions on the temple by the countrys civilian leadership and may balk at what they perceive as giving further ground to Cambodia.

title: Russia: Four Arrested for Plotting Attack
description: Russian authorities have arrested four people suspected of planning a major terrorist attack in the Moscow region, Aleksandr Bortnikov, the head of Russias domestic intelligence agency, said Monday. The suspects, who were arrested several days ago, were from Russias North Caucasus, a violence-plagued, mostly Muslim region that is a hotbed of terrorist activity in Russia. Mr. Bortnikov said the suspects had planned to bomb transportation infrastructure and other crowded places, but did not provide further details. The police confiscated a homemade bomb with an estimated explosive force of 22 pounds of TNT, as well as other weapons and maps.

title: Schools Dropping 413 From Staff
description: The District of Columbia public schools has sent termination notices to 413 teachers and other school employees, including 288 for poor performance, under an evaluation system that has become a national model. District officials said that 113 of the employees had been rated ineffective, and that an additional 175 had been rated minimally effective for a second consecutive year in a system that emphasizes students performance on standardized tests as well as on classroom observations. In addition, 104 employees will be let go because they failed to meet state license requirements, and 21 others because they were unable to find permanent positions a year after losing their previous jobs as a result of budget cuts and program changes. Supporters of the evaluation system have praised it as setting clear standards and enforcing consequences for ineffective teaching. But it is disliked by some unionized teachers and has been criticized as doing little to help struggling teachers and not factoring in the challenges faced by those working in poor schools.

title: No Protection for Pines in Peril
description: The Fish and Wildlife Service said Monday that the whitebark pine, devastated by bark beetles and fungus, deserved to be listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act. But it said it could not spare money and staff time to do so and to give the trees the protections that come from a listing. The agencys finding noted that scientific studies showed a substantial and pervasive decline throughout almost the entire range of the species in the West. The decline has been linked to global warming because the pine beetle is increasingly able to survive warmer winters and cause more damage when spring arrives. In the hardest-hit areas, Yellowstone and Glacier National Parks, about two-thirds of whitebark pines are gone.

It is staffed by Chai Lifeline, an organization whose more-usual mission is to restore the light of childhood to children whose innocence ended when life-threatening or lifelong illness was diagnosed. It was not designed for such a tragedy; then again, what is?

title: Waiting for a Deal

Yes, ladies and gentlemen, we are assured that an agreement is near. We think. Could get hung up, though. So check back when more lawyers in suits pony up to another microphone and we feel more of our brain cells sliding into a deep freeze.

description: The gay pride parade continues in Riverdale, the longtime home of Archie Andrews and his friends. Kevin Keller, the first openly gay resident of the town, who was introduced in issue No. 202 of Veronica in September, will have his own monthly comic book starting in February. Hes proven to be incredibly popular, said Jon Goldwater, co-chief executive of Archie Comics. Were just so proud of the success of Kevin and the fact that he adds a new dynamic to Riverdale.

title: Watermelon Gazpacho
description: This is adapted from a watermelon and tomato soup in Anya von Bremzens wonderful book "The New Spanish Table." Ill admit that I was skeptical about this recipe when I tried it, but it turned out to be a delicious surprise. The celery brings this combination together, so dont leave it out.

description: MADRID  Spain sold one-year bills on Tuesday at the highest yield since 2008, underlining broader concerns about the ailing euro zone economies amid tense negotiations over another rescue package for Greece.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama seized on the re-emergence of an ambitious bipartisan budget plan in the Senate on Tuesday to invigorate his push for a big debt-reduction deal, and he summoned Congressional leaders back to the bargaining table this week to start talking turkey.

title: Geography Report Card Finds Students Lagging
description: Even as schools aim to better prepare students for a global work force, fewer than one in three American students are proficient in geography, with most eighth graders unable to explain what causes earthquakes or accurately describe the American Southwest, according to a report released Tuesday morning.

title: The Very Long Weekend
description: I apologize. This blog post is anything but timely. I admit to being laid low by recent events: a Memorial Day fire led to a nightmare June of inspector hunting and permit gathering, culminating in two days of actual repair  all of which brought us to our third opening in less than a calendar year. Just in time for the Fourth of July. And fireworks. Not the celebratory exploding rainbows of the Grucci Brothers, more like the gruesome tales of the Brothers Grimm where an evil queen casts evil spells while stirring a smoldering cauldron behind a castle parapet in some dark forest.

title: Mercedes-Benz Builds Twin Torture Chambers for Climate Tests
description: On Monday, Mercedes-Benz announced the completion of two climatic tunnels built to simulate extreme weather conditions for testing vehicles at its technology center in Sindelfingen, Germany.

title: State Department Wont Seek Extradition of the Quaids, Prosecutor Says
description: While they may live in fear of so-called star whackers, the Hollywood couple Randy and Evi Quaid are momentarily safe from United States authorities and will not be extradited from Canada, The Associated Press reported. The husband and wife fugitives have been wanted in California for months, and not by fans who want to tell Mr. Quaid they loved his performance in The Last Detail: in 2009 the couple were arrested in Texas for skipping out on a hotel bill in Santa Barbara, Calif., and missed several court dates before finally facing justice. (Charges against Mr. Quaid were dropped, and Mrs. Quaid was sentenced to probation and community service.)

title: Court Permits Hindus Who Were Served Meat to Sue for a Purifying Trip to India
description: A New Jersey appeals court has ruled that a group of Hindu diners can sue to be flown to India to resolve a dispute over an order of samosas, The Star-Ledger is reporting.

Instead, Id suggest that you devote most of your attention to President Obamas approval ratings and perhaps the favorability ratings of the Republican candidates, as well as to things like economic forecasts.

title: A Screen-Free Week at the Beach?
description: ML Nichols, a founder of theparentconnection.org, had better not be reading this today. She is off on vacation in Nantucket, Mass., and she was the one who declared it a screen-free week at the family beach house. After all, her Web site is dedicated to healthy parent-child connections, and is filled with photos of beach sand and backyard tents and trees, so she wants to practice as she preaches.

title: Once-Celebrated Recklessness Leads to Dykstras Financial Fall
description: LOS ANGELES  Before promoting a single stock or venturing into the perilous world of magazine publishing, Lenny Dykstra lived the good life, essentially risk-free. He signed autographs, shook hands and banked the profits from his car-wash business.

title: More Reserves May Be Asked of Top Banks
description: Regulators said on Tuesday that 28 of the worlds biggest and most interconnected banks would be required to hold more capital in reserve than less important banks would under proposals intended to keep the failure of one or two large institutions from causing a calamity.

title: A Growing Crowd Follows The Bachelorette and Her Search for Love
description: Reality programming once again dominated prime time as a two-hour version of The Bachelorette was the most-watched program on Monday evening, with an average of 7.7 million viewers tuning into ABCs matchmaking show. As Ashley Hebert met the families of her various suitors and whittled down her true love options to three from four, the audience numbers actually grew over the course of the episode.

title: Paul McCartney Documentary, The Love We Make, Coming to Showtime
description: No amount of coverage of the lives of the Beatles could make us say its all too much, and the cable networks are surely relieved to hear it. Following an announcement by HBO that it had acquired a documentary about George Harrison, Showtime said on Tuesday that it would broadcast a nonfiction feature about Paul McCartney and his experiences in New York after the 9/11 terrorist attacks. The film, The Love We Make, will chronicle Mr. McCartneys journey from Sept. 11, 2001, when his plane was grounded on a New York tarmac, through his planning for and performance at the Concert for New York City at Madison Square Garden the next month. The Love We Make will feature footage from that concert as well as appearances by Mr. McCartneys friends and colleagues, including David Bowie, Eric Clapton, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Pete Townshend, as well as his daughter Stella. It is directed by Bradley Kaplan and Albert Maysles, the venerated co-director of Grey Gardens and Gimme Shelter, as well as the 1964 documentary Whats Happening! The Beatles in the U.S.A.

description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Google thinks it can be young and crazy again. And it is betting $200 million that it is right.

title: Anticlimax in Long-Running CSX Railroad Court Case
description: Remember the epic battle between CSX, the big railroad company, and the Childrens Investment Fund Management, a British hedge fund? If you do not, you are not alone. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit appears to have forgotten it as well. It took the federal court two years to give out its opinion deciding the litigation fight between the parties, in a ruling that came down on Monday that left some issues unsettled long after the battle subsided.

title: The Lure of Cocaine, Once Hailed as Cure-All

Mariani combined ground coca leaves with Bordeaux in the 1860s and marketed his tonic wine under the name Vin Mariani. Each fluid ounce contained six milligrams of cocaine. The wine expert Robert Parker would surely have given this bright liquid 110 points.

description: WASHINGTON  Representative Michele Bachmann suffers from migraine headaches so intense that she has sometimes sought emergency medical treatment, but the congresswoman said Tuesday that the condition would not preclude her from serving as president if elected.

title: The Chain Gang
description: We saw it first on the spring runways at Valentino and Chlo  models wearing delicate gold anklets with the daintiest flats. Then, for resort, the Row collaborated with the jewelry designer Ileana Makri on charmy versions of the accessory. And earlier this week the blogger Garance Dor confessed her love for the delicate adornment. Its official: The anklet is de rigueur again. I made one for myself last summer, and I absolutely love it, the jewelry designer Irene Neuwirthsays. I dont wear it every day, but I do find that once I put it on I dont take it off. Cant wait until the Rows resort version hits stores? Dor recommends doing it yourself. I love the simple ones  tiny gold or silver bracelets will do, small beads I put on a string, or even just a piece of colored cord, she says. Its charming when it feels easy.

title: DuPont Is Sued Over New Herbicide

description: Kota, in the northern Indian state of Rajasthan, once was the dominion of Umed Singh II, a maharajah who is said to have enjoyed hunting big game from his 1925 Rolls-Royce New Phantom Torpedo Tourer. While there is no record that a torpedo had been mounted to the car, the body-style distinction is appropriate, as seemingly every other form of ballistic matriel found its way onto the cars flanks or into its cabin.

description: As Pilobolus continues its 40th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater, the group, which started in 1971 and is named after a fungus, is  by the looks of it  working hard to maintain its playful edge. At least that was evident in Monday nights program, which was overlong and slightly improvised to make up for the dancer Eriko Jimbos recent injury.

title: At G.E. Plant in Connecticut, Volts Plug In to the Sun
description: PLAINVILLE, Conn.  On Monday morning, no fewer than five Chevrolet Volts were charging on 100 percent renewable energy from General Electrics parking-lot Solar Carport. Opened in May, the 100-kilowatt solar installation, which also offers some shade and weather protection and has 10 connected G.E.-built chargers, is projected to last 25 years and provide 125 megawatt-hours of electricity annually, according to G.E.

title: Strong Sales Help Extend Apple Streak
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Strong sales to shoppers in emerging markets and to business customers helped Apple extend its lengthy streak of stellar performance in its earnings report on Tuesday.

title: Illegal Sale of Rice Wine Thrives in Chinese Enclaves
description: The restaurant looks like so many others in the roiling heart of Chinatown, in Lower Manhattan: a garish sign in Chinese and English, slapdash photos of featured dishes taped to the windows, and extended Chinese families crowding around tables, digging into communal plates of steamed fish, fried tofu and sauted watercress.

title: All Hail the Gang of Six (or Seven)
description: Finally, some not-dispiriting news from Washington: President Obama has given his qualified support to a new plan to reduce the deficit, remarking that it is broadly consistent with what weve been working on at the White House. And who put forward this proposal that could help stave off economic catastrophe? A bipartisan group of seven senators called the Gang of Six. (Congress has never been good with numbers.) Earlier this year, Bill Keller wrote a column for the magazine praising the gangs efforts, which he said proved that the word politician need not be a synonym for craven, and its certainly worth rereading now.

title: A Daughter of Strauss-Kahn Is Questioned
description: PARIS  Investigators have questioned the daughter of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, as part of an investigation into accusations that he attempted to rape a young writer, Tristane Banon, in 2003, an official at the prosecutors office said on Tuesday.

title: Critics Picks Video: This is Spinal Tap
description: A. O. Scott turns his critical meter up to 11 when looking back at Rob Reiners 1984 comedy This Is Spinal Tap. The film, which takes a mockumentary look inside the workings of the fictional rock band Spinal Tap, succeeds because it takes its characters seriously.

title: Profit Up 13%, UnitedHealth Raises Outlook
description: The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nations largest health insurers, reported its second-quarter results on Tuesday, and the good news for the industry appeared likely to continue. UnitedHealth announced a double-digit increase in profits and raised its estimates for 2011 earnings, according to its news release. Its net income rose 13 percent, to $1.27 billion, or $1.16 a share, compared with $1.12 billion, or 99 cents a share, one year ago. And revenue increased 8 percent, to $25.23 billion.

title: Joffrey Ballet Dancers Agree to Tentative Deal
description: After threatening a lockout, the Joffrey Ballet has reached a tentative settlement with its dancers, The Chicago Sun-Times reported. The company, based in Chicago, was in a contract dispute over salaries and rehearsal hours. The Joffrey wanted to increase the hours, to the chagrin of the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union representing the dancers and stage managers, who maintained they were not being compensated adequately for the extra time. This month the managers of the Joffrey sent a letter to its dancers, who were on a scheduled vacation, telling them that performances would be canceled unless a contract was signed. Christopher Clinton Conway, the Joffreys executive director, told The Sun-Times that, pending a vote by the dancers, a tentative agreement had been reached. The new contract, for five years instead of the previous contracts three, includes a minimum 10 percent raise. The dancers will be back in class on Monday, and rehearsals will begin, as planned, on July 25, Mr. Conway said. Representatives for the guild could not be reached, The Sun-Times said.

title: Bushwacker Is a Tough Bull
description: Since October 2009, no professional bull rider has been able to stay on Bushwacker for eight seconds. At a recent event in Pueblo, Colo., the riders explained why he's so tough to ride.

title: Jumping and Spinning, a Ballerina With Hooves
description: Dustin Elliott, a 145-pound professional cowboy, popped into the chute and felt energized by the lights above and the 1,600-pound bull beneath him. He wrapped a rope around his right hand, twisted right to left four times, then bounced up and down three times. The bull, meanwhile, looked casually to the left and waited.

title: Pakistans Military Plotted to Tilt U.S. Policy, F.B.I. Says
description: WASHINGTON  Pakistans military, including its powerful spy agency, has spent $4 million over two decades in a covert attempt to tilt American policy against Indias control of much of Kashmir  including funneling campaign donations to members of Congress and presidential candidates, the F.B.I. claimed in court papers unsealed Tuesday.

title: Hahn Is Sworn In to House of Representatives
description: The House of Representatives welcomed its 433rd member on Tuesday when Janice Hahn was sworn in, one week after her special election victory to replace former Representative Jane Harman in Californias 36th Congressional District.

title: Panel Recommends Coverage for Contraception
description: WASHINGTON  A leading medical advisory panel recommended on Tuesday that all insurers be required to cover contraceptives for women free of charge as one of several preventive services under the new health care law.

title: Columbia Student to Be Sentenced to 6 Months Over Drug Ring
description: A Columbia University student who was the main target of an undercover investigation of a ring that sold drugs from the campus will be sentenced to six months in jail after pleading guilty Tuesday to selling cocaine.

title: Shades of Gay
description: Long before New York sanctioned same-sex marriage, iO Tillet Wright, a photographer and writer based here, was at work on a project celebrating sexual freedom. My goal is to show the humanity that exists in every one of us through the simplicity of a face, she says of her mission to photograph as many people as possible who arent 100 percent straight.

title: New Yorks New Frozen Treats
description: I HAD never been so grateful to see a banana.

title: Quick! Before Summer Melts Away
description: New Yorkers enjoying the new sweets of the season at street fairs, flea markets and street carts.

description: Proposed legislation in Congress seeks to reduce identity theft by eliminating distribution of Social Security numbers. Not on the computer, but on a small piece of paper carried by millions of people: the Medicare card.

title: Legal Drama Has a Change of Venue, From Cable to Satellite
description: A select group of television viewers received an unusual voice mail recently. Hi, this is John Goodman, it began, in that actors familiar husky voice. Im calling to tell you about the season premiere of the Emmy Award-winning show Damages, starring Glenn Close, Rose Byrne and me. Tune in tomorrow night on Channel 239. Hey, its only the best show on television. And its only on DirecTV.

title: Iced Coffee and Tea: (Not) Taking the Heat
description: ICED coffees and teas should be some of summers simplest pleasures, especially when we just steep them in cold tap water, with no kitchen heat and next to no effort. But if you make even a desultory search for advice on cold brewing, you may find yourself mopping your brow deciding how, and even whether, to proceed.

title: Q. and A. With Harold McGee on Brewing Coffee and Tea
description: In his Curious Cook column this week, Harold McGee, whose most recent book is Keys to Good Cooking: A Guide to Making the Best of Foods and Recipes, writes about making iced coffee and tea. On Diners Journal hell be answering readers questions about brewing coffee and tea, hot or cold. Submit your question as a comment below and hell respond later this week.

title: Damson Plums Flavor Finger Lakes Gin
description: Damson plum jam is utterly English. But take those dark little plums, grown by Red Jacket Orchards in Geneva, N.Y., extract the juice and mix it with small-batch gin from upstate and you have a thoroughly New York drink. Its old-fashioned sloe gin, updated (sloes are a small plumlike fruit). Tart-sweet and 33 percent alcohol, its labeled liqueur by Scott Krahn, who makes it in the Finger Lakes region to add to the line of products made by his company, the American Gin Company based in Manhattan. It does wonders for iced black tea on a late summer afternoon. Use it in sparkling wine to give a new twist to kir royale. Or mix it 50-50 with plain gin, a splash of orange juice and a few drops of orange bitters over ice, and call it whatever you want. The liqueurs name, Averell, nails its Empire State pedigree as it refers to a former governor, a Harriman, from a line of railroad moguls.

title: Staff Tells N.R.C. That U.S. Rules Need Overhaul After Fukushima
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commissions rules are a patchwork that needs to be reorganized and integrated into a new structure to improve safety, the agencys staff told the five members of the commission on Tuesday at a meeting.

description: HAMA, Syria  In this city that bears the scars of one of the modern Middle Easts bloodiest episodes, the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad has begun to help Syrians imagine life after dictatorship as it forges new leaders, organizes its own defense and reckons with a grim past in an uncertain experiment that showcases the forces that could end Mr. Assads rule.

title: Diligently Turning Dostoyevsky German
description: Its not apparent from the title, but Vadim Jendreykos elegant, slightly chilly documentary, The Woman With the 5 Elephants, is a profile of Svetlana Geier, a small and formidable woman who was the pre-eminent translator of Dostoyevskys novels into German. (The five elephants refer to her valedictory project, a 20-year effort to retranslate his five major novels, which she completed in 2007; she died, at 87, in 2010.)

Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: Ombudsman Criticizes ESPNs Rules in Review of Reporters Book
description: A report by the Poynter Review Project, ESPNs ombudsman, concluded Tuesday that fuzzy in-house rules about letting writers be co-authors of books with subjects they cover led in part to the networks benching of the reporter Bruce Feldman. title: A Better Sort of Pig
description: In May, I went to Iowa, primarily to learn more about so-called conventional agriculture, those thousand-acre farms growing corn and soybeans, planted, tended and harvested largely by machine. (We have plenty of the other type  whats variously called traditional, or alternative, or non-conventional  in the Northeast.) But thanks to an auspicious combination of topsoil, climate, topography and weather, Iowa is among the best locales for farming in North America, and I saw a wide range of practices.

description: ASPEN, Colo.  Twitter is facing a federal government investigation, competition from Google+ and the departure of two of its founders. But Dick Costolo, Twitters chief executive, has a message for the naysayers: the business is growing just fine.

title: Trusting Families to Help Themselves
description: On Friday, I reported on the Family Independence Initiative (F.I.I.), an organization that encourages low-income families to define their own goals and work towards them in mutual support groups, while carefully documenting their successes. (F.I.I. pays modest stipends for the research data provided by families.). So far, the few hundred families that F.I.I. has worked with have demonstrated impressive gains in areas like income and savings, debt reduction, skills training, and improvements in childrens grades and health care.

title: Trenton Left-Hander Rushes to the Majors
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When a player is promoted to the majors for the first time, the first person he tells is usually a parent. It was no different Tuesday for the left-hander Steve Garrison, who was recalled by the Yankees. Except that Garrison did not share the good news with his mother, Patty, over the phone. He just walked into the next room.

description: For three days last month, an artist named Kyle McDonald secretly programmed computers at two Apple stores in Lower Manhattan to shoot a webcam picture every minute. As people squinted, frowned, glared, grinned, grimaced, snarled and other ways looked at the screens, their pictures were snapped, silently. Then the photos were automatically sent to Mr. McDonalds server.

He has spent much of his 18 months in the corner office cleaning up the mess left by his predecessor, Ken Lewis. But despite the yeoman efforts, he has failed to convince investors that he is turning the company around.

title: Lottery Numbers

description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle by Peter A. Collins comes with a Notepad, and I highly suggest reading it so you catch all of the great stuff he has managed to cram into the grid. If you are not solving in a way that enables you to see it, the Notepad says: When this puzzle is done, you will find that the ends of the answers to the five starred clues, when in the 15-/67-Across, comprise a 1-/71-Across. title: A Gay Man Seeks a Place in an Orthodox World
description: In his evocative 2009 docudrama, The Temperamentals, the playwright Jon Marans examined the stigma of being gay in pre-Stonewall America, when the threat of exposure could leave friendships, careers and even lives dangling by a thread.

description: The father of a man who plotted in 2009 to set off homemade bombs in Manhattan subway cars tried to thwart investigators by destroying evidence and misleading a grand jury, a relative testified on Tuesday.

description: A lawyer who helped to plot a $100 million securities fraud scheme that sold fundamentally worthless stocks to a series of investors, including Yale University, was convicted of grand larceny on Tuesday, prosecutors said.

description: Last year, Cole Real Estate Investments of Phoenix, a sponsor of nontraded real estate investment trusts, refunded $3 million to the West Warwick, R.I., pension board, which had bought shares in one of its REITs despite strenuous objections from its investment adviser, who resigned in protest.

title: Reyes and Beltran Return to Lineup, Lifting Mets Spirits and Fortunes
description: Jose Reyes had kicked off his plaid sneakers by 3:40 p.m. on Tuesday and had his wrists taped for batting practice, which was still an hour away. He said he had arrived at Citi Field at 1:50, a half-hour earlier than usual, eager to play his first game for the Mets in 17 days.

description: The Ivy League will announce on Wednesday that, in an effort to minimize head injuries among its football players, it will sharply reduce the number of allowable full-contact practices teams can hold.

title: City Asking Cuomo to Veto a Measure It Helped Write
description: For the last three years, lawyers for the Bloomberg administration have argued in court alongside transportation union lawyers for the extension of unusual job protections for school bus drivers and other employees that can amount to lifetime job guarantees. But now that unlikely alliance is heading toward an abrupt end.

title: West Calls Wasserman Schultz Vile
description: Representative Allen West, Republican of Florida, called Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida, the most vile, unprofessional, and despicable member of the U.S. House of Representatives in an e-mail to her on Tuesday.

Ivins, an Army scientist, prepared the deadly powder in his Army laboratory.

title: Harrisburg Council Rejects Financial Rescue Plan
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  The City Council in this financially struggling city rejected a statesponsored recovery program on Tuesday, in an act of rebellion against state and county officials who had repeatedly pressured the city to accept it.

title: Diabetes Drug Dapagliflozin Rejected by F.D.A. Panel
description: A federal advisory committee voted 9 to 6 on Tuesday that a first-of-its-kind diabetes drug should not be approved for use because of safety concerns, including a possible increased risk of breast and bladder cancers.

title: Delaware: Suit Filed Over Herbicide
description: A Pennsylvania homeowner and an Indiana golf course company have filed a class-action lawsuit against DuPont charging that the company was negligent or reckless in putting a new weed killer on the market. The suit, filed Monday in federal court in Delaware, asserts that the herbicide, Imprelis, is killing trees, shrubs and ornamental plants across the country. It seeks compensation for all damage suffered as a result of applications of Imprelis, an injunction barring DuPont from selling the product and unspecified punitive damages. In a statement, DuPont said it was confident that this purported class-action lawsuit is unfounded, and we will oppose it vigorously.

title: California: Inquiry Into Life on the Run
description: A federal grand jury is to hear testimony on the time that the Boston crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger and his girlfriend, Catherine Greig, spent evading the authorities, living under aliases in a Santa Monica apartment a few blocks from the beach. Joshua Bond, the property manager of the building where Mr. Bulger and Ms. Greig lived since the late 1990s, said he received a subpoena last week asking him to appear in federal court in Boston next week. Mr. Bulger and Ms. Greig used the aliases Charles and Carol Gasko while they lived in Santa Monica, paying their $1,165 rent for their two-bedroom, rent-controlled apartment in cash. A tip led the F.B.I. to their apartment, and agents said they found guns, a hand grenade, handcuffs and $822,000 in cash hidden inside the walls.

title: Ecolab Nears $5 Billion Deal for Nalco
description: Ecolab, the disinfectants maker, is near a deal to buy the water treatment company Nalco Holding  for about $5 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

His left hamstring required no such treatment after holding up on the mound and in his mind. But the Yankees perception of a successful game did not begin and end with Colon, however impressively he pitched.

A bill, approved by a House committee last week, would do just that, damaging one of most important civil rights programs in the country.

title: Taxis Beyond Manhattan
description: Manhattan looks like a sea of taxis, but its a different picture in many other parts of the city. A city study of GPS data shows that 97.5 percent of the more than 13,230 yellow cabs pick up their fares in Manhattan or at the two city airports. That leaves about 80 percent of the citys population underserved.

description: LONDON  Rupert and James Murdoch said repeatedly during their extended testimony before a parliamentary committee in Britain that their involvement in managing the News Corporations response to the phone hacking scandal was limited. title: Spirit of Middle East Protests Doesnt Spare Israel
description: TEL AVIV  The tents are lined up on the grassy median of this citys most stylish avenue, scores of them, populated by a downtown mix of characters: the unemployed down-and-out next to the artistic elite; half-naked men in straw hats; women in minidresses. Surrounding them are protest posters (The only place left to live is the cemetery) and designated spots for cooking or getting an Internet connection.

title: Jordans Protesters Ask Little, and Receive Less
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Since January, when Jordans protest movement started holding regular demonstrations, the marches have grown, and persisted, but have never reached a critical mass. Hobbled by infighting and outflanked by King Abdullah II and his security forces, the protesters keep calling for greater freedoms and an end to corruption, but remain frustrated that their regular gatherings  sometimes only two-hour affairs  have hastened no real change.

title: Athletic Performance and the Monthly Cycle
description: What makes a female athlete different from a male athlete? Watching Abby Wambach leap above defenders in a World Cup soccer game to head the ball decisively into the net, or seeing her teammate Megan Rapinoe streak a pass down the pitch, the answer might seem to be: not much. As a group, female athletes, like their male counterparts, display coordination, strength, grace, speed, stamina and a bracing competitiveness.

title: Baryshnikov Arts Center  Announces Fall Season
description: The New York premiere of C.I.C.T./Thtre des Bouffes du Nords production of Samuel Becketts Fragments is one of the highlights of the Baryshnikov Arts Center 2011 fall season, which will run from Sept. 8 to Dec. 16. Fragments is the centers second co-presentation with Theater for a New Audience. Three new dance pieces, by the choreographers Deganit Shemy and Liz Gerring and the Irish step dancer Colin Dunne, are also in the lineup. Musical offerings include a co-presentation with the Orchestra of St. Lukes and two world premiere evening-length performances by the International Contemporary Ensemble.

title: U.S. to Close 800 Computer Data Centers
description: The federal government plans to shut 40 percent of its computer centers over the next four years to reduce its hefty technology budget and modernize the way it uses computers to manage data and provide services to citizens.

title: Israelis Board Yacht Off Gaza
description: Israeli naval forces boarded a French yacht off the Gaza coast on Tuesday, as the yacht tried to breach the Israeli maritime blockade of the Palestinian enclave. The forces met no resistance, Israeli military officials said, and steered the yacht toward the Israeli port of Ashdod. The yacht is a remnant of an international flotilla that had planned to challenge the blockade last month but was mostly thwarted. The military said that when the yacht reached Ashdod, the passengers would be questioned by the Israeli police and then turned over to immigration authorities.

title: France: War Dead Are Honored
description: French President Nicolas Sarkozy on Tuesday presided over a national ceremony in remembrance of the seven service members who were killed in Afghanistan last week, the deadliest week for French troops there since 2008. The entire country bows before your coffins, Mr. Sarkozy said in a speech at the Htel des Invalides, where Napoleon is buried. Five of the troops died in a suicide attack in eastern Afghanistan, while a French Navy commando was killed by insurgents and a 22-year-old soldier was shot by friendly fire. The toll amplified the calls to speed up the withdrawal of French troops from the country. In a surprise visit to Afghanistan last week, Mr. Sarkozy said that France would withdraw 1,000 of its approximately 4,000 troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2012.

title: India: Clinton Urges Open Markets
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pressed India on Tuesday to open its markets further and to amend a crucial regulation that would make it possible for American companies to bid for lucrative nuclear contracts there. Mrs. Clinton, stopping in India for three days on a 12-country tour, also pledged the United States support in fighting terrorism. Her visit, her second as secretary of state, came a week after three bombs ripped through heavily populated areas of Mumbai, killing 19 people.

title: China: Reporting Team Disbanded
description: One of Chinas leading investigative reporting teams has been disbanded because it focused too much on social ills, reporters in the team say. The China Economic Times five-person team was a rarity in China. It had tackled a variety of social problems, most recently for exposing how officials had covered up the distribution of fake vaccinations that had led to childrens deaths.

title: Is Dividing a Company the Way to Beat the Affordable Care Act?
description: Thats one notion that seems to be circulating among small-business owners and their advisers lately. Consultants at McKinsey & Company floated the suggestion as part of their controversial report on employer views of health insurance. And in The Timess coverage of that report, Milt Freudenheim interviewed a small-business owner who said he was hoping to game the system. The owner, Gerry Harkins, who is also chairman of the National Federation of Independent Businesss Georgia State Leadership Council, said he might split his Atlanta-based construction company into two smaller companies to evade the overhauls employer mandate, specifically the penalties on companies that fail to offer affordable health insurance to employees.

title: Afghanistan: Taliban Deny Reports of Leaders Death, Citing Hacking
description: Taliban spokesmen denied reports sent through their e-mail and in text messages early Wednesday that their movements leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was dead, saying that their Web sites and telephones had been hacked. Zabiullah Mujahid, one of the spokesmen, reached by telephone, said: The enemy hijacked our telephone numbers and e-mails. They have sent out false texts and statements about death of Mullah Omar. In reality he is alive and in good condition.

title: Does Google Make Us Smarter, Dumber or Both?
description: Why is your brain on Google better than your brain sans Google? Because it gives you somewhere to store all that trivia you would otherwise have to waste precious brain cells remembering. Or so says Jonah Lehrer, via Andrew Sullivan on the Daily Dish, who points out that Google not only helps us remember but also helps us correct our often faulty memories. While the Web enables all sorts of other biases  it lets us filter news, for instance, to confirm what we already believe  the use of the Web as a vessel of transactive memory is mostly virtuous. We save hard drive space for what matters, while at the same time improving the accuracy of recall. So forget all those warnings about how the Web just makes us dumber. Its perfectly okay if you have to Google something you just read two seconds ago.

title: Now Showing | Paul Thek in Theory and Practice
description: If youve had your fill of glossy Pop Art and are suffering from aesthetic indigestion, Prelude: Paul Thek in Process, set to open this week in Berlin, is a wonderful palate cleanser  not to mention a poignant reminder that, when it comes to art, the means can be as, well, meaningful, as the ends. The curator Susanne Neubauer has focused on the ephemeral nature of a visionary artists practice, assembling rare slides, photographs, taped interviews, letters and other documents. The installation echoes Theks work, which, like his process, often reflected a sense of transience. A cascade of newspapers from walls to floor and pools of chicken wire are meant to evoke the spirit of his 1969 piece Chicken Coop.

title: Yemen on the Brink of Hell

The Arab worlds democratic uprising was five months old, and patience among the protesters in Taiz  Yemens second largest city  was wearing thin. Maqtari had been one of the first and most fearless leaders of the movement. She is a remarkable figure: a 31-year-old university administrator and fiction writer, she is also a childless divorcee who refused, until recently, to wear the abaya, the all-covering gown that is practically mandatory for women in Yemen. Tiny and frail, she has a round, lovely face, with level brows and tranquil brown eyes.

title: Takeout Totes
description: This is the season of the less-is-more clutch, with handfuls (pun intended) of designers offering palm-friendly options for girls on the go. Add to the list Beth Goodman, who in 2009 launched Marie Turnor Accessories, a collection of bags modeled after the most ubiquitous strapless carrier of all  the lunch bag. The idea came to her in Paris when she spotted a woman holding a perfect red paper bag. I saw it as being a clutch, Goodman explained. It just looked to me like it should be, it was such a chic and simple shape. I knew I had to create one in leather. Her signature style, appropriately named the Picnic, is made of buttery-soft leather and comes in red, black, tan and white. For summer, Goodman is including a range of limited-edition colors  pale pink, purple, gold, bright turquoise and a sparkling aqua. Versatile, featherweight and with minimal hardware, theyre a welcome relief for our wardrobes and shoulders both.

He briefly dated the models Gisele Bndchen and Kate Moss. He entertained celebrity friends like Naomi Campbell at Nells, now closed. And in 2006, his family hosted a 10-day, three-city Indian wedding for him and Priya Sachdev, a model and former investment banker, inviting guests like former President Bill Clinton, Deepak Chopra and Sean Combs.

description: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota on Wednesday responded to questions about her tendency to suffer migraine headaches by releasing a letter from her doctor saying she is in good health.

The Dr. Siri series, set in the 1970s, has been so popular that it once landed Mr. Cotterill on a slab in the Munich city morgue, where he was asked to pose for promotional photos.

title: The Pied Piper of Happiness
description: NOT long after Joseph Peter, a tech entrepreneur turned photographer and feel-good missionary, took over the sixth floor of a triangle-shaped building at the intersection of Bleecker and Lafayette Streets in September, he hung a sign on the door. It read: Warning: You are now entering an energy field of happiness. You will leave happier. We are not responsible for any loss of unhappiness.

description: Three nonprofit advocacy groups that were denied tax exemption by the Internal Revenue Service were all units of Emerge America, an organization devoted to cultivating female political leaders for local, state and federal government.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Its rough going for the female characters in this months sampling of new fiction. A daughter is sold while her mother sleeps; a woman is kicked around by her lover; a girl goes missing; a young woman is framed for murder; and another lives off the land. Not your typical beach reading.

title: From the Grand Bargain to the Gang of Six
description: Like Jon Chait and Matt Yglesias, Im a little puzzled by the sudden wave of optimism about a potential deal based on the Gang of Sixs just-released bipartisan deficit reduction plan. So far as I can tell, the Gang of Six proposal bears a broad resemblance to the grand bargain that President Obama supposedly offered to John Boehner, except that the Gangs tax reform proposals are more detailed (and raise more revenue) and its proposals for Social Security and Medicare cuts are less specific (theres a lot of requiring Senate committees to come up with budget-cutting reforms). Depending on what came out of the entitlement reform process, I suppose that the Gangs proposal could be a better deal for conservatives than what Obama offered Boehner. But more likely it would turn out to be a somewhat worse deal, with higher taxes and fewer real entitlement cuts, than the bargain House Republicans already inclined against when their own leader seemed to be considering it. (I recommend reading James Capretta for the sharpest conservative case against the Gangs proposals, and Reihan Salam for some important qualifiers.)

title: Scientist Under Inquiry Resigns From Harvard
description: The behavioral psychologist Marc Hauser has resigned from the Harvard faculty, 11 months after the university accused him of being solely responsible for eight counts of scientific misconduct.

But beyond Florence and Siena are stony hill towns and sun-blistered dales that remain unfamiliar even to seasoned Italophiles. Here are three gems that promise to provide what their overrun neighbors cannot.

title: A First in Long History Of Newport Folk Festival
description: For the first time in its illustrious past the Newport Folk Festival has sold out tickets for its two days of events in advance, partly because of a strong effort to promote the event through social networking sites, organizers said. The festival, which was started in 1959 and became famous in the 1960s during the heyday of protest songs, has sold out before, most recently in 2002, when Bob Dylan returned to perform there after an absence of many years. But in past years people could always get tickets at the gate, even on the last day of the festival, which is held at Fort Adams State Park on Narragansett Bay. This year, all 20,000 tickets were sold in advance. George Wein, the producer who founded the festival with Pete Seeger, said the Internet buzz was only a sign of something deeper: a resurgence of interest in folk music in recent years, as rising bands like Mumford & Sons have racked up hits on pop and rock charts using a folk template. Alongside established headliners like Emmylou Harris, left, and Elvis Costello, above left, the lineup this year includes hot indie-rock groups with folk-inflected styles, like the Decemberists and the Head and the Heart.

title: Dudes Night Out
description: THE life-parodying-Hollywood scene at the Entourage premiere reached its self-referential height around the time Andrew Dice Clay lighted a cigarette just off the red carpet. Mr. Clay, who plays himself on the show (that is, an aging comic seeking a comeback), wore a sleeveless leather jacket with Brooklyn in rhinestones on the back, blue snakeskin boots and tinted glasses.

title: Gunbar
description: NEW YORKS disappearing grunginess is often romanticized, but not every love letter is inked with enough passion. Gunbar, which opened in June, attempts to introduce the aesthetics of shuttered dives like Don Hills, CBGB and the Hole to the meatpacking district.

A large crowd braved sweltering weather to hear the Festival Chamber Ensemble play works by Berio, Emmanuel Sjourn, Corrado Maria Saglietti and Vincenzo Gambaro.

title: Claire Cain Miller on tension over Twitter apps; safeguarding voicemail; Intel's 320 Series solid-state drive; news.
description: Is Twitter competing with outside developers who have created apps for it? Bettina Edelstein speaks with Times technology reporter Claire Cain Miller about strains between Twitter and third-party developers. The phone-hacking scandal in Britain may have you wondering about your own cellphone security. J.D. Biersdorfer has info and tips for keeping your voicemail secure. And speed demon Pedro Rafael Rosado takes a look at the Intel 320 Series 160 GB 2.5-inch SSD. The news roundup includes a Google+ iPhone app; William Shatner shaking up Google+; a Reddit founder charged with data theft; Amazon Kindle textbook rentals; and the Toshiba Thrive tablet. J.D.'s tip of the week: making shortcuts for Web apps in Chrome.

But grid operators in that region, and in New England and New York, said they were confident they could meet demand during the current heat wave.

title: Puritan Widow Confronts a Randy, Profane King

If she is a character written by Howard Barker and played by the incomparable Jan Maxwell, she sets off on a journey to collect the pieces, no matter what that trip might do to her.

title: Time for Sharing the Love and the Record Labels
description: Hows this for noncompetitive collegiality? You would think that John Zorn, the composer and saxophonist who also runs a new-music label, Tzadik, and an East Village performance space, the Stone, would use his small concert hall mainly as a showcase for his own music and for the works his label releases. He does some of that, but Mr. Zorn also regularly offers the Stone to other composers to do with as they please, often for weeks at a time, and they, in turn, present other composers. He also invites record labels that (in theory) compete with his own to offer showcases of their composers and performers.

title: Tax Bills Imperil Slavery Museum
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va.  Its been 10 years since L. Douglas Wilder, the nations first elected black governor, unveiled a plan to build the United States National Slavery Museum on 38 acres here. It was to be the only institution of its kind, housed in a soaring glass-and-travertine building and illuminated at night so that cars passing on I-95 could see the full-scale replica of a slave ship in its atrium.

description: Hans J. Wegners Oculus chair was designed in 1960, but there were only two prototypes made  one in orange fabric, the other in leather  and the chair was largely forgotten. A half-century later, in 2009, it was rediscovered when Knud Erik Hansen, the owner of the furniture maker Carl Hansen & Son, received an e-mail from the Wegner studio with a picture of the chair from a 1968 magazine.

title: In Germany, Minimalism and Transparency
description: BERLIN  Long before Eva-Maria Steidel bought the stately apartment that once belonged to the chief architect for East Berlin, Hermann Henselmann, she had fallen in love with the grand boulevard that he helped mastermind. The broad street, Karl-Marx-Allee, which her apartment overlooks, was a kind of East Berlin Champs-lyses lined with monumental eight-story buildings done in a muscular style of Stalinist architecture known as Socialist Realism. The boulevard is where East Germanys top-ranking communist officials lived in generous apartments in wedding-cake buildings. After the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, she was determined to live there.

title: As U.S. Steps Back, Europe Takes Bigger Role in Mideast Peace Push
description: WASHINGTON  It is a truism of Middle East peacemaking that the United States is the pivotal player  the most credible broker between the Israelis and the Palestinians. But with talks at a standstill, the Obama administration now finds itself on the sidelines, and Europe is emerging as the key diplomatic actor.

title: Food Crisis in Somalia Is a Famine, U.N. Says
description: MOMBASA, Kenya  The United Nations on Wednesday officially declared Somalias food crisis a famine in several parts of the country, with millions of people on the brink of starvation and aid deliveries complicated by the fact that Islamist militants aligned with Al Qaeda control the famine zones.

title: Zynga Is Hit With Countersuit Over Game Designs
description: Vostu, a Brazilian company whose social games are popular in South America, filed a countersuit against the online gaming giant Zynga on Wednesday, responding to a suit from Zynga claiming that Vostu copied its game designs.

title: Randstad to Buy SFN for $710 Million
description: Randstad Holding, the global temporary employment services company, said on Wednesday that it would buy the SFN Group for $709.8 million in cash to expand its human resource offerings in the United States.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Twitters Developers
description: On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a Times technology reporter, about tension between Twitter and its third-party developers. Twitter has been buying companies that produce apps for Twitter or developing the apps on its own, which has raised questions about how the company treats competitors.

title: Yankees Still Toying With Batting Order
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Brett Gardner leads the Yankees in on-base percentage, and he bats eighth or ninth. No one on the team has driven in more runs than Curtis Granderson, who is also tied for the most home runs, and he bats second. That lineup configuration seemed to work for Manager Joe Girardi when he had a full complement of players.

title: A TV Mayor Is Mulling a Run for the Real Job
description: LOS ANGELES  Like most aspiring actors here, Eric Garcetti has a day job: he is president of the City Council, and he is openly pondering a run for mayor of Los Angeles.

title: In L.A., Romney Returns to Familiar Script
description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD  With the paint peeling from the rooftops of the shuttered store fronts here, it was not exactly a glamorous backdrop. But it is likely for that reason that Mitt Romney chose this desolate strip mall in the San Fernando Valley, just north of Los Angeles, as the spot to criticize President Obamas economic policies.

title: Social Media History Becomes a New Job Hurdle
description: Companies have long used criminal background checks, credit reports and even searches on Google and LinkedIn to probe the previous lives of prospective employees. Now, some companies are requiring job candidates to also pass a social media background check.

title: Campus Crusade for Christ Is Renamed
description: Campus Crusade for Christ, a ministry founded by the evangelist Bill Bright, is changing its name because the word crusade has negative associations with the bloody Christian conquests of the 11th to 13th centuries. The new name, Cru, is already used by many of the groups members and will go into full circulation in early 2012. When the group was founded in 1951, it was common for American evangelists to refer to their ministries as crusades. But missionaries working internationally say they now find that the term often causes offense, especially to Muslims. Another reason for the name change, according to a spokesman: Much of the work of the group, which has 25,000 missionaries in 191 countries, is no longer only on campuses.

description: Q.

title: Pennsylvania: Family Loses Decision in Dispute Over Rare Coins
description: The federal government was right to claim 10 rare gold coins worth millions of dollars each from a Philadelphia family in 2004, a jury decided Wednesday. The government had argued that since the mint never officially released the $20 Double Eagles, the coins  in the possession of the family of a Philadelphia gold dealer who died 21 years ago  must have been stolen and remained the property of the government. Only one such coin has ever been sold, bringing $7.6 million at auction in 2002. Judge Legrome D. Davis of Federal District Court will further rule on a motion that the government is the rightful owner of the coins. Assistant United States Attorney Jacqueline Romero said that the jurors understood why it is were going after these things, and that theres a larger principle involved here. The Langbord family, heirs of the dealer, Israel Switt, are expected to appeal the decision.

title: Over .500, Pirates Get Back in the Mix
description: PITTSBURGH  For 18 years, baseball teams have known where to shop for help in the pennant race. The Pittsburgh Pirates have finished each of those seasons with a losing record, and by July, things are usually so hopeless that they trade veterans to contenders. The last two World Series winners have each included two players acquired from Pittsburgh for prospects.

title: Lack of Coordination Hampers Libyas Rebels
description: While their tactical success has been remarkable, the guerrillas efforts have been weakened by poor communication and a dearth of ammunition.

title: In Bankruptcy Court, Arguments Over Dollars and Sense
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  The Los Angeles Dodgers need a lot of money, that much is clear. At stake during a hearing Wednesday in federal bankruptcy court is who will lend the team $150 million: Major League Baseball or a hedge fund, Highbridge Capital.

title: Admissions Survey
description: Admissions officers at 123 top graduate schools of education, engineering, psychology and public administration responded to a survey by Kaplan Test Prep. The full report will be released Aug. 1.

description: KIKLA, Libya  Ahmad Harari, a Libyan rebel fighting to overthrow Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, recounted how he was almost killed last week.

description: ROCHESTER  Abby Wambach came home on Wednesday to a heros welcome.

title: Despite Downgrade, Pluto Adds to Entourage

title: China: Death Toll Increases in Xinjiang
description: The authorities have increased the death toll in a clash on Monday in the restive western border region of Xinjiang, saying now that 18 people died in the violence. The state media reported on Monday that two police officers and two hostages had died in an attack on a police station in the city of Hotan. But state media said Wednesday that 14 others had also died in the attack. Exile groups representing the regions largest minority, the Uighurs, said that the police had opened fired on unarmed demonstrators. But the state media said that protesters had attacked the station with grenades and explosives. Over the past two years, a series of riots and protests against the countrys majority ethnic group, the Han, has resulted in hundreds of deaths.

title: Italy: Two Setbacks for Belusconi
description: The lower house of Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of a lawmaker from Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis People of Liberty party, allowing his arrest on corruption charges. The vote, by a secret ballot, was a blow to Mr. Berlusconi, showing that factions within his center-right coalition had gone against his wishes and voted to allow the arrest of the lawmaker, Alfonso Papa. Prosecutors in Naples have charged Mr. Papa with corruption, including the illegal dissemination of information protected by state secrecy in a complex scandal involving the trading of favors by people who prosecutors say are close to members of Mr. Berlusconis cabinet. In another sign of government disarray, Mr. Berlusconis coalition lost a vote in Parliament on Wednesday on a plan to resolve a garbage crisis in Naples.

title: 36 Hours in Aspen, Colo.
description: ITS an open secret that Aspen isnt just a glamorous winter resort. As the lineup of private jets at the tiny airport will attest, summer is when the mountain towns festival scene brings in celebrities of almost every category  the likes of Yo-Yo Ma for the seasonlong Aspen Music Festival, Mario Batali for the Food & Wine Classic and Sandra Day OConnor for the Ideas Festival. Along with them come classical-music fiends who carry their own scores and Food Network fans who go wild for live knife-skill demos from the stars ofIron Chef. Your seatmates on the puddle-jumper from Denver, however, are just as likely to be semi-pro cyclists or whitewater hounds sniffing out the best place to shoot the rapids. They know that summer in Aspen is when nature is in full swing, and the glowing fields of wild blue flax, prairie smoke and sunflowers, framed by snowcapped peaks and groves of aspen, do a fine job of wooing attention away from the glitterati. Not that you have to choose one world over the other. Its entirely possible to go high-adrenaline by day and highbrow culture by night.

title: Egypt Antiquities Department Downgraded
description: Egypts antiquities department has been downgraded from a ministry to a cabinet-affiliated office, according to the Los Angeles Times, which cited an Egyptian cabinet spokesman Thursday. The announcement came after a new Cabinet was sworn in that did not include an antiquities minister. Egypts antiquities agency had been elevated to a ministry by the former president, Hosni Mubarak, in the last days of his rule; previously it had been under the Ministry of Culture. It still remained unclear, however, who the government intends to appoint to run the office. Last Sunday, officials said the prime minister, Essam Sharaf, planned to replace Zahi Hawass, the longtime antiquities chief, as part of a cabinet reshuffling aimed at appeasing protesters. Since the revolution, Mr. Hawass has come under fire for his ties to the Mubaraks and his financial relationships with American organizations like National Geographic. Mr. Sharaf at first said that he would appoint Abdel Fattah el Banna, a professor at the University of Cairo, as the new minister of antiquities, but he reversed himself after the choice drew protests from archeologists. In the meantime, Mr. Hawass said that Mr. Sharaf had asked him to continue to go to work, according to the Art Newspaper.
