title: Spare Times July 2-28
description: Staten Island Outloud: Bessie Coleman (Saturday) She left a legacy of firsts, but Bessie Coleman, an early-20th-century pilot, is not a household name to many outside the aviation industry. She was the first black American woman to become a pilot, and the first black American, man or woman, to hold an international pilots license. (Above, shes with her Curtiss JN-4 biplane in the 1920s.) Her story will be brought to life in a reading from her biographies on Saturday at 3 p.m., commemorating the 90th anniversary of her first flight. Sponsored by Staten Island OutLoud, the reading came about because a board member who had faced sexism when she sought to learn how to fly had developed an interest in female aviators, said Beth Gorrie, OutLouds executive director. Coleman faced both sexism and racism, causing her to study in France. In the United States she became a popular figure, performing stunts at air shows and surviving numerous crashes. But on a flight in 1926 to scout locations for a parachute jump, Coleman, then 34, was in a plane that took an unexpected plunge; not at the controls and not buckled into her seat, she was ejected and fell to her death. Her mechanic, who was flying the plane, also died. Members of the Bessie Coleman Aerospace Legacy, formerly the Bessie Coleman Foundation, are expected to attend the reading; model planes, including a model of Colemans biplane, will be flown. Miller Field, 801 New Dorp Lane, at Cedar Grove Avenue, Gateway National Recreation Area, New Dorp, Staten Island, (718) 907-0709; statenislandoutloud.org; free, but spectators should provide their own seating. Aptly, the reading will take place next to some old airplane hangars. (Anne Mancuso)

If they just run wild biting people, half the dwarves in the colony will be infected in no time, he said, shaking his head. That would be no fun. He was silent for a moment. Maybe they have to bite you three times before youre infected?

title: Blind Ambition of Leather-Clad Heads
description: Who is that masked man?

title: The Horror of Yesterday and the Everyday of Today
description: Sarahs Key, Gilles Paquet-Brenners adaptation of Tatiana de Rosnays best-selling novel, is undone by its very premise: that the two stories it tells can coexist in the same film.

title: Government Sells Stake In Chrysler
description: DETROIT  The federal government on Thursday shed the last of its stake in Chrysler, giving majority control of the carmaker to Fiat, the Italian company, while leaving taxpayers $1.3 billion short of recovering the full investment they made two years ago to keep Chrysler from going out of business.

title: PHOEBE WASHBURN: Temperatures in a Lab of Superior Specialness
description: Zach Feuer Gallery

title: CIPRIAN MURESAN
description: David Nolan

title: COLOR FIELD REVISED
description: Loretta Howard Gallery

title: The Deadline Draws Near as Debt Ceiling Negotiations Continue
description: The U.S. draws closer to defaulting on its debt as the negotiations to raise the debt ceiling continue at the White House. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, White House correspondent Jackie Calmes, and chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: DAVID ZINK YI: Pneuma
description: Hauser & Wirth

title: Dodd-Frank, One Year Later
description: As the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory law turned a year old on Thursday, the laws chief architect came to its defense.

title: ELLA KRUGLYANSKAYAAND BENJAMIN SENIOR
description: James Fuentes LLC

title: When Sex Is Loneliness Multiplied
description: William Blake said that what men and women require of one another is the lineaments of Gratified Desire. Woody Allen said of masturbation, Its sex with someone I love. But nothing is ever as simple as these sages would suggest, a point made with a lot of skin and a measure of wit in Autoerotic, Joe Swanberg and Adam Wingards collection of four tales of sexual confusion in Chicago.

title: Her Fans, Squealing, Wont Hold Their Peace
description: NEWARK  One big set piece for Taylor Swifts new touring arena show acts out the title song of her 2010 album, Speak Now. On Wednesday night at the Prudential Center here, where her four-night run concludes on Sunday, it was a full-scale wedding scene, with a bride whose gown was, per the lyrics, shaped like a pastry.

title: Improvisation, as Well as Intensity
description: These days many performers in classical music speak to audiences to share insights and stories. But it is not often that an artist disavows a performance he has just given.

title: How to Hide From Annoying People on Google+
description: Googles new social network, Google+, has been open to new members for only a few weeks, yet an estimated 10 million people have already signed up. This means many Google+ users are already facing a problem they had on Facebook: How do you deal with people who want to be your Google+ buddy if you dont really like them that much?

title: Rangels Birthday Fund-Raiser Regains Its Popularity
description: Its been barely half a year since Representative Charles B. Rangel, the long-serving Harlem Democrat and dean of New Yorks Congressional delegation, was censured by an overwhelming majority of his House colleagues for failing to pay income taxes and misusing his office to solicit fund-raising donations.

title: The Night Belongs to Teenage Yearning
description: The teenagers in The Myth of the American Sleepover, David Robert Mitchells lovely debut feature, are linked in a great chain of liking, which is their euphemism for longing. Do you smoke? a boy asks a girl when she hands him a lighter to use on a bug-repellent candle. No, she says, but I used to like a guy who smoked.

title: Everyone Meets Stan Lee at the Con
description: SAN DIEGO  A favorite theme at Comic-Con has always been  what else  Comic-Con. Those who attend count their years of faithful attendance, and love to tell stories about their first visit, their weirdest encounter, or how they met a wife, or an ex-wife, while navigating through a herd of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles at some long-ago Con.

title: At the Edge of the World
description: Images from the Lyonel Feininger retrospective.

title: When Repression Was a Muse
description: Art in New York is going through a junk food phase.

title: Video Shows Confrontation on West Bank
description: Updated | Friday | 2:44 p.m. A video uploaded to YouTube by an Israeli human rights group on Wednesday shows an Israel Defense Forces officer pointing a gun at a Palestinian who appears to be unarmed. The group, BTselem, says it was filmed on June 18 at a gasoline station in Beit Ummar, a town in the West Bank.

title: To Boldly Go: A Starfleet Six-Pack
description: Sitting in a starship captains chair is a big job. Making a documentary about the actors whose posteriors have occupied that hallowed space through four decades of Star Trek and its spin-offs takes a big man. Thank the Vulcan gods that William Shatner was available.

title: David Bowie
description: Prologue: Genius Steals

title: David Bowie, the Cool Chameleon From Mars
description: A few years ago the critic Chuck Klosterman, writing about rock music, made an argument of the sort that can really disrupt a dinner party. Mr. Klosterman declared, Given the choice between hearing a great band and seeing a cool band, Ill take the latter every single time. He didnt add, but he might have, Discuss.

title: A Big Voice and an Awful Lot of Refinement for a Long Island Honky-Tonk
description: DEER PARK, N.Y.  Matty Ts Roadhouse is a tiny Northern outpost of Southern attitude, with signed memorabilia on the wall, a D.J. with a black cowboy hat and a Long Island accent, and a handful of fans testing out their line-dancing moves to Toby Keith songs between acts.

title: Two Worlds, Not Quite Colliding
description: Images from Another Earth, a film that blends drama with science fiction.

title: Showing Off Eclectic Tastes
description: THE tattoos on the body of the Brazilian rapper Marcelo D2 are more than decorations; they are also a statement of musical purpose and direction. One arm shows the image of the samba singer Jos Bezerra da Silva above the logo of the hardcore punk band Black Flag, while the face of Jimi Hendrix peeks out from the other. And on his neck is printed the title of John Coltranes most influential recording, A Love Supreme.

title: Sorting Through Lending Costs
description: PLENTY of people have ideas about what you should be told when youre shopping for a mortgage, but for now, that may not be much help.

title: Sigmund Freuds Cocaine Years
description: On April 21, 1884, a 28-year-old researcher in the field now called neuroscience sat down at the cluttered desk of his cramped room in Vienna General Hospital and composed a letter to his fiance, Martha Bernays, telling her of his recent studies: I have been reading about cocaine, the effective ingredient of coca leaves, Sigmund Freud wrote, which some Indian tribes chew in order to make themselves resistant to privation and fatigue.

title: Living in a Different World, Searching for a Second Chance
description: At one point in Another Earth, a coming-of-adulthood story that improbably blends a plaintive drama with romantic longing and far-out science fiction, a young woman, Rhoda (Brit Marling), apprehensively moves through her old room in her familys home as if she were a stranger. Once a bright 17-year-old bound for M.I.T., she had taken a calamitous turn while drinking and driving, a detour that sent her to prison. Booze, youth and stupidity led to the accident, as did her distracting long look at a newly discovered planet, the blue marble twin of our own that gives the movie its metaphorically resonant title.

title: Down South, Where the Stereotypes Bloom
description: This month I had occasion to spend 10 days in rural Alabama, on a lake serving as a weekend redoubt for the swells of Birmingham to the north and Atlanta to the northeast. The local restaurant, elegantly rustic in the manner of a dining spot in Aspen or Jackson Hole, offered a hickory-grilled rib-eye for $38 and an appetizer constructed around heirloom figs. Not far away, the only grocery store in town carried farro, interesting cheeses and a line of artisanal pickles from a fashionable Brooklyn purveyor that I am unable to find at my own neighborhood supermarket in that very borough.

title: Toronto Exchange Owner to Begin Talks With Maple Group
description: OTTAWA  After abandoning a plan to merge with the London Stock Exchange, the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange said Thursday that it will begin talks with the investment group that made a hostile bid in May.

title: A Studio That Doesnt Smack of a Dorm
description: ZACH LINDER, who had always shared an apartment, had every intention of renting a place of his own. Envisioning a small one-bedroom in a residential Brooklyn neighborhood, he drew up a budget: $1,400 was my soft ceiling and $1,500 was my hard ceiling, he said. I thought I was being pretty reasonable and not tremendously overly neurotic and picky.

title: Boogaards Brother Could Face Drug Charges
description: MINNEAPOLIS  A brother of Derek Boogaard, the hockey enforcer for the Minnesota Wild and the Rangers who died of a painkiller-and-alcohol overdose in May, faces potential felony narcotics charges in relation to his brothers death.

title: Not That Kind of Nose Job
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

title: Putting the Park in Park Avenue
description: THE Park Avenue automobile tunnel under Murray Hill used to be pretty hairy, a 1,500-foot-long, two-lane, two-way road with solid walls on each side, not much clearance and cars barreling along at highway speeds.

title: Connecticut Developers Bank on Young Singles
description: DEVELOPERS are zeroing in on downtown revitalization efforts in Hartford and Bridgeport, where new rentals have proved popular with young singles. In both cities, the market is hot for studios and one-bedrooms  partly, developers say, because this generation of 20-somethings does not like to share.

title: Blockbuster Growth in the Mets Attendance
description: Suddenly the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a hot ticket. Nearly 5.7 million people visited the museum in the fiscal year that ended June 30  the highest number in 40 years and over 400,000 more visitors than in the previous year.

title: Bygone Era, for Sale in Summit
description: SUMMIT

title: A New Stage for Old Theaters
description: BEFORE Cyrus Hakakian acquired the Westbury Theater at a bankruptcy auction seven years ago, he never expected to end up in the entertainment business as well as beinga landlord. A garment industry entrepreneur, he owns Cyrus Knits, a manufacturer of womens knit blouses.

title: From Theorems and Numbers, the Geometry of a Diverse Career
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  Throughout my life I have been able to see in my minds eye the painting I want to paint and the path I need to take to get there, the artist Dorothea Rockburne has said. At 78, she is having her first full-dress retrospective, Dorothea Rockburne: In My Minds Eye, at the Parrish Art Museum here.

title: Central Park Moonlight, Igniting Love for Mimi and Rodolfo
description: Some opera companies come to the park, and they go, and they come, and they go, a spokesman for the New York Grand Opera said from the stage of the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park before the companys performance of Puccinis ever-popular Bohme there on Wednesday evening. The implication was obvious: at a time when even the mighty Metropolitan Opera has abandoned its longtime custom of presenting free concert performances of operas in the park each summer, the New York Grand Opera has carried on with its staged productions.

title: Q & A
description: Anonymity vs. Public Voting

title: Gary Jacob
description: Mr. Jacob, 61, is an executive vice president of the Glenwood Management Corporation, which develops, builds and manages rental apartments, including the Lucerne on the Upper East Side, Barclay Tower in TriBeCa and Emerald Green in Midtown. It recently began construction on its latest building, the Crystal Green. Glenwood was founded in 1961 by Leonard Litwin, the chairman.

title: Senate Acts to Keep Mueller at F.B.I.
description: The Senate on Thursday set in motion a process to extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for about two years, after Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, agreed to stop blocking legislation necessary for that effort.

title: Vampires Meet Auteurs at Fan Fest
description: SAN DIEGO

title: Many Seek to Revamp Post Office
description: WASHINGTON  Until the deficit negotiations took center stage this summer, several members of Congress had another issue they wanted to focus on: an overhaul of the Postal Service, which is on the brink of insolvency.

title: Borders to Begin Liquidating on Friday
description: The Borders Group prepared to enter its final chapter  liquidation  on Friday after a federal bankruptcy judge approved its plan to wind down its remaining stores.

title: TimesCast | Close To A Debt Deal
description: July 21, 2011 - The Obama administration tells Congressional leaders it's closing in on a major budget deal with Republicans.

title: Emrick, Voice of the N.H.L, Leaves Devils
description: The best local sports announcers are often as well known and as beloved as a teams players. Think of Vin Scully and the Dodgers. Marv Albert and the Knicks. Mel Allen and the Yankees. Chick Hearn and the Lakers. Mike (Doc) Emrick became that distinctive figure for Devils fans for 21 seasons.

title: A New Spider-Man Suit Debuts to Decidedly Mixed Reviews
description: SAN DIEGO Hollywood uses Comic-Con to introduce bits of upcoming films to the hardest of the hard-core fans, betting that the resulting frenzy will overflow into the mainstream. The risk is a negative reaction, which sends studios into crisis mode. Even lukewarm clapping can mean months of damage control.

title: Wearing the Green, in More Ways Than One
description: WOODLAWNS name is a pretty good example of truth in advertising: forested parks, lots of trees, thickets of greenery around the low stoops of century-old houses. Yet in this quiet corner of the Bronx along the Westchester border, the landscape feature that truly stands out is the bluestone in the sidewalks.

title: Weekend Miser
description: The summer is filled with free and inexpensive live performances all over the city. Indoor and outdoor. Classic and comedy. Look to the Miser to find the one thats right for you.

title: Remember the Rangers? Theyre Winning Again
description: In Major League Baseball, some teams narratives have an easier time grabbing headlines than others.

title: R. Kelly Back at Home After Throat Surgery
description: R. Kelly, the rhythm and blues singer, was hospitalized briefly this week and underwent surgery to drain an abcess from one of his tonsils, his spokesman said. It is unclear when the 44-year-old Grammy award winning singer, known for his seductive vocals and lascivious lyrics, would be well enough to perform again. His appearance at a festival in Jamaica this weekend would likely be cancelled, the spokesman, Allan Mayer, said.

title: After the Space Shuttle
description: The smooth landing of the shuttle Atlantis on Thursday closed an era in Americas human space flight program that had triumphs and tragedies over the past three decades but was long overdue to end. The question now is whether the nation can summon the will to push hard for a far more ambitious set of manned voyages.

title: House Tour: Claverack, N.Y.
description: This open-plan house uses passive-house techniques to heat and cool the home not with technology, but with purposeful design.

title: House Tour: Claverack, N.Y.
description: HOW MUCH $595,000. Taxes: $6,000.

title: Mayor Gives $50 Million to Anti-Coal Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Expressing frustration with the paralysis at the national and international levels on setting policies to combat climate change, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday that he would donate $50 million to the Sierra Clubs campaign to shut down coal-fired power plants across the United States.

title: Ostalgia
description: Images from an exhibition of art from and about Russia and the former Soviet bloc, now on view at the New Museum.

title: Nose Job
description: Aircraft nose cones are treated as canvases at a gallery in East Hampton.

title: An Unsatisfying Life
description: For a popular television actor, the leap to film can be dicey. Once the public has warmed to a specific persona, it can fiercely resist any dismantling of the illusion  which is why Steve Carells movie characters shrewdly retain the essence of his alter ego from The Office, Michael Scott.

title: A Modernist Who Thrived at the Margins of Painting
description: Talent moves in mysterious ways, often not according to the dictates of the artists who possess it or the art experts who seek to define and categorize it.

title: A Look at West Indies Cricket
description: For his documentary Fire in Babylon, a history of the West Indian dominance of international cricket in the 1970s and 80s and of the symbolic weight its teams carried in a post-colonial era, Stevan Riley makes use of a variety of beguiling components. There is archival match footage, unfamiliar and exotic to the American viewer. There is an unusually charismatic and authoritative group of talking heads, including former star players like Michael Holding, Gordon Greenidge and Vivian Richards. And there are breaks for cricket songs by reggae and calypso musicians, most notably Lord Short Shirts Vivian Richards, a lilting, evocative tribute to that legendary batsman.

title: A Cop Meets Bollywood
description: According to Singham, a fists-of-steel throwback of a Bollywood film, India suffers from three things: pollution, population and corruption. As for the first two, well, what to do? For corruption, though, the movie has a solution: Bajirao Singham (Ajay Devgn), a superman cop grown in village soil, with bulging muscles and rock-hard morals.

title: Conversion of Apartments to Rentals for Tourists Is Surging
description: Last year, Pamela Kelley went to her landlord with a business proposition: She would move out of her rent-controlled apartment in the Russian Hill neighborhood of San Francisco if the owner agreed to turn the unit into a vacation rental and pay Ms. Kelley to manage it.

title: Where Werner Herzog and Pee-Wee Herman Vie for Attention
description: SAN DIEGO  Never mind Stan Lee, the sophisticated star-watchers should keep an eye peeled here for Werner Herzog.

title: Clogging of Courts Is Expected After Cuts
description: Drastic cutbacks at San Francisco Superior Court could be a boon to the expensive, for-profit dispute resolution industry, as people with the means to do so increasingly decide to pay for their own judge to resolve divorce, child custody and other legal battles.

title: Tracking the Heat and Humidity
description: A bubble of hot and humid air is sitting over much of the Eastern United States.

title: Suit Filed Arguing Title IX Uses Quotas
description: A group that advocates for changes to the gender-equity law known as Title IX announced Thursday that it was suing the Department of Education, arguing that the department is violating the Constitution by forcing high schools to use what it claims is a quota system to afford greater opportunities for female athletes.

title: A Fine Tune To Match Your Entree
description: How does Bob Dylan taste?

title: Inside Scientology
description: Introduction: The World's Fastest-Growing Religion

title: Scientologists, Catholics and More Money Than God
description: We do not need these books to tell us that money and religion make for a poisonous combination. But it is of some interest to see that ancient truth confirmed in both a church as relatively new as Scientology and one as ancient as Roman Catholicism. Even religious leaders develop a certain swagger when they know they are backed by bundles of cash. When a French court fined Scientology nearly a million dollars, one of its officials shrugged that off as chump change. And when the Vatican ran a deficit of nearly 2.4 million euros in 2007, an Italian journalist familiar with the churchs finances dismissed the debt as chopped liver. Chump change or chopped liver, both churches have bigger sums they can get to and use, and few outsiders are given a look at how they do it. These two books trace the cash source of theological confidence.

title: Lawsuits and Intrigue Over 3M Diagnostic Test
description: It is a legal scrap with tabloid sensibilities: extortion charges, libel claims, British royalty  and a prominent American protagonist, the 3M Corporation, purveyor of staples like Scotch tape and Post-it notes.

title: Defending Little Dogs but Playing Both Sides
description: When a special interest group tried to defeat Representative Senfronia Thompsons insurance bill this session with a flier condemning the nanny state and showing an infant suckling a womans breast, Ms. Thompson could not contain her outrage. In one of her famously impassioned speeches between threats to bloody noses  she blasted what she called the objectification, disrespect and violence toward women, slamming her fist so hard against the lectern that her bracelet shattered.

title: Carmageddons Big Surprise
description: So, they shut down a 10-mile stretch of one of the worlds busiest freeways for repair last weekend, in the nations most driver-stressed metropolis, and gave it a scary name  Carmageddon. Predictions were that Los Angeles would look like Mike Huckabees arteries before he lost a hundred pounds, and that chaos and road rage would reign under the tired sunlight of the Southland.

title: Prince Andrew Is Ending His Role as Business Envoy
description: LONDON  Prince Andrew will resign as an ambassador for British businesses abroad, Buckingham Palace said Thursday.

title: Sharing Patents to Wipe Out AIDS
description: Not since the announcement in 1996 that antiretroviral therapy could effectively control H.I.V. has there been a season of AIDS news as hopeful as this one. Trials of a new microbicide have brought positive results; ongoing studies of circumcision are showing that it gives strong, lasting, protection; a man has been cured of H.I.V. infection  and new animal and clinical trials are raising hopes that he wont be alone.

title: Fewer Perks and More Work for Wall St.s Summer Interns
description: Wall Street interns have gone from pampered to pummeled.

title: A.M.D. Turns to Profit From Loss
description: Advanced Micro Devices, a maker of processors for personal computers, reported quarterly profit on Thursday that beat analysts estimates, citing orders for a new range of chips.

title: Haboobs Stir Critics in Arizona
description: PHOENIX  The massive dust storms that swept through central Arizona this month have stirred up not just clouds of sand but a debate over what to call them.

title: Tiger Woodss Caddie Fires Back
description: Tiger Woods has always demanded loyalty from employees and associates as a prerequisite for continued employment or association. His caddie, Steve Williams, was always the embodiment of the loyal employee, going to whatever lengths he deemed necessary to protect Woods on the golf course and off it.

title: After Blaze, Sewage Floods City Rivers
description: The rivers that run into New York Harbor will be unfit for recreational activities at least through Sunday because of a catastrophic fire that shut down one of the citys largest sewage treatment plants, the citys health department said Thursday.

title: Debt Ceiling Uncertainty Puts States at Risk
description: The federal debt ceiling debate is already complicating life for state and local governments.

title: A Turn to Internal Punishments in Ticket-Fixing Cases
description: A former top police union official who is a central figure in an investigation into ticket-fixing pleaded guilty in a Police Department administrative court on Thursday to fixing summonses  whenever he was asked, in the words of a department prosecutor.

title: Time for a Much-Needed Respite at Saratogas Summer Meeting
description: These days there is plenty for horsemen and horseplayers to wring their hands over. No genuine stars emerged from this springs Triple Crown races, and no older horses have run their way into our consciousness.

title: The Atlanta School Cheating Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlanta Finds Its Identity as Tree Haven Is Threatened
description: ATLANTA  The sprawling canopy of magnolias, water oaks and pines that earned Atlanta the nickname The City in a Forest is looking significantly thinner these days.

title: Farm Thieves Target Grapes, and Even Bees
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  Sgt. Walt Reed said he could tell right away that the grapes were stolen. They looked like an ordinary bunch. Except, he said, for the way they were dressed.

title: M.T.A. Chief Is Resigning to Take a Job in Hong Kong
description: Just two years after being named chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Jay H. Walder announced on Thursday that he was resigning to take over the MTR Corporation, which runs Hong Kongs sleek subway and commuter rail systems.

title: Feeling the Heat? Its Worse in Newark
description: NEWARK  This city has a problem. Weve all heard about it, even if we give no more than a passing thought to the misfortune of those suffering here.

title: Con Ed Says Its Prepared for High Electricity Use
description: After the withering summer last year, officials at Consolidated Edison took solace in the forecast of merely average heat this year. But at midday Thursday, those hopes faded as the digital thermometers projected on wall-size screens climbed through the 90s and bolstered the sense that New York City was caught in a serious heat wave.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Pledge of Civility
description: To the Editor:

title: In Marriage Lottery, City Expects to Meet Demand
description: New York City officials said Thursday that they expected to accommodate every couple who entered a lottery for the chance to wed on Sunday, the first day that same-sex marriage will be permitted in the state.

title: A Change at the Top Has Jeter Following Gardner in the Yanks Lineup
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Derek Jeter is identified as the Yankees leadoff hitter, but he has batted second much more often over his career. He returned to that familiar role Thursday night against the Tampa Bay Rays after being dropped to accommodate Brett Gardner, whose .621 on-base percentage since the All-Star break earned him a promotion to the top of the order. Manager Joe Girardi hinted at such a change Wednesday, and on Thursday he suggested that he might maintain that configuration against right-handed pitching.

title: Memorial Fund for Slain Boy
description: The parents of Leiby Kletzky, the 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who was kidnapped and murdered last week, set up a memorial fund on Thursday and released a statement urging people to give to charity in his memory.

title: Local Service Airlines
description: To the Editor:

title: Antitrust Hurdles Seen for Merger of Drug Benefit Managers
description: Two of the nations largest pharmacy benefit managers, Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, said on Thursday that they wanted to combine forces in a $29.1 billion merger that would account for about four of every 10 prescription claims in the country.

title: Cant Stop Flash Crashes
description: To the Editor:

title: Ads Wherever You Go
description: To the Editor:

title: The Iraq Timetable
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Editor in Hacking Case, Found Living in Florida, Says He Will Return to Britain
description: LONDON  A key figure in Britains widening phone hacking scandal who had worked as an editor at The News of the World surfaced in Florida on Thursday, saying he was preparing to return to Britain and was talking to the British police.

title: The Capture of Ambrose Burnsides Valet
description: The brigade of Col. Ambrose Everett Burnside stumbled into the Union capital early in the morning of July 22, 1861. Foot-sore and exhausted after an all-night retreat following the debacle at Bull Run, the men and officers desperately sought food, then sleep.

title: After a Deal, Only More Challenges
description: This article is by  Louise Story,   Eric Dash and  Julie Creswell

title: To Cap, or Not
description: As people do more with their broadband connections  streaming movies, downloading music, moving files to and from the cloud  it might seem natural for Internet service providers to impose data caps on users to manage their networks and deal with congestion.

title: To Preserve Its Currency Union, Europe Needs a Financial Union
description: If there was one lesson to be learned from the European sovereign debt crisis, it was that monetary union by itself cannot work indefinitely. If Europe really wants to preserve the advantages of the euro currency, it will need far more fiscal and economic integration. Nations will have to give up a significant amount of sovereignty.

title: European Debt Crisis Timeline
description: Europes struggle with hundreds of billions of dollars in debt has rattled global markets, engendered protests and spawned flurries of deal-making.

title: U.S., Seeking to Reshape Electric Grid, Adopts a Power Line Rule
description: WASHINGTON  Federal regulators laid down principles on Thursday for planning and paying for new power lines, part of a long-term policy effort to help the nations electricity grid grow enough to meet the demands of renewable energy and a competitive electricity market.

title: Another Victory for Political Machines
description: The Internal Revenue Service has abruptly stopped its investigation of whether gift taxes are due from fat-cat donors to nonprofit advocacy groups, which are emerging as increasingly powerful, and stealthy, players in American politics.

title: Why Is It Called a Wave?
description: Much of the country  and now the Northeast  is in the throes of an excessive heat alert. If a heat wave were a storm, like a blizzard or a hurricane, many people would have taken emergency measures, hunkering down, battening the hatches. But a heat wave comes with cloudless days, creating the illusion that it is merely a little more summer than they counted on.

title: Me, Michele and Our Migraines
description: Washington

title: Friday: Hassle-Free Fashion Item
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Have you ever wondered why the same old entries seem to keep popping up in puzzles time and again? Nothing against Brian Eno or Yoko Ono, but how many times can you stand filling in these names? Sometimes you just want to fill in a combination of letters youve never written before.

title: Set Aside That Scythe, and Lets Put on a Show
description: Lamenting the overwhelming burden of his job in one lush, soaring number after another, the Grim Reaper sings like a dream in the new musical Death Takes a Holiday. As played by the handsome British actor Julian Ovenden, he looks pretty slick too, particularly when he dons the guise of a Russian prince to play hooky from his corpse-culling duties and mingle with some swells in a swanky Italian villa. Small wonder that a voyage into the great unknown holds a strange allure for the imperiled heroine of this gorgeously sung but fusty musical, which opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater in a Roundabout Theater Company production. (Mr. Ovenden, seen in a preview performance, missed opening night because of illness and is expected back by next week.)

title: TimesCast | Greek Rescue Plan
description: July 21, 2011 - European leaders work  on a short-term solution to Greece's debt problem.

title: Read My Lips: No New Taxes
description: Washington

title: F.D.A. Issues Alerts on the Heart Drug Multaq
description: American and European regulators issued safety alerts on Thursday about Multaq, a drug approved two years ago to treat abnormal heart rhythms.

title: The Grand Bargain Lives!
description: Imagine youre a member of Congress. You have your own preferred way to reduce debt. If youre a Democrat, it probably involves protecting Medicare and raising taxes. If youre a Republican, it probably involves cutting spending, reforming Medicare and keeping taxes low.

title: Hot, and Getting Hotter
description: A wave of intense heat has enveloped most of the country with 40 states experiencing temperatures in the 90s and above.

title: Milk Campaign Ended Amid Social Media Firestorm
description: ACAMPAIGN by a milk marketer to address the serious subject of premenstrual syndrome in a humorous fashion  by focusing on how men purportedly suffer from its effects along with women  is being ended early after an outpouring of criticism and comments about the tone of the ads and even a parody on FunnyorDie.com.

title: The Lesser Depression
description: These are interesting times  and I mean that in the worst way. Right now were looking at not one but two looming crises, either of which could produce a global disaster. In the United States, right-wing fanatics in Congress may block a necessary rise in the debt ceiling, potentially wreaking havoc in world financial markets. Meanwhile, if the plan just agreed to by European heads of state fails to calm markets, we could see falling dominoes all across southern Europe  which would also wreak havoc in world financial markets.

title: Among Victims, an Amish Farmer Quick to Adapt
description: JASPER, N.Y.  For several golden years, Melvin Hershberger lived the Amish dream. He rose early with his wife and brood of children, who now number a dozen, to tend to the familys goat herd, twice a day milking 70 goats by hand.

title: Express Scripts Bid for Medco Health Carries Risks

The combination would create a behemoth in the pharmacy benefits management industry. So much so, it looks like a provocation to trustbusters.

title: Rays Find Extra Ounce of Offense to Escape Pitching Duel

Sabathias vacation in the Bahamas to James Shieldss sojourn to the All-Star Game in Arizona, there exists plenty of evidence that confirms that they have, in fact, left Yankee Stadium, where on July 10 they engaged in a captivating battle, each pitching a complete game without allowing an earned run. Playing on synthetic turf, not grass, and under a dome, not a bright sky, they reunited for a duel Thursday night at Tropicana Field, and it was as if they had never taken off their uniforms.

title: Canada: Penalties for Ex-Commander
description: Canadas former military commander in Afghanistan was fined about $7,400 and given a symbolic reduction in rank after pleading guilty to having had a sexual relationship with a subordinate and for trying to block an investigation of the affair. The former commander, Daniel Mnard, 45, a brigadier general, had his rank reduced to colonel by a military judge in Montreal on Thursday. But because he has retired from the military, he will retain his former rank. General Mnard had the relationship with a female master corporal under his command in Afghanistan.

title: Soldiering On When the Job Is White Hot

title: Sweating Through Flats and Sharps
description: CHICAGO  When the enormous stage doors roll open for the Grant Park Orchestras performance, a rush of hot air surges in among the musicians. The humid heat tends to send the instruments out of tune  and in unhappily assorted directions (the metal instruments notes may go sharp even as the woodwinds go flat). And there have been moments when Mary Stolpers flute suddenly seemed to wish, in all the sweat, to slide right off her face.

title: Senate Acts to Keep Mueller as Director of F.B.I.
description: The Senate set in motion a process on Thursday to extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for about two years, after Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, agreed to stop blocking legislation necessary for that effort. By a voice vote, the Senate passed a bill that would create a special shortened term for the directorship that would last through 2012, and made an exception to a law that forbids anyone from serving in the position for more than 10 years. The House is expected to pass the bill swiftly. After President Obama signs it into law, he will nominate Mr. Mueller for the shortened term, and the Senate has already agreed to vote on confirming him after just two hours of debate.

title: Military Reportedly Set on Repeal of Dont Ask
description: The Pentagons leadership is expected to tell President Obama as early as Friday that the armed forces are now trained and ready to implement a repeal of the militarys ban on openly gay troops, officials disclosed. A repeal of the dont ask, dont tell legislation was signed by Mr. Obama in December, and the Defense Department and the individual military services have been training their personnel in preparation for lifting the ban. But the defense secretary, Leon E. Panetta, and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, are required to certify to the president that the military is ready to implement a repeal without jeopardizing national security. The president then must endorse that certification, with a repeal coming into force in 60 days. News that certification was expected Friday was first reported by The Wall Street Journal online.

title: Sink and Swim
description: The night before the mens 4x100-meter freestyle relay at the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, Cullen Jones was in bed, not sleeping, when Michael Phelps, his megastar teammate, knocked on the door. Michaels like, LeBron and all the N.B.A. guys are downstairs, and they want to say hi to us,  Jones recalled. Im half asleep. I say, What!? This is huge for me. Huge. A group of N.B.A. players calling on a bunch of relay swimmers is equivalent to Obamas dropping by a state assemblymans home. So I pull on clothes and run downstairs, Jones, who is 27, told me as he recovered after a practice on the black leather couch in his apartment in Charlotte, N.C. Le-Bron is talking to Michael, saying: Good luck. Trying to get eight gold medals? Thats crazy. And here I come racing in, Im shaking guys hands. Then I hear LeBron go, Wait, you got a brother on the team?

title: Why Writers Belong Behind Bars
description: While researching the Marquis de Sade several years ago, I came across an intriguing biographical tidbit: that crazed French libertine, whose string of luridly violent works gave rise to the term sadism, actually began his literary career as a travel writer. In 1775, Sade embarked on a yearlong grand tour of Italy, and wrote an enormous (and enormously tedious) manuscript about the journey entitled Voyage dItalie. The rambling opus, filled with ruminations on Florentine museums and Neapolitan customs, was never completed. Sades attention wandered to more carnal pleasures, and in 1777, he was arrested for a long list of unsavory imbroglios, including one that historians call the Little Girls Episode. Sade was thrown into the prison of Vincennes, and would spend most of his remaining life incarcerated. Voyage dItalie soon joined a range of half-finished manuscripts from his youth, scraps of verse and staid dramatic pieces, none of which Sade ever had the discipline to bring to fruition.

title: Strauss Joins Sibeliuss Vacation
description: HOW, you may ask, does an opera by Richard Strauss find its way into a music festival devoted largely to the world of Jean Sibelius? This great Finnish composer is the focal point of this years SummerScape extravaganza now under way at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and an important operatic novelty is invariably a highlight of the festival. But Sibelius never wrote an opera of any size or substance. To include one by Strauss  even a relative rarity like Die Liebe der Danae, which receives what is said to be its first fully staged performance in the New York region on Friday evening  seems a bit of a stretch.

He did so in a program consisting entirely of his own compositions, a rare feat in an era when the composer-pianist is an increasingly endangered species.

title: Prying Eyes
description: Once women got tired of being cast as helpless victims in crime novels and began running their own investigative agencies, authors had to scramble for other marginalized groups requiring the services of a detective hero. For more than a decade, P. L. Gaus has been writing quietly spellbinding mysteries about one such group, the conservative Old Order Amish of Holmes County, Ohio. Returning to the region in the seventh installment of his series, HARMLESS AS DOVES (Ohio University, $24.95), Gaus offers a sensitive account of the impact on this community when outsiders (that is, the cops) descend to deal with an Amish youth who has confessed to the murder of his fiances older, richer and very persistent admirer.

title: Up Front: Introducing Geoff Dyers New Column
description: Geoff Dyer, the author of uncategorizable books variously related to D. H. Lawrence, jazz, photography and India, has been strongly praised by his British contemporaries. According to Zadie Smith, his prose is the equal of anyone in the country, and James Wood refers to his works louche and canny delight.

title: An Academic Authors Unintentional Masterpiece
description: In this column I want to look at a not uncommon way of writing and structuring books. This approach, I will argue, involves the writer announcing at the outset what he or she will be doing in the pages that follow. The default format of academic research papers and textbooks, it serves the dual purpose of enabling the reader to skip to the bits that are of particular interest and  in keeping with the prerogatives of scholarship  preventing an authorial personality from intruding on the material being presented. But what happens when this basically plodding method seeps so deeply into a writers makeup as to constitute a stylistic signature, even a kind of ongoing flourish or extravagance?

title: Now Showing | Talk to Me
description: Talk to Me: Design and the Communication between People and Objects, which opens on July 24 at the Museum of Modern Art, explores the ways in which people and objects communicate through design. In nearly 200 recent and new projects, the exhibition considers the personalities that designed objects now have through their interactive relationships with their users. Organized by Paola Antonelli, the senior curator in the museums department of architecture and design, and Kate Carmody, a curatorial assistant in the department, the exhibition examines everything from the now-famous MetroCard vending machines in New York to the Bat Billboard, which uses voice-recognition software to translate the calls of bats into messages that are displayed on the screen of the billboard. (The billboard itself also serves a low-tech function  that of housing the bats.)

description: It is 1851 in the Oregon Territory, and Charlie and Eli Sisters have been ordered by the Commodore to go to California and kill a man called Hermann Kermit Warm. They ride their horses, Nimble and Tub, and along the way meet the weeping man and a dentist, Reginald Watts. These characters and their names, not completely Dickensian, or even Pynchonian, but not exactly commonplace either, are emblematic of Patrick DeWitts novel The Sisters Brothers  not always serious, not always funny, sometimes derivative of old westerns, sometimes a parody of them.

title: Turkish Club Seeks to Add Another Star: Kobe Bryant
description: The Turkish basketball club Besiktas has made an offer to Los Angeles Lakers guard Kobe Bryant to play for its team during the N.B.A. lockout and is awaiting an answer from Bryants agent, Besiktas Coach Ergin Ataman said Friday.

title: Heir Apparent at EADS Stirs Controversy With Web Video
description: PARIS  Arnaud Lagardre, the French billionaire who has been widely expected to become the chairman of the European aerospace group EADS next year, became an unwitting Internet sensation this past week after a Belgian magazine released a video of him posing and cuddling with his young, supermodel girlfriend.

title: Big Deal | Landmark Status Weighed for Barbizon
description: The Barbizon, the 23-story brick building on the corner of 63rd Street and Lexington Avenue, has been reinvented several times over the last century, and the next chapter may be written by the citys Landmarks Preservation Commission. At a city hearing scheduled for Tuesday, the building is up for consideration as a landmark.

title: Around the World in One Day
description: Life in a Day features montages of ordinary acts from YouTube videos submitted by thousands of people who filmed themselves on July 24, 2010. Watch six clips from the 95-minute documentary.

title: Overtime in Soccer City
description: On the second Sunday in July, exactly one year after the final game of the 2010 World Cup was played here at Johannesburgs Soccer City stadium, the cappuccino machine inside the V.I.P. suite was firing up. A bottle of wine cooled in the fridge across the bar. In the stadiums bathrooms, fresh liners were tucked into the wastebaskets and the soap dispensers were refilled to the brim, as if the 90,000 fans that flooded the venue in 2010 might reappear at any moment. Ephraim Nong, a stadium tour guide, showed me the pitch from the V.I.P. viewing deck. It is maintained religiously, he said: cut three times a week, the grass in shadow artificially sunned using giant lamps hung on wheeled racks.

title: Around the World in One Day
description: How exactly do you make a documentary about a day in the life of a planet  about how people all over the world eat, sleep, pray, work and even learn to shave? You could start by asking everyone on YouTube to film their daily activities on a specific date; in this case, on July 24, 2010. Then you could ask all those people to send you their raw footage; in this case, 4,500 hours worth.

title: The Cold Call
description: He wanted to meet inside the mens restroom in the undergraduate library. I said, No, outside, by the reference books. When he asked how hed know me, I told him Id be wearing a baseball cap and a Marilyn Monroe T-shirt. I didnt mention that I was a scrawny 115 pounds or that my face was ravaged by acne. And I didnt mention that the hair beneath the baseball cap was a newly dyed neon orange.

title: Cornel West Flunks the President
description: Whats with the black suit, white shirt, black tie outfit you always wear? Do you have anything else in your closet?  Ive got four black suits that I circulate, and they are my cemetery clothes  my uniform that keeps me ready for battle.

title: Dont Ask, Do Tell?
description: A woman I was sleeping with, in an explicitly nonexclusive, dont ask, dont tell relationship, found a pimple and panicked that she had a sexually transmitted disease. I encouraged her to let a doctor assuage her fears, which he did the next morning, but first she insisted I tell her if Id slept with anyone else. I had. (Safe sex.) But I worried a yes might end the relationship; saying nothing would have been the same as saying yes. So I lied. Was I ethically obligated to respond honestly? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: A Regulator Scorned
description: I first met Sheila Bair when she worked for Senator Bob Dole on his Senate finance committee staff; Joe Noceras article demonstrates what an outstanding public servant she has been as the former head of the F.D.I.C. She will probably hate me for saying this, but President Obama need look no further than Sheila as the successor to Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner.

title: The Dark Art of Breaking Bad
description: This is a great program, unique among television series for its implacable moral ambiguities. I dont blame Walt, then I do, then I dont. The inscrutable morality in the program is cathartic for me, and its a formidable artistic achievement to keep the totally metaphysical conflict going. But I found it curious in David Segals article that Vince Gilligan, the shows creator, said that he could not understand why someone would chose virtue in an absurd universe. The answer to this question is easily taken from Camuss Plague and any number of existentialist texts. I think Gilligan is putting us on. In fact, when the debris from the exploded airplane falls into Walts pool, I thought the authors intention was to tip his hand and justify the need for a social contract. (This scene would have made a good ending for the series.)

title: The Enthusiast
description: The Enthusiast: Tony Gervino, contributing editor, The New York Times Magazine

title: Magically Resistant to the Ego-Bloating Properties of Hollywood Life
description: Harriet Daimler, the protagonist of Iris Owenss 1973 novel, After Claude, has a knack for eviscerating self-satisfied urban types. After rolling her eyes at a slender girl passing a joint ( Im wrecked, she bragged, as though it took a special talent to get stoned), Harriet utters a relatable prayer: Lord, spare me these dimpled darlings who are always congratulating themselves for not having any thoughts or feelings.

title: On Green Dread and Agricultural Technology
description: Greenpeace would do well to start picking its shots more carefully.

description: Tundra Ale, which uses locally grown barley and hops, will be paired with food on Friday, from 6 to 8 p.m. at Jimmys No. 43, 43 East Seventh Street (Second Avenue), in the East Village, to benefit Slow Food. Tickets are $25 for Slow Food members and $35 for others.

description: An interactive family tree covering 15 generations of the Van Dusen family, among the earliest Europeans to settle in New York City.

description: ALPE dHUEZ, France  After 2,105 miles and nearly three weeks of racing, through three perilously steep climbs into the Alps, the Tour de France will be decided Saturday in a 26-mile sprint through Grenoble. This is like deciding a marathon with a 100-meter dash.

description: THE project earned him an easy A.

title: Former China Mobile Official Sentenced in Bribery Case
description: SHANGHAI  A former executive at China Mobile, one of this countrys biggest state-owned telecommunications companies, was sentenced to death with a two-year reprieve Friday for accepting bribes, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

title: You Say Filandia, I Say Freedonia
description: Filandia is a town set high in the mountain slopes of the Cordillera Central range in Colombia. It is not connected with Finland, a European country that is much larger and considerably farther north, and has a different flag.

title: Bonnie Jo Campbells Rural Michigan Gothic
description: Bonnie Jo Campbells first novel, Q Road, published in 2002, told the story of Rachel Crane, an isolated and determined young woman who lives in meth country outside Kalamazoo, Mich., with her even more eccentric mother, Margo. After Margo shoots a local womanizer who has designs on the under-age Rachel, she disappears, and Rachel, more out of practicality than love, marries the farmer who owns the property where she and her mother have always lived. Q Road was widely praised for its authentic rendering of rural Michigan: part dump, part wilderness and part farmland. Once Upon a River, Campbells second novel, leaves off where Q Road began  it is the story of Margo Crane, herself a difficult and willful young woman, who is 15 when the novel opens in the late 1970s.

title: The Heat Starts Early, Then Breaks a Record
description: The temperature climbed to 104 in New York City  2 degrees shy of the citys record  and 108 in Newark, the highest temperature ever recorded there, as a heat wave around the region intensified on Friday afternoon.

description: SAN DIEGO  It is unusual for Hollywoods smaller production companies to preen at Comic-Con. Its expensive, for starters, and their business partners  the big movie studios  generally prefer to control the messaging.

description: He was the most interesting man in London, conventional wisdom had it. I dont think I ever met anyone more remarkable.

title: 104 Degrees in Central Park and Power Use Set Records
description: Updated, 3:15 p.m. | The mercury reached 104 degrees in Central Park at 2:10 p.m. on Friday, the hottest New York City has been since July 21, 1977, and only two degrees shy of the hottest temperature ever officially recorded in the city, the National Weather Service said.

title: Fake Apple Stores Get Fake News Video
description: Earlier this week I wrote about a series of fake Apple Stores that have been cropping up in China. They look so real that even the store employees, who wear authentic Apple T-shirts and branded name-tags, believe they work for the real Apple.

description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Gordon S. Wood, Historian of the American Revolution
description: Gordon S. Wood is more than an American historian. He is almost an American institution. Of all the many teachers and writers of history in this Republic, few are held in such high esteem. Part of his reputation rises from his productivity  a stream of books, monographs, articles, lectures and commentary. Now he has added The Idea of America (along with a new edition of John Adamss Revolutionary writings in two volumes for the Library of America series).

title: Obama / Nixon
description: Bruce Bartlett says what youre not supposed to say: Obama has governed as a moderate conservative, somewhat to the right of Richard Nixon. The frothing-at-the-mouth comments are an extra bonus.

description: Michigans congressional delegation has warned in a letter to the White House that new automobile fuel economy and emissions standards being drafted by the Obama administration are not reasonably feasible given the state of current technology and consumer buying habits.

title: A World War II Veteran Revisits His Saviors
description: Bobbie Ann Masons new novel opens with a little history. A note explains that during World War II, thousands of Allied aviators crashed or parachuted into Occupied Europe, and many were helped home by the escape-and-evasion networks of the French Resistance. This information is followed by the roster of a flight crew based at Molesworth Airfield in England, home of the 303rd Bomb Group  specifically the men who took one Flying Fortress, the Dirty Lily, on a raid over Frankfurt on Jan. 31, 1944. This squadron did indeed bomb this German city from this airfield, but not on this night. And the names of the crew are fictitious. The Girl in the Blue Beret is a work in which the real and the imaginary are joined.

title: Slow Down and Savor Middle and High School
description: Dave Marcus, the author of Acceptance: A Legendary Guidance Counselor Helps Seven Kids Find the Right Colleges  and Find Themselves, is a reliable source of measured advice on the college admissions process and on the importance of keeping it in the proper perspective. (Regular readers of The Choice know this first-hand from his posts for us, including one last year about a son who marches to the beat of a different educational drummer, which prompted several hundred comments.)

title: Travels North of the Amazon
description: Have you ever considered visiting the Guianas, that fabled South American realm of gold and sugar, home to, as the British travel writer John Gimlette reports,head-crushing jaguars, strangling snakes, rivers of stingrays and electric eels, not to mention giant otters, half-puppy, half-torpedo, that snack on piranhas? The regions tangled green knot of jungle, rock and savannah  now home to the countries of Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana  crouches between Venezuela and Brazil, veined by thousands of turbulent rivers, mulchily recoiling from 900 miles of Atlantic coastline.

title: N.F.L. Owners Vote Puts Pressure on Players
description: In a way, you do have to hand it to the N.F.L owners. Once they set sail on the Good Ship Lockout, they have been all in. Never mind that it was an obvious ploy to fatten their bottom lines, to grab more of the leagues $9 billion in revenue and take advantage of a players union it believed would fold like a $2 umbrella. And now that the players have shown to be more in the $20 umbrella neighborhood, the owners rolled out their latest strategy, ratifying a collective bargaining agreement the players hadnt agreed to and telling them theyre the ones holding up the season.

title: From Budget Cuts to Dirty Bombs
description: Washington

title: Stories of the Unkindness of Strangers
description: In At the Zoo, one of the stories in Caitlin Horrockss impressively sharp first book, a little boy recalls his grandfathers interpretation of mouse thoughts: Im small! Im frightened! Oh no! An owl! The boy thinks, Im sorry youre small and frightened; we are the same. But quickly, his mind shifts. Not the same. I am much bigger than you. I could hurt you. Still in day care, hes already exhibiting this most Horrocksian trait, excitement at the capacity for harm.

title: Grand Bargains, Pro and Con
description: While we wait (and wait, and wait ) to find out if John Boehner and Barack Obama are about to snatch a significant deal from the jaws of a parliamentary maneuver, I recommend reading Yuval Levins powerful case against the sort of larger bargain that Ive been suggesting conservatives should consider in these negotiations. The problem with the big deals that have been floated to date, Levin points out, is that none of them seriously address the long-term growth of Medicare spending: The entitlement reforms being considered, from retirement-age increases to modest means-testing, will generate only extremely modest savings when set against the projected cost explosion in the coming decades. And so it would be a mistake, he argues, for Republicans to make a significant concession on taxes without getting genuine structural reform to Medicare (along the lines of the Ryan plan, or the more centrist Rivlin-Domenici alternative) in return  a policy mistake, because it would concede too much for too little, and a political mistake, because calling something a grand bargain would leave the impression that our deficit problem has somehow been dealt with, when in fact this round of negotiations is just the opening act for a much larger and necessarily more controversial process of reform.

title: Adam Rosss Unsettling Stories
description: Adam Rosss first novel, Mr. Peanut, which came out last year, showcased blazingly original work by a writer whose influences ranged from Raymond Chandler to Italo Calvino. His second book, a collection of stories, confirms the promise of his first. Ladies and Gentlemen is clever in all the right ways, even while paying homage to the most traditional of forms.

title: Asked & Answered | Helmut Lang
description: Back in 2008, when Helmut Lang installed a busted up disco ball on the floor of the Journal Gallery in Brooklyn, he explained that, in his mind anyway, the piece related to the Janus mythology  looking back and moving forward. Its also about transitions and new beginnings, representing time as one half respects the past and the other one looks into the future, he said. But with his new installation at the Fireplace Project in East Hampton, N.Y., it appears that the past is no longer an issue for the designer who took what turned out to be a permanent hiatus from fashion in 2005 and has been working full time as an artist pretty much ever since. Make It Hard, as the show is called, comprises about 20 pillar-like sculptures, which Lang created after he shredded the thousands of pieces that remained in his archive. Sad as it may be to think about all of those wasted moleskin coats, lace and rubber dresses and motocross pants, Make It Hard is a poignant realization of Langs long-held conviction that fashion and art have become one. On the eve of the opening, Lang talked to The Moment about art, the passage of time and why there will never be another Helmut Lang sample sale ever again.

Another variation of these vampire chronicles comes in Blood Work, which enters our hardcover list at No. 1 this week. The book is by Kim Harrison, whose Hollows novels are about a vampire and a witch who solve crimes. This original graphic novel delves into the early days of their partnership. title: The Arts Take Root in Portugals Cradle City

Profanity, served up in the warm, open-throated intonations of this region of northern Portugal, is as much a part of the menu as the veal chop or tripe stew. The matronly but sharp-tongued owner, Augusta Ribeiro, routinely dresses down customers for refusing wine, and once, I was told, she called a man impotent for asking for hot sauce. When I stopped in for lunch with Rui Torrinha, a local cultural organizer, it wasnt long before he was being harangued for his vegetarianism.

title: Zahi Hawass Discusses His Departure
description: Zahi Hawass, whose departure as Egypts minister of antiquities was announced in a cabinet reshuffle this week, said in an e-mail Friday that, while he continues to supervise the agency while his replacement is found, he will not be staying on for more than a few days to help with the transition. Mr. Hawass said, I am retiring to focus on my own work, as a scholar and a writer, adding he is looking forward to living quietly as a private person, away from politics. On Thursday, the Egyptian government said it is downgrading the antiquities department from a ministry to an office reporting to the prime minister, reversing a decision by former president Hosni Mubarak in the last days of his rule to elevate its status. It is still not clear who will run the office, which will again be known as the Supreme Council of Antiquities. Mr. Hawass was pushed out, along with several other cabinet members, as part of an effort by Prime Minister Essam Sharaf to appease protesters who had returned to Tahrir Square to demand further changes in the government.

title: Tips on Turning Back the Clock
description: The decision on how much money, and time, to spend prepping for an admissions test is personal. Buy books or CDs or DVDs; take full courses or short refresher classes; browse the Web (where I found an enlightening video on how to solve probability problems). But all agree: older applicants need to give themselves enough time to study and drill. This is not a test you can cram for, says Lee Weiss, the director of graduate programs for Kaplan Test Prep.

title: A New Business Worldview
description: The Master of Business Administration began as a distinctly American creation, developed in response to the galloping industrial growth of the late 19th century and the new American phenomena to which it gave rise: the modern corporation, scientific marketing, mass advertising, investment banking. The professional manager was born and, to train him, the worlds first graduate school of management  at Dartmouth, in 1900. Eight years later, Harvard began offering what it claims was the worlds first M.B.A. And for the next century, the American academy was the uncontested capital of practical business education.

title: A Little Rusty?
description: On the first day of test prep, after we had tackled a mini-G.R.E., the instructor assured our class that though she was 30 years old, she was still up on the latest test-taking trends. Finally, I thought, a problem I could easily solve. Answer: the last math class I had taken was three years before she was born.

title: Betting on an E.M.B.A.
description: To make class, Valeri Cordn gets up at 5:30 a.m. on a Thursday to catch a flight from Costa Rica to Boston. At 8:30 a.m. Friday, hes in his seat at Building E62 of the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management in Cambridge, where he will pretty much stay put for two intensive days of business education. Sunday morning  72 hours after leaving home  he flies back to his wife and three children, usually through Miami, Atlanta or Dallas.

title: Looking Ahead Behind the Ivy
description: The pace of change in business is quickening, and business schools are scrambling to keep up. A number of prominent B-schools, the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Business School among them, have rethought their programs and are making changes to reflect the increasingly global scope of business and to improve students leadership and teamwork skills. Some schools are asking students to wrestle with questions about the ethical lapses that contributed to the financial crisis. Nitin Nohria, new dean of Harvard Business School and co-author of Paths to Power: How Insiders and Outsiders Shaped American Business Leadership, discussed the new courses, and the goals and thinking behind them.

title: The Joke Is on the Ph.D.
description: Jorge Cham's comics started out as just another way for a grad student  himself  to procrastinate. Now hes helping millions of others do the same.

title: The Left-Leaning Tower
description: Why are conservatives such a minority at so many graduate schools? Conservatives like to blame liberal bias. Liberals like other explanations.

title: Dissing the Doctorate
description: Adam J. Ruben spent seven years working on a Ph.D. in molecular biology at Johns Hopkins. On the side, he performed at open mikes and wrote a book that didnt count toward his publish-or-perish count. Surviving Your Stupid, Stupid Decision to Go to Grad School was published by Broadway Books last year. Now Dr. Ruben teaches an undergraduate class on the stand-up comic in society at Johns Hopkins, when hes not at his day job at Sanaria, working on a vaccine for malaria. Another hobby: rapping.

title: A Two-for-One Deal: Bachelors Plus Masters
description: Do you want a masters with that bachelors? Think of it as adding fries and a Coke for an Extra Value Meal.

title: Citations to Avoid
description: In thesis writing or application essays, impressive citations are important. Here are a few to leave out:

title: The Critter People
description: Beyond the noisy throngs marveling at the dinosaurs, the dioramas and the immense blue whale, up on the fifth floor where visitors are not allowed, the American Museum of Natural History takes on an entirely different character.

title: R.O.I.
description: Graduate school has long been a recession hideout, a place to add new skills and credentials that, presumably, increase job opportunities and salary in a market recovered by graduation. A year after 2008s economic meltdown, applications to graduate school rose more than 8 percent. Last year, as the country hobbled toward recovery (or not), 27 percent of college seniors said they planned to attend immediately after graduation, up from 21 percent in 2007, according to the National Association of Colleges and Employers.

title: The Essential T.A.
description: Jason G. Ball was thrilled when he was accepted two years ago at the University of California, Los Angeles, and could pursue a Ph.D. in political science. He was so thrilled, he enrolled without any assurance of a teaching assistantship or other financial support.

title: GMAT Makeover
description: Anyone contemplating business school wants to know whether to take the GMAT now or wait until next June, when the integrated reasoning section is introduced. First, ask yourself this: Does an Excel file give you pause? The new section is what came of a 2009 survey of 740 faculty members, who were asked what the GMAT should measure that it didnt. The section will replace one of two essays, and is heavy on data interpretation. As the business environment changes, the business curriculum changes, explains Ashok Sarathy, vice president for the Graduate Management Admission Council, which administers the test. What doesnt change: total test time (at three and a half hours) and the verbal and quantitative sections. Try your hand at this preview, which GMAC created for Education Life. There are four new question types: multi-source reasoning, graphics interpretation, two-part analysis and sorting tables.

title: How to Talk to Real People
description: Recognizing that scientists can be really, really hard to understand, Emory last semester introduced Communicating Science to teach grad students to write for and talk to laypeople. Students create presentations, blog and compose elevator speeches addressing various scenarios (see below).

title: The Masters as the New Bachelors
description: William Kleins story may sound familiar to his fellow graduates. After earning his bachelors in history from the College at Brockport, he found himself living in his parents Buffalo home, working the same $7.25-an-hour waiter job he had in high school.

title: Paying for an M.B.A.
description: Getting an executive M.B.A. can be onerous, both logistically and financially. While there are some scholarships, many students rely on loans.

title: The Art of Community Engagement
description: Traditionally, a Master of Fine Arts program is studio-centric: students work in a single medium, putting together a unified body of work and attempting to become better artists. But today's M.F.A. programs have taken to challenging the conventional mold. One of the more popular alternatives is community art, in which students are encouraged to create work with larger public outreach.

title: Admissions Tally
description: The latest statistics from top law schools and full-time M.B.A. programs.

description: MILLION-DOLLAR Duesenbergs and vintage Italian racecars crossing the auction block will hardly be surprising sights at the sales scheduled to take place in conjunction with the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance on the Monterey Peninsula of California next month.

title: On Their Childrens Schools, Politicians Should Save the Outrage
description: If youre a politician who has all kinds of things to say about public education, do voters have the right to know where you send your children to school?

title: Univision Triumphs on a Barren Night of Broadcast TV
description: A relatively barren television landscape on Thursday night  with the big four networks running either comedy repeats or reality shows  allowed the Spanish-language Univision to score a ratings victory in the category advertiser-coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-olds with its 8th Annual Youth Awards show, Premios Juventud. The three-hour ceremony, which featured performances from Ricky Martin and Pitbull, averaged 4.1 million total viewers. The winners were determined by online vote at univision.com. CBS had the most total viewers on the night thanks to a live eviction episode of Big Brother (6.7 million viewers). Love Bites, the sole NBC series not in repeats, fell to just under 1.8 million viewers for its (unplanned) final episode. The show was canceled earlier this week.

title: Settlement Ends Bitter Infighting at a Fraternity
description: A century-old fraternity that was recently embroiled in internal strife between the national executives and members of several local chapters has reached a resolution to end the bitter infighting.

title: Survivor of Attack Leads Nuclear Effort in Iran

title: The Minimalist: Fast Blueberry Jam
description: If youre a gardener, a farmers market enthusiast, or a member of a community-supported agriculture group, there will probably come a point in the summer when you will find yourself overwhelmed with fresh berries, which seem like a ticking time bomb as they begin to soften and rot. When that point comes, dont think  just make jam.

title: Obama Should Raise the Debt Ceiling on His Own
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA should announce that he will raise the debt ceiling unilaterally if he cannot reach a deal with Congress. Constitutionally, he would be on solid ground. Politically, he cant lose. The public wants a deal. The threat to act unilaterally will only strengthen his bargaining power if Republicans dont want to be frozen out; if they defy him, the public will throw their support to the president. Either way, Republicans look like the obstructionists and will pay a price.

title: Creating Uncommon Vibes
description: OVER the last year I thought a lot about two albums by young jazz musicians: Sun Rooms, by Jason Adasiewicz, and Waking Dreams, by Chris Dingman. Both are vibraphonists, Mr. Adasiewicz from Chicago, Mr. Dingman from New York. Theyre both seekers, both invading the space between free improvisation and the consensual mainstream jazz language, both suggesting changes of style and even function in their instrument. ... Hold on. What? Theyre both vibraphonists?

title: The Lincoln MKZ Hybrid Has a Trick Eyeball
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif.  In a mall parking lot here, I was trying to back a new Lincoln MKZ Hybrid, which I review in Sundays Automobiles section, out of a spot. Two huge S.U.V.s were parked on either side of me, blocking my field of view of oncoming vehicles. Backing slowly, an alarm suddenly warned me of approaching cross traffic. The alert saved me from a collision with a careless, speeding driver.

title: Gay and Married with Children
description: Among the 823 couples who plan to marry in New York City on Sunday are many with children. Odds are they have filled out a lot of legal documents already  to adopt and provide health care for their children, to establish guardianship, to smooth inheritance. What does this additional legal step mean, or not, when you have been raising children together for years, even decades?

description: PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss.

title: Fte Accompli | Soire From Outer Space
description: Organizers of the annual Prospect Park Summer Soire could not have picked a better night to throw a retro space-themed party. The landing of the Atlantis early Thursday morning, which marked the end of NASAs shuttle program, and by extension, the end of an era in space exploration, had everyone thinking about starships and galaxies. If entering the events space, a charming 1905 Beaux Arts-style boathouse, to music from 2001: A Space Odyssey felt a bit kitschy, well, so was the 70s space-age-inspired look that prompted the party. Call it cosmic, but it worked.

title: A Wedding? Oh, Yes, We Did That, Too
description: MY parents, Betty and Terry Doonan, met in a Royal Air Force soup kitchen at the end of World War II. They had both run away from home a few years prior and were disinclined to return to their respective birthplaces.

title: Seeking a Place to Settle, Without Being Too Settled

title: A Great Way to Eat Your Fruit
description: This brown butter cake is a happy landing pad for almost any summer fruit. Try it with apricots, sweet cherries, berries (a mix would be perfect) or plums. As long as the fruit is juicy and soft, it will work. The juicy factor, however, does rule out apples and most pears unless you poach or saut them first a good thing to keep in mind if youre saving this recipe for fall.

title: Getting Interactive at Comic-Con With Conan the Barbarian
description: SAN DIEGO Patience is often in short supply on Comic-Cons trade show floor, where lines of fans waiting to get an autograph or check out a particular booth snake through the already gridlocked aisles. Lionsgate, the studio that Saw built, is normally one of the biggest line generators, because it loads its exhibit area with technology. Last year, for instance, the studio invited attendees to make videos of themselves trapped inside a coffin; Lionsgate then emailed them the result to share with their friends online. The stunt promoted Buried, a thriller starring Ryan Reynolds, and it was a huge Comic-Con hit (although it didnt pay off in box office success).

Through his dances he reveals the meat of the human condition, and he likes it raw.

description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book party, same-sex marriage, and a hot day in Newark.

title: Celebrating Forefather of Graffiti
description: A short Greek-American kid named Demetrius who lived on West 183rd Street in the late 1960s was by no means the first teenager to think of writing something in indelible ink on someone elses property. He never considered himself an artist, and his illicit career of leaving his name and street number on hundreds, maybe thousands, of surfaces throughout the five boroughs of New York City ended after only a couple of years, when he put aside his Magic Marker and went off dutifully to college.

title: This Sunday: The Story My Mom Will Try to Skip
description: There are few things in life that I avoid as strenuously as video games. Sure, I played a bit of Pong and Pac Man in my day. But when games started becoming these immersive, life-devouring experiences, I stayed away. Not because I consider them stupid or beneath me. I dont know whether such games make us smarter or if they represent important achievements of pop culture. All I know is that if I brought an Xbox into my apartment, Im scared I might never do anything else.

title: War of the Rose
description: David Brooks and me, on Charlie Rose tonight. No columnists were harmed in the making of this program  possibly because one was in northern Virginia and the other in central New Jersey.
