title: Living With the Greenhouse Effect
description: Living with the greenhouse effect was the subtitle of my October, 1988, cover story for Discover Magazine  my first lengthy exploration of the science pointing to a growing human influence on climate. The cover line on the piece, which followed a scorching summer across much of the country, was, This summer was merely a warmup.

title: Light to Broadway

Newhouse Theater, presented by Lincoln Center Theater. Ms. Lavin is starring this fall in the Off Broadway play The Lyons.

title: The Simple Pleasure of Tacos
description: THE appeal of tacos lies in their simplicity, in their hot-off-the-griddle-ness, their savory, spicy two bites of pleasure. Ill admit Ive eaten my share of tacos on the run, and happily, at market stalls south of the border, some unlikely joints in Texas and in downtown Manhattan. Part of the joy is the immediacy and the pace. Hunger sated, now. Another part is seeing a real taco master at work. Ive patronized a popular place in San Franciscos Mission district for more than 20 years. The tacos are excellent, but a big part of the draw is watching the sole longtime chef flipping tortillas, chopping meat and building beautiful tacos at incredible speed, never losing his cool.

title: Biography Revives Push to Reopen Malcolm X Case
description: The death of Malcolm X, shot dead at the Audubon Ballroom in Upper Manhattan in 1965, never inflamed the public imagination in the same way the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. did. But scholars have long believed that a bungled investigation resulted in the imprisonment of the innocent and allowed some of those responsible to go free. Over the decades, efforts to reopen the case have failed.

title: Emotional Guy, Speaking for Others
description: Danny Aiello, a big guy with a big New Yawk accent, is best known for roles like Sal, the boisterous pizzeria owner in Spike Lees 1989 film, Do the Right Thing, which won him an Oscar nomination. In the play The Shoemaker, which is now in previews and opens on Sunday at the Acorn Theater, Mr. Aiello is a different kind of New Yorker. A wounded immigrant, he seethes with rage and sadness in the title role of an Italian Jewish shoemaker named Giuseppe, holed up in his shop in Hells Kitchen on 9/11, trying to shut out the chaos outside and the memories of loss it ignites.

title: A Taco Truck in Your Kitchen
description: A good taco is a wonderful thing, whether you get it through a stainless steel truck window or at a favorite taqueria. Or at your house. For summer entertaining, tacos are fast, easy, and mighty tasty, made from the simplest ingredients. Take a steaming corn tortilla, add a little sizzled spicy pork and splash of salsa. Now, open a cold beer.

It was early in the second half of a concert called The Key Players, part of the Jazz in July series. A projection on the back wall showed both pianists hands at work as they imbued an aptly titled standard, We Could Make Such Beautiful Music Together, with an air of thoughtful, chummy competition.

description: Kaplan Inc., a subsidiary of The Washington Post Company, agreed Friday to pay $1.6 million to bring an end to investigations and charges relating to the surgical technology program at its CHI Institute in Broomall, Pa.

description: CAMP ASHRAF, Iraq  The more than 3,000 people living here once represented a powerful paramilitary organization bent on overthrowing the government in Iran. In the 1970s, the group killed Americans in Tehran, and after being given refuge by Saddam Hussein its members were suspected of serving as a mercenary unit that took part in his violent suppression of the Kurds in the north of Iraq and the Shiites in the south.

description: WASHINGTON  In 2005, when the State Department invited Native Deen, one of the most prominent Islamic hip-hop groups in America, to do a good-will tour of Mali, Senegal and Nigeria, the bands members did not know what to do.

description: The lawyer representing Levi Aron, the man accused of kidnapping, killing and dismembering an 8-year-old boy in Brooklyn, announced on Friday that he had brought in a lawyer with deeper experience in mental health issues and the insanity defense to assist him.

title: Cameron Under Pressure
description: Since we gathered here last, the News International phone-hacking scandal has unfolded with staggering speed: the past week brought the resignations of top News Corporation executives and two ranking British police officials, the unexplained death of a former News of the World editor and whistleblower, and the beginning of sometimes dramatic government hearings on the matter, one featuring Rupert and James Murdoch, a shaving cream pie and an amazing flying spouse (pink jacket).

description: Everybody talks about the weather, but I guess TV meteorologists have to do it more cleverly, said Jay Trobec, a weatherman at KELO-TV in Sioux Falls, S.D., as he sought to explain why the phrase heat dome is suddenly being heard and seen everywhere.

title: Finding a Place in the Neighborhood
description: A classic neighborhood spot in a neighborhood without many, Sud Vino & Cucina has already become the kind of place the locals root for after just four months. In a developing corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant, on Bedford Avenue just south of Lexington, the space hits many familiar notes: a long exposed brick wall functions as a rotating art gallery; Edison bulbs dangle from the ceiling on red cords; the bar is fashioned out of wood reclaimed from a Brooklyn water tower. But it has won ardent fans for its homey feeling (a painting of the restaurants name by the owner Giuseppe Di Francos daughter Jaiden, 7, hangs at the front of the room), its selection of about 20 wines and its menu of rustic Italian pastas, salads, antipasti and crostini. On Wednesday, two waiters on a culinary expedition were quickly won over.

title: Law Students Alter Ego: Filmmaker
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: Riding the Rails to Ride the Waves
description: ON any given summer morning, they pop up on the A-train platform at Nostrand Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, along with the Caribbean women headed to nursing duty in Queens and the security workers and European tourists off to Kennedy Airport: young men with bagged surfboards dangling from their shoulders. Out to the Rockaways in Queens they ride, mostly getting off at Broad Channel, changing for the shuttle to the main break at Beach 90th Street, where new waterfront condominiums overlook rows of Dutch Colonials and enormous apartment complexes jut out to the shoreline far into the distance.

description: It felt like Death Valley as stifling heat reached down on Friday and took the city in its clammy grip, transforming the streets and sidewalks into hot griddles and creating instant dripping wretchedness.

description: The father of a man who plotted to set off homemade bombs in Manhattan subway cars was convicted of obstructing justice and conspiring to obstruct justice during a federal investigation of his son.

Im all for the concept, so long as Im the one deciding whats acceptable and doing the reforming. And I have something that most of the other self-appointed judges dont: the Putt-Putt System of Personal Redemption.

title: Dodgers Ordered to Bargain With M.L.B. on a Loan
description: A federal bankruptcy court judge on Friday rejected the Los Angeles Dodgers plan to borrow $150 million from a hedge fund and ordered them to negotiate cooperatively with Major League Baseball for a loan of the same amount on better terms. But the judge, Kevin Gross, said the loan could not lead to control of the team.

description: Two days after the momentous victory of Southern arms at the Battle of Bull Run, the first train crowded with Union prisoners of war rolled into Richmond, Va. A motley crew of bedraggled federals poured out of the cars. Curious citizens buzzed with excitement as guards marched the men through the Confederate capital.

title: Working as a Way of Living
description: Robert Wilson, the multifaceted artist and the director of avant-garde creations like Einstein on the Beach, is one cosmic cat. Mr. Wilson is as likely to collaborate with Lou Reed and Laurie Anderson as with members of the local Shinnecock Indian tribe. He established the Watermill Center on Long Island, a cultural think tank for young artists and scholars, in 1992 and acknowledges it as his legacy; its annual benefit gala is July 30. Mr. Wilsons 70th birthday is being celebrated Oct. 4 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with the opening of his production of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weills Threepenny Opera. He keeps to a daily work regimen, but on Sundays allows himself time to relax and smell the roses on his six-acre retreat.  ROBIN FINN

title: Giving Voice to Immigrants, Past and Present
description: Ambivalence about immigration is as American as, well, corned beef, pizza, knishes, black-eyed peas, empanadas  and apple pie. Which is why Toward a Better Life: Americas New Immigrants in Their Own Words  From Ellis Island to the Present (Prometheus Books, $26) is a welcome reminder that the vast majority of todays newcomers are tomorrows productive citizens and that they gravitate here for the same reasons their predecessors did for centuries; some of them even become the antiforeigners of the future.

Tankers, container ships and other freighters, most of which burn a coarse petroleum sludge called bunker fuel, now contribute about 3.3 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions, though some analysts argue the figure may be considerably higher. Without new restrictions, emissions from increased shipping could nearly triple by 2050.

The average estimate of 22 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg was $1.28 a share. Sales rose 16 percent to $6.91 billion. Stock in McDonalds, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $2.02, to $88.56 a share.

title: City Is Stunned at Teenagers Arrest in Parents Deaths
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, FLA.  Tyler Hadley was giving a party for 60 people at his home here last Saturday night when, according to police, he confessed to a friend that he had killed his parents. The friend refused to believe him, until the 17-year-old Mr. Hadley showed him a bloody shoe print in the garage. title: France: Kidnapping Was Part of Ritual
description: A teenage girl, whose kidnapping on Sunday from a park in Privas, in southeast France, riveted the country, was found unharmed on Friday, apparently taken by her fiancs family as part of a Chechen premarriage ritual, the police said. The girl, who was not named and who was thought to be 16 or 17, was found by the police in the southwestern Haute-Garonne region with the family of her fianc, said a spokeswoman for the Privas police. The family said they were simply following an old North Caucasus tradition, like others in the Chechen diaspora. The kidnapping originates as a response by a man when a young womans family refuses a marriage. After the abduction and a night spent away from home, the young women is considered soiled, and the family would then consent to the union. Religious leaders among the Chechens, who are mostly Muslim, are trying to put an end to the tradition.

description: My Sunday column argues that we usually think of national security challenges coming from terrorists or enemy countries, but one major challenge to American national security right now comes from the grotesque mishandling of the Washington budget battle. I wish we were as vigorous in standing up to domestic threats to national security as foreign ones, but were not. Read the column and post your thoughts.

title: Beijing Bars Writers From a Literary Celebration, Continuing a Crackdown
description: BEIJING  For Chinese authors who join the international writers organization PEN, membership would appear to have very few privileges. Many of its members are subjected to frequent harassment; four of them are currently in prison, including one of its founders, Liu Xiaobo, the essayist and Nobel Peace Prize laureate serving 11 years for subversion. All told, the group counts 40 journalists, novelists and historians imprisoned because of their writings.

title: In the City of Brotherly Heat
description: PHILADELPHIA  In Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, the temperature was 100 degrees when Kyle Kendrick threw the first pitch against the San Diego Padres at 4:12 p.m., but the heat didnt dampen the spirits of the officially sold-out crowd.

title: Change in Rating Formula Creates Anxiety in Schools
description: On Friday, the Texas Education Agency will publicly release its annual accountability ratings for the states 1,000-plus school districts. School officials always eye this day with nervous anticipation, but this year many are feeling more than a twinge of dread.

title: With Some Rich Car Fans, Formula One Could Work
description: Sebastian Vettel of Germany is dominating Formula One again this season, building on his 2010 championship with six wins in nine races. But thats nothing compared with the underdog triumph that Formula One itself just pulled: getting money from the state of Texas.

title: Tension Turns Into Approval Among Spider-Man Fans at Comic-Con
description: SAN DIEGO  They came, they saw and some walked  several hundred Comic-Con attendees poured out of the giant Hall H about halfway through the Amazing Spider-Man presentation. But Sony Pictures Entertainment and its coming reboot of the Spider-Man series won the battle for fans hearts and minds at the fan convention on Friday.

title: A Neophyte in the House, but Not in Politics, Sours on the Experience
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Players Committee Expected to Ratify N.F.L. Labor Agreement on Monday
description: N.F.L. players and owners made such significant progress on their remaining differences Saturday that tentative plans were being made for the players executive committee to meet in Washington on Monday. The hope is that they will vote to ratify the agreement that will end the lockout after more than four months.

title: Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Military Chief in 1990s, Dies at 75
description: Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the first foreign-born soldier to become the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, died Saturday morning at an Army hospital in Washington State of complications after a stroke. He was 75.

title: Charles Manatt, Former Democratic National Chairman, Dies at 75
description: Charles T. Manatt, a lawyer who founded one of the countrys largest law firms and served as chairman of the Democratic National Committee during the Reagan administration, died on Friday of complications stemming from a stroke. He was 75.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 24
description: With time running out for a deficit reduction compromise to avert a federal government default, all eyes are on President Obama and Congressional leadership. The Sunday talk shows are no exception.

title: For Young Campers, Island Turned Into Fatal Trap
description: OSLO  It has been a rite of passage for Norways liberal elite for decades: a summer camp set on a verdant Nordic isle called Utoya, where this week hundreds of young people gathered to meet government ministers, dive into election strategy sessions and maybe find a little summer romance.

title: James T. Molloy, Last Doorkeeper of the House, Is Dead at 75
description: James T. Molloy, the 34th and last doorkeeper of the House of Representatives, known for heralding the opening of joint sessions of Congress by bellowing Mr. Speaker, the president of the United States! from the rear of the House chamber, died on Tuesday in Rochester. He was 75.

title: Warren Leslie Dies at 84; Wrote Book That Rankled Dallas
description: Warren Leslie, who in 1964 raised hackles in Dallas, his adopted hometown, when he contended in a book that a climate of right-wing extremism had primed the city to become the scene of a national tragedy  the assassination of President John F. Kennedy  died on July 6 at his home in Chicago. He was 84.

description: It was high noon on Saturday, about an hour before the first pitch at Yankee Stadium, where fans were anticipating several scorching hours and the possibility of the temperature reaching triple digits for the second day in a row.

title: Norway Attacks Put Spotlight on Rise of Right-Wing Sentiment in Europe
description: BERLIN  The attacks in Oslo on Friday have riveted new attention on right-wing extremists not just in Norway but across Europe, where opposition to Muslim immigrants, globalization, the power of the European Union and the drive toward multiculturalism has proven a potent political force and, in a few cases, a spur to violence.

title: Mets Santana Is Hopeful but Cautious About Return

With Water and Bobbleheads, Cincinnati Copes
description: CINCINNATI  A brief midday thunderstorm quickly gave way to sunny skies and staggering heat and humidity as the Reds faced the Atlanta Braves. The Reds offered fans free sunscreen and cups of ice, temporarily lifted a ban on open containers of water being brought into the ballpark and opened three air-conditioned rooms for distressed fans to escape the heat.

description: The article is by  Mark Mazzetti,  Eric Schmitt and  Charlie Savage.

description: Public spaces almost universally serve as great equalizers, but perhaps none so much as the public pool. Los Angeless aquatics division operates 38 outdoor pools. New York City has 54, thanks in part to the controversial Parks Commissioner Robert Moses, who opened 11 enormous swimming pools in the oppressively hot summer of 1936, during the Depression. And there must be thousands covering the distance in between, millions of games of Marco Polo, hundreds of millions of handstand contests.

Its current show also has a particularly contemporary feel, referencing the recent political upheavals of the so-called Arab Spring.

description: As dozens of jubilant same-sex couples set out on Sunday to celebrate their nuptials in Queens, there was at least one disappointed resident.

description: For their first date, Steve Mulrooney and Jerome Van Wert rode the Staten Island ferry under the moonlight. title: Gay Marriage | Downtown Brooklyn, 10:40 A.M.
description: Christine C. Quinn, speaker of the City Council, witnessed the marriage of Justin Daniel, 32, right, and Joshua Cogswell, 35, in Brooklyn. The couple have been together for 10 years. When Mr. Daniel had trouble removing his ring so that Mr. Cogswell could put it back on for the ceremony  he had had it on for so long  Ms. Quinn unleashed one of her trademark belly laughs, joking that it reminded her of an I Love Lucy episode. Mr. Cogswell said that the couple had not expected the council speaker to attend their wedding, but that having the surprise guest was awesome.

title: Puerto Rico in History, Imagined and Real
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  On a cold, clear January day in 2008 Esmeralda Santiago walked downstairs to her office in her hilltop home here to immerse herself in writing the final pages of Conquistadora, her new novel. She was a week away from the deadline for this epic about her beloved Puerto Rico featuring a big cast of characters that includes the slave-driving, sugar plantation queen of the title, one Ana Cubillas. But when Ms. Santiago opened the computer document of her manuscript that day, the words looked something like this: Agttt Higg Bowq Sm. Pvxef byiz alwb.

description: LONDON  Can a bailout fund whose backers include some of the countries it may be called upon to bail out really succeed? Thats the question being asked by skeptical investors about the European Financial Stability Facility  the rescue fund of 440 billion euros, or $632 billion, that is being given new, amplified powers to help the euro zone end the sovereign debt crisis.

description: Gwendolyn Williams, 49, and Karen Cofield, 48, met in rehab. They were working through addictions to crack cocaine. Five years later, theyre still together, living on 167th Street in the Bronx, with a cat named MooMoo.

description: Diana Khan, 46, never thought she would be trading in her Muslim headscarf for a wife.

description: For Sarah Solovay, a New York City-based singer and songwriter who opened for John Mayer this spring, summers are particularly sweet. Ms. Solovay spends her days recording music and her nights performing on the Lower East Side or working on new music.

description: SHANGHAI  A year after opening a flagship store here, Apple has a problem that any retailer would envy: the huge 16,000-square-foot space is already too small.

description: Daniel S. Loeb, the founder of Third Point, isnt shy about speaking his mind.

title: Moodys Blues, Poor Standards, and the Debt
description: The invaluable Mike Konczal tells us the truth about the rating agencies and public-sector debt: not only do they constantly make mistakes, they do so in a consistent direction. Namely, they hold public-sector borrowers to vastly higher standards than they hold private borrowers.

description: Its extremely satisfying having just 20 friends on the new Google+.

title: The Cool Ferocity of a King Inflamed by Jealousy
description: A thrill of true feeling runs through virtually every scene of the Royal Shakespeare Companys production of The Winters Tale at the Park Avenue Armory. Scalding jealousy, hunger for revenge, young love in rapturous bloom, the soul-corroding sorrow of regret: all are evoked in the saturated colors that have sometimes been missing from the companys New York repertory season this summer.

title: Through a Portal, to a World Where Listless Blue Creatures Await
description: The Studio, as its called, is a rectangular room with a gray floor and a silver-tin ceiling. It is one of those anonymous places in Brooklyn  on an industrial block in Sunset Park  where dances are built and then delivered to a theater. For Sugar doesnt live here, seen on Friday night, the choreographer Stacy Grossfield stays put.

title: Steady Stream of Poses, Leaps and Everyday Chaos
description: In terms of watching dance in a park, the only circumstance more unappealing than SummerStage on its own  seeing dances with little or no nuance gets dull  is SummerStage during a heat wave. (Although it does help to imagine the life of a baseball catcher in August.) On a steamy Saturday night the festival offered a somewhat thematically random program, showcasing Jamel Gaines and his Creative Outlet Dance Theater of Brooklyn (the warm-up act) and Keigwin + Company (the headliner).

title: Pursuing Answers, Two Years After a Tragic Collision
description: The story of Diane Schuler and the horrifying collision she caused is a series of mysteries that probably cant be solved but that could, from some angles, be seen as fairly easy to explain. The layers of anger, guilt and what many would call blind faith that surround the case, however, have given it a tragic intensity, making the unanswerability of the questions seem profoundly painful.

title: In Movie of Mine Rescue, Producer Looks to His Roots
description: LOS ANGELES  In a study crammed with keepsakes of his Hollywood life, Mike Medavoy, the movie producer, keeps a black-and-white snapshot of some boyhood soccer pals. He is the gangly mop-top in the middle. The legend reads: Chile, 1957.

title: La MaMa Lineup for 50th Season
description: La MaMa Experimental Theater Club has announced the lineup for its 50th season and is calling it Homecomings. Its the companys first full season since the death of its founder, Ellen Stewart, in January. A two-day celebration, on Oct. 16 and 17, to open the season and honor Ms. Stewart, above, will feature a World Block Party with Blue Man Group and the Silver Cloud Singers, among others, and a performance by Patti Smith at a La MaMa 50 Gala. Season highlights include a revival of the director and choreographer Ping Chongs experimental 1985 play Angels of Swedenborg; a Hip-Hop Theater Festival; and the world premiere of Stopped Bridge of Dreams, a new work by John Jesurun. A new artists-in-conversation series, Monday Nights at La MaMa, is also scheduled and is to feature Julie Taymor, Philip Glass and other La MaMa alumni discussing their work. In a statement released by the company the artistic director, Mia Yoo, said the coming season would bring together artists who have worked here through the years with artists who are new to La MaMa, creating a dialogue, an energy, whatever you want to call it, this combustible creative force that will move the theater into the next 50 years.

title: Captain America Outperforms His Peers
description: Superhero fatigue? Not at the North American box office, where the summers fourth major movie based on comic book characters, Captain America: The First Avenger (right, Chris Evans in the title role) was a strong No. 1 over the weekend, selling an estimated $65.8 million in tickets. That result beat the opening totals for the summers other three superhero films: Thor, X-Men: First Class and Green Lantern. The Disney-owned Marvel Studios, which produced the well-reviewed Captain America for about $140 million, and Paramount Pictures, which distributed it, had worried about competition from Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (Warner Brothers). But the boy wizard fell to second place in the second weekend, taking in about $48 million for a new domestic total of $274 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Friends With Benefits (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was third with an estimated $18.5 million. Showing continued strength, Transformers: Dark of the Moon (Paramount) was fourth, taking in about $12 million for a four-week total of $326 million. Horrible Bosses (Warner) chugged along in fifth place, selling an estimated $11.7 million for a three-week total of $82.4 million.

title: Spider-Man Villain Cited in Comic-Con Scuffle
description: Rhys Ifans, who has been cast to play a villain in The Amazing Spider-Man film next summer, was cited with a misdemeanor battery charge on Friday night in San Diego before a panel at Comic-Con International, the countrys most important comic book convention, in which he was scheduled to appear to promote the movie, according to TheWrap.com. The police said that Mr. Ifans, above, shoved a female security guard after a member of his entourage was unable to enter the hall where the panel was taking place. In a statement Lt. Andra Brown, a spokeswoman for  the San Diego Police, said that Mr. Ifans had been abusive, belligerent and aggressive, and that he had been given a citation. The panel was organized to quell fans doubts about the direction of the popular Spider-Man character. The movie is a large financial risk for Sony Pictures Entertainment, which plans a series of wall-crawling adventures featuring Andrew Garfield in the title role. Rhys Ifans was detained by Comic-Con security after a brief incident backstage prior to and immediately following the Amazing Spider-Man panel, a Sony spokesman said in a statement. Police were notified, and a citation was issued to Mr. Ifans, who deeply regrets this incident. The film is to be released next July.

title: Accuser of Strauss-Kahn Goes Public
description: The woman who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, of sexual assault in a Manhattan hotel room has granted her first interviews to Newsweek and ABC News, which will begin broadcasting segments of the interview Monday morning on its Good Morning America program.

title: No Vaccine for Agony From Viral E-Mail
description: The readers to whom Helen Schulmans novel This Beautiful Life will most appeal are those who already know everything about it. Ms. Schulman holds a mirror up to the lives of moneyed, elite New York private-school families and invites such people to nod in recognition. In terms of a less provincial audience This Beautiful Life should please anyone who enjoys seeing the destruction of a happy family framed as a self-fulfilling prophecy. The cover art depicts a house of cards. What might happen to that house of cards by the time Ms. Schulmans story of a calamitous prep-school sex scandal is over?

title: Four Pianists, Teaming and Competing
description: Bill Charlap and Bill Mays faced each other squarely across the 92nd Street Y stage on Wednesday night, each stationed at a piano, taking turns but hardly holding back. It was early in the second half of a concert called The Key Players, part of the Jazz in July series. A projection on the back wall showed both pianists hands at work as they imbued an aptly titled standard, We Could Make Such Beautiful Music Together, with an air of thoughtful, chummy competition.

And then there is timeless comedy, which, properly performed, should feel as old as the hills and as fresh as ocean air. Or in the case of One Man, Two Guvnors, Richard Beans smash play at the National Theater, ocean air scented with the fumes of warm beer, melting taffy and frying fish and chips.

title: What Migraines? New Yorkers Defend Their High Heels

title: China Finds More Bodies, and a Survivor, in Trains Wreckage
description: BEIJING  Rescuers said Monday that they had recovered several more bodies from the wreckage of Saturdays high-speed train collision in eastern China, putting the death toll at 39, including two Americans.

title: Evolution Right Under Our Noses
description: To study evolution, Jason Munshi-South has tracked elephants in central Africa and proboscis monkeys in the wilds of Borneo. But for his most recent expedition, he took the A train.

title: A Mystical Tale, From Tee to Green
description: For many golfers Michael Murphys 1972 novel, Golf in the Kingdom, is practically a sacred text. Its about a young man, modeled on Mr. Murphy himself, who on his way to an ashram in India stops off in Scotland, where his life is transformed by an encounter with a golf pro and mystic named Shivas Irons, who knows as much about Pythagoras and the Hindu scriptures as he does about hitting a high fade. Several filmmakers have felt similarly transported by reading the book, and Golf in the Kingdom has been optioned or in development since before it was even published. Gus Van Sant was interested for a while. Sean Connery was approached about playing Shivas. Clint Eastwood fell in love with the book and clung to the rights for a decade or so before giving up.

title: Varied Views of Obamas Environmental Record
description: Yale Environment 360, an online publication of the universitys school of forestry and environmental studies, has rounded up some assessments of President Obamas performance on environment and energy issues as his first term shifts into its home stretch. The commentary comes from people as varied as Joe Romm of the liberal Center for American Progress, who gives the president an F, to Kenneth Green of the libertarian American Enterprise Institute, who criticizes the president for letting the Environmental Protection Agency overstep its bounds.

title: Drink Up | North Philly Beer, Part 1
description: On Poplar Street, between Second and Third Street in the Northern Liberties neighborhood of Philadelphia, there sits a placard placed by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission. It reads, AMERICAS FIRST LAGER: In 1840, John Wagner brought lager yeast from his native Bavaria and brewed the nations first lager beer. Later, other German immigrants began brewing lagers, which soon became popular & promoted growth of Americas brewing industry.

title: What the Well-Dressed Salad Is Wearing This Summer
description: Are you wilting faster than an overdressed salad? I am. Its hot out, and to me thats salad weather. (Actually, every season is salad weather to me, but I crave it more as the temperature rises.) The best-tasting salads rely on good greens lightly coated in a well-made vinaigrette, which is a snap to make once you know a few little tricks. The first is to always dissolve the salt in the acid before adding the oil. Then give it a good whisking or, even easier, shake, shake, shake it up in a jar. To see it all come together, watch my latest video.

It was quarried in Mankato, Minn., and gives the park a warm kind of glow, not only from the outside but also from the dugout roofs, the backstop and the corner walls, near the foul poles. It is local, enduring and appealing.

title: Guess Whos Tanking?

Well, it has been fairly calamitous  but not for the United States. The big news, instead, is that Italian and Spanish spreads  the difference between interest rates on their bonds and interest rates on (presumably safe) German bonds  have widened drastically again. Last weeks big rescue plan apparently didnt restore confidence.

On Monday, Animal Planet announced that it had started filming on a program tentatively titled The Faroe Islands Project, which it said will chronicle Sea Shepherds campaign to stop an annual whale hunt known as The Grind in the Faroes, an island group and Danish protectorate between the Norwegian Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.

title: The Memory of All That
description: When I started spending time with the man who would be my husband, I began to notice a strong and pleasing odor of coffee wafting up from his feet. Not only did his shoes smell good, they also occasionally contained a few grains of actual coffee grounds. This was, I soon discovered, the consequence of Nick having purchased an enormous and ancient coffee grinder from a defunct A&P in Vermont for eight dollars. In his tiny makeshift cabin on the edge of a forest in rural Connecticut there was only one electrical outlet wired seriously enough not to blow all the fuses every time he ground coffee, and it was in the back of his only closet. How could I not fall in love with a man whose feet smelled of freshly ground coffee?

title: When Granny Met Gershwin, and Other Gossip
description: By all descriptions, the 1926 musical Oh, Kay! qualifies as light entertainment. But when the novelist Katharine Weber saw a 1989 revival, at the Goodspeed Opera House in Connecticut, the show came with weight attached. Its music was written by George Gershwin, who had been the lover of Kay Swift, Ms. Webers maternal grandmother, who may have inspired the shows title character. In any case, one of Ms. Webers theatergoing companions, an old friend of the family, told her that Ms. Webers father had once been a beau of Ms. Swift, who had subsequently introduced him to her daughter, who became Ms. Webers mother. If that were true, then her father would have been her grandmothers lover. The mind reels before this erotically annotated genealogy.

title: Showdown Nears on Debt as Obama Warns of Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic-led Senate and Republican-led House on Monday barreled toward a showdown on competing plans to cut spending and raise the debt limit as a resolution to the intensifying crisis remained farther from sight just one week before a possible federal default.

description: After months of speculation on hip-hop blogs and in publications, Kanye West and Jay-Z announced on Monday that they would release their first album together, titled Watch the Throne, (Roc-A-Fella. Roc Nation/ Def Jam) on Aug. 8. But the record will initially only be available through iTunes. The album will go on sale in record stores and on Internet outlets four days later.

title: Their Zeal Changed Lives, if Not the System
description: Man down in the mens washroom! This cry is not part of the usual hospital soundtrack, but when Dr. David A. Ansell heard it as he sped down a corridor in the old Cook County Hospital in Chicago, he barely broke stride. He veered into the mens room, tried the locked door of the stall where a crumpled body lay, hoisted himself up over the fetid contents of the adjacent toilet, balanced on the metal divider and prepared to descend and administer CPR.

title: CBS Wins Sunday Night With Familiar Shows
description: CBS once again held the top ratings spot for Sunday in both total viewers and adults 18-49 with two mainstays, 60 minutes (8.2 million viewers) and Big Brother (6.9 million). They were followed by the debut of the networks latest reality show, Same Name, in which a celebrity lives the life of an ordinary person who shares the same name; 5.3 million viewers watched the episode on Sunday featuring the actor David Hasselhoff. Future guests are to include Kathy Griffin, Mike Tyson and Reggie Bush of the New Orleans Saints. On AMC, Breaking Bad retained a large portion of its season-premiere audience with a total of 2 million viewers for the second episode. It was the second-most-watched episode in series history. Breaking Bad is ahead of last seasons viewership total by 30 percent.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Lincoln Center
description: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the sixth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Lincoln Center.

title: Dolphin Tool Helps to Find Fare on Seafloor
description: In the 1980s it was discovered that some bottlenose dolphins in Shark Bay, Australia, rip up marine basket sponges from the seafloor and place them on their beaks for protection as they forage for food along rocky substrate. It is the only known instance of tool use by dolphins in the wild.

title: Shes a Rainbow
description: In the artist Alia Penners eyes, everything looks better covered in rainbows. Not girly, pastel rainbows, but brilliant acid hues that bring to mind Peter Max and Sonia Delaunay. When the California-born artist isnt painting rainbow-framed portals into alternate universes, she brings her pop psychedelic sensibility to album covers and posters for L.A. bands and happenings, helping to define the contemporary look of the city. Now, after dipping her toes into fashion with illustrations for Erin Wassons RVCA ad campaign and the hand-lettered titles for a Missoni film by Kenneth Anger, Penner, the former fashion editor of Arthur magazine, has introduced Mombi, a line of dresses named for a witch in Frank L. title: Intern Rising | Victoria Horning Handbags
description: I never carried a real handbag until I started designing them, says the debutante accessories designer Victoria Horning. But now, every morning I take the bag I choose to wear so seriously! Horning, a 24-year-old Manhattanite who graduated from some of fashions most prestigious prep schools (read: internships at Vogue, Alexander Wang and Nina Ricci), had terrific experience and no place to tote it. So, she started a label, making bags and cummerbunds out of calf hair, leather, alligator and stingray. It was a relatively modest project  that is, until word got out and her girlfriends wanted in. Today, the made-in-New York collection features six handbags, including the off-white lambskin one that Horning chose for her appointment with T (above). I just hope to see lots of girls wearing them, especially the Kates, she says. You know, Bosworth and Moss. Oh, yes.

title: Getting To a Deal
description: Last nights prime-time back-and-forth between President Obama and John Boehner was interesting political theater, and a useful digest of the arguments (shared sacrifice versus no new taxes) that were going to hear a lot over the next year or so  both in the presidential election and, if we only get a short-term increase in the debt ceiling, in the run-up to the next round of deficit brinksmanship. But it felt irrelevant to the endgame thats currently taking shape in Congress. The president will almost certainly sign any bill that can pass both houses of Congress, and were down to three scenarios for how that happens. Assuming that Boehner can muster enough Republican votes to pass the plan he announced yesterday which would cut a trillion dollars in discretionary spending, raise the debt ceiling for six months, and then empower yet another bipartisan commission try to negotiate a longer-term deal  and assuming that Harry Reid can find the votes to push his plan, with similar spending cuts but a longer debt-ceiling extension, through the Democratic-controlled Senate, then some compromise between the Boehner plan and the Reid plan seems like a natural solution to the impasse. (Ezra Klein has one plausible example of what such a compromise might look like.) However, enough Republicans regard Boehners plan as a sellout to begin with that the speaker of the House might not be able to make that compromise, in which case it becomes a question of who cracks first: Enough moderate Senate Democrats to push the Boehner plan through that body, or enough moderate House Republicans to push a version of the Reid plan through the House. (Note that Nancy Pelosi has endorsed Reids plan, suggesting that most House Democrats would vote for it if necessary.)

title: Met and Chorus Union Agree on Contract
description: The Metropolitan Opera and the union representing choristers, stage managers, dancers and staff directors have reached an agreement on a new three-year contract, officials said on Tuesday. Talks were continuing with the other two major unions at the Met, those representing the stagehands and orchestra. The agreement with the American Guild of Musical Artists, which covers the chorus, was reached in May and ratified on June 19 during the Mets tour of Japan. Met officials wanted to hold off on the announcement until the other two contracts were settled. The chorus agreement was to have expired on Sunday, the same day that the other two agreements end: with the orchestra, represented by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians; and the stagehands, represented by Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees. The guild employees received 2 percent raises for each year. The talks are being led by Joseph Volpe, the former general manager, who was succeeded by Peter Gelb. Mr. Volpe himself is a former stagehand and is considered well versed in labor matters at the Met. The Met finished this year without a deficit but has an accumulated deficit of $51 million, Mr. Gelb said. Pension funds are $78 million underfunded, and the endowment is $243 million, more than $100 million off its peak before the recession. We have large financial weights hanging on our backs that we are constantly reminded of, he said.

title: The Reid Plan vs. the Boehner Plan
description: With only days to go before the deadline to raise the debt limit or face national default, there are two plans on the table: the Reid plan endorsed by President Obama; and the Boehner plan, which Mr. Obama has suggested he would veto if it ever reaches his desk.

title: Negotiators Nearing Deal on Mileage for Vehicles
description: DETROIT  The Obama administration and automakers are nearing an agreement to increase fuel economy standards for vehicles to 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025, a lower target than the White House had sought.

title: Lebanon: Bomb Hits U.N. Convoy
description: A roadside bomb planted at the entrance to the southern port city of Sidon struck a United Nations convoy Tuesday, wounding five French soldiers, one of them seriously, the United Nations said. The attack comes just two months after another bomb near the same spot wounded six Italian peacekeepers. Prime Minister Najib Mikati ordered an investigation, though there was no immediate claim of responsibility.

title: Cant We Do This Right?
description: There is only one thing worse than Republicans and Democrats failing to agree to lift the debt ceiling, and that is lifting the debt ceiling without a well-thought-out plan and with hasty cuts totaling trillions of dollars over a decade. What business do you know  that is still in business  that would operate this way: making massive long-term cuts, negotiated by exhausted executives, without any strategic plan? It certainly wouldnt be a business youd expect to thrive. Maybe you can grow without a plan. But if you cut without a plan, you will almost surely hit an artery or a bone that could really debilitate you. That, I fear, is where we are heading.

title: Affluent Buyers Reviving Market for Miami Homes
description: MIAMI  South Florida is the default capital of the country. Here in Miami-Dade County, one out of five households with mortgages is in foreclosure. Nearby Broward and Palm Beach counties are not far behind. Nearly 200,000 South Florida families are stuck in the mire of default.

title: 4 Are Charged in Drug Sting
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan announced Tuesday that they had charged four men from other nations, including Iran and Lebanon, in connection with sting operations run by the Drug Enforcement Administration. Two men were charged with conspiring to provide material support to Hezbollah, which the United States considers a terrorist organization. Officials said they sought to buy surface-to-air missiles from informants working for the D.E.A. One of the men, along with a third defendant, was also accused in a heroin conspiracy to benefit Hezbollah. Another man, an Afghan, was charged with narcoterrorism conspiracy in a scheme to move arms and money to the Taliban, officials said.

title: Perfect, No, but One to Remember

Everywhere he went, he was greeted warmly, with players and coaches and staff shaking his hand and smiling. Cone was part of four championship teams with the Yankees, but he is remembered, as much as anything else, for his one day of perfection: July 18, 1999, when he retired all 27 Montreal Expos he faced in pitching only the third perfect game in franchise history.

title: Georgia: Mother Gets Retrial in Jaywalking Death
description: A judge on Tuesday granted a retrial to a woman who was sentenced to probation for her role in her 4-year-old sons death in a street-crossing accident. The case of Raquel Nelson, 30, has prompted a national outcry from parents and lawyers who argue that it would be unfair to make her spend up to three years in jail because she allowed her young son, A. J., to cross the street outside of a crosswalk. He was killed in an Atlanta suburb in a hit-and-run accident in October. Before the judge granted the retrial, a jury had sentenced Ms. Nelson to a year of probation on a misdemeanor charge of vehicular homicide. The driver served six months in jail for the crime. Ms. Nelsons lawyer said she would probably accept the retrial in order to disprove her guilt, even though that would reopen the possibility of jail time.

title: How Exercise Can Keep the Brain Fit

Activity appears to be critical, though scientists have yet to prove that exercise can ward off serious problems like Alzheimers disease. But what about the more mundane, creeping memory loss that begins about the time our 30s recede, when car keys and peoples names evaporate? Its not Alzheimers, but its worrying. Can activity ameliorate its slow advance  and maintain vocabulary retrieval skills, so that the word ameliorate leaps to mind when needed?

title: Stinger: James OKeefes Greatest Hits
description: The temperature was hovering near 90 degrees on the afternoon of Memorial Day when James OKeefe III emerged from the woods and ambled over to my car. He was tall and thin, with pale skin and matted reddish hair. When his mug shot ran in the papers, some people told him he looked like Matthew Modine. Others said Lee Harvey Oswald. On the day I met him, he wore muddy work boots, filthy jeans and, despite the heat, a long-sleeved shirt. Keeps the mosquitoes off, he said. All day he was in the outback of a regional park just west of the Hudson, breaking rocks with a pickax to construct a trail. As a boy he was an Eagle Scout, but this wasnt a nature project. OKeefe, the man whose video stings helped take down high-ranking people at National Public Radio and led to the demise of Acorn, the nations biggest grass-roots community organizing group, was doing federal time.

title: Apes From the Future, Holding a Mirror to Today
description: THE evolution of species takes place over millenniums. Pop-culture franchises just dont have that kind of time. Rupert Wyatts Rise of the Planet of the Apes, opening Aug. 5, is the seventh film about the peculiarly advanced simians invented by Pierre Boulle in his 1963 novel Planet of the Apes and the first in 10 years. The last Apes picture, directed by Tim Burton, was a remake of Franklin J. Schaffners original 1968 adaptation of the Boulle novel; the first film generated four sequels, a couple of TV series (one live action, one animated), a line of comic books and a jungleful of merchandise before the brand began to peter out, ceding its dominance to other, stronger market beasts like Star Wars and Batman. The apes had a nice run, but nothing lasts forever. Species die out. Empires fall. Profits decline. New heads of studios rise.

title: Babies to Heroes: A Field Guide to Big-Screen Men
description: THERE are times, particularly during the summer, when the big screen seems overrun with the alpha and omega of contemporary masculinity: the big babies of comedies and the hard-bodied manly men of superhero fantasies. There are a handful of other types in play, yet even these represent a fairly limited spectrum, from the idealized to the abject. The movies may be male dominated, but images of men are surprisingly narrow: often missing in action is the regular guy who wakes up every morning, kisses his wife (or husband) and manages not to do anything especially silly or heroic in the course of his working day.
