title: Now Selling | Textfield Titles at Creatures of Comfort
description: For its fifth in-store project, the SoHo shop Creatures of Comfort collaborated with the publishing and distribution company Textfield Inc. on No More Reality, a temporary bookstore and exhibition. Through Aug. 25, works by the artists Phil Chang, Arthur Ou, Eduardo Sarabia and Anna Sew Hoy  all Textfield Inc. favorites  play a supporting role to the printing house founder Jonathan Maghens curiously obscure and graphic selection of paperbacks and monographs. No book costs more than $100 (not even the artist Jennifer Doyles lovingly compiled Municipal du Futbol, about amateur soccer in Los Angeles, which includes two clothbound books, a jersey, nine artist lithographs and a poster). Pick up The Portable John Latham or the hilarious Hippie Photos and Surfer Man by the photographer Doniella Davy while you shop for Maison Martin Margiela clothes and Robert Clergerie shoes (falls tassel-top loafers and embossed leather wedges just arrived, p.s.).

title: Afghan Deadpan: Kabul Gets Its Version of The Office
description: Saad Mohseni, an Afghan media mogul who owns the popular Tolo TV network, has alerted his Twitter followers to stand by for the debut next month of a new comedy series, The Ministry, which appears to be an Afghan version of The Office in all but name.

title: A Proenza Schouler Deal Is Near
description: A European private-equity firm is expected to sell its shares in the design house Proenza Schouler to a group of New York investors led by John Howard, the chief executive of Irving Place Capital, and Andrew Rosen, a seasoned garment industry executive behind Theory and Helmut Lang.

title: Math Camp
description: On Bard Colleges campus, a free summer camp for low-income students who excel in mathematics.

title: Caucus Video: Speaker Boehners Perilous Moment; Mitt Romney in New Hampshire
description: Jackie Calmes reports on whether House Speaker John A. Boehner can control members of his caucus in the debt ceiling standoff. Also, John Harwood reports from inside Mitt Romneys campaign in New Hampshire.

title: G.M. Says Opel Unit Not for Sale
description: DETROIT  General Motors is not interested in selling its European unit, Adam Opel, the carmakers chief executive said Wednesday, countering widespread speculation.

title: Where the Job Growth Is: At the Low End
description: Theres more unhappy news for the millions of Americans hoping for a surge in the number of good, high-paying jobs  a new report concludes that the great bulk of new jobs created since the economic recovery began are in lower-wage occupations, paying $13.52 or less an hour.

title: Capitalizing on a Weak Commercial Real Estate Market
description: From 2009 to 2010, the commercial real estate market in the United States seemed bottomless. Whether seeking manufacturing, office or retail space, those looking to lease or buy were in the drivers seat, said Fred Schmidt, president and chief operating officer for Coldwell Banker Commercial in Parsippany, N.J. After the supply of space hit a peak in the fourth quarter of 2010, he said, the market began a slow recovery  but its definitely still a tenants and buyers market.

title: N.F.L.s Game of Catch-Up
description: While everyone seemed to predict that the end of the N.F.L. lockout would result in a free agency free-for-all, no one stepped forward with a properly absurd proposal for how it should be handled. We like the idea of putting all players names on Ping-Pong balls and have them spit out of a lottery hopper. Or perhaps the whole thing should be handled like Bingo. Auction paddles, anyone? No, wait, lets just play it all as a big video game. Or maybe Bob Barker has some time on his hands. Plaxico Burress, come on down!

title: Met Museum to Stay Open for McQueen Show Later Than Ever Before
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has never catered to the late-night crowd, but on Aug. 6 and 7, the last two days of its blockbuster exhibition Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty, it will keep the show open until midnight. Having combed through the museums records, officials there said they believed that this would be the first time the Met has stayed open so late.

title: Renaming the Campaigns
description: A soldier will fight long and hard for a bit of colored ribbon.

title: Are You Paying Too Much for Space?
description: Weve just published a small-business guide by Eilene Zimmerman that offers several examples of small-business owners who have taken advantage of one bright spot in a dark economy  a favorable market for leasing or buying commercial real estate.

title: When You Want to Collect Social Security vs. When You Should
description: Last week, we reviewed AARPs new Social Security calculator, which helps you figure out when to begin collecting benefits. This week, were reviewing some more tools that will help you make this decision. Below, we take a look at the second one.

title: Accuser in Strauss-Kahn Case Meets With Prosecutors
description: The hotel housekeeper who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her arrived at the Manhattan district attorneys office shortly after 10 a.m. Wednesday to meet with prosecutors handling the case.

title: In China, a More Western Approach to Elder Care
description: In any discussion here about the decision to move an older person into some sort of care facility, we can virtually count on a denunciation in the comments section, often from someone citing immigrant roots. Americans are too self-centered, too careerist, goes the criticism.

title: Photo Replay: July 27
description: The world swimming championships continued in Shanghai and Ervin Santana threw a no-hitter for the Los Angeles Angels in Cleveland.

title: Lehman Suit by Investors Is Allowed to Continue
description: 6:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Winehouses Record Sales Skyrocket; Adele No. 1 for 11th Week
description: The numbers are in: Amy Winehouse, who died last Saturday at age 27, will re-enter the Top 10 of the Billboard album chart this week, with her music racking up greater sales in the days after her death than it had since January.

title: Bucking the Speaker, and Crossing the Line
description: Tensions in the House Republican caucus are running so high that an e-mail by a junior staffer has riled its members.

title: New Norway Video Shows Strength of Blast
description: New videos from the moment of the blast in Oslo and its immediate aftermath have continued to emerge as Norway struggles to cope with scale of Fridays devastating violence.

title: BMW Group Appoints New President for North American Region
description: Jim ODonnell, the president of BMW of North America, is retiring on a high note, with the company entertaining realistic notions of becoming the No. 1 luxury automotive brand in the United States. The executive will be succeeded in October by Ludwig Willisch, who oversaw BMWs M performance division before being promoted to head European sales.

title: British Police Make Arrest in Net Attacks
description: The British police announced the arrest on Wednesday of a 19-year-old man who they said was the spokesman of the online vigilante group Lulz Security, which has claimed responsibility for a string of attacks on the Web sites of government agencies and private corporations.

title: Flooding in Bronx After Water Line Breaks
description: A major water supply line in the Bronx burst on Wednesday morning, flooding Jerome Avenue for several blocks near 177th Street, halting traffic, disrupting subway and bus service and damaging two nearby gas mains.

title: Beards: Rugged? Trendy? Or Unreliable?
description: The beard has become a symbol of youthful rebellion (and a different sort of conformity) for the first time since the heyday of Fillmore East.

title: What Your Beard Says About You
description: FOUR years ago, I grew the first full beard of my adult life on a whim. I was 41, and it was neither a fashion statement nor a midlife crisis, but it came at a fortuitous time: the style world just happened to be entering the Postmillennial He-Man Beard Epoch.

title: Chelsea Hotel to Stop Taking Reservations
description: The legendary Chelsea Hotel will stop taking reservations next Tuesday, Curbed reports. Living With Legends: Hotel Chelsea Blog reports that the news could mean many things, including the chance to do construction under reduced scrutiny or challenge the union.

title: Taking the Scissors to Annoying Labels
description: LEAH MISSBACH DAY, 52, a photojournalist in Chicago, likes designer labels like Balenciaga, Alexander Wang and Dries Van Noten. But not next to her skin. I cut them out because theyre scratchy and they bug me, she said. Ive got a whole drawer full of tags.

title: Mets Set to Send Beltran to Giants
description: The Mets and the San Francisco Giants are on the verge of completing a trade that would send Carlos Beltran to the Giants in exchange for a top prospect who is likely to be Zack Wheeler, a right-handed pitcher taken in the first round of the 2009 draft. The pending deal was confirmed by a person in baseball with knowledge of the talks. More details here, with updates to follow. Are the Mets on the right path, and should more big names be following Beltran out of town?

title: A Hectic, and Often Hidden, Day in the Life
description: As if there wasnt enough going on at the United States Capitol on Wednesday, it was all happening with cameras rolling.

title: N.F.L. Free-for-All Central
description: Big signing news of the day, so farThe Titans added a bit of stability with the signing of former Seahawks quarterback Matt Hasselbeck on Monday, although that is sort of like saying youve added some fresh water to the Atlantic Ocean. But after sending Vince Young into exile and having Kerry Collins retire instead of dive into this reclamation project, the Titans desperately needed not to throw their first-round draft pick Jake Locker straight into the lion pit. They put out a call for a veteran stop-gap and Hasselbeck, 35, answered, to the tune of $21 million over three years, the Tennessean reported.

title: Textile Museum to Move to George Washington University
description: The Textile Museum  will move to George Washington Universitys Foggy Bottom campus and become part of a new museum scheduled to open in 2014, the two institutions announced on Tuesday.

title: Boehner on Why to Back His Plan
description: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, told a radio host on Wednesday that Republicans should support his plan for a debt ceiling increase because Barack Obama hates it, Harry Reid hates it, Nancy Pelosi hates it.

title: Beltran All but Gone to the Giants
description: CINCINNATI  Carlos Beltrans jersey was still on view Wednesday afternoon in the same corner stall where it had been all week at Great American Ballpark, a lingering reminder of what was and no longer is.

title: Angels Ervin Santana Throws No-Hitter Against Indians
description: CLEVELAND  Ervin Santana pitched the first solo no-hitter for the Angels in nearly 27 years, getting some long overdue revenge against the Cleveland Indians and leading Los Angeles to a 3-1 win Wednesday.

title: What Would Che Say?
description: OF beautiful people Cuba has many. Any visitor to the island or its satellite country, Miami, knows that.

title: Theater Talkback: In Protest of Pre-Show Announcements
description: This summer ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Recent posts have examined the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in Funny Girl and unusual settings for Shakespeare stagings. This week, Laura Motta, a New York-based writer, editor and blogger (her blog signature is Lucky) writes about the value of letting shows speak for themselves.

title: S.B.A. Unveils New Venture Capital Fund
description: The Small Business Administration announced on Tuesday that it had formed a $130 million venture capital fund to invest in high-growth companies in Michigan. The fund is the first of what Karen Mills, the S.B.A. administrator, said is a $1 billion commitment over five years through what the agency calls Impact Investment funds, part of the Obama administrations Startup America initiative announced in January.

title: Now Showing | Knotty and Nice
description: New York design aficionados who are looking to beat the heat will find nothing but cool this summer at Ralph Pucci International, where a series of exhibitions, all on view through the end of the year, illustrates the very different approaches of their subjects. Revival, by the French designer Jerome Abel Seguin, contains nine sculptural pieces made of slices of enormous mahogany trees that were felled in central Java early in the 20th century. The pieces, some of which even contain large stones that became embedded in the trees, are at once graphic and textural, primal, and extremely powerful.

title: Americas Got Talent Makes Another Splash in the Ratings
description: Buoyed by the record-setting performance of Professor Splash, a professional diver who belly-flopped into a 12-inch kiddie pool from 3 stories up, Americas Got Talent on NBC was once again the most watched show on Tuesday with 11.2 million viewers overall, and it was No. 1 in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, according to Nielsen data.

title: Shift in Europe Seen in Debate on Immigrants
description: BERLIN  Less than a week after the mass killings in Norway, evidence of a shift in the debate over Islam and the radical right in Europe already appeared to be taking hold on a traumatized Continent.

title: Finding Humanity by Breaking Rules
description: Leah Millis grew up in Denver. A trip to Haiti as a teenager inspired her pursuit of photojournalism as a career. Now 23, she is studying at the Metropolitan State College of Denver and spending the summer as an intern at The Star Tribune in Minneapolis. Her conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited.

title: Its All Over but the Face-Saving?
description: It remains unclear whether the House will pass a bill by the speaker, John A. Boehner, to raise the debt ceiling, though prospects appear to be significantly better today than they did yesterday. Still,the mathlooks to be pretty close.

title: Reversing the Brain Drain:  Expanding Medical Opportunities in Rwanda
description: For decades, young doctors and nurses have been fleeing poor countries for the bright lights and fat paychecks of wealthier nations, abandoning the parts of the world with the highest burden of disease and most desperate need for medical help. Sixty percent of medical doctors who trained in Ghana in the 1980s have since left the country, and there are more Ethiopian doctors in Washington DC than in all of Ethiopia. Sub-Saharan Africa today houses more than a tenth of the worlds population, and shoulders a quarter of the global burden of disease, but it has just three percent of the worlds health care workers.

title: O.K. to Go Dance Crazy
description: OK Go is premiering their latest video All Is Not Lost, which includes an interactive HTML5 version.

title: Sundances Digital Move Seeks to Link Filmmakers and Audiences
description: LOS ANGELES Every year more than 50 percent of the movies shown at the Sundance Film Festival fail to achieve the big prize: acquisition by a theatrical distributor. Can Sundances new year-round digital delivery plan help those cinematic leftovers find an audience?

title: Fill-In | The Federal Debt Ceiling
How the South Bronxs Ruins Became Fertile Ground
description: This week in my Gotham column I wrote of the resurrection of the South Bronx, a brilliant coming back to life that owes much to the multidecade efforts of government.

title: Proxy Access in Limbo After Court Rules Against It
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has taken a chainsaw to the Securities and Exchange Commissions proxy access rule, striking it down in a 21-page opinion. A panel of three judges from the appeals court based its ruling last week on what it perceived to be the S.E.C.s failure to fully consider the costs and the benefits of this rule. With the S.E.C. wounded and proxy access seemingly on life support, if not dead, the question is what comes next?

title: Getting a Refund for Taxes Paid on Airfares
description: Earlier this week our colleague Joe Sharkey reported on a lapse in federal airfare taxes.

title: Unredacted Documents: Federal Officials Quietly Question Shale Gas
description: The Times reviewed thousands of pages of documents related to shale gas, including hundreds of industry e-mails, internal agency documents and analyst reports. A selection is here.

title: Online Music, Unshackled
description: Everybody seems to think that record company executives are big, greedy dunderheads. How dare you charge for music? the college set shouts. Music wants to be free!

title: Once Unthinkable, Breakup of Big Banks Now Seems Feasible
description: What was made can be unmade.

title: British Authority Bans Two Ads by LOral
description: For LOral, beauty is not always in the eye of the beholder.

title: Mystery Tombstone Finds Its Place of Rest
description: A year later, the mystery of why the tombstone of a woman who died in 1910 was found on the Lower East Side remains unsolved, but the tombstone has finally been installed in its rightful place: at the grave site of the woman, Hinda Amchanitzky, who wrote what has been described as the first Yiddish cookbook published in America.

title: Walter Reed Hospital Holds Closing Ceremony
description: WASHINGTON  History has marched through the halls of Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where presidents, princes, kings and generals mingled in their hospital gowns.

title: Scene City: AIDS Benefit Turns Up Heat
description: Like zombies in the dusk, grim-faced guests on the summer social circuit arrived at Steven Kleins AIDS benefit in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: When the Party Approaches Its Boiling Point
description: STEVEN KLEIN is an affable photographer whose work has a dark and sadistic edge that verges on the demonic. And just below its surface, the big party he hosted last Saturday at his sprawling property in Bridgehampton, N.Y.  West Kill Farm  for AIDS Community Research Initiative of America had a bit of an edge, too.

title: TimesCast | July 27, 2011
description: The columnist David Leonhardt argues for long-term commitment to the nation's fiscal health; Britain recognizes the rebels as Libya's legitimate government; and Amy Winehouse's record sales skyrocket.

title: A Walk Down Money Lane
description: DealBook takes a historical tour of lower Manhattan's famous real estate. Richard M. Warshauer, a senior managing director at Colliers International, has been leading the annual tours for 24 years.

title: Homes for $1.495 Million
description: A house in California with Pacific views; a renovated barn on 58 acres in Indiana; and a house on seven acres in Connecticut.

title: Tomato Stracciatella
description: Stracciatella is like an Italian egg drop soup. This particular version is adapted from one of my favorite cookbooks, "Cooking From an Italian Garden," by Jon Cohen and Paola Scaravelli. Id never seen a stracciatella with tomatoes until I came across this recipe.

title: Trenton Pizzeria Stakes Claim to Being the Nations Oldest
description: Nick Azzaro, above, says his pizzeria in Trenton, N.J., not Lombardis in Manhattan, is the oldest in the country. And it seems as if hes making a fair claim.

title: Homegrown Hurt
description: We are so accustomed to seeing terrorism through the lens of 9/11 that it may be hard to recapture how shocking it was to realize, 16 years ago in Oklahoma City, that devastating terrorism can be completely homegrown. The mass murder committed in Norway last Friday by a Norwegian anti-immigrant extremist brings Oklahoma City forcefully to mind for the first time in a long while. The bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building on April 19, 1995, by two disaffected Americans killed 168 people. At the time, it was the worst single incident of terrorism ever committed on American soil. Todays young adults, not yet then even in their teens, may barely remember it.

title: Jeremy Clarkson Goes Digital in Forza 4
description: If the automotive world, or the world in general, needs more Jeremy Clarkson, its about to get it, thanks to Microsoft.

title: A Walk Down Money Lane
description: Manhattans financial district offers a wealth of history for the real estate-inclined tourist. Richard M. Warshauer, a senior managing director at Colliers International, has been leading the annual tours for 24 years. Earlier this year, DealBooks Ben Protess took a walk with Mr. Warshauer to see what he could learn.

title: In Southern Styria, a Hilltop House
description: A three-bedroom house with two guesthouses and a pool in Styria, Austria is on the market for $2.5 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Austria
description: A THREE-BEDROOM HILLTOP HOUSE WITH TWO GUESTHOUSES IN STYRIA, AUSTRIA

title: Shopping for Footstools With Steven Sclaroff
description: The interior and product designer shopped for quirky footstools near his TriBeCa office.

title: The Game Is Afoot, But Which One?
description: President Obama said on Monday night that the battle over the debt ceiling was a dangerous game weve never played before, and we cant afford to play it now.

title: U.S. Soccers Home and the Worlds New Destination
description: Harrison, N.J.

title: Blackstone Is Said to Hold Talks to Buy Emdeon
description: The Blackstone Group is in discussions to buy Emdeon, a medical data services provider, for about $3 billion including debt, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: A Gamble on Art on the Redneck Riviera May Not Be Paying Off
description: ATLANTA  When the Ohr-OKeefe Museum of Art opened in November in Biloxi, Miss., residents were not sure what to make of the quirky little museum dedicated to an eccentric Mississippi potter and designed by the architect Frank Gehry.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, Korea and China.

title: Estimates of When the U.S. Will Run Out of Money
description: Chart showing the amount of the nations cash reserves and estimates for when it will run out if the debt ceiling is not raised.

title: Republicans Show a Motivational Video
description: As motivational videos go, you can see how it might be appealing.

title: Summer Styles | Great Lengths
description: We have yet to see separates make a significant comeback, even though were a month into summer. Maxi dresses with allover prints and simple silhouettes are everywhere, and women are opting to wear them most often with shoes that disappear behind the longer hemlines. The actress Halle Berry, with her daughter Nahla, pairs a graphic ikat with a fringed bag and barely there sandals, while the breakout star of the summer, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, puts a casual spin on wallpaper print and the Gossip Girl actress Jessica Szohr accessorizes a strapless with long gold chains.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, South Korea and China.

title: The Bad Girls Before Amy Winehouse
description: Amy Winehouse was a 5-foot-3 almanac of visual reference.

title: A Bad Girl With a Touch of Genius
description: ITS hard to look that cheap and pull it off, John Waters said admiringly of Amy Winehouse, some days after the English singer was found dead in her London bed.

title: To Fill a Gap in Commercial Radio, Classically Trained Apps
description: Its been a long decade for classical music fans, with the virtual disappearance of the genre from commercial radio.

title: Callahan and Rangers Agree to Terms on New Deal
description: 3:46 p.m. | Updated  Rangers President and General Manager Glen Sather announced Wednesday that the club has agreed to terms with forward Ryan Callahan on a new contract.

title: Victims of the Norway Attacks
description: The police in Norway have now confirmed the identities of all 77 people killed in Julys attacks on Oslo and Utoya Island. Learn more about the victims.

title: What You Get for ... $1.495 Million
description: CORYDON, IND.

title: With 17 Hits, Mariners End 17-Game Skid
description: The Seattle Mariners tried everything over the past three weeks, shuffling lineups and altering warm-up routines and even shaving mustaches, in an attempt to break their franchise-worst run of 17 consecutive defeats. Nothing worked.

title: Pac-12 Conference to Create Seven TV Channels
description: The Pacific-12 Conference, which has made no secret of its desire to create a network to showcase its newly expanded league, announced Wednesday that it would create six regional channels and a national one.

title: S&P Finds Merit in Some Debt Plans
description: One of the countrys major credit rating agencies said on Wednesday that some of the deficit-cutting plans being considered in Congress could help to avoid a downgrade in the nations credit rating, The Associated Press reported.

title: Permies at Work
description: An eco-ideology with no publicists or big names, has bubbled from the underground, into the mainstream, as a way of moving toward a sustainable future.

title: Japans Comfort Music
description: About a week ago, Rob Walker had a Riff column in the magazine on the declining interest in hit charts and No. 1 songs. That was on my mind when I saw a report last weekend on TV Japan, a cable service in the United States. The report said that sales of oldies in Japan had taken off since the earthquake/tsunami/nuclear disaster. People, it seems, are seeking comfort in those old, familiar tunes.

title: Study of Medical Device Rules Is Attacked, Unseen
description: Allies of the medical device industry are waging an extraordinary campaign in Washington to discredit a coming report by one of the countrys pre-eminent scientific groups that examines possible new regulations on the industry.

title: War Changes a Man, and a Play
description: The journey from invincible optimism to embittered defeat is a short one for Harry Heegan, the young soldier at the center of Sean OCaseys 1928 play The Silver Tassie. The echoes of Harrys joyous cries at a soccer victory in the plays opening scene still seem to be resounding in the air when he raises his voice at its mournful end, strumming a banjo and hymning the death of his young spirit as his friends and family look on in awkward sympathy.

title: 81 Children Rescued in Raids on Trafficking Ring, Chinese Officials Say
description: BEIJING  In a significant illustration of Chinas illicit trade in babies, the Ministry of Public Security said Wednesday that the police had rescued 81 children from a major child trafficking ring that had operated throughout eastern China.

title: In Western Water Wars, Fighters and, Yes, Peacemakers
description: Writing about water in a region where water is scarce can be a daunting business. In a graduate program, the prerequisites would be geology, hydrology, chemistry, law and engineering  especially law and engineering. The people involved in the issue (who call themselves water buffaloes, not without pride) tend to be defined by their fights as much as their accomplishments. In fact, when they are won, the fights are synonymous with their accomplishments.

title: Rock Chronicle Inspires Battle Over Its Legacy
description: Steve Baltin had been toiling as a freelance music writer for a decade when an entrepreneur named Jason Turner approached him a year ago about resurrecting Creem magazine, the irreverent and sardonic publication that defined rock in the 1970s. The offer to edit a once-famous magazine was tempting, to say the least.

title: A closer look at Lion, the new version of Mac OS X; website translation; the term "rickrolling;" news.
description: Alan Yacavone, an Apple expert from the Times's News Technology team, stops by to discuss Lion and its new features and design changes. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Jack Welde, the CEO of Smartling (http://www.smartling.com), about website translation and how his company uses the cloud and the crowd (-sourcing) to offer different language options. Freshly rickrolled, Pedro Rafael Rosado has something to say about that old prank. The news roundup includes YouTube taking up 22 percent of all mobile bandwidth; Walmart giving its Vudu video service an extra push; a new Mozilla mobile platform project; the resignation of a top U.S. cyber official; release of the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 tablet with 4G service; and an Apple security update. J.D.'s tip of the week: a feature in Microsoft Office 2010 and 2007 for Windows called KeyTips, which lets you jump into ribbon menus with just a few keystrokes and shows you what to press.

title: Fine Tuning Behind Closed Doors
description: A look at six rehearsals at the 42nd Street Studios in Times Square.

title: Rehearsals, Side by Side and Glorified
description: FORTY-SECOND STREET has long catered to the needs of New Yorkers, tourists, theater lovers, moviegoers, small-time hustlers, global corporations, shoppers, restaurateurs, news hounds, thrill seekers, hopefuls and has-beens. But until the New 42nd Street Studios was completed in 2000, there was precious little space for performing artists to rehearse.

title: In Turkey, a Sprawling Home In a Series of Caves
description: A couple carved a sanctuary from a hillside of buff-colored volcanic rock in Cappadocia.

title: A Journeyman Soul Singer Embraces His Audience in Word and in Deed
description: The line between showmanship and sentiment is often thick and impermeable, but midway through his Tuesday evening performance in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, Charles Bradley obliterated it.

title: Swedish Pair Wins Von Zedtwitz Title by Less Than a Board
description: TORONTO  At the American Contract Bridge Leagues Summer North America Championships here on Sunday the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs was won by Peter Bertheau and Per-Olla Cullin from Sweden. They finished less than a board ahead of Tarek Sadek from Egypt and Zia Mahmood of New York. Third were Jan Jansma from the Netherlands and Jay Borker of Greenwich, Conn. Bertheau and Cullin will play for Sweden in this years Bermuda Bowl world team championship, but not as partners.

title: Senate Extends Term of F.B.I. Director
description: The Senate on Wednesday voted unanimously to extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller III as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, allowing him to serve for two more years.

title: The Great American Hall of Wonders
description: Images from a new exhibition of Art, Science, and Invention in the 19th Century.

title: The Catching of Two Joseph Hellers
description: Just One Catch is a soup-to-nuts chronicle of the life of  Joseph Heller. It is by Tracy Daugherty, who should not be confused with Mr. Hellers daughter. Erica Hellers own book about her father is Yossarian Slept Here, and there are many places where Hellers daughter and Mr. Daugherty overlap. This situation is so jarring that it has driven Christopher Buckley, not ordinarily known for cornball silliness, to two giddy attacks of wordplay. About the biography he blurbs, A major achievement, or should I say major major major? in honor of Major Major, a major character in Hellers Catch-22. His blurb for Ms. Heller: I think this is going to be one hell(er) of a memoir.

title: The World as America Dreamed It
description: WASHINGTON  The first thing we see on entering the new exhibition at the Smithsonian American Art Museum here is a life-size painting of a formally dressed, graciously welcoming, aged gentleman. He is lifting a heavy red drape and gesturing as if inviting us to visit the marvels within. Beyond the curtain we glimpse walls lined with hundreds of glass cases, each containing stuffed birds. We see visitors strolling past, engaged in contemplation or struck with amazement. We also spot part of a mastodon skeleton, discovered in 1801 by the same man who lifts the curtain.

title: TeenNick Finds Success in the Nostalgic 90s
description: Viacoms research appears to have been proved right: twenty-somethings do want their old Nickelodeon shows back.

title: Obama the Moderate Conservative
description: No time to do any original posting tonight. But for those who missed the first time I linked to it, heres Bruce Bartlett  an economic adviser to Ronald Reagan  explaining why Obama is indeed a moderate conservative in practical terms.

title: Best of All Possible Worlds: When Life Gives You Mud, Take a Mud Bath
description: It would be comforting to imagine that The Optimists, Goran Paskaljevics viciously funny gloss of Voltaires Candide, was a site-specific satire of this Serbian directors homeland in the post-Milosevic era. The films five vignettes, whose characters cling to irrational optimism in the face of poverty, injustice and hatred, are all set in an unidentified Eastern European wasteland of bleak farming villages, one of which has been inundated by a flood.

title: Government Seeks More Information on Googles Admeld Acquisition
description: The Justice Department has asked Google for more information and time as it investigates the search giants $400 million acquisition of Admeld, a display advertising company, Google said on Wednesday.

title: A Publisher Plays Coy With Book Release
description: Over the last few days buyers for bookstores around the country have opened their e-mail to find a mysterious last-minute addition to the Little, Brown & Company fall lineup.

title: Its Never Too Late to Learn How to Succeed While in Fortress Mode
description: If you enjoyed Jonah Weiners article on Tarn and Zach Adams and the brilliance of their computer game, Dwarf Fortress, then you will likely also enjoy this interview with Wiener over on the excellent Boing Boing podcast Gweek 010. And if at some point during your reading of the story you thought to yourself, with some small amount of melancholy, I would like to learn how to plant crops and forge weapons and protect myself against vampire dwarves, but I am not the kind of person who even knows how to distinguish the military from the nobles, then you are in luck. At the University of Reddit, starting Aug. 3, theres a class being offered on Dwarf Fortress basics. So go forth and remember, the hippos like the sewers!

title: Republicans Seek Big Cuts in Environmental Rules

Briefs attacking the Florida law, in which a defendant need not know that a substance is illegal to be convicted of possessing or selling it, had been filed by groups including the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, the American Civil Liberties Union and dozens of law professors. Judge Mary S. Scriven of Federal District Court threw out the drug delivery charges against Mackle Vincent Shelton, and ordered a new sentencing hearing on other charges. Floridas unique law expressly eliminating mens rea for drug offenses, the judge wrote, is atavistic and repugnant to the common law. The state is expected to appeal the decision, which could leave hundreds, if not thousands, of convictions in question and affect pending cases.

title: Losing at Restaurant Roulette

I asked.We had reservations at three restaurants and chose this one.Shes not kidding, said her boyfriend.Im delighted, I said. But I feel bad for the other guys.Dont worry, she said. We called and canceled.Were very polite people, added her beau. Picky, but polite.Just curious, I said. When did you call them?When was it, honey? Six, six-thirty?Yes. title: Alex Trebek Chases Suspected Burglar, Inspiring Awful Jeopardy! Jokes

title: Twin Blasts Leave 12 Dead in Iraqi City
description: BAGHDAD  Two explosions struck outside a bank in Tikrit, Saddam Husseins hometown, on Thursday, just as soldiers were lining up to cash their paychecks. The first report on casualties indicated that 12 people died and 28 were wounded, a local official said.

title: Eurofail

title: Q. and A.: The Rambunctious Garden
description: The Madrona Woods cascade down a hillside and through a ravine, connecting the Seattle neighborhood where I live with Lake Washington below. Thanks to volunteer efforts and timely financing, native plants thrive along the pathways, and a restored creek empties into the lake at a recreated cove, offering habitat for salmon fingerlings.

title: When They Play Women, Its Not Just an Act
description: FOR someone whose only acting experience was playing a Boy George lookalike in a high school production of the musical The Wedding Singer, Harmony Santana is having an incredible year. Ms. Santana is making her big-screen debut in Rashaad Ernesto Greens coming-out drama Gun Hill Road, which had its premiere in January at the Sundance Film Festival. Last month the movie made a splash on the gay film-festival circuit, opening Outfest in Los Angeles and closing Newfest in New York. It opens commercially in New York on Aug. 5.

title: Italy's Borrowing Costs Jump
description: PARIS  Italys borrowing costs rose almost a full percentage point from a month ago at an auction of 10-year bonds Thursday, to the highest rate in more than a decade, in another troubling sign that the latest rescue package for the euro zone has not eased investors concerns.

title: With Sales Plummeting, Nintendo Pares Outlook And Cuts a Retail Price
description: TOKYO  In a striking reversal of fortune for the worlds largest video game maker, Nintendo drastically cut its annual profit outlook on Thursday and said it would deeply discount its new 3DS hand-held device as it struggles to stem a flow of users to casual online games.

title: After a Year of Inspections, 69 Percent of City Restaurants Have As
description: A full year after the citys health commissioner, Thomas A Farley, placed the first blue-and-white Grade A food-safety placard in the front window of Sparks Deli in Long Island City, Queens, officials say nearly every restaurant in New York has been inspected and most are making the grade.Of the citys 24,000 restaurants, 69 percent had been issued an A, 15 percent a B and 4 percent a C as of July 1, said Susan Craig, a health department spokeswoman. Twelve percent had grade pending designations.During the course of the year, 40 percent of the restaurants received an A grade on initial inspection, Ms. Craig said. Of the restaurants initially granted a C grade, 55 percent had advanced to an A or B grade on their next inspection.

title: Foreign Entanglements, New York Style
description: George Washington took the presidential oath of office in Lower Manhattan in 1789, but he didnt spend much time here; the countrys nascent government soon moved to Philadelphia. Maybe if he had stuck around longer, people in this city would have taken closer to heart his later warning against foreign entanglements.

title: L-3 to Spin Off a Government Services Unit
description: L-3 Communications Holdings said on Thursday that it planned to spin off some of its government services operations into a new company, freeing it from potential conflicts of interest with its parent.

title: Border Crossers

title: Life on the Line
description: El Paso and Ciudad Jurez lie together uncomfortably like an estranged couple, surrounded on all sides by mountains and desert. The cities are separated by the thin trickle of the Rio Grande, which flows through concrete channels, built to put an end to the rivers natural habit of changing course and muddying boundaries. One side is Texas; the other, Mexico. The borders way of life  its business, legitimate and otherwise  has always relied upon the circumvention of this dividing line.

title: Suicide Bombers Attack Afghan Provincial Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban launched one of their most audacious surprise attacks on Thursday, sending a squad of at least seven suicide bombers into the capital of a relatively stable southern province with the aim of assassinating the provincial governor and an influential powerbroker. Neither was killed, but security and health officials said at least 21 civilians had died in the collateral mayhem, half of them children.

title: The Lowdown | Wade Slitkin
description: When Wade Slitkin leaves a room, the most common utterance is: That kids gonna do big things. Slitkin just has this air about him  of intelligence and keen intuition. Hes the kind of guy you would trust with your puppy. A street-smart product of inner-city public schools, Slitkin worked in special markets for several major book publishers, until it became clear that he was building rocket ships in the belly of a dinosaur. Two years ago, he scraped up his savings and, together with two of his buddies, Stephen Lynch and Brett Dovman, created Panelfly, an app designed to revolutionize storytelling in modern times. Cryptically described as SuperMedia, Panelfly, according to the official description, unlocks the full potential around a media franchise, pulling related films, books, games, interviews and art together into a singular experience, transforming how we experience entertainment altogether. At a time when everyone in the publishing and media industries is scratching their heads and bordering on desperation, Slitkin is being heralded as a boy genius.

title: George Clooneys Ides of March Will Open Venice Film Festival
description: Though it was bad news for Julius Caesar The Ides of March has already proved a good-luck charm for George Clooney: his new political thriller of that title will make its debut as the opening night offering of the Venice Film Festival, its organizers said on Thursday. Mr. Clooney directed the film, which is adapted from the Beau Willimon play Farragut North, and stars as an aspiring presidential candidate who turns to a novice press secretary (played by Ryan Gosling) to help manage his campaign. Other films that will be shown in competition at the festival, which will run from Aug. 31 through Sept. 10, include Roman Polanskis Carnage, his film adaptation of God of Carnage, starring Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly; Dark Horse, a new film by Todd Solondz, starring Mia Farrow, Christopher Walken, Justin Bartha and Selma Blair; William Friedkins film version of Killer Joe, starring Matthew McConaughey and Emile Hirsch; and David Cronenbergs Dangerous Method, his drama about Carl Jung and Sigmund Freud. The festivals out-of-competition lineup will include W.E., a new film directed by Madonna; Contagion, directed by Steven Soderbergh; and Wilde Salome, directed by and starring Al Pacino. The festivals closing-night film will be Damsels in Distress, the first new feature in more than a decade from Whit Stillman.

title: The Great Fleet Street Novel
description: If youd gone to a publisher in 1981 with a proposal for a science-fiction novel that consisted of a really clear and simple description of the world today, William Gibson told The Paris Review recently, theyd have read your proposal and said: Well, its impossible. This is ridiculous.  Youd have gotten a similar reaction if youd gone to a publisher earlier this year with a proposal for a novel that went something like this: journalists on a British tabloid hack into and delete the voice mail messages of a missing (murdered, it turns out) teenage girl. Their activities are exposed by a rival outfit, to widespread public outrage. The paper in question is shut down by its owner, despite having a circulation of millions. Senior policemen, who hired former journalists from the paper as press officers, resign. Evidence emerges of illegal payments from the paper to corrupt police in exchange for information about celebrities, politicians and crime victims. Several journalists are arrested, including two former editors of the paper, one of whom had worked for the prime minister. A whistle-blower is found dead (though police say it isnt suspicious). The papers owner, mogul of an international media empire, is summoned to testify before Parliament. And the allegations of wrongdoing just keep coming.

title: 36 Hours in Budapest
description: LIKE much of post-Communist Europe, Budapest has replaced the image of the impoverished East with symbols of international luxury, like the Four Seasons Hotel Gresham Palace and a new branch of Nobu, the high-end Japanese restaurant. But unlike many other cities in the region, the Hungarian capitals brightest spots are often native-born, rather than imports. From stately Buda in the west to Pests shabby-chic streets east of the Danube, a range of new attractions show off the achievements of local artists, producers, vintners and chefs. Even if you dont end up tasting every last domestic food specialty identified as a hungarikum, or tracking down every up-and-coming designer, a weekend here provides a glimpse of the citys justifiable pride, as well as an authentic sense of place.

title: Good and Evil on Cable
description: In the interest of talking about something besides the debt ceiling for a moment, heres an engaging Chuck Klosterman piece comparing moral agency on Mad Men, The Wire and The Sopranos to the moral landscape of AMCs returning hit Breaking Bad (currently the best show on television, for my money). Klosterman notes that all of these series grapple with morality  more than anything else, its the reason theyre better than the shows around them. But he argues that the first three examples all create realities where individual agency is detached and questions of personal moral choice arent foregrounded: Mad Men because its set in the 1960s, making its characters actions more a commentary on the era than a window into their souls, The Wire because its more political than philosophical, bent on constantly emphasizing the way everyone is simultaneously good and bad in order to offer a critique of American society as a whole, and The Sopranos because the fact all its major characters were involved with organized crime and its protagonist murdered people for money meant that there were never any unresolved questions over Tony Sopranos goodness.' (We knew he was fundamentally bad, Klosterman argues, because otherwise he couldnt exist as the person he was.)

title: The Netflix-Hulu Divide
description: While it has been known that Netflix and Hulu streaming users are consuming internet bandwidth at a huge and ever increasing rate, what hasnt been widely reported is just what theyve been watching with these services. According to a recent survey conducted by Nielsen, less than half of Netflix users watch on their home computer, instead opting to connect via video-game consoles hooked up to their television. Conversely, almost 90 percent of Hulu users watch directly on their computer. Thirty-six percent of all Netflix users watch both movies and television shows while, unsurprisingly, 73 percent of Hulu users watch television programs. Only 9 percent who use Hulu use the service to watch movies. Streaming on mobile devices such as cellphones or tablets like the iPad hasnt gone beyond early adopters just yet  only 6 percent of Netflix users and 3 percent of all Hulu users watch on the go.

The round-up includes the Big Baby (e.g. smiley, sexless Kevin James or the Zach Galafianakis type, edgier, crueler, with beards); the Brave Boy (brooding and brash, like Harry Potter or [10 points here if you can name Shia LaBoeufs character in the Transformer films]*); the Husband (henpecked and undersexed); and the Wimp (subsets include the Nerd, the Geek, the Nebbish and, often offensively, the Gay Guy).

title: Ex-Yankee Irabu Found Dead
description: Hideki Irabu, the former Yankees pitcher who struggled to live up to grand expectations after coming over from Japan, was found dead in Los Angeles on Thursday. He was 42. Police are investigating Irabus death as a possible suicide, according to various reports.Irabu came to the United States in 1997 billed as one of Japans premier right-handed pitchers. The Padres owned his rights, but Irabu refused to play for any team but the Yankees. San Diego traded him to the Yankees, who signed him to a four-year, $12.8 million contract.His career began with such promise, when he struck out nine and allowed two runs as the Yankees defeated Detroit in his major league debut, on July 10, 1997. That start proved the highlight of the season. He was banished to the bullpen and the minor leagues, and he finished the year 5-4 with a 7.09 earned run average.In 1999, Steinbrenner erupted after Irabu failed to cover first base during an exhibition game, calling him a fat toad. In three seasons with the Yankees, Irabu was 29-20 and pitched in only one postseason game, when he came out of the bullpen to allow eight runs to the Red Sox in Game 3 of the 1999 American League Championship Series. Two months later, Irabu was traded to Montreal, where he started 14 games over 2000 and 2001, before finishing his career with Texas in 2002. He retired in 2004 after pitching two seasons for the Hanshin Tigers in Japan.

The photographer Juergen Teller visited Kiev three times in five months for the project, and the photos he took on these trips speak to the extraordinary wealth he saw there. Tellers view of Kiev is steeped in the language of fashion and excess  models, hair, makeup, styling  and interspersed with more candid snaps of everyday scenes.

How can I inform her that her involvement in my babys life will wane if she does not comply with my wishes? Anonymous

Just when the beats per minute have accelerated beyond 160, and you are gasping for air, a momentary respite gives you a few seconds to wipe your brow, catch your breath and take a sip from your water bottle. Then youre shoved back into the race. I cant recall another thriller that has maintained this kind of velocity without going kablooey and losing its train of thought.

title: Total Family Breakdown, 21st-Century Manhattan Style

As the video, forwarded again and again, goes viral, the tabloid media go bananas, linking Jake and Daisy in an ominous and humiliating celebrity. What can the future hold for unformed, vulnerable kids who bumble their way into the lowliest realm of the permanent record that is the Internet? (Or, in Daisys case, reach it by simulating sex with a toy baseball bat.) Should their parents be held responsible, or are they equally victimized by the seductions and traps of digital life?

title: A Russian Who Ignores Those Old Stereotypes
description: It seems odd that a pianist as accomplished as Dmitri Alexeev does not perform in New York more often than he does. Now 63, Mr. Alexeev studied at the Moscow Conservatory and won a string of competition prizes in the early 1970s. But he has sidestepped the stereotypes of both Russian pianism (big, brawny and loud) and the international competition style (dazzling but risk averse). His recital on Wednesday as part of the International Keyboard Institute and Festival at the Mannes College the New School for Music showed him to be a thoughtful, poetic player willing to go out on a limb, interpretively, usually to superb effect.

Its sound, more distractingly, was pure Strokes: strobing guitar chords, peppy bass line, terse drumming.

title: Faces Still Alive, Centuries Later
description: The most useful knowledge we have about the great 17th-century Dutch painter Frans Hals is what we glean from the vibrant, shimmering surfaces of his art. He was an amazingly gifted technician, capable of defining the human face in passages of seemingly quick, vivacious brush strokes that convey both physical solidity and expressive fluidity. He was also something of an empath, intuitively alert, it would seem, to what was going on behind those faces. He approached his subjects with an open, nonjudgmental equanimity, whether he depicted them singly or in groups, in dignified repose or unbridled revelry.

description: THEY have a family resemblance, but the 1907 Cook house, at 973 Fifth Avenue, takes a back seat to the ebullient Whitney residence, next door at 972. The pair, both designed by Stanford White, are just above 78th Street, and the first is slim, pared down, almost invisible compared with its much wider neighbor, which has rich ornament and a pushy bowed front.

title: Kiwanuka Back With the Giants
description: The Giants agreed to terms with defensive end Mathias Kiwanuka, who missed all but three games last season with a neck injury.

title: Judge Dismisses Atheists Suit Against Texas Governors Prayer Rally
description: HOUSTON  A federal judge on Thursday dismissed a lawsuit filed against Gov. Rick Perry of Texas by a national group of atheists seeking to block his participation in and promotion of a Christian-centered prayer rally next weekend.

title: Whats a Guy to Do if His Wife Cheats on Him? Head to the Mall
description: Crazy, Stupid, Love is, on balance, remarkably sane and reasonably smart. Directed by Glenn Ficarra and John Requa, this movie, packed with appealing stars, is a smooth blend of modern comic genres with a surprising undercurrent of dark, difficult emotion. Essentially a study in the varieties of masculine sexual confusion, it travels the circuit from bromance to a kind of Y-chromosome weepie that might be called male-odrama, with a detour into the briar patch of adolescent awkwardness.

title: In Baring Facts of Train Crash, Blogs Erode China Censorship
description: BEIJING  After all the wind and storm, whats going on with the high-speed train? read the prophetic message posted last Saturday evening on the Chinese microblog Sina Weibo. Its crawling slower than a snail. I hope nothing happens to it.

title: After a Year, No Answers in N.B.A. Players Death
description: MEMPHIS  A year after the body of the veteran N.B.A. player Lorenzen Wright was discovered in a wooded area in this citys southeast suburbs, family and friends gathered Thursday for a candlelight vigil outside the FedEx Forum to draw attention to the still-unsolved killing.

title: Soldier Held Amid Claim of Terror Plot at Fort Hood
description: An Army private who had been absent without leave since earlier this month was arrested this week near Fort Hood with a gun and suspicious materials in what local law enforcement officials described on Thursday as a terror plot to kill other soldiers.

title: Straight From Uday Husseins Inner Circle
description: As people across the Arab world struggle to shake off the burdens of dictatorship, the release of The Devils Double, a slick English-language excursion into Saddam Husseins Iraq, might seem either timely or insensitive. Shot in lurid, gilded tones; pulsing with pop decadence, the film is less an anatomy of authoritarian politics than a gangster movie. Mercedes-Benz sedans hurtle through the streets; men in dark suits and sunglasses share the screen with women in lingerie; guns are drawn and fired; and life is either a nonstop war or an endless party, or both.

title: Sept. 11 Revealed Psychologys Limits, Review Finds
description: The mental fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks has taught psychologists far more about their fields limitations than about their potential to shape and predict behavior, a wide-ranging review has found.

title: Should Unhealthy Foods Be Taxed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Useless Studies, Real Harm
description: Minneapolis

title: Mismatched Partners in a Crime Comedy
description: Popping with glorious, bright color and off-color jokes, The Guard is an Irish comedy and almost incidental thriller, though mostly its something of a bait and switch. The tasty bait (and reluctant buddies) are Brendan Gleeson and Don Cheadle, two of the best utility players in contemporary English-language cinema. Alone or together, they can be reason to see any movie. Even when theyve been self-consciously set off against each other for maximum quirk, as they are here, these are performers who can dig a little deeper than their material.

title: Deal-Making Lifts Lazard and Evercore
description: Lazard said on Thursday that its second-quarter profit rose 23 percent from the period a year ago as increasing deal activity and growth in assets under management bolstered results, the investment bank said on Thursday.

description: CINCINNATI  Terry Collins was asked Thursday morning whether he would be keeping a particularly close eye on any of his pitchers as the Mets approached the final two months of the season.

description: It passed with only scant notice, as with so many of the rude extremes of American life in a kinetic media age. The bodies of those Norwegian children slaughtered by a terrorist had yet to be fully recovered, let alone buried, when Glenn Beck compared the victims to Nazis.

description: Epocrates has won over nearly half of the nations doctors for its free smartphone apps that lets them look up information on drug dosing, interactions and insurance coverage while seeing a patient.

title: The Trials of Team Afghanistan
description: Afghanistan has a national mens basketball team, although it is made up of young Afghan-Americans with modest doses of collegiate experience. The team has a coach, although actually holding a full practice can require a mad scramble that includes cross-country flights. When the practices do occur, he sometimes puts up as many as seven players in his home near Sacramento.

title: Twitter as Police Scanner Draws Feedback in Seattle
description: SEATTLE  A flurry of Twitter messages that began early Tuesday morning from the Seattle Police Department puzzled many Twitter users. Was there a sudden crime wave in Seattle? Was the city under attack? Had a computer gone haywire?

title: Atheists Sue to Block Display of Cross-Shaped Beam in 9/11 Museum
description: In the days after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, some workers and mourners at the World Trade Center site seized upon a cross-shaped steel beam found amid the rubble as a symbol of faith and hope.

description: ASPEN, Colo.  The recently departed director of the nations main counterterrorism center said Thursday that Al Qaeda in Pakistan still posed a serious threat to the United States, and he warned that assessments that Al Qaeda was on the verge of collapse lacked accuracy and precision.

title: Inner City vs. Outer Space
description: Teenage delinquents go from hoods to heroes in Attack the Block, a jacked-up horror comedy that pits inner-city residents against outer space invaders.

title: Capitols Tremors Unsettle White House, Too
description: The White House was taken by surprise late on Thursday afternoon by the news that Speaker John A. Boehner, facing a Republican rebellion and scrambling for votes, had once again delayed House action on his proposal to increase the nations debt limit in return for spending cuts.

title: A Young Tibetan Lama Prepares for a Greater Role
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.  At the age of 7, he was deemed to be the 17th reincarnation of the Karmapa  one of the most revered figures in Tibetan Buddhism  and whisked from the yak-hair tent of his nomad family in the Himalayas to be groomed in a monastery for leadership.

title: Beltran Already at Ease Wearing a New Uniform
description: PHILADELPHIA  As Carlos Beltran pulled on a San Francisco Giants uniform for the first time, the large television next to his locker in the visitors clubhouse here on Thursday afternoon broadcast the Mets sweep-completing victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Company With Political Ties Is Sole Bidder on Jail Contract
description: Officials in Essex County, N.J., announced Thursday that only one company had bid on a contract to run a 450-bed immigration detention center that federal officials would like to turn into a model for such facilities across the country.

description: Standing on a BART platform or strolling down Market Street, it is easy to pick up snippets of languages other than English  rapid-fire Spanish, of course, or maybe animated Mandarin.

title: Increasingly, a Ritual Is Bypassed

But when Lisa Rothman, an Oakland career counselor, gave birth to her two sons, now 2 and 5 years old, she did not even consider having their foreskins removed.

title: Life Is a Wheel | Bruce Weber Cycles Across America
description: Follow Bruce Webers journey as he bicycles across the United States.

title: Sleep? For N.F.L. Agents, the Action Is Nonstop
description: David Canter was sitting in a hibachi restaurant in South Florida late Wednesday afternoon, having his first food of the day and trying to jam in some family time before the phone rang again. For an agent juggling multiple clients, this has been the most unusual and exhausting week in N.F.L. history  a crash course in multitasking melded with a case study on the effects of sleep deprivation.

description: Supporters of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya appeared for a rally in Tripoli on Thursday evening.

description: Golf may be the worlds dullest spectator sport, not counting soccer: it takes a long time for not much to happen. By that standard, Golf in the Kingdom captures the game perfectly.

title: U.S. Regulator Says Fukushima Lessons Can Percolate
description: Its official: the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has been outvoted on his proposal that the panel decide within 90 days on the recommendations it received from its Fukushima task force.

description: OSLO  Nearly all Norwegians of a certain age know where they were when Oddvar Bra suddenly broke his ski pole in the final sprint of a championship ski race in 1982, and Norway had to settle for a tie with the Soviet Union. But the common expression, Where were you when Bra broke his pole? has suddenly given way to a darker question  where were you when Anders Behring Breivik was killing Norways children?

Under the bright blue sky, the crew began to cut down thousands of marijuana plants that were flourishing with the help of an irrigation system in a remote section of the forest in Tehama County.

The World as YouTube Knows It

description: There may still be a way out for Jefferson County, the Alabama county being crushed by its debt.

title: The Centrist Cop-Out
description: The facts of the crisis over the debt ceiling arent complicated. Republicans have, in effect, taken America hostage, threatening to undermine the economy and disrupt the essential business of government unless they get policy concessions they would never have been able to enact through legislation. And Democrats  who would have been justified in rejecting this extortion altogether  have, in fact, gone a long way toward meeting those Republican demands.

title: Paths That Cross in Los Angeles
description: The multistory movie  weaving together episodes of several unrelated characters as their paths cross  has held a place of honor in Hollywood since Grand Hotel. In recent years a Los-Angeles-specific subgenre has grown like Topsy, from the entrancing Short Cuts to the less fabulous Crash to any number of weaker efforts: These days every film student in Southern California must be assembling a thesis project with a lineup of locals intended to reveal the Connectedness of Us All.

description: The Obama administrations decision to suspend $800 million of its $2 billion in annual security aid to Pakistan inevitably raises the question of why the United States should continue to give Pakistan any military aid at all.

title: Japanese, in Shortage, Willingly Ration Watts
description: TOKYO  With Japan suffering from electricity shortages this summer, Michio Kuniyuki has stepped up his conservation patrols of Rikkyo University.

title: On to Richmond! Or Not
description: It didnt take long for Horace Greeley, the nations most loved, hated and widely read newspaper editor, to become impatient with the progress of the war. From the moment news of Major Robert Andersons surrender at Fort Sumter reached New York City, drumbeats and bugle calls for immediate military action could be heard in the columns of Greeleys paper, the New-York Tribune. Never mind the logistical challenge of assembling, arming and training a suitable military force  the people, or at least the editors, were ready, and there was hardly a moment to lose. What appeared to be lacking, from Greeleys perspective, was a necessary vigor from President Lincoln and his administration.

title: Hideki Irabu, Briefly a Yankee Sensation, Dies at 42
description: Hideki Irabu, a former Japanese baseball star who was hailed as a pitching sensation when he joined the Yankees in 1997 but who fell short of expectations, prompting an angry George Steinbrenner to label him indelibly as a fat, pus-sy toad, was found dead on Wednesday in the Los Angeles suburb where he lived. He was 42.

title: Detroit, the Union and Improving Times
description: Detroits automakers have rebounded since the dismal days of 2009, when Washington steered General Motors and Chrysler through bankruptcy proceedings on the taxpayers dime. Sales of cars and light trucks have slowed slightly recently, but they are still expected to hit 13 million this year, up from 10 million in 2009. The carmakers posted a combined profit of $6 billion in the first quarter of the year.

title: No Excusing the A.T.F., or Congress
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives  perennially hogtied by the gun lobbys power over Congress  made a colossally dumb decision when it concocted a sting operation that let 2,020 high-powered weapons slip across the border into Mexico.

title: Oh, Is That the Law?
description: There are so many things wrong with New York States self-dealing redistricting process. Time to add one more to the list: One of the first decisions made by the bipartisan mapmaking committee  made up of two state senators, two members of the Assembly and two politically connected experts  was to violate a new state law requiring that prisoners be counted in their home districts, not where they are serving time.

title: Gay in Amsterdam in the 1980s
description: A gay tragedy in three acts and more than a dozen excellent songs, House of Boys conveys an emotional honesty that overrides its dated style.

title: Judges Ruling in Madoff Case Could Reduce Money for Victims
description: A federal judge ruled on Thursday that the bankruptcy trustee trying to recover billions for those who lost money in Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme did not have the right to sue banks and other third parties on behalf of the victims.

title: Treating the Cause, Not the Illness
description: In 1965, in an impoverished rural county in the Mississippi Delta, the pioneering physician Jack Geiger helped found one of the nations first community health centers. Many of the children Geiger treated were seriously malnourished, so he began writing prescriptions for food  stipulating quantities of milk, vegetables, meat, and fruit that could be filled at grocery stores, which were instructed to send the bills to the health center, where they were paid out of the pharmacy budget. When word of this reached the Office of Economic Opportunity in Washington, which financed the center, an official was dispatched to Mississippi to reprimand Geiger and make sure he understood that the centers money could be used only for medical purposes. Geiger replied: The last time I looked in my textbooks, the specific therapy for malnutrition was food. The official had nothing to say and returned to Washington.In some ways, the United States has come a long way since Lyndon Johnson declared the war on poverty. But in others, were still at square one. We now have a variety of federally-supported nutrition programs, but the health care system remains senselessly disconnected from the social determinants of health. In this regard, the United States has fallen behind the rest of the world. If a politician in India announced a public health plan that neglected malnutrition, he would be ridiculed. Here, leaders make this kind of omission all the time. Almost all of the debate about the 2010 Affordable Care Act was consumed with questions about health care access and quality. But if we really want to improve the health of millions of people, we have to address the conditions that make them sick.

title: Surprise Ending to Day of Strong-Arming, Head Counts and Meetings
description: WASHINGTON  After two hours of impassioned debate, the Capitol was braced for the grand finale of Speaker John A. Boehners days of strong-arming members on the most important vote of his Congressional career. Suddenly, with no warning and just minutes from a vote Thursday evening, the conversation on the House floor turned to naming post offices.

title: By Sterilizing Stray Cats, City Hopes to Cut Shelter Numbers
description: New York City has reached an agreement with animal-advocacy groups under which it will avoid having to build full-time shelters in Queens and the Bronx, but will step up its efforts to sterilize feral cats and to require owners to spay or neuter free-roaming cats.

title: Making the Diaper Change Easier for the Changer
description: IN a new commercial for Huggies Little Movers Slip-On Diapers, which have leg holes and slide on like underwear, a baby rolls over twice in the same direction as a voiceover begins, Huggies presents a whole new way to change a rolling pin.

title: A Parolees Dilemma
description: In Forged Chuco (Manny Perez), just released from prison after serving eight years for the killing of his wife, has a very rough return to the world. Cesar (Jaime Tirelli), leader of the violent gang from the old days, gives him a job to do, whether he wants it or not. And Chucos son, Machito (David Castro), who saw his parents final fight as a child, has become a troubled teenager, abused and homeless. When he finds his father, he must introduce himself before warning: You killed my mother. And Im going to kill you.

title: An Accuser Gets Her Day, Though Not in Court
description: Ive been asking God, Why? Nafissatou Diallo said at the end of two minutes of halting, nerve-racked, soft-spoken-to-the-brink-of-inaudibility speech. Why me?

title: Slower Racial Change Found in Census of City
description: New York City edged a baby step closer to racial equilibrium in the last decade, according to census results released this month. Compared with the 1990s, the numbers of Hispanic and Asian New Yorkers grew more slowly; blacks recorded their first population loss since the Civil War; and non-Hispanic whites, who registered their smallest population loss in decades, also logged the biggest gains of any group among young children.

title: Powerlifting as Escape
description: Perched somewhere between hard-luck tale and inspirational story, All She Can, about a high school girl trying to win a scholarship to the University of Texas, mostly feels as ponderous as the sport that might be her ticket out: powerlifting.

title: Jerome Liebling, Socially Minded Photographer, Dies at 87
description: Jerome Liebling, whose subtly powerful pictures and the lessons he drew from them influenced a generation of socially minded photographers and documentary filmmakers, died on Wednesday in Northampton, Mass. He was 87.

title: The Slow Life in Trefeurig
description: Not much happens in Gideon Koppels film Sleep Furiously, an impressionistic documentary about Trefeurig, a farming community in Wales. A calf is born; a choir sings; a cake is baked. The action heats up a bit when the film checks in with a yellow library van, manned by a kindly fellow who chats with the villagers about books and the town.

title: Syrians Planning for Stepped Up Protests During Ramadan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The relentless cycle of protest and crackdown in Syria over the last four months appears poised to enter a new phase in the coming Muslim holy month of Ramadan, with activists planning to capitalize on religious rhythms to hold nightly demonstrations despite fears of an even harsher government reaction.

title: Friday: Theyre Subject to Inflation and Deflation
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Well. This is an interesting-looking grid. And its not meant to represent anything other than your standard Friday crossword grid. Its certainly not implying that its anything else, unlike a certain Sunday puzzle from not too long ago that I am still getting mail about, by the way.

title: Carmakers Back Strict New Rules for Gas Mileage
description: DETROIT  Four years ago, the American auto industry was so opposed to higher fuel economy standards that executives of Detroit camped out in Washington in an unsuccessful bid to undercut them.

title: Long Fights for Sports Equity, Even With a Law
description: In 1998, the University of Southern California was accused of denying its female students a fair chance at participating in sports. Thirteen years later, the federal agency charged with investigating sex discrimination in schools has not completed its inquiry of U.S.C.

title: Hospitals in Brooklyn Defended at Hearing
description: A stream of hospital administrators, a state assemblyman, doctors and advocates for immigrants took the microphone at a sometimes raucous hearing in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday to plead with state officials not to close, merge or shrink troubled hospitals in the borough.

title: Boutique Firms Are Bearing Up
description: Wall Street firms that specialize in mergers and acquisitions are hitting a few wobbles after a good run. Lazard missed second-quarter estimates on Thursday, though only by a penny, because of lower growth in advisory fees than peers. Evercore Partners delivered a similar underperformance as compensation expenses more than doubled. And Greenhill & Company has been frantically trying to calm nerves about departing executives.

description: Jerome Liebling, a photographer, filmmaker and teacher, died Wednesday at 87.

description: The Jets spent the early part of the week shoring up their offense with the signing of receiver Santonio Holmes. Now, General Manager Mike Tannenbaum is likely to turn his attention to reinforcing the defense.

description: Amazon, the online retailing giant, announced a deal with NBCUniversal for access to part of Universal Pictures film library on Thursday, its second such pact in the streaming video space in as many weeks.

description: Zachary Harrison Wheeler has always gone by Zack  Z-A-C-K  a decision his parents readily admit has led to plenty of awkward moments.

description: The waiting continued at the Capitol Thursday night as the Republican leadership worked late looking for votes that could rescue House Speaker John A. Boehners debt ceiling bill.

title: U.S. Ties a Russian to Bombings in Georgia
description: MOSCOW  American intelligence officials have concluded in a classified report that a Russian intelligence officer may have been behind a string of bombings in the nation of Georgia last year, including an explosion near the United States Embassy, but that there is no evidence of a plot to attack American installations, an American official said Thursday.

title: Tiger Woods Returns, as Do Questions
description: Tiger Woods ended an 11-week absence from the PGA Tour Thursday night with the surprising announcement that he would play next week at the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational at Firestone Country Club.

description: The Government Accountability Office, the investigative arm of Congress, will evaluate the actions of the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs fraud; the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, which appointed the trustee; and the Securities and Exchange Commission, in the liquidation of Madoffs firm.

description: Republican leaders in the House have announced that there will be no vote on the debt ceiling bill Thursday night, an indication that Speaker John A. Boehner remains short of the votes necessary to pass his legislation.

title: Despite Changes, Scandal Remains Hot Topic for Big Ten
description: CHICAGO  With Nebraska joining the Big Ten and the addition of divisional play and a championship game, the conference is anticipating a historic season. But scandal was an unavoidable topic of discussion Thursday as coaches and conference officials addressed reporters on Big Ten media day at a downtown hotel here.

title: On the Links, Taking Aim at Obama, and Politics
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Keith Tassio was steaming, and the fierce summer sun was only partly to blame. Golfers view their game as a respite from lifes frustrations, and here he was, about to putt on the ninth hole of one of Scottsdales many, many golf courses, being asked about Washington, of all things.

title: In Stronghold of Liberals, a Call to Levy More Taxes
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.  Arthur May, a laid-off computer programmer in this proudly liberal suburb of Boston, has been watching the showdown over the federal debt ceiling with growing revulsion  aimed mostly at Republicans.

title: Irabus Arrival Came With Signs of Trouble
description: Back in 1997, the arrival of Hideki Irabu to the major leagues was big news. Irabu was not the first or the best pitcher to come from Japan, but he had made a bit of a spectacle of demanding to play for the Yankees even though the San Diego Padres had purchased his contract from the Chiba Lotte Marines.

title: Report on Dead Polar Bears Gets a Biologist Suspended
description: The federal government has suspended a wildlife biologist whose sightings of dead polar bears in Arctic waters became a rallying point for campaigners seeking to blunt the impact of global warming.

title: Bill to Ban Stimulant Drug Advances in Senate
description: A bill that would ban the new stimulant drug known as bath salts passed the Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously Thursday. The bill, which was sponsored by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, would make mephedrone and methylenedioxypyrovalerone illegal to possess or sell. Both would be added to the list of controlled Schedule I substances. Bath salts are typically sold online or in convenience stores or head shops, and doctors report seeing agitated, violent behavior in some users. At least 29 states have banned bath salts, which are sold under names including Ivory Wave and Vanilla Sky and are typically injected, smoked or snorted. The bill will go to the Senate floor.

title: Maryland: Historian Is Indicted in Theft of Documents
description: Barry H. Landau, a New York-based presidential historian and writer, was indicted Thursday by a federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to steal historical documents and sell them, according to the United States attorneys office in Baltimore. Mr. Landau, 63, and Jason Savedoff, 24, his colleague, who was also charged, could face up to 10 years in prison if convicted of theft of documents, which federal prosecutors say include a letter from Benjamin Franklin to John Paul Jones taken from the New-York Historical Society.

description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: London Theater Journal: A Pig That Would Make a Playwright Proud
description: LONDON  Never let it be said that the pig is not a lady. Yes, the title character of Betty Blue Eyes, the slyly winning new musical at the Ivor Novello Theater, is irrefutably porcine. She emits odors that cause everyone around her to gag, and you do need to watch where you step after shes been in the room. Yet this over-size porker has a shy, persuasive charm that can only be described as genteel. The same may be said of the show in which she appears.
