description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about United Nations leadership.

Yet the lavishly designed show opened to a crush of negative reviews, leaving producers wondering how they would earn their money back once tourists stopped buying tickets.

title: The Bears Are Coming (Again)
description: Reading in todays paper about recent bear attacks in Colorado, I was reminded of Darcy Freys prescient story from a few years ago about particularly audacious bears in the Canadian town of Whistler and the biologists who study them. Frey wrote about bears that lift the door handles of trucks to take possession of the cabs; bears that manage to snag the bait from a trap with one foot while holding the steel gate open with the other; bears that stroll munificently through the crowds at the Canada Day parade; bears in the pubs, the hotels, the day care centers, the landfills, meat lockers, grease vents, underground parking garages. In Whistler, if a bear doesnt get into something humans are guarding, its usually because too many other bears got there first.

title: Great Books: Kids Edition
description: Last July, our staff writer Susan Dominus, who was then working as the papers Big City columnist, wrote a story about Jenny Rosenstrach, the keeper of a wonderful cooking blog called Dinner: A Love Story. The blog contains plenty of great (sometimes Bittman-esque) recipes  for grilled pizza, say, or minty peas (and also Manhattans)  and if you have any interest in the cooking or eating of food, it wont disappoint. But it also occasionally contains book recommendations for kids. Usually, the suggestions come from Jennys daughters or from her husband, Andy. But in the past few weeks, something amazing has been going on over at DALS. The recommendations are coming from authors, and not just any authors, but some of the greatest childrens lit (or any lit) writers alive. Here is Pseudonymous Boschs summer reading list, for instance. And here are the recommendations made by Lemony Snicket (a k a Daniel Handler, who was the subject of this profile in our magazine back in 2001). And here is the summer reading list provided by George Saunders, whose genius is impossible to overstate and whose name popped up on our own great-fiction list just a couple weeks ago. Maybe once we finish contemplating our favorite sentences (and by the way, speaking of George Saunders, there are many amazing sentences in his most recent short story in the New Yorker), well move on to our own subjective rankings of childrens books. Until then, these are pretty solid guides.

title: Will Plug-In BMWs Turn Enthusiasts On?
description: FRANKFURT -- BMWS designers and engineers have long vowed that the companys eventual battery-powered cars would not be geekmobiles but true BMWs, with all the zip, handling and style that the German automaker is known for. Norbert Reithofer, the chief executive, is fond of saying that an environmentally friendly auto should not be a vow of poverty on wheels.

title: Catching Up With Tanner Foust, a Very Busy Driver
description: Two years ago, Tanner Foust was known in the world of drifting competitions and virtually nowhere else. Now, he is among the most recognized, and recognizable, drivers in the country, despite not competing in high-visibility race series like Nascar or IndyCar.

title: Jobs Deficit, Investment Deficit, Fiscal Deficit
Outside Madrid, Celebrating a Fashion Designer Who Embraces Art
description: Fans of the late Alexander McQueen who fear that the world of fashion has lost forever a designer who can combine boundless theatricality, scrupulous styling and high art might be heartened by the Fashion Art exhibition, which collects works by Manuel Fernndez, a designer with a similar flair. A selection of 100 of his breathtaking gowns and jackets are now on view through Sept. 18 at the handsome Tomas Y Valiente Center of Art (Calle Legans, 51, Fuenlabrada; 34-91-492-1120; www.fundacionfai.org), about 20 minutes by train from Madrid.

title: Venezuelas Vinotinto: The New Vintage?
description: Copa Amrica in Argentina is over, Uruguay has taken home the trophy for the 15th time, and the rest of South America assesses whether the balance of soccer power has been altered. If so, the net winner is Venezuela, which was eliminated in the semifinals, on penalty kicks against Paraguay, without having lost a match.

title: Walter Reed Closes as a Wounded Times Photographer Covers the Ceremony
description: HOW has history marched through the halls of Walter Reed Army Medical Center?

title: Seoul Sets Terms for Resuming Talks With North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea must suspend all activities at its nuclear complexes and allow United Nations inspectors to verify a freeze before the six-nation negotiations can resume on economic and other rewards for the country in exchange for ending its nuclear weapons programs, the chief South Korean nuclear negotiator said Friday.

title: Moodys Puts Spains Debt on Review
description: LONDON  Casting a greater shadow over Spains economy, Moodys Investors Service said Friday that it might cut the countrys credit rating in the coming months because of concerns about rising borrowing costs and the risk that private investors might have to bear some of the pain in any future bailouts.

title: Long Story Shortlist: Rebellion, Evolution and Baseball
description: Kei Igawa: The Lost Yankee,by Bill Pennington (July 23, 2011)TRENTON  In the middle of a bright Manhattan summer afternoon, the Yankees $46 million pitcher steps from his fashionable East Side apartment building and slips into a waiting Lexus for a chauffeured ride to the ballpark. Read more

title: Report on Air France Crash Points to Pilot Training
description: PARIS  The co-pilot at the controls of the Air France jet that went down two years ago after leaving Brazil, killing 228, had not been trained to fly the aircraft in manual mode or to promptly recognize and respond to a speed-sensor malfunction at high altitude, according to a detailed analysis by French investigators released Friday.

title: Cut the Deficit  On Your Phone
description: Doubtless all this talk of debt ceilings has many Americans saying the same thing: I cannot get enough! Please, more complex budget analysis!

title: Poland Blames Crew and Controllers for Fatal Crash
description: BERLIN  A Polish government report on Friday blamed the poor training of a Polish flight crew, as well as Russian air traffic controllers, for the 2010 crash in Russia that killed President Lech Kaczynski, his wife and 94 others. The report had the immediate effect of forcing out Polands defense minister, whose office was responsible for training the pilots.

title: Is Better Task Management on Your To-Do List?
description: Like many small-business owners, Keith Goldstein often has so much on his plate that its hard to keep track of it all. So Mr. Goldstein, who owns 60-employee Everest Waterproofing and Restoration in San Francisco, does what most people do to remember what needs to get done: He writes it down on a to-do list. Sometimes he scribbles a list in a notebook, but he prefers to type it into his iPad, whence its zipped by app to his e-mail. I use my inbox as my real to-do list, he said. If a note isnt an action item I move it out of the inbox, so whatever is in there is about something I need to get done.

title: How a Bill Becomes a (Battered) Law
description: The Daily Show With Jon Stewart featured a musical performance on Thursday night by a figure near and dear to DealBooks heart: HR-4173, also known as the Dodd-Frank Act.

title: BSkyB Plans Share Buyback and Higher Dividend
description: 7:51 p.m. | Updated

title: Literacy and the Population Problem
description: The worlds population is expected to pass seven billion in late October. A few weeks ago, I joined my colleague Celia Dugger in writing about worrisome new population projections from the United Nations. Instead of peaking in this century, as previously expected, the new projections suggested that the human population would continue growing all the way into the next century, probably topping out above 10 billion.

title: A Drug for Down Syndrome
description: Early in the evening of June 25, 1995, hours after the birth of his first and only child, the course of Dr. Alberto Costas life and work took an abrupt turn. Still recovering from a traumatic delivery that required an emergency Caesarean section, Costas wife, Daisy, lay in bed, groggy from sedation. Into their dimly lighted room at Methodist Hospital in Houston walked the clinical geneticist. He took Costa aside to deliver some unfortunate news. The baby girl, he said, appeared to have Down syndrome, the most common genetic cause of cognitive disabilities, or what used to be called mental retardation.

title: Sensory Trip to a Paradise on Screen
description: Spectral whales undulate through ethereal mist, their hides speckled with winking gems that pulsate to a throbbing bass line. Gleaming motes of color spin and coalesce into flowers, layer upon layer of shimmering petals. A girl named Lumi, born in outer space and transported to cyberspace, beckons you to rescue her digital consciousness.

title: Libyan Woman Who Claimed Rape Arrives in U.S.
description: After fleeing to Tunisia and then heading for Europe, Eman al-Obeidy, the Libyan woman who said she was brutally raped by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, arrived in the United States this week, CNN reported on Friday.

title: Breast-Feeding Doll Is Coming to America
description: Theres a new doll entering the American toy market called the Breast Milk Baby. In addition to the doll, little girls (and boys) get a halter top that they can wear, with two flowers that symbolize breasts.

title: Drink Up | North Philly Beer, Part 2
description: Here is the second installment of our bar-hopping guide. When it comes to beer in Philadelphia, Anders Larson, a bartender at the groundbreaking Northern Liberties pub 700 Club, puts it best: Its a happy time to be a Philadelphian. You can rarely say that! This installment takes a look at the Fishtown neighborhood.

title: Study Faults Approval Process for Medical Devices
description: The governments system for regulating many medical devices like artificial hips should be abandoned and replaced because it fails to examine their safety and effectiveness before sale, according to a report released Friday by one of the nations top scientific groups.

title: New Data Shows Sharp Slowdown in Growth Rate
description: WASHINGTON  The economy slowed to a snails pace in the first half of 2011, underscoring a growing risk that the recovery itself may hang in the balance with budget and debt decisions in Washington.

title: Stagnation Nation
description: The GDP estimates for second quarter are out, and theyre ugly. Basically, very weak growth for the first half of 2011  indeed, growth well below the economys potential, so were actually losing ground in the effort to reduce the gap between what we should be producing and what were actually producing. This is a recipe for rising, not falling, unemployment.

title: Whiskey, Whiskey Everywhere at Brooklyn Store
description: Whiskey nerds is how George Ruotolo and his brother, Justin, describe themselves. With another partner, Rob Magill, they own bars, including The Whiskey Brooklyn, next to which they have carved out a wee dram of a shop with more than 100 different whiskeys. (They like to say 99 at any given time.) Most are bourbons, ryes and blended whiskeys made in America, often by craft distillers from Brooklyn to Berkeley, Calif.

title: With Verizon Dividend, Any Deal Is Deferred
description: There has been a question hanging over Verizon Wireless for some time as its two owners, Verizon and Vodafone, battled it out to decide the fate of the unit. The answer, it turns out, was worth $10 billion.

description: OLYMPIC NATIONAL PARK, Wash.  Beginning late this summer, one of the most promising and pure acts of environmental restoration the region and the nation have ever seen will get under way here, experts say, in the form of the largest dam removal project in American history.

title: Obama to Speak on Debt Crisis
description: President Obama will deliver a statement about the debt-ceiling fight at 10:20 a.m. at the White House. His appearance will start what is sure to be an eventful day in the partisan showdown over the budget, with the clock ticking toward midnight on Tuesday, when the government will exhaust its ability to pay all its bills without additional borrowing.

title: Opportunity on Madison
description: WHEN word came last spring that the Metropolitan Museum of Art would lease the Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue after the Whitney Museum leaves it for a new downtown home in 2015, the first thing I felt was joy. When I learned that the Met planned to use the building to display its own collection of modern and contemporary art, my instant thought was: Why?

description: After decades of cleanup and the efforts of committed conservationists like Don Riepe, Jamaica Bay is once again a rich sanctuary for shorebirds in New York City.

description: What do you think Congress should do: raise tax revenues, cut programs or just increase the debt ceiling?

description: WASHINGTON  After a 24-hour delay and concessions to conservatives, the House on Friday narrowly approved a Republican fiscal plan that the Senate quickly rejected in a standoff over the federal debt ceiling that was keeping the government on a path to potential default.

description: MOSCOW  An early-morning explosion deep in a coal mine in Ukraine on Friday killed 17 miners and left 9 others missing in a nation where poor maintenance and lax safety regulation make mining a perilous profession.

title: Spain Calls Snap Elections
description: SANTANDER, Spain  Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero said Friday that he would call an early general election for Nov. 20, bowing to pressure from opposition politicians and business leaders after the governing Socialist Party suffered severe losses in regional and municipal elections two months ago.

title: Mark Rylance Gives Away His Tony Award for Jerusalem
description: Folks, this may come as a surprise from a man who, in lieu of giving an acceptance speech at an awards show chose to recite a bit of verse from an obscure poet, but Mark Rylance, it seems, has done something eccentric. Mr. Rylance, who last month won a Tony Award for his portrayal of a hard-living quasi-mystical itinerant man in the Jez Butterworth play Jerusalem, has given away that trophy to a British man who helped inspire his performance.

title: Hawk Cam | Bobby Visits Nest as Pip Explores Union Square
description: Things have been quiet indeed up on the red-tailed hawk nest above Washington Square Park. But on Thursday afternoon at about 2:45, Bobby, father of Pip, came back to do a little ritualistic tidying. John Blakeman, hawk expert and nest watcher, said that the visit means that Bobby has every intention of returning to the nest to breed again.

title: When Shilling on the Web, Think Small
description: Mariah Carey and Barack Obama each had something to sell this week, and they made live videos to do it. Both videos bombed. Ms. Careys pitch on HSN, for tracksuits and other sundries from her fashion label, was too weird. Mr. Obamas pitch on the networks for Congressional compromise wasnt nearly weird enough.

title: Range-Extending Option for Electric BMW i3: a Smart Hedge?
description: On Friday in Frankfurt, BMW showed working prototypes of its i3 electric runabout and i8 plug-in hybrid sports coupe. The carbon-fiber-reinforced concepts were relatively faithful to the renderings that accompanied the launch of the German automakers i subbrand in February. A new wrinkle, however, is the addition of an optional gasoline-burning range extender for the i3, an otherwise purely electric car.

description: Were busy working behind the scenes these days, including helping our Newspaper in Education colleagues with their annual series of teacher workshops (PDF), which this year weve enjoyed presenting out at The New York Times printing plant in Queens. description: President Obama urged deadlocked lawmakers on Friday morning to find a way to resolve their differences and compromise as the clock ticks toward the possibility of a default if the nations debt ceiling is not raised by Tuesday.

description: Abby Goodnough and Marc Lacey visited ideologically divergent districts in Massachusetts and Arizona. They found differing political views but an agreement about the dysfunction of Washington.

description: ISLESBORO, Maine  President Obama on Thursday afternoon nominated Ronnie Abrams, a lawyer at Davis Polk & Wardwell, to serve as a judge in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said he would move ahead on Friday with a Democratic plan to increase the debt limit, saying he could no longer wait for House Republicans to complete their version.

title: How Do You Feel About Medicare?
description: What Americans really think about Medicare: They like it. They dont want to see it significantly changed. But theyre conscious of the federal deficit and willing to consider a number of strategies to reduce the gap, including raising taxes on high earners, spending less on foreign aid and overseas military commitments, and limiting tax deductions for large corporations. Theyre even amenable to certain cost-cutting measures in Medicare itself.

title: Plants, Climate and a Midsummer Festival
description: Laura Fox, a postdoctoral researcher with the University of Pennsylvania, writes from Mongolia, where she is studying the effects of climatic warming on steppe vegetation.

title: On Hudson Pollution, Back to Routine Worries
description: Water tests along the Hudson River show that bacteria levels are falling near the North River Wastewater Treatment Plant in Harlem, which stopped treating sewage for a few days last week because of a fire.

title: Linda Ronstadt Writing a Memoir
description: Linda Ronstadt is joining the music memoir club with her own book, Heart Like a Wheel, said her publisher, Simon & Schuster. The memoir, titled after her hit 1974 album, will focus on her long career, during which she has sold more than 100 million records. Few singers have been as wide-ranging or as distinctive in their artistry, Jonathan Karp, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, said in a statement. Linda Ronstadt has a singular voice, and that is true on the page as well. The book is tentatively scheduled for publication in 2013.

title: Jamaica Bay: Wilderness on the Edge
description: OF all the ways to describe Jamaica Bay  it is the citys largest open space, it is a perch of choice for more than 300 species of birds, it is that wetland thing you fly above while landing at (or leaving) Kennedy Airport  the most suggestive of its singularity is that it sits within the only national park in the United States you can reach by subway.

title: Heart and Soul
description: Susana Baca, the acclaimed singer and soul of Afro-Peruano music, became the first black cabinet minister of independent Peru when she was sworn in as minister of culture on Thursday by the countrys new president, Ollanta Humala. Baca, 67, is revered for mixing Andean and African rhythms and has played a key role in the revival of Afro-Peruano music and dance  folkloric traditions long sidelined in Peru.

title: G.O.P. Fervor Cuts 2 Ways for Boehner
description: WASHINGTON  There is an old Texas saying often applied to politics that you need to dance with the one that brung you. But many of the Tea Party-infused freshmen who helped the Republican Party take control of the House last November are here to polka while their leadership is begging them to waltz.

title: Helen Schulman on her novel, "The Beautiful Life"; how computers reveal the jargon of fiction; best-seller news.
description: This week, Helen Schulman on her new novel, "The Beautiful Life"; the linguist Ben Zimmer explains how computers reveal the jargon of fiction; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: 8,400 Volvo S80 Sedans Recalled for Sudden Loss of Power Assist
description: Volvo is recalling about 8,400 of its S80 sedans from 2007 for possible steering problems.

title: Google Introduces Hotel Search
description: Google on Thursday joined sites like Kayak, Expedia and Hotels.com by introducing a tool for searching hotels.

title: In Court, Lost in Translation
description: The most recent controversy in the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case has exposed an area in the criminal justice system where questions regularly arise: translations.

title: For S.E.C. Interns, Wall Street Is a World Away
description: DealBook recently examined the lives of Wall Street interns, who spend their summers wrangling pitch books and trimming Excel spreadsheets. (And sometimes, blogging surreptitiously.)

title: London Theater Journal: A Wink and a Smirk, but Rarely a Blush
description: LONDON  Women without knickers kept showing up on the stage the other day, in two different theaters. And, honestly, I wasnt hanging out in those hole-in-the-wall clubs in Soho, land of gentlemens entertainments bathed in sad neon light. No, I was in respectable fringe theaters, watching earnest and worthy productions of plays with big themes  which happened to involve women in search of sexual satisfaction removing their underpants and then waiting for something to happen.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Mysteries of Lisbon
description: The critic A. O. Scott narrates a scene from Raoul Ruizs Mysteries of Lisbon, in which the central character is escorted by his mentor to find out who his mother is.

title: The All-American
description: James Traub challenges Senator John Kerrys impression that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is prepared to make real sacrifices for peace by claiming that theres scant evidence that this is so. On the contrary, Netanyahu has demonstrated his commitment to peace in both word and deed. In 2009, he articulated his policy of a Palestinian state side by side with the Jewish state and in a recent speech to Congress, he stated that, in a peace agreement, some settlements will end up beyond Israels borders and that with creativity and goodwill a solution can be found to the Jerusalem issue. He removed hundreds of checkpoints to strengthen the Palestinian economy in the West Bank and implemented an unprecedented 10-month moratorium on new settlement construction. Throughout, he has repeatedly expressed his readiness to negotiate with the Palestinians, without preconditions, to achieve peace.

title: Block Quote
description: Gone from this mid-70s film are the euphoric bams and pows and the psychedelia of the television version; gone are Alfred, Robin, the bat signal and virtually everything that made the kids version so much fun. Indeed, Clint Eastwood makes his leather mask (mixed with his rough, leathery visage) into something akin to a fetish show. The film starts with a scene in a pool hall. Three roughnecks harass a group of women when Batman shows up. They have knives, but this Batman (with no real tricks up his sleeve) is a born brawler. When Batman finally beats the tar out of the three guys, he looks at the women with a vacuous stare. The credits then play over Batman listening to a cop-radio mix with Quincy Joness score. After the opening three against one, youve got the clever standoff fight of the heavyweight-boxer type against Batman; the 40-against-one standoff in the alleyway; the marksmen fight with its constant zoom-ins; and the raid on Jokers palace. Had Peckinpah directed these last two sequences (and not, as has been credited, Eastwood, with an assist from Hal Needham), it might be one of the greatest films Peckinpah ever directed. Still, when people ask me whats my favorite superhero film, I usually point to this one. Or Ang Lees Hulk.

title: Jon Favreau, From Swingers to Aliens
description: The new film youve directed, Cowboys and Aliens, has a pretty absurd name. The Times even reported last year that when people saw the trailer, theyd laugh, thinking it was a parody. Did you ever consider renaming it?

title: Geekdom Revisited
description: In junior high school, I was bullied. A boy named Dominick made fun of my appearance until I could barely look at myself in the mirror. He and his friends snapped my training bra in the hallway. They heard I made out with a boy after a school dance and started calling me a slut. I had stomachaches in the morning and cried myself to sleep at night.

title: Theres No I in Tea Party
description: I wasnt even a page into this article before it dawned on me that you revealed the crux of the problem in Washington (where I now live). Note that Kevin McCarthy rides bikes with Republicans, meets all morning with Republicans, dines with Republicans: its like existing in an endless loop of self-congratulatory, self-assured (some would say arrogant) self-talk. How are these people ever to know what anyone else is thinking if all they do is meet with each other?

title: Miranda July Is Totally Not Kidding
description: Miranda July is dark, dark, dark. I hate earnestness, and I am often allergic to sincerity, but if thats all you see in her work, youre missing the point. The cutesiness and humor are there to counterbalance the terror and anxiety of everyday life; the former gives you a little relief while you gird yourself for the latter.

title: Money Cometh to Me Now!
description: Travis Cross, a 43-year-old unemployed hairdresser, was among the 200 or so people, most of them black and sharply dressed, filling the pews of Mount Pleasant Baptist Church in Norfolk, Va., late last month. They had come to see visiting preacher Dr. Leroy Thompson  the man of God, himself, Cross called him  hold his Money Cometh to You conference, which promises that the Lord can solve even the worst financial problems. It was a message the congregation desperately wanted to hear; some of the bordering neighborhoods have unemployment rates over 15 percent.

title: Armchair Ethicist
description: Have a strong opinion? Discuss this letter with the Ethicist at nytimes.com/6thfloor on Tuesday, Aug. 2, between 1 and 5 p.m., E.S.T.

title: The Prescription to Save Ailing Superheroes
description: Its probably not a good sign for the superhero genre as a whole that the most talked-about comic-book movies of summer 2011 are the ones due out in 2012. But its not even August, and the conversation in superhero-nerdspace is all about leaked trailers for The Dark Knight Rises and The Avengers, both scheduled to be released next year, or about how Andrew Garfield, that kid from The Social Network, looks in his Spider-Man suit.

title: A Mild-Mannered Maniac
description: In the small bookstore of the Cinmathque Franaise in Paris, a wall of shelves is devoted to works by and about the great auteurs  monographs, coffee-table tomes, DVDs. The pantheon of world cinema is too large for the available space, so the masters are arrayed in double rows, one behind the other. In order to browse, you must dig and rearrange, and on a recent visit, I felt a bit like a cinephile-archaeologist or a monomaniacal archivist as I burrowed past Ozu and Pasolini and displaced a row of Scorsese, making my determined way to Raoul Ruiz. I unearthed a small cache of movies directed by this Chilean-born filmmaker, who has made his home in Paris since the mid-1970s. I also found a book of interviews from the 1980s and another, Potique du Cinma, based on lectures he gave, mostly at American universities, over the years. The title of one lecture is Cinema as Clandestine Voyage, which might describe a curious viewers sometimes baffling but frequently enchanting journey through Ruizs films.

title: Duty Calls
description: Ive been called for jury duty, and Im shocked by the lies that other prospective jurors tell to get themselves disqualified. I know thats not fair; everyone deserves his day in court. But its not fair to me that because of their lies Im more likely to suffer the inconvenience of a long trial. May I tell the lawyers things about myself that are perfectly true but which Im mentioning only to get out of the jury box and back to my job? DAVID S., NEW YORK

title: Merck Plans More Job Cuts
description: Merck will cut about 13,000 jobs by the end of 2015, in addition to the 20,000 jobs it has shed since a merger in 2009, the pharmaceutical company announced Friday in its quarterly earnings report.

title: Impressed by Weeds
description: To Britains train spotters, bird-watching twitchers and upper-class twits, let us now add the weed geek. Not so long ago, youd find them of a weekend on coach tours of East London refuse tips (a k a landfills). You could listen for their whistles when they chanced upon a choice specimen, and watch as they gathered to photograph the plant and debate its identity. If you looked carefully among the participants, youd espy Britains foremost nature writer, Richard Mabey, the author, most recently, of Weeds: In Defense of Natures Most Unloved Plants.

title: Nicholas Ray Archives Find a Home in Texas
description: Nicholas Ray, the director of the 1955 film classic Rebel Without a Cause, was pretty much banished from Hollywood in the early 1960s as a result of his drug and alcohol addictions, and volatile temper. But his early work influenced a generation of filmmakers. Now his voluminous archives have been bought from his widow, Susan Ray, by the Harry Ransom Center, a humanities research library and museum at the University of Texas at Austin.

description: Superfund designation halted large-scale construction around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. But as small businesses and artists move in, there has been a different kind of development.

title: Why We Deregulated the Banks
description: Seven years ago, James Mann published Rise of the Vulcans, a history of the neoconservative foreign-policy advisers who rose to prominence with the presidency of George W. Bush. Mann traced the groups origins to the 1970s, when figures like Dick Cheney and Donald Rumsfeld got their start in government, and told how events from East Asia to Kuwait solidified their faith in American assertiveness abroad. Of course, Mann was writing against the backdrop of the Iraq invasion. The belief system he chronicled had culminated in overreach.

description: New York has played many roles on television recently.

title: The Truth About Federal Spending
description: Whenever someone like me or Bruce Bartlett points out how little Obama resembles the rights portrait of a raging leftist, someone is sure to come back with the assertion that Obama has presided over a vast expansion of federal spending. Even people who really should know better, like John Taylor, do it.

title: Top Generals Quit in Group, Stunning Turks
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys top military commanders resigned en masse on Friday, a move without precedent in Turkish history that many analysts saw as a failed effort by a beleaguered institution to exert what is left of its dwindling political power.

title: How Sweet It Is: $27 Million in Fees for Dunkins Underwriters
description: Earlier this week, Dunkin Brands made its stock market debut with a blockbuster public offering, with shares soaring 46.6 percent on the first day of trading.

title: A Dutch Factory Town, Now a Design Center
description: SOMETIMES the most sublime and unusual enterprises can grow out of the grimmest of circumstances. In the late 1970s and 80s, Philips, the multinational company best known for electronics, which had been based in the small city of Eindhoven in southern Holland since its founding in the 1890s, started to farm out its production to Asia. Not only were hundreds of skilled professionals out of work, but the city was also left with several abandoned and polluted factory complexes just a few minutes from the city center.

title: A Fresh Face for U.S. Soccer
description: After courting him twice without success, the United States Soccer Federation on Friday hired Jrgen Klinsmann to coach and revive a seemingly stale mens national team.

title: A Neighborhood for Man and Dog
description: NEARLY three years ago, when Richard Rethemeyer moved to New York from San Francisco, he paid $1.16 million for 1,400 lovely square feet in the ClockTower, at 1 Main Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn. The plan was for his girlfriend to join him there.

title: Paddock Notes from Budapest, Good, Bad and Indifferent
description: BUDAPEST  Somehow the rain stayed away from the Hungaroring on Friday, but there were some wet tears here and there with some of the news items floating around the paddock.

title: Paddock Notes from Budapest, Good, Bad and Indifferent
description: BUDAPEST  Somehow the rain stayed away from the Hungaroring on Friday, but there were some wet tears here and there with some of the news items floating around the paddock.

title: The Caucus | Debt Fight Down to the Wire
description: July 29, 2011 - Jennifer Steinhauer reports on the back and forth in Washington. Also, voices from voters in Massachusetts and Arizona.

title: Tuning in to Nostalgia (and Even Videos) on MTV
description: First, lets put to rest a common misunderstanding: yes, MTV still plays music videos. Honest. Watch in the early morning for an hour or two under the AMTV tag  Ive seen them only when awake for a doctors appointment or, more likely, up late for an overnight deadline, but theyre there, you naysayers.

title: Summer Tomatoes: Stuffed, Sweet and Souped Up
description: Few foods are as versatile as the tomato, as Martha Rose Shulman demonstrates in this weeks Recipes for Health. She offers tomatoes that are Sicilian and stuffed, slow roasted, sweet and sour, souped up or succulent in salad.

title: Latest Out of Tailpipes: Electricity With Exhaust
description: EVEN the most efficient of modern cars has a wasteful streak: only about a quarter of the energy contained in the fuel the engine burns is converted to motion. Much of the lost energy flows out of the tailpipe in the form of hot exhaust gases, researchers at General Motors say.

title: Europes Incentive Plans for Spurring E.V. Sales
description: EUROPEAN governments are reaching deep into their pockets and plumbing the depths of their imaginations to get electric vehicles out of showrooms and onto the highway. Though the goals of the individual countries are mostly similar  carbon-free fleets in pollution-free cities  many different approaches to making it happen are in place.

title: Original Model T's
description: No. 2 in a series of commissioned artworks.

title: Original Model T's
description: No. 2 in a series of commissioned artworks.

title: The Fine Art of Dwarf Fortress
description: Last Sunday the magazine published a story about two brothers and their creation of the computer game Dwarf Fortress. The story presented a visual challenge  a photograph of Tarn and Zach Adams working on computers seemed like an unsatisfactory option. Instead, we had the idea of creating portraits of Tarn and Zach Adams from the ASCII characters and 16 colors (seen below) that are the building blocks of their game. So we contacted Tarn to see if he would help us with this. What ensued sort of blew our minds.

title: Reviving a Habitat
description: The largest dam removal project in American history will take away barriers that have contained the Elwha River in Washington State for nearly a century.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE LONGEST WAR: The Enduring Conflict Between America and Al-Qaeda,  by Peter L. Bergen (Free Press, $16.) Bergen, a national security analyst for CNN and the author of two previous books about Osama bin Laden, covers the global sweep of the last 10 years  the Sept. 11 attacks, the invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq, Americas relationship with Pakistan and the death of Bin Laden  and provides an intimate look at Al Qaedas history and motives.

title: Amazon.com Moves Closer to Acquiring a Major British Rival
description: Amazon.com, which has an estimated 70 percent of the online book market in Britain, got closer this week to controlling the rest of it when the Irish Competition Authority approved its pending purchase of a major rival, the Book Depository. But the blessing of the main regulatory body, the Office of Fair Trading, is no sure thing in a country that appears to be more concerned about media monopoly in the wake of the News Corporation hacking scandal.

title: In Sapphires New Novel, Life Without Precious
description: Fifteen years after the heralded publication of her first novel, Push  the basis for the 2009 film Precious  Sapphire has written a new novel, The Kid, which traces the life of Precious second child, Abdul. At its best, The Kid captures the grueling heartbreak of trying to love anything when the world doesnt love you enough, of trying to summon desire or affection in the absence of any healthy context for either one.

title: Inside the List
description: NAMING NAMES: The cover of Laura Ingrahams latest best seller, Of Thee I Zing: Americas Cultural Decline From Muffin Tops to Body Shots, shows the conservative firebrand dressed up like George Washington crossing the Delaware.

title: Master of the Gilded Age Congress
description: Every serious student of Congress is familiar with Thomas B. Reed, a dominant speaker of the House near the end of the 19th century who was known as a czar for his use of the House rules to achieve the goals of his Republican majority. He was the precursor of the much more authoritarian Uncle Joe Cannon, whose ham-handed exercise of power led to the storied 1910 revolt that created the seniority system in Congress. It was Reed who transformed the speakership for the 20th century, but to most Americans, he is at best a dim figure from history, perhaps a candidate for a particularly tough question on Jeopardy!

title: Being German in 1945
description: The story of the denazification of Germany after 1945 comes in two versions. The one we know best allows us to congratulate ourselves on a job well done. We turned the most powerful and frightening dictatorship in Europe into a stable, peaceable and functioning democracy for the first time in its history. This is the story we grew up with during the cold war, one that justified the partition and occupation of the country over many decades. And the invasion of Iraq in 2003 made it seem relevant in an entirely new way. It stood as a salutary contrast with the sheer superficiality and short-sightedness of the Bush administrations approach to military occupation.

title: A Novel of Dark Sexual Obsession
description: The allure of destructive relationships is complicated. We dont like them when they happen to us (or maybe sometimes we do), but we love reading or talking about them. Its the drama, the guaranteed narrative arc. We know they almost always end badly, but the details are so irresistible: She did what? Again? What was she thinking? Why would anyone go back after the deadbeat took her car, ate all her bacon and gave his 12-year-old the keys to her apartment without telling her he had a 12-year-old? Thats crazy. Tell me more!

title: Caucus Video: Debt Fight Down to the Wire
description: Jennifer Steinhauer reports on the back and forth in Washington on the debt ceiling. Also, voices of voters in Massachusetts and Arizona.

title: A Scrappy Slum Urchin Goes to Sea
description: In his Lectures on Literature, Vladimir Nabokov suggests that for The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, Robert Louis Stevenson borrowed his fog . . . from a Dickensian studio to envelop a conventional London. The British writer Carol Birch similarly borrows elements of Dickenss London for Jamrachs Menagerie, her 11th novel and her first to be published in the United States.

title: The Age of Anti-Serious Seriousness
description: Like most critics, Lee Siegel is sometimes right. Unlike most critics, he is always abrasive, even when the reader happens to agree with him. A writers inexhaustible readiness to vex his audience requires some fortitude, and Siegel is nothing if not energetic. In essays on many subjects involving art, literature, the Internet, politics, film and television, he presents himself as a gadfly whose assiduous pursuit of the truth must inevitably cost him some friends. I am not what you would call a nice critic, Siegel wrote in The Guardian of London in 2008. Fair enough. So exactly what kind of critic is he?

title: The Pitfalls and Pleasures of the Current Realist Novel
description: Lately the realist novels been getting realistic. Originally developed in response to a highfalutin form gone stale, realism has a long and glorious tradition of extraordinary yarns about ordinary people. But the name realism was never quite right. Authors as disparate as Mark Twain, mile Zola and Edith Wharton are called realists, which would be fitting if you spent your adolescence drifting down the Mississippi, worked out your love problems by drowning your rival and attempted suicide by sled.

title: Know Thyself: Easier Said Than Done
description: A few days before a review of my latest book appeared in these pages, I wrote to my editor, saying I had seen an advance copy and how much I liked the color illustration of the yellow moon. He replied that I must be mistaken, since the Book Review doesnt use color. The next weekend he wrote to say he couldnt think what had come over him  he reads the Book Review every week, and had somehow not noticed the color. Odd. And yet these lapses can happen to the best of us. Ask yourself what the Roman number four on the face of the church clock looks like. Most people will answer it looks like IV, but almost certainly the truth is it looks like IIII.

title: The Jargon of the Novel, Computed
description: We like to think that modern fiction, particularly American fiction, is free from the artificial stylistic pretensions of the past. Richard Bridgman expressed a common view in his 1966 book The Colloquial Style in America. Whereas in the 19th century a very real distinction could be made between the vernacular and standard diction as they were used in prose, Bridgman wrote, in the 20th century the vernacular had virtually become standard. Thanks to such pioneers as Mark Twain, Stephen Crane, Gertrude Stein and Ernest Hemingway, the story goes, ornate classicism was replaced by a straight-talking vox populi.

title: Editors Choice
description: AN ANATOMY OF ADDICTION: Sigmund Freud, William Halsted, and the Miracle Drug Cocaine,  by Howard Markel (Pantheon, $28.95.) An absorbing and well-documented account of the ways cocaine affected the careers of two clinical pathbreakers.

title: Sex, Lies and Data Mining
description: The concentrated essence of this curious book is contained in its 11th chapter, which attempts to explain what the Mona Lisa has in common with Chicken McNuggets, vampire novels and the concluding scene of most pornographic videos. Each of these works of human creativity, Ogi Ogas and Sai Gaddam write in A Billion Wicked Thoughts, exploits perceptual trickery to arouse and gratify our desires. The enigma of the Gioconda smile; the technologically engineered craveability of fast food; the alluring, alpha among alphas quality of the paranormal hero; that climactic moment beamed to watchers on a hundred million laptop screens: all rely on the artful manipulation of our brains.

title: The Role of Government Spending
description: As Congress continues to wrangle over a debt reduction bill that will inevitably cut government spending, Fridays estimates of second-quarter gross domestic product provided a sobering look at how a decline in public spending and investment can restrain growth.

title: Vietnamese Grilled Duck Salad With Cucumber, Radishes and Peanuts
description: Time: 40 minutes plus at least 90 minutes marinating

title: Duck Fat for Later, a Salad for Now
description: WHEN I cook duck, its just as often for the rendered fat as it is for the meat. As much as I love the gamy, sweet flesh, its the fat that I really crave. I keep a jar of the heady stuff in the fridge, pulling it out when I want to saut fish or potatoes or kale, or pop a vat of popcorn. I use it to make pie crusts and biscuits, and to fry chicken. When my supplies run low, I simply cook up some more duck to replenish it.

title: Democrats Threaten Saturday Night Debt Fever
description: Get ready for Mr. Smith meets the debt ceiling.

title: Obama and Bush to Visit New York for 9/11 Anniversary
description: The 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks will be a grand but subdued affair in New York City that will involve two presidents, poetry readings and visits by victims family members to the new memorial, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday.

title: Hollywood East
description: Major television shows and feature films find benefits to shooting in Queens.

title: Sandwiches Take a Turn With Tomatoes
description: OLD Mr. Brown, a man I knew in Oakland, Calif., never ate anything but sandwiches. Ask him to a meal, pass the breadbasket. He put everything, from soup to nuts, between two slices. Evidently it was a lifelong obsession.

title: Killers of Libyan Rebel General Were Among His Own Forces
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The leadership of the Libyan rebels acknowledged late Friday that a group of their own soldiers had killed their top military commander, contradicting statements made a day earlier as the rebels scrambled to avoid tribal revenge attacks that could divide their ranks.

title: Genworth Plans for Possible Split
description: Shares of Genworth Financial rose on Friday after its chief executive said that the insurance company was getting prepared to split off its mortgage insurance business.

title: Little More Than Great Tomatoes and Bread
description: Good tomatoes are in, finally. Real, farm-grown meaty tomatoes, like classic Beefsteak and Brandywine and Lemon Boy, and sweet cherry tomatoes of different colors. So a fine tomato salad comes to mind, but what about a sandwich? Not a BLT; not tomato, avocado and sprouts. Rather, a Mediterranean sandwich of tomatoes with capers, anchovy and basil, piled into a freshly baked roll. A little bit soggy, completely heavenly. And no need to turn on the oven. Read about it, along with a few other sandwich reveries, in this weeks City Kitchen.

title: The Prius V: A Hybrid That Hauls More Stuff
description: TESTED 2012 Prius V (though Toyota, which seems to have a shortage of capital letters, prefers v).

title: Living in Midland Beach, S.I.
description: Small one-story bungalows built decades ago, and two-story brick semidetached homes or town houses built more recently, sit side by side in this Staten Island neighborhood.

title: Germany Goes Electric
description: With the battery-powered i3 compact and i8 plug-in hybrid sport coupe, BMW is making an ambitious venture into electric-car development.

title: Economic Growth: Worse Than We Thought
description: The good news six months ago was that the United States economy, as measured by gross domestic product, had completely recovered all the losses it suffered in the recession.

title: Wall St., Prepared for the Worst, in Wait-and-See Mode
description: Wall Street executives and traders will spend the weekend holding their breath as the debt impasse continues to suck all the oxygen from the room.

title: Low Prices, Slow Traffic, Copious Sand
description: WHEN Lina Shuster takes portraits of clients for her photography business, she often uses the beach as a backdrop. Luckily for her, that means going just a few blocks from home.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Haunted Real Estate (and Hero)
description: The hardcover list has three new books this week. At No. 1 is Volume 4 of Locke and Key, by Joe Hill and Gabriel Rodriguez, about Keyhouse, a family estate in New England whose doors transform anyone who walks through them. The Lockes are the family in question and they must navigate various crises while learning about the mansion and the various keys. The writer is the son of Stephen King, who knows a bit about New England suspense. The series began in 2008 and has completed four six-issue storylines so far. The current series, Clockworks, began this month.

title: In Battle for Patents, Google Buys a Batch From I.B.M.
description: In the heated battle for technology patents, Google is using its checkbook to bulk up.

title: Islamists Flood Square in Cairo in Show of Strength
description: CAIRO  Tens of thousands of Egyptian Islamists poured into Tahrir Square on Friday calling for a state bound by strict religious law and delivering a persuasive show of force in a turbulent country showing deep divisions and growing signs of polarization.

title: Bomb Hits Syrian Pipeline as Protests Continue
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government said Friday that an oil pipeline had been hit by a bomb in what the authorities called a terrorist attack, as the countrys uprising continued with the Friday protests that have become a ritual there. Security forces killed nine people at the demonstrations, protesters and activists said.

title: Project Runway Returns
description: Let the squabbling begin.

title: Owning a Ranch Offers Returns Beyond the Financial
description: AMONG the fantasies that keep many of us going on dreary days, owning a vast ranch out West would surely rank up there, along with living on a beach or gazing out over your vineyard at night.

title: Cars and Fuel: What Constructive Compromise Looks Like
description: Environmentalists, politicians, corporate and union lobbyists and the auto industry have been embroiled for months in hashing out the details for cutting the fuel use and emissions of American cars and light trucks through 2025, and the result was on display in Washington today.

title: Big Deal | An S. Klein Sale Item
description: In the summer of 1909, a year after the giant house on Westerleigh Road in Purchase, N.Y., was built, it was described by The New York Times as one of the finest country mansions in Westchester County.

title: Moving a Special Needs Child to China
description: Having a family means constructing an equation. Every choice, each conclusion, means shuffling all the factors, deciding how much weight to give to each.

title: Giants Restructure Jacobss Contract
description: The Giants and running back Brandon Jacobs have agreed to a restructured contract that will provide the team with much-needed relief under the salary cap.

title: U.S. Soccer Gets Its Man: Klinsmann Hired
description: After a long courtship, Jrgen Klinsmann was named coach of the United States national team on Friday. He will be introduced at a news conference on Monday, and will coach his first game against Mexico on Aug. 10 in Philadelphia. Read Jer Longmans article here, and come back to comment.

title: Revved-Up Cinema
description: A look at the custom work that went into the making of the film Bellflower.

title: 2007 Letter Clearing a Tabloid Comes Under Scrutiny
description: LONDON  When a Parliamentary committee first confronted The News of the World with charges of phone hacking in 2007, the papers owners produced a reassuring, one-paragraph letter from a prominent London law firm named Harbottle & Lewis.

title: Options for Self-Publishing Proliferate, Easing the Bar to Entry
description: IM a snob. Oh, I dont particularly care what kind of car you drive or if you wear the latest designer fashions, but until recently I turned up my nose at authors who published their own books.

title: Build the Apocalypse Inside Your Garage
description: THE indie drama Bellflower, opening Friday, charts a familiar tale, the blossoming and deterioration of a romance. But the way the story is told is far from conventional. This might be the first relationship tale that begins with cricket eating and involves a bleach-squirting muscle car and a homemade flamethrower.

title: The Jam | Erick Swenson
description: The Texas installation artist Erick Swenson is known for turning heads with his portrayals of hybrid creatures that look hauntingly real. His 2004 Whitney Biennial contribution showcased an animal with a fawnlike body, ears of a rabbit and a nose of a dog, frozen in a dramatic stance over what appears to be a woven rug (but is actually hand-painted fiberglass). He once created a half-eaten carcass of a killer whale and laid it across a monstrous crumpled-up ice floe  a piece so well done, critics said, it could be a natural history museum display. So how does Swenson fit in here with our downtown playlist, brought to you by Sean Hanratty? Hanratty chose Swenson for The Jams fifth installment not only because of their shared Texan roots but also because, he says, Ive always been so intrigued with the sort of fantastical nature of his work and materials. I knew his playlist would contain a lot of classic songs with a very strong backbone.

title: 2 More Deaths Attributed to Heat
description: Two additional deaths were attributed to the heat on July 23, the city medical examiners office said on Friday, bringing the heat-related death toll for the day, when the temperature reached 100 degrees, to four.

title: Recipes for Summer Tomatoes
description: A variety of ways to use tomatoes at the height of the season.

title: Restaurant Report: Delancey, in Seattle
description: On a quiet street in the Ballard neighborhood of Seattle sits a cozy little restaurant on the verge of being thrust into a rather public life.

title: Letters: Planning the Perfect Vacation
description: To the Editor: The headline says it all: Planning the Perfect Vacation (Practical Traveler, July 24.) Two words that should never come between you and a little R&R are planning and perfect. If they are still part of your modus operandi, you are not there yet.

title: North Fork Dining Catches Up
description: THE North Fork of Long Island has developed a reputation for its wineries. Just as the vineyards of Napa and Sonoma led to the emergence of a vibrant dining scene, a growing number of chefs with impressive pedigrees  including some with Long Island roots  are opening their own restaurants on the North Fork to feed the winery-hopping crowds.

title: Hotel Review: La Maison Blanche on Shelter Island, N.Y.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Dalston in East London Welcomes New Arrivals
description: A traditionally Jewish area in East London morphs into a multiethnic working-class enclave.

title: Montanas Fading Glaciers
description: Glacier National Parks skein of well-maintained trails traverses every section of its million-plus acres and can accommodate any level of ability.

title: Casa Lever Spreads Out to Its Park Avenue Terrace
description: Casa Lever is opening an outdoor bar, lounge and restaurant in the public courtyard that wraps the lobby of Lever House, its home. This elaborate seasonal addition, which will open on Wednesday, if not earlier, will double the restaurants capacity.

title: Automakers React to 54.5 M.P.G.
description: After months of hand-wringing by industry lobbies and environmental groups, President Obama announced the new round of Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards, known as CAFE, on Friday in Washington. The standards call for a 5 percent annual increase in fuel economy for passenger cars from 2017 to 2025, culminating in a mandated 54.5 miles per gallon.

title: Tension Rises as Islamists Dominate Tahrir Square
description: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, tens of thousands of Egyptians poured into Tahrir Square on Friday for a day that had been billed as one of unified protest against the interim military government. But the turnout was lopsided, dominated by members of religious movements, ranging from the most conservative, the Salafists, to the relatively moderate Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Indulging a Fantasy
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about what for some is the ultimate fantasy: owning a ranch out West. He says that owning a ranch, and selling the products raised on it, has lately emerged as an alternative investment class. But he quickly adds that the investment is only for the wealthy who are not looking for a quick return.

title: Red Tails, Lucass Tuskegee Airmen Movie, Lands a Release Date
description: It was a long time ago  1994, to be precise  when George Lucas produced his last film that was not connected to his Indiana Jones or Star Wars fantasy franchises. Now his long-in-the-works film about the fighting men of a very different war finally has a release date: on Friday, Lucasfilm said that Red Tails, a film about the Tuskegee Airmen, the all-black pilot group that fought in World War II, would be released on Jan. 20. The film is directed by Anthony Hemingway, who has directed for television series including Treme, True Blood and CSI: NY, and its ensemble cast features Cuba Gooding Jr., Terrence Howard and Bryan Cranston, as well as Tristan Wilds (of The Wire and 90210), Cliff Smith (better known as the rapper Method Man), Ne-Yo and Elijah Kelley.

title: European Soccer Clubs Challenging FIFA
description: PARIS  Long disgruntled European soccer clubs are mounting a muscular new challenge to FIFA, the international soccer federation, by pressing a dispute over finances and decision-making into the political arena, where the powerful body will face scrutiny of its management.

title: A Vines Acoustics Send a Bat Signal
description: Flowers attract bees and birds with their colors and scents. Now, a new study reports that a rain forest vine in Cuba attracts nectar-feeding bats with sound.

title: Wall Street Wives Finds a Cast
description: Wall Street Wives is one step closer to the small screen.

title: Madoff Trustees Job Just Became Much Tougher
description: Shannon Stapleton/ReutersIrving H. Picard, the court-appointed trustee in the Madoff fraud case.

title: Nibblers Affect Climate Tales That Tree Rings Tell
description: For more than 100 years, tree rings have served as a reliable way to estimate past climate conditions because in warmer years, which usually mean better growing conditions, tree rings tend to be wider. But herbivores that nibble away at trees also have an effect on tree ring size  a phenomenon that was known but never measured. Now, researchers from Norway and Scotland report the significant effect of grazing sheep on tree ring size over a nine-year period.

title: Heidi Klum and Tim Gunn Make It Work on Runway
description: The fashion guru Tim Gunn and the model Heidi Klum made a not quite triumphant but still satisfactory return to New York City as Project Runway had its Season 9 premiere on Lifetime on Thursday night. The fashion designer competition averaged 2.7 million total viewers according to Nielsen, making small gains over the premiere from last season. It was certainly an eventful episode, as four of the twenty contestants were eliminated by the 20-minute mark.

title: Exposing Literary Style, One Word at a Time
description: In this weeks Mechanic Muse column for the Book Review, I look at how vast new databases and techniques can help scholars of the digital humanities zero in on the nitty-gritty of literary style, right down to the level of individual words. An exciting development over the past few years is that many of the tools that scholars use to plumb the depths of literary usage are now publicly available online. These resources arent locked up in an ivory tower, accessible only to an elite band of researchers. Call it the democratization of digital scholarship.

title: On the Street | Sizzling
description: The fashion star of the recent heat wave was the shirt, in its many styles.

title: Lawyers, Coins, and Money
description: So if something does pass the House, it will demand a constitutional balanced-budget amendment as the price of a second vote next year. I think we can safely say that the political process has failed. Now what?

title: This Sunday: Where Would You Like to Go?
description: A pleasure of making this magazine (and, I hope, reading it) is the wide range of places we get to cover. Its one factor that we take into account as we put together an issue  how many different corners of the world can we pack into our pages? Heres where our writers take us this week:

title: A Citys Hard Edges, Softened by Joy
description: Is there a creature as imaginative or as indefatigable as the city child in search of a place to play? New York would seem to have been designed for everything but youthful frolic. And, to be sure, it can hold great perils. Yet from generation to generation  ever since the kids sang Ring Around the Rosie and London Bridge Is Falling Down  the sidewalks of New York have yielded to youngsters inexhaustible need to frisk, exult, screech, plot and plunge.

title: Twilight of the Glaciers
description: AN hour or so up ahead, at the higher elevations along the trail that leads over Siyeh Pass, huckleberries were ripening. Even a dawdling day hiker like me knows that huckleberries can quickly mean grizzlies in Glacier National Park. I indulged a nervous tic and patted around for the loud red aerosol can on my belt, whose label reads Counter Assault. Its effective as a bear repellent, but even more reliable at making an urbanite feel faintly ridiculous.

title: In Europe, Five Libraries That Offer Respite From the Crowds
description: EUROPEAN cities are feet-on-the-pavement destinations, where many of us find ourselves trudging along familiar routes with hordes of tourists just like us. To take a break, we are likely to stop at the cafes and museum gardens already overcrowded with fellow travelers.

title: To Japan or Not? Travelers Weigh Risks With Bargains
description: THE earthquake and tsunami that hit northeastern Japan on March 11, and the nuclear crisis that followed, have had an impact on nearly every corner of the economy, perhaps none more directly than the tourist industry. The number of foreign visitors has plunged 50 percent since the triple disasters, according to the Japan National Tourism Organization.

title: TimesCast | July 29, 2011
description: The House prepares to vote on Speaker John A. Boehner's modified plan to raise debt ceiling, and new data show that the United States' economic growth has slowed considerably since last year.

title: Big Deal | Sold for $30.55 million
description: A penthouse at the Time Warner Center that closed for $30.55 million was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

title: Ruling Upholds Gene Patent in Cancer Test
description: In a closely watched case, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday that genes can be patented, overturning a lower court decision that had shocked the biotechnology industry.

title: Pasta With Anchovies and Arugula
description: Mark Bittman more than triples the greens in a punchy pasta recipe from the Minimalist archives.

title: Tip of the Week: Shortcuts into Offices Ribbon
description: Hate having to grab the mouse to navigate the Ribbon in Microsoft Office? The KeyTips feature, built into all the programs in the Office 2010 and Office 2007 suites, lets you jump into Ribbon menus with just a few keystrokes so you can leave the mouse on its pad.

title: Audrey Saunders and Robert Hess
description: THE couples first face-to-face meeting in 2002 took place exactly where it should have  at a bar.

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: Did Niagara Falls host the first same-sex wedding in New York State? Hard to say.

title: Charting Wu Lyf at the Knitting Factory
description: Wu Lyf is an indie rock band from Manchester, England, known for its churchy anthems and its secretive, anonymous air. (The bands name supposedly stands for World Unite/Lucifer Youth Foundation and is pronounced woo life.) The band recently released its debut album, Go Tell Fire to the Mountain (L Y F Recordings) and performed at the Knitting Factory in Brooklyn. The artist Andrew Kuo breaks the show down.

title: Chic in Review | Americas Biggest Top Model
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Finding Poetry in a Couples Pain
description: ROME

title: Polar Bear Science and the Spin Cycle
description: [Oct. 2, 2012, 1:23 p.m. | Updated | Charles Monnett, the federal biologist at the heart of the investigation described below, has been cleared of scientific misconduct over his polar bear surveys (report link), but his case remains a source of disputes at several levels  as described in detail by Jill Burke in Alaska Dispatch. Theres more from Natures news blog. Media Matters (repost at Climate Progress) is pressing Fox News, which promised to follow the investigation after hyping it, to report the results.]

title: Striking Out the Side, and Then Some
description: Ron Montgomery leaned close to his computer in Williamsburg, Va., on July 1 as a radio play-by-play man 600 miles away described the most unforgettable inning of his sons life.

title: The New York Film Festival Brings Carnage to Opening Night
description: The New York Film Festival has announced its opening-night selection, but its director is not likely to walk the red carpet.

title: Pictures of the Day: Norway and Elsewhere

title: Some Death, Some Struggle, Some Strain, Yet So Much Still Is Joyful
description: No choreographer alive is more bewildering than Mark Morris. Much of his work is strikingly cerebral and schematic, and yet its main effect tends to be the direct opposite. His dancers exude a visceral urgency, an innocent charm and a you could do this too simplicity of style that turn the connection between them and the audience into a bond of love and recognition. On one level, his dances are all about the raw stuff of dance itself. On another, they plainly have much to say. They are about the multiple layers of their music, and yet, in terms of timing, imagery and structure, their fit to the score is frequently  deliberately  disconcerting.

Presumably, so have their listeners, some of whom are closing in on 50. But they dont have much else in common, and thats partly why their collaboration on Thursday at PNC Bank Arts Center here  repeated on Friday at Jones Beach  felt like a bright idea.

title: Danes Deliver Rare Works by a Native Son

To put that date into perspective, the institution was founded 100 years before the Dresden Staatskapelle, often cited as one of the worlds oldest orchestras; 435 years before the Norwegian composer Johan Svendsen inaugurated the Danish orchestras symphonic concert series; and 441 years before the Danish composer Carl Nielsen took his position among its second violins.
