title: Senate Tables Boehner Bill
description: The United States Senate quickly dispatched the debt ceiling bill passed by the House Friday evening, tabling the Republican bill indefinitely and moving quickly to start consideration of a Democratic plan that would avoid default on Tuesday.

title: Partners Push a Tap Wine Manifesto
description: WARNING: Wine Not Beer, reads the disclaimer on the draft handle behind the bar at Terroir Tribeca, a wine bar on Harrison Street in Manhattan. Youll find the same thing at the restaurants Buttermilk Channel and Colicchio & Sons, where the taps dispense red, white and ros, all from a keg-wine company known as the Gotham Project.

title: The Courage to Testify, but No Desire to Elaborate
description: The boy is 13 now, whip-thin and taller than he was two years ago, but after what happened then, not as quick. He opened the door of his familys 14th-floor apartment in a Bronx project on Thursday morning and said no, he could not talk right now, because his parents were not home.

title: The Southern Cross
description: Confederate Gen. G.T. Beauregard was worried. It was the afternoon of July 21, 1861, and fighting had raged since daylight after General Irwin McDowells Union army attacked Beauregard from across the small Virginia stream known as Bull Run. The battle seesawed throughout the day, but fresh troops rushed in from the Shenandoah Valley had finally given Beauregard the advantage. Now, just as victory seemed certain, he spied a heavy column of troops more than a mile away maneuvering on his flank.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. The liner notes for one of my albums mentions a Black Swan Records in New York. It sounds interesting. Could you tell me about the company?

title: Yogi Guardians, on a Healing Mission
description: ANA FORREST is an itinerant yoga teacher riding the circuit, selling out workshops in South Africa and conducting training sessions in Houston. She is to Yoga Journal as Angelina Jolie is to Us magazine: a mainstay.

title: A Huge Star Was Stuck Outside, Stamping Her Feet
description: No one could ignore the elephant in the room, or rather at the corner of Franklin and Church Streets in TriBeCa on Thursday night. Minnie, a 5,000-pound Asian elephant, ambled down the street at 10 p.m. to the Theater Bar, where she spent the night outside snorting up fish-shaped candy and causing a minor traffic jam.

title: Caddie Choice Serves as Window Into Woodss Thinking
description: Everything is just talk until Tiger Woods actually shows up next week in Akron, Ohio, for the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational, rested and presumably healthy after three months of his new R&R: recuperation and rehabilitation.

title: Global Concern Over U.S. Debt Ceiling Disagreement
description: PARIS  While the debt debacle in Washington preoccupies America, it is causing jitters in power corridors from Beijing to Brussels. The stewards of the worlds largest economies are anxious for a compromise, to keep their own finances from suffering collateral damage.

title: How Different Types of Republicans Voted on Boehners Revised Debt Plan
description: Analysis of how different Republican blocs voted on the revised debt plan.

title: Muddying the Budget Waters
description: All the political wrangling over the budget in Washington has been focused on one theme: how much the government should cut and when those cuts should take effect.

title: Afghan Team Denied Chance at 2012 Olympics
description: Afghanistans national mens basketball team will not get a chance to qualify for the 2012 Olympics after requests for visas to travel to a prequalifying tournament were denied.

title: Regulators Seek Records on Claims for Gas Wells
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission sent subpoenas this week to energy companies asking them for documents about how they calculate and publicly disclose the performance of their shale gas wells, according to oil and gas industry lawyers.

title: End of a Bar, and Its Surprisingly Artistic Life
description: MARS BAR, the dive joint on the first floor of 11 Second Avenue, closed last week amid ballyhoo. (It was mentioned in the Metropolitan cover story on July 17, Waiting for the Wrecking Ball.)

title: In Uganda, a Failure to Deliver
description: A lawsuit over the death of a woman in labor may be the first legal test of an African governments obligation to provide basic maternal care and also raises questions about the impact of foreign aid.

title: Governor Said to Have Irked Transit Leader Who Is Leaving
description: Jay H. Walder, chairman of the embattled Metropolitan Transportation Authority, traveled to Albany earlier this year seeking help for a transit system in peril. Mr. Walder, a kid from Queens who rose to the top of his field and harbored big ambitions for his state, was not unlike the man he had hoped to see: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Spinning the American Songbook
description: On Sunday afternoons for the past four decades, Jonathan Schwartz has been spinning the wax and waxing poetic on all things Sinatra and American standard. Now 72, Mr. Schwartz can be heard every day of the week on Sirius Satellite Radio  Channel 71  but weekends still find him at his longtime home on the FM dial, WNYC. He lives in Midtown Manhattan with the actress  Zohra Lampert, whom he married last year. Mr. Schwartzs daughter, Casey, 28, and son, Adam, 24, often join them for dinner.

title: Maternal Deaths Focus Harsh Light on Uganda
description: ARUA, Uganda  Jennifer Anguko was slowly bleeding to death right in the maternity ward of a major public hospital. Only a lone midwife was on duty, the hospital later admitted, and no doctor examined her for 12 hours. An obstetrician who investigated the case said Ms. Anguko, the mother of three young children, had arrived in time to be saved.

title: Sorry, W.J.B., to Bring This Up Again
description: You  collectively, and perhaps you specifically  delighted me by your thoughtful and articulate responses to my confessional column involving the William Jennings Bryan jape committed by me and my rascally friends.

title: Nova Is Set to Return to the Yankees Rotation, for a Day at Least
description: Manager Joe Girardi needed a little prodding Friday before announcing that Ivan Nova would start the second game of a day-night doubleheader Saturday against the Baltimore Orioles at Yankee Stadium. Exactly what happens to Nova after that will be determined once he pitches.

title: How Would You Shore Up Social Security?
description: This weeks Your Money column discusses a proposal that would tinker with one of the most beloved features of Social Security: the cost-of-living adjustment.

title: In Belarus, Just Being Can Prompt an Arrest
description: MOSCOW  Iron-fisted authorities in Belarus have responded to a burst of creative modes of protest by young protesters with a rather surreal innovation of their own: a law that prohibits people from standing together and doing nothing.

title: The Madoff Trustees Bad Day
description: Jed Rakoff is one of the most respected federal judges in the country, so when he issues an opinion calling one sides arguments convoluted, conjecture and a stretch, people tend to take notice.

title: Bloggingheads: Debt Limit Endgame
description: Jonathan Rauch, left, of the Brookings Institution and Rich Lowry of National Review debate possible conclusions for the debt limit crisis.

title: Asomugha Rejects Jets; Picks Eagles
description: Every once in a while, a player comes along who consumes a teams attention. For the Jets, that player was Nnamdi Asomugha, the elite, free-agent cornerback of the Oakland Raiders.

title: Its Up to the Senate
description: It was hard to imagine that the House bill to raise the debt limit, and slash and burn the economy, could get any worse. But on Friday it did.

title: Some Good News for the Planet
description: There is at least some positive news from Washington: a major agreement to bring American consumers cleaner cars  dramatically cutting greenhouse gas pollution, raising fuel economy standards and increasing Detroits ability to compete in world markets.

title: New York Judges Deserve a Raise
description: New York States 1,300 judges have not had a raise or even a cost-of-living adjustment for a dozen years. Their salaries now lag behind the pay of federal judges, senior assistant district attorneys and Legal Aid lawyers in New York City. In many instances, judges even earn less than their own law clerks whose salaries are set by union collective bargaining. Judges on the State Supreme Court, New Yorks main trial court, earn $136,700  $37,300 less than comparable federal judges.

title: Judge Agrees to Limit Writers Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge dealt a setback on Friday to the Obama administrations crackdown on the leaking of government secrets to journalists, sharply limiting what prosecutors can ask the author of a book about the C.I.A. in court.

title: Soldier Arrested in Suspected Bomb Plot Had Series of Disputes With Army
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The 21-year-old Army private arrested here this week made his first appearance in federal court on Friday, two days after telling investigators he planned to detonate explosive devices at a restaurant frequented by soldiers from nearby Fort Hood, the culmination of a series of disputes between the private and the military over his Muslim beliefs and his pending deployment to Afghanistan.

title: John Boehner, Escape Artist
description: With the House of Representatives voting tonight to pass an implausibly right-wing debt ceiling bill after failing, yesterday, to pass the somewhat more plausible but still quite conservative alternative, Ezra Klein expressed bafflement at John Boehners legislative strategy:

title: Mending Fences
description: While the horses have been on vacation across the road in a neighbors pasture, my own pastures have grown into what looks like the first stage of abandonment. The grass is high, and so are the thistles and burdock. Here and there, sumac is trying to grow unnoticed. Several of the fences are down  intentionally  and in two of the pastures lie the trunks of dead sugar maples, cut into log lengths. They remind me of whale bones I once saw on an island off the coast of southern Chile.

title: Off-Season Reduced, N.F.L. Runs Through Millions
description: After more than four months of fighting over money, the National Football League has proved  in four of the most frenetic and expensive days in its history  that it did not forget how to spend it.

title: Filly Remains Undefeated
description: The undefeated See You at Peelers won her division of Yonkers Raceways $233,230 New York Sire Stakes Rye Pace on Thursday, her 21st lifetime victory and eighth as a 3-year-old. An easy two-and-a-half-length victor, she completed the mile in 1 minute 52.2 seconds, a track record for her 3-year-old filly weight class.

title: John H. Marburger, Bush Science Adviser, Dies at 70
description: John H. Marburger III, a physicist, former college president and Democrat who served as science adviser to President George W. Bush and was frequently called on to defend his policies on birth control, stem cell research and climate change, died Thursday at his home in Port Jefferson, Long Island. He was 70.

title: White House Adviser says U.S. Has 6 Months to Knock Out Rattled Qaeda Leadership
description: ASPEN, Colo.  President Obamas top adviser on Pakistan said Friday that the United States had six months to deliver a knockout blow to Al Qaedas senior leadership in Pakistan while the group was still in turmoil after the killing of Osama bin Laden.

title: Philanthropists Start Requiring Management Courses to Keep Nonprofits Productive
description: Pierre M. Omidyar and Peter B. Lewis are in many ways opposites. Mr. Omidyar, the founder of eBay, is shy, soft-spoken and formal, while Mr. Lewis, who made Progressive Insurance into the powerhouse it is today, bluntly speaks his mind and revels in stopping people midsentence by taking off his prosthetic leg during meetings.

title: Obama Reveals Details of Gas Mileage Rules
description: DETROIT  President Obama announced new automobile fuel-efficiency standards on Friday that require an average 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025. But even if the auto industry manages to meet the new standards, it is unlikely car buyers will see many fuel-economy stickers with such high mileage.

title: Lottery Numbers
That Aug. 2 Deadline? It May Be Impossible, Veteran Lawmakers Say
description: WASHINGTON  Here is advice from veterans of past budget battles in Congress that went to the brink: This time, be afraid. Be very afraid.

title: Precautions at New York Post as Tabloid Inquiry Expands
description: Employees of The New York Post, Rupert Murdochs irreverent and hard-charging city tabloid, were told Friday to keep any documents that may pertain to the kind of illegal activity that has led to arrests and a widening investigation at the News Corporations British newspapers.

title: Absences Stand Out as Giants Practice
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Seventy-seven Giants players reported to the Timex Performance Center for the first day of training camp Friday, but most of the talk was about two players who were not there: Plaxico Burress and Osi Umenyiora.

title: Robert C. W. Ettinger, a Proponent of Life After (Deep-Frozen) Death, Is Dead at 92
description: Robert C. W. Ettinger, a science fiction writer and physics instructor whose idea of freezing the dead for future reanimation repelled most scientists, inspired Woody Allen and Mike Myers to some of their best work and persuaded at least 105 game humans to pay $28,000 each to have their bodies preserved in liquid nitrogen at his Cryonics Institute in suburban Detroit, died on July 23 at his home in Clinton Township, Mich. He was 92.

title: Enjoy Park Greenery, City Says, but Not as Salad
description: Maybe it is the spiraling cost of food in a tough economy or the logical next step in the movement to eat locally. Whatever the reason, New Yorkers are increasingly fanning out across the citys parks to hunt and gather edible wild plants, like mushrooms, American ginger and elderberries.

title: Saturday: Something Seen on a Pad
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Did this Saturday puzzle seem easier to you than others? It started off a bit slowly for me in the northwest, but once I got that all-important toehold, it fell pretty easily. It was well worth hanging in there, too. Patrick Berrys grid today is crammed with shiny, brand new entries and irresistible cluing.

title: Free Concerts, Yonkers to Tarrytown
description: WHILE the Caramoor and Litchfield festivals fill the first weekend in August with some of the finest jazz a fan can buy, Westchester will be awash in free performances throughout the month as Jazz Forum Artss 12th annual summer concert series concludes with 16 shows at five locations.

title: Where Summertime Means Jazz
description: FOR jazz fans, the absence this summer of a festival in New York City produced by George Wein, who founded the Newport Jazz Festival and for many years staged sister events in the city, has been conspicuous. But the undiminished presence of the Caramoor and Litchfield jazz festivals  both among the top-ticketed events in the metropolitan region  has offered some consolation.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: My Very Own Captain America
description: My grandfather spoke to me this week. That wouldve been unremarkable if not for the fact that he died four years ago.

title: Debt Crisis? Bankruptcy Fears? See Jefferson County, Ala.
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  A few hundred miles north of here, politicians are fighting over debt. It is a spirited debate, full of discussions about what kind of country will be left for future generations and pledges not to kick the can down the road.

title: Visual Meditations on Death
description: Death may be the greatest of all human blessings, the Greek philosopher Socrates wrote. Many years later, the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas offered a divergent view: Do not go gentle into that good night.

title: From Elite Duck-Hunting Enclaves to Public Pastures
description: RIFLES, decoys and low-slung boats are among the objects and images that greet visitors to Private Places Public Spaces: Suffolk Countys Elite Hunt Clubs and Regional Decoys, a new exhibition at the Suffolk County Historical Society in Riverhead. But the shows aim reaches beyond tracing the history of a recreational activity and a folk art on Long Island, said Kathryn M. Curran, the curator of the show and the historical societys incoming director.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Mets Get Close Look at Pitcher They Know
description: WASHINGTON  On the second anniversary of his shoulder operation, Chien-Ming Wang toed the pitchers rubber at Nationals Park here as many curious people fixed their eyes upon him and his rebuilt shoulder.

title: China Jails Journalist Who Reported on Corruption
description: BEIJING  A Chinese court has upheld the eight-year sentence of an investigative journalist in Shandong Province who had already completed a four-year term on charges of extortion and blackmail  charges that his lawyers say were concocted to silence him.

title: For Republican Freshmen, the Power of Saying No
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Mo Brooks of Alabama knew his own power when he stood face to face with Speaker John A. Boehner in the cloakroom off the House floor.

title: For Young Artists, a Return to the Easel
description: SOME vegetarians have issues with the name of an exhibition currently at the Shore Institute of the Contemporary Arts, in Long Branch, according to Doug Ferrari, the museums executive director. The show, Fresh Meat/Young Blood: New Jerseys New Masters, displays the work of the latest crop of graduates from New Jerseys master of fine arts programs.

title: Myths, Legends and Cuban Culture
description: One thing you will learn at Ajiaco: Stirrings of the Cuban Soul is that Cuba contains an extraordinary mix of cultures, derived from many African ethnic groups, Europe, Asia and the native Amerindians. What is not apparent in this exhibition, on view at the Newark Museum, is that contemporary art associated with Cuba  that is, made by artists living in Cuba or who are Cuban-born but living in the United States  is similarly heterogeneous.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Vince Young Is New Project for the Eagles
description: The Eagles, having shipped their backup quarterback, Kevin Kolb, to the Cardinals on Thursday, found his replacement in Vince Young, who was released by the Titans on Thursday. The Eagles last quarterback reclamation project, Michael Vick, said he was thrilled the team was taking on Young as its next project.

title: Nuclear-Detection Effort Is Halted as Ineffective
description: ASPEN, Colo.  The Obama administration has quietly canceled a much-criticized billion-dollar program to equip ports across the United States with detectors to pick out radioactive material and nuclear weapons being shipped into the country, after acknowledging that the devices did not work.

title: Phone Hacker Points Finger at Paper
description: The private investigator who went to prison for his role in the phone hacking scandal at The News of the World said Friday that he had acted on instructions from the newspaper.

title: Locally Grown Food, From Backyard Hive
description: ITS a hot July day at Peter Pratts Inn in Yorktown Heights and the honeybees are, well, busy. Standing here in full bee-protection regalia, with Craig Purdy, a co-owner of Peter Pratts and the mami Caf in Croton-on-Hudson, I am about to see where honey comes from.

title: Sandwiches Get Creative
description: What do restaurant chefs chat about in the kitchen while preparing dinner? If the chefs are Jonathan Contes, 29, and Tate Morris, 34, who are part owners of Mosaic in St. James, the talk frequently turns to the perfect sandwich.

title: View a Yacht, or Two, With Your Dinner
description: A BALMY summer night, a waterfront table for two and views of glistening white yachts at anchor: that sums up the allure of  the Patio at the Freeport Inn and Marina. The new restaurant, which opened in May, is mainly outdoors; the interior contains a 30-foot bar and a few small tables.

title: Death Toll Rises From High-Speed Train Crash in China
description: The death toll from a high-speed train crash in eastern China last week rose to 40 late on Thursday as a critically injured passenger died in the hospital.

title: Defying a Stereotype With Gourmet Dishes
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.

title: From the Sea to Your Plate
description: Fish and chips are the headliner at Cod Almighty Chippery. But at this fast-casual restaurant, which opened last August in a strip mall in Westfield, there are also other catches: po boy sandwiches with fried clams ($8.25), fish tacos ($7) and steamed mussels ($7.95), to name a few.

title: A Local Italian Staple, Back to Its Family Roots
description: THE crowd of cars around Luchentos Ristorante had long intrigued me, but it was a recent facade renovation that propelled me through the doors. Once there, I found a dining style evocative of scenes in vintage photographs or films.

title: Battle for Libya | July 29, 2011
description: Thousands of mourners attended the funeral of top rebel military commander, Gen. Abdul Fattah Younes, in Benghazi on Friday.

title: Obamas Crucible Moment at Intersection of Politics and the Economy
description: WASHINGTON  It was a day that brought fresh evidence of all the forces converging on President Obama in the latter half of his term: a weakened economy he cannot lift, a deeply divided Congress he cannot move and, as a result, a level of political risk he seems hard-pressed to control.

title: Biologists Suspension Is Not Related to Scientific Integrity, Bureau Official Says
description: A spokeswoman for the federal Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement issued a brief statement on Friday denying that Charles Monnett, a wildlife biologist and manager of scientific contracts, was suspended because of possible misconduct involving his scientific reports on dead polar bears in the Beaufort Sea. Melissa Schwartz, the bureaus deputy chief of staff and communications director, wrote in an e-mail, The agency placed Mr. Monnett on administrative leave for reasons having nothing to do with scientific integrity, his 2006 journal article or issues related to permitting, a reference to the bureaus role in permitting offshore drilling. Any suggestions or speculation to the contrary are wrong, Ms. Schwartz concluded. Dr. Monnett was told of the leave in an official letter on July 18, which referred to a continuing investigation by the departments inspector general into integrity issues. A few days before his suspension, a long-running contract involving polar bear research by scientists at the University of Alberta was abruptly put on hold. It is not clear whether the action involving that contract is connected to Dr. Monnetts suspension.

title: Judge Orders Release of Nixons Watergate Testimony
description: A federal judge in Washington has ordered the release of hundreds of pages of President Richard M. Nixons 1975 testimony about Watergate. The judge, Royce C. Lamberth III of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, wrote in a decision issued Friday that nearly 40 years later, Watergate continues to capture both scholarly and public interest. The Obama administration objected to the release, citing the privacy of people mentioned in the testimony. But Judge Lamberth wrote that the undisputed historical interest in the testimony, among other factors, far outweighed the need to maintain the secrecy of the records. The transcripts will not be released right away; the government can appeal the decision. Stanley I. Kutler, a leading Watergate historian who filed suit to get the documents last year, said that Nixons grand jury testimony was a rare opportunity to hear him  what should I say?  unplugged. There are no aides, there are no lawyers, there are no spin doctors. With the possible penalty of perjury over his head, Professor Kutler said, My guess is he told those people the truth. A spokesman for the Department of Justice, Charles S. Miller, said the agency was reviewing the judges decision and had not determined its next step.

title: Ruthless and Relentless, Phillies Amaro Strikes Again
description: Which adjective best describes Ruben Amaro, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies. Ruthless? Relentless? Both work pretty well. Amaro made another significant trade on Friday, acquiring the two-time All-Star outfielder Hunter Pence from the Houston Astros for three minor leaguers and a player to be named later.

title: Corrections: July 30
description: NATIONAL

title: David Servan-Schreiber, Exponent of Cancer Treatments, Dies at 50
description: PARIS  Dr. David Servan-Schreiber, a psychiatrist and best-selling author whose cancer diagnosis at the age of 31 compelled him to explore and then popularize the use of natural and holistic methods in dealing with cancer and depression, died on July 24 in a hospital near Fcamp, France. He was 50.

title: Photo Replay: July 29
description: The day in sports, including day 14 of FINA World Swimming Championships and more N.F.L. teams returning to training camp.

title: Like Seaside Heights, but With a Duomo
description: FLORENCE, Italy

title: Lawyers for Clemens Ask Judge to Dismiss Charges
description: The lawyers for Roger Clemens have asked a federal judge to dismiss the charges against him, accusing the prosecutors at Clemenss perjury trial earlier this month of sabotaging the governments case to elicit a mistrial because the proceedings were going badly for them.

title: Burnett Goes 8 Innings, but Gives Up More Than Yanks Can Afford
description: The Yankees right-hander A. J. Burnett retired the Baltimore Orioles on 10 first-inning pitches Friday, but one was hit so hard that Nick Swisher slammed into the wall making a running catch. Soon, the Orioles smacked just enough pitches to open spots, dooming Burnett again.

title: Changing Gears Electronically
description: A look at an electronic gear system that will be used by some teams in the Tour of California that begins Saturday.

title: Victims of Flight 3407
description: Musicians and law students, parents and pilots were among the 50 people who died on Continental Connection Flight 3407.

title: The Weekend Word: Rejection
description: Todays Times

title: NATO Strikes at Libyan State TV
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  NATO said Saturday that it had disabled three Libyan state television transmission dishes in Tripoli with airstrikes overnight, as the alliance took steps to remove the main instrument of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis propaganda from the airwaves.

title: End of a Bar, and Its Surprisingly Artistic Life
The Corrosion of the Conservative Economic Mind
description: First Michael Boskin, now John Taylor: there seems be an epidemic of politically conservative economists who used to be technically competent repeating the obviously wrong falsehood that Reagan ushered in an era of unprecedented growth.

title: Warped Discourse, Again
description: Just worth reminding everyone: We have a deeply depressed economy  more deeply than we realized, according to the GDP revisions  which is clearly suffering from a lack of demand. Meanwhile, the government is able to borrow at very low interest rates:

title: The Malevolent Ex-Maestro
description: After playing a key role in creating the greatest economic disaster in three generations, you might have expected Alan Greenspan to lie low. But no, hes out there issuing opinions, which for some reason still get listened to. Worse: he keeps calling for a return to the very regime he favored before, the regime that led to disaster.

title: Thomes Pursuit of 600 Interrupted by Aches
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Jim Thomes two lockers at Target Field contain the usual trappings of a veteran player: workout T-shirts of various designs, multiple pairs of cleats and assorted knick-knacks. But the one visible concession to Thomes age  he turns 41 on Aug. 27  was the hand-held muscle stimulator, about the size of a hair dryer, plugged in and ready for use.

title: Moves at Trade Deadline Can Be Great Deal of Trouble
description: The most important thing to know about baseball trades made in July is that most of them do not amount to much. Few of the stars traded to contenders will be the difference between winning and losing, and few of the young prospects traded for stars will become stars. Still, we have had a flurry of activity leading to Sundays deadline for nonwaiver trades (dont ask), with stars like Carlos Beltran and numerous lesser lights changing teams and kindling hope among their new teams fans.

title: In Final Seconds, Vettel Takes Pole Position Again
description: BUDAPEST  Yes! Yes! shouted Sebastian Vettel in his car on his wind-down lap on Saturday after scoring pole position for the Hungarian Grand Prix on Sunday.

title: In Final Seconds, Vettel Takes Pole Position Again
description: BUDAPEST  Yes! Yes! shouted Sebastian Vettel in his car on his wind-down lap on Saturday after scoring pole position for the Hungarian Grand Prix on Sunday.

title: Red Bulls Go to London  and Win
description: The Red Bulls may be struggling mightily in their domestic league, but that malaise was left behind when the club traveled to London for the Emirates Cup and came away with a 1-0 win against Paris St. Germain at the home of Arsenal in north London on Saturday morning.

title: Amid New Talks, Some Optimism on Debt Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  New budget talks between top Congressional Republicans and President Obama made progress late Saturday, suddenly stirring optimism that a last-minute deal could be reached to avert a potential federal default that threatened significant economic and political consequences.

title: Taking a Closer Look at the Result of a Credit Downgrade
description: WASHINGTON  As political leaders race to avoid a default on the nations debts by striking a deal to borrow more money, there is a growing chance that a secondary goal, preserving the nations pristine credit rating, might slip beyond reach.

title: Variety: A Proportional Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Hands up if you were (or still are) comic book fans. Me too. I still enjoy secretly thumbing through some of the comics that might be lying around the house (being able to enjoy the things of childhood a bit longer is one of the reasons I had kids in the first place), but I never really gave much thought as to why cartoonists made the interesting choice to letter their characters voices in all capital letters.

title: Gunmen Attack Sinai Gas Pipeline
description: CAIRO  For the third time this month, gunmen attacked the strategic pipeline carrying natural gas from Egypt across the Sinai Peninsula to Israel and Jordan, Egyptian security officials said on Saturday.

title: Some Bankers Never Learn
description: YOUD think the mortgage bust would qualify as a teachable moment.

title: Sure Cure for the Debt Problem: Economic Growth
description: NOT so long ago, the National Debt Clock, perched above the Avenue of the Americas, a block east of Times Square, was running backward.

title: With Tannenbaum, Jets Show Audacity From the Top Down
description: Examine Mike Tannenbaums transaction history as the Jets general manager, and an obvious pattern emerges. He trades up, he trades down, he trades sideways. He deconstructs, he rebuilds. He acquires players with checkered pasts, hazy presents and promising futures.

title: Turkish Prime Minister Climbs a Higher Perch in Wake of Resignations
description: ISTANBUL  Fifty years ago, when a populist prime minister tangled with the Turkish military, he ended up on the gallows, the mandate of three election victories little consolation. This time around, the rivalry climaxed with most of Turkeys military command resigning simultaneously, its leader complaining of powerlessness and bad press.

title: A Q&A With Jerry Glanville
description: The N.F.L. is back in business, and its 32 coaches are scrambling to cram months of preparation into a couple of weeks. There are some underemployed football coaches out there, but Jerry Glanville, though idle, had the pedal to the metal in the hills of north Georgia.

title: The Trust That Makes a Team Click
description: This interview with  Peter Lscher, president and C.E.O. of Siemens A.G., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Whats With All the Bernanke Bashing?
description: POOR Ben Bernanke.

title: For Caddies, Theres More Than Just Schlepping a Bag
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va.  Stepping inside the ropes at a PGA Tour event is not for the faint of heart. It requires physical strength, mental toughness, resiliency, good golf course management, accuracy, a lot of nerve and a thick skin.

title: Coming Soon: Invasion of the Walking Debt
description: AMERICA has always had an apocalyptic strain. Yet it also seems to believe that if, or when, The End comes, it will still come out on top.

title: The Video Store, Reinvented by Necessity
description: ON Sunday evening, a group of men and women will gather in a screening room here to watch  and sing along to  the movie musical Jesus Christ Superstar. Many will be festively attired in bell-bottoms, love beads and big-hair wigs.

title: Lessons Learned on TV for Eduardo Perez
description: Eduardo Perez had worked more than five years as an analyst for ESPN before the Florida Marlins hired him as hitting coach in June. Perez, 41, played in the majors as recently as 2006, but the lessons he took from his television producers have come in just as handy as anything he learned as a player.

title: Putting a Shared Office to the Test
description: Q. You work from home and want to try co-working, in which you share office space with others but work independently. How do you get started?

title: John Stott and Evangelical Christians

But then I saw that John Stott had died, and I didnt want to miss the chance to write about him and evangelicals more broadly  hence my Sunday column on the subject. We in the op-ed world dont write about religion perhaps as much as we should: its a huge force shaping society and policy, and yet rarely makes the op-ed pages. And evangelicals in particular, especially serious ones, tend to be neglected since there are so few evangelicals in major news organizations. About one-third of America is evangelical, yet youd be hard pressed to find many (with the exception of black evangelicals, whose politics are very different from white evangelicals) in leading news organizations.

Despite the recent blows to Mr. Schwarzeneggers image in the United States with his disclosure that he fathered a child out of wedlock, his career was so exciting and so special and I think the Austrian people are really proud of him, Helga Forstner, the museum coordinator, told the BBC.

description: At dawn on Sunday, Syrian security forces backed by tanks and snipers stormed Hama and other cities, killing at least 75 people in a brutal crackdown by the government of President Bashar al-Assad against the four-month old uprising against his rule.

title: HSBC to Sell Upstate N.Y. Branches to First Niagara for $1 Billion
description: 3:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Lochte and U.S. Cap Dominance With a Flourish
description: SHANGHAI  Ryan Lochte captured his fifth gold medal on the final day of the world swimming championships with a performance that may help him stake a claim to being the best in his sport.

title: Yankees Make Zero Moves as Deadline Passes
description: It wasnt the most exciting trade deadline in recent memory, but there were a couple of significant moves on Sunday.

title: Jeter Leaves Game, but Finger Is Not Broken
description: Derek Jeter departed Yankee Stadium for a seven-game trip late Sunday afternoon with a thick wrapping around his right middle finger, which was battered twice by flying baseballs within 18 hours. His finger is not broken, and Jeter, not surprisingly, said he was hurting but fine.

title: Tax Cut Memories
description: Obama, at his press conference last December, announcing his surrender to the GOP on tax cuts; the questioner was Marc Ambinder:

title: The Debt Ceiling, in Pop Culture
description: During the financial crisis, the bank-run scene from Its A Wonderful Life proved a useful pop-culture reference for helping people understand what was happening to the economy.

title: Button Wins Wild, Rain-Soaked Hungarian Grand Prix
description: BUDAPEST  The Formula One rules makers have sometimes considered sprinkling tracks with water to artificially enhance the excitement of the racing.

title: Button Wins Wild, Rain-Soaked Hungarian Grand Prix
description: BUDAPEST  The Formula One rules makers have sometimes considered sprinkling tracks with water to artificially enhance the excitement of the racing.

title: Mets Long Trip Ends With Loss in 9th Inning
description: WASHINGTON  Daniel Murphy rushed in to retrieve the bunted ball and without the slightest hesitation spun around and fired the ball to third baseman David Wright to cut down the lead runner in a tie game in the ninth inning.

title: A Very Big Man and the Brother Who Resents Him
description: When the journalist David Whitehouse began circulating the first few chapters of his debut novel, Bed, he soon found himself picked up as a London client of the William Morris Agency. He was amazed at this good fortune. Suddenly, I was walking around like Charlie Big Potatoes, thinking all sorts of good things were going to happen to me, he has told interviewers. But what actually did happen was, well, nothing.

title: Reid Backs Debt Deal and Hopes for Sunday Night Debt Vote
description: 5:29 p.m. | Updated A spokesman for Senator Harry Reid said the Senate majority leader has signed off on the debt-ceiling agreement pending caucus approval.

title: A von Trier Tragedy, Recast as Opera
description: If Sarah Bernhardts definitive performance in Victorien Sardous 1887 play La Tosca had been available through Netflix, would Puccini ever have based an opera on it? Would his Tosca have stood a chance?

title: Children in the Fields, but Not at Play
description: The Harvest/La Cosecha, an earnest documentary about child migrant farmworkers in the United States, has a muckraking agenda but a melancholy soul. As it follows a 16-year-old boy and two girls, 12 and 14, through one harvest cycle, it depicts their lives as a more or less voluntary indentured servitude and provides a detailed, sometimes heartbreaking, mostly hopeless portrait of a permanent American underclass. But the tone is never angry; resignation is the primary note, and an ability to endure that isnt so much resilience as stubbornness.

title: Benghazi Clash Exposes Cracks in Rebel Ranks
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Rebel fighters challenging the rule of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi waged an eight-hour gunfight here in their de facto capital on Sunday, against what their leaders called a fifth column of Qaddafi loyalists who had posed as a rebel brigade. It was the latest sign of discord and trickery in the rebel ranks to emerge in the four days since the killing of the rebels top military leader, Gen. Abdul Fattah Younes, a former Qaddafi confidant who had defected to their side.

title: Divas Struggles and Songs, Shared With Candor
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  Opera singers have written their share of celebrity tell-all memoirs. The soprano Deborah Voigt recently sold her autobiography to HarperCollins, scheduled for release in two years. She has already gone public about her struggles with obesity, which led her to undergo gastric bypass surgery in 2004.

title: Exploring the Intricacies of the 17th Century
description: The 4x4 Baroque Music Festival began as an early-music fans farewell to the summer, with four free concerts offered around Labor Day. This year the festivals players  a core of early-music stars, including the harpsichordist Avi Stein and the violinist Robert Mealy  have moved it to midsummer: the series began on Friday evening and runs through Wednesday at St. Peters Lutheran Church.

title: Monday: Whacked-Out Mental State
description: Administrivial Tournament Save the Date Alert! Will Shortz has announced the date of the 2011 Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, the proceeds of which benefit the Pleasantville Fund for Learning. Save Oct. 21 (exact starting time to be determined) if you will be in the area and would like to have a fun, low-key tournament experience, meet some of your favorite constructors and help raise money for a great cause. Plus, if history holds, the desserts provided are not to be believed. The location will be Wills brand-new table tennis club  the Westchester Table Tennis Center, located at 175 Tompkins Ave., in Pleasantville, N.Y. Its three and a half blocks from the Pleasantville train station on MetroNorth. Im told that the space is twice as large as the former location, which should nicely accommodate the growing legions of tournament fans, and you can even arrive early and play some table tennis! You can read more about the club here, and registration for the tournament is accepted at the door.

title: Flaunting Latino Clichs in Effort to Defuse Them
description: FOR some Hollywood movies, clichs are everything. An asteroid destroys a major city. A shadowy figure appears behind someone in the reflection of medicine cabinet mirror. A Latina maid marries a successful businessman and lives happily ever after.

title: Muscling Through a Murky, Hardcore Night in a Box
description: People straighten up around John Joseph, the singer for the Cro-Mags. He reminds you that the best of his music, New York hardcore, has a history and a set of standards, musical and ethical; he has no time for what people choose to do outside of those standards. Hes not hectoring you, exactly, about punk and veganism and the economy and your ability to rise to the occasion; hes making strong recommendations and asking withering questions. Like What are you, tired?

title: Romantic Temperament Applied to Monuments
description: The pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin is fearless. No successful performer can afford to show fear from the stage, but with Mr. Hamelin, fearlessness is something more: a positive attribute, a confident calm that he exudes even while unleashing volcanic eruptions of sound and emotion.

title: A Malian Singer Sets Her West African Message to a Dance Beat
description: Regal, righteous and funky, the Malian singer and songwriter Oumou Sangare commanded the stage of Celebrate Brooklyn! on Friday night at the Prospect Park Bandshell. Wearing a white caftan, a red necklace and a white headscarf that her movements kept shaking loose, Ms. Sangare praised and admonished: End forced child marriage, share good fortune, seek wisdom, dont waste your youth. She was taking on the traditional West African singers role as community conscience while delivering her messages with a modern kick.

title: Uncertainty Driving Treasury Bill Fluctuations
description: In normal times, it is hard to find a financial market that is more boring than the one where short-term Treasury bills are traded.

title: Girl-Group Hits From Rocks Women
description: It was all about love. Waiting for it, finding it, showing it, fearing for it, fighting for it, sometimes losing it, sometimes taking it all the way to happy-ever-after marriage. On Saturday afternoon the rock archivists of the Ponderosa Stomp and Lincoln Center Out of Doors presented a fond four-hour marathon of girl-group songs from the early 1960s, sung by the women who made them.

title: Into the Pool, Slowly but With Feeling
description: Forty years after they began to collaborate, the performance duo Eiko & Koma remain among New Yorks greatest and most extraordinary performers. Their particular secret is that, while moving with extreme slowness, they are masters of suspense. Watching, youre kept on tenterhooks: what will happen next?

title: Ahab Has a Wife and a Heart. Oh, and a Whale.
description: Some people argue passionately over which is the Great American Novel, Moby-Dick or The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.

title: Film Hitches a Weird Ride on Keseys Bus
description: Magic Trip: Ken Keseys Search for a Kool Place, a film by Alex Gibney and Alison Ellwood that opens on Friday, is an exercise in what they call archival vrit. Its a documentary that uses old footage to recreate a documentary that Kesey intended to make about his 1964 cross-country bus trip  the one so memorably chronicled in Tom Wolfes account, The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test.

title: Cry Havoc! The Blood Sport Called Politics
description: With the country mired in political stalemate and economic peril looming, imperialism suddenly doesnt sound so bad, does it?

title: No High-Card Points, but a Decision to Make
description: TORONTO  At the Summer North American Championships here, the final of the premier event, the Spingold Knockout Teams, was scheduled to finish late on Sunday. The 64-board match was between Team Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) and Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bob Hamman, Zia Mahmood, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell.

title: Ticket Sales Start-Up Aims at Smaller Box Offices
description: On July 23, 3,000 carnivores salivated their way through Meatopia, a festival on a Brooklyn pier where 45 chefs from around the country offered fleshy dishes like veal belly gyros and Southern pulled-pork shooters.

title: State Department Taps will.i.am for China Effort
description: The State Department is teaming up with the hip-hop artist will.i.am, a founder of the Black Eyed Peas, to organize a concert in Beijing this year to encourage cultural and educational exchanges between the United States and China. The announcement came after Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met on Friday in Washington with will.i.am, above, a creator of the 2008 viral video Yes, We Can that boosted support for Barack Obama among the young, to discuss the Obama administrations 100,000 Strong Initiative, aimed at increasing the number and diversity of Americans studying in China. For the event will.i.am and other American and Chinese artists will perform; no date or location for the show has been specified.

title: The Kings of Leon Are Feeling the Heat
description: Despite their image as road-hardened Southern boys, the Kings of Leon seem to have wilted over the weekend in the heat of Texas, where the band cut short a concert on Friday night in Dallas and postponed a show on Saturday in Houston. Before going offstage, promising but failing to return, the lead singer Caleb Followill told the Dallas audience, Im about to fall down here because Im so goddamn hot. But a pair of tweets by the bass player Jared Followill, his younger brother, suggested that tensions within the group, which has had a string of chart-topping CDs, may also have figured in the actions. There are internal sicknesses & problems that have needed to be addressed, he wrote in one message. In the other one he added: I cant lie. There are problems in our band bigger than not drinking enough Gatorade.

title: Two Theater Chains Block Documentary
description: Two major movie theater chains, AMC and Regal, have instructed their properties not to show Electric Daisy Carnival Experience, about an increasingly popular annual electronic dance music festival, after a confrontation between fans and the police during an event last week in Los Angeles to promote the film, which is scheduled to open nationally on Thursday. It is extremely disheartening that some theaters wrongly associated an unaffiliated block party, and its disorderly crowd, with the private screening of the film, Insomniac, the movies promoter and the festivals organizer, posted on its Web site, adding that the movie, which features interviews with or performances by rave music stars like David Guetta, Steve Aoki and DJ Kaskade, whose impromptu street performance set off the Los Angeles disturbance, will continue to be shown in hundreds of theaters nationwide.

title: Judge Says TV Will Show Mubarak on Trial
description: CAIRO  The trial of former President Hosni Mubarak will be held in a large hall that can accommodate 600 spectators, and will be broadcast on Egyptian state television, the judge who will preside over the trial said Sunday.

title: Julius Caesar
description: Photos from the Royal Shakespeare Company production at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: Shes Got the Power!
description: At Lincoln Center on Saturday afternoon Shes Got the Power! presented a four-hour marathon of girl-group songs from the 1960s.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Bringing Comfort Food to Print Fans
description: After an improbable rise as a chef who took a tiny noodle shop in New York and parlayed it into a kind of punk rock culinary movement and five wildly successful restaurants, David Chang seemed destined to become a television star. Now famous and ubiquitous, he would be a natural to join the legions of knife-wielding, apron-wearing stars who terrorize amateur cooks for the benefit of an audience. Either that or he could look into the camera and patiently explain how you too could make food that would knock people out of their chairs.

title: Opposing the Health Law, Florida Refuses Millions
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  When it comes to pursuing federal largess, most of the states that oppose the 2010 health care law have refused to let either principle or politics block their paths to the trough. If Washington is doling out dollars, Republican governors and legislators typically figure they might as well get their share.

title: Exploring a City Hidden Behind Its Modern Face
description: There is the Atlanta that most tourists see, all shimmering skyline, vast parks and Olympic torch statues. And then there is the hidden city, the one you see with a flashlight when A. J. Arend is your guide.

title: A Patent Fever Over Smartphones
description: A Patent Fever Over Smartphones

title: Childrens Publisher Backing Off Its Corporate Ties
description: Two months after Scholastic, the worlds largest publisher of childrens books, was hit with a barrage of criticism for distributing an unbalanced curriculum sponsored by the coal industry, the company is cutting back its InSchool marketing divisions corporate-sponsored projects, and creating a new review board to vet its materials.
